Title: Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023
Date: 2024-11-17
Publisher: Statute Law Database
Identifier: http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2023/55

## Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023

      B e it enacted  by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the
advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this
present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

### Levelling-up missions

#### Setting missions

##### Statement of levelling-up missions

1

1.1

A Minister of the Crown must prepare, and lay before each House of Parliament,
a statement of levelling-up missions.

1.2

A “statement of levelling-up missions” is a document which sets out—

1.2.a

objectives which His Majesty’s Government intends to pursue to reduce
geographical disparities in the United Kingdom significantly (“levelling-up
missions”), within a period specified in the statement (the “mission period”),
and

1.2.b

details of how His Majesty’s Government proposes to measure progress in
delivering those levelling-up missions (the “mission progress methodology and
metrics”).

1.3

In the course of preparing a statement of levelling-up missions, the Minister
of the Crown must have regard to—

1.3.a

the importance of the levelling-up missions in the statement (taken as a
whole) addressing both economic and social disparities in opportunities or
outcomes, and

1.3.b

the needs of rural areas.

1.4

The mission period for a statement of levelling-up missions must not—

1.4.a

begin before the statement has been laid before each House of Parliament, nor

1.4.b

be shorter than five years.

1.5

A statement of levelling-up missions must specify a target date for the
delivery of each of the levelling-up missions in it, which may be before or at
the end of the mission period.

1.6

If different target dates are specified under  subsection (5)  for different
levelling-up missions, the statement of levelling-up missions must give
reasons for the different dates.

1.7

The first statement of levelling-up missions must come into effect before the
end of the period of one month beginning with the day on which this section
comes into force.

1.8

A statement of levelling-up missions comes into effect when—

1.8.a

the statement has been laid before each House of Parliament and published by a
Minister of the Crown, and

1.8.b

the mission period in the statement begins.

1.9

Before the end of the mission period in a statement of levelling-up missions
(“the old statement”), a Minister of the Crown must prepare a new statement of
levelling-up missions, lay it before each House of Parliament and publish it.

1.10

The mission period in the new statement of levelling-up missions must begin no
later than immediately after the end of the mission period in the old
statement.

1.11

When the new statement of levelling-up missions comes into effect it replaces
the old statement, which ceases to have effect.

1.12

References in this Part to the current statement of levelling-up missions are
to the statement of levelling-up missions for the time being in effect.

##### Statement of levelling-up missions: devolution

2

2.1

In the course of preparing a statement of levelling-up missions, a Minister of
the Crown must—

2.1.a

have regard to any role of the devolved legislatures and devolved authorities
in connection with the levelling-up missions in the statement, and

2.1.b

carry out such consultation as the Minister considers appropriate with the
devolved authorities.

2.2

A Minister of the Crown must prepare a document which sets out how the
Minister has complied with subsection  (1) (a) .

2.3

A Minister of the Crown must lay the document mentioned in subsection  (2)
before each House of Parliament, and publish it, at the same time as, or as
soon as is reasonably practicable after, the statement of levelling-up
missions is so laid and published.

#### Reporting on missions

##### Annual etc reports on delivery of levelling-up missions

3

3.1

A Minister of the Crown must prepare reports on the delivery of the levelling-
up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions, in accordance
with this section.

3.2

In the course of preparing each report, the Minister of the Crown must have
regard to the needs of rural areas.

3.3

Each report must—

3.3.a

include the Minister’s assessment of the progress that has been made, in the
period to which the report relates, in delivering each of the levelling-up
missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions as it has effect at
the end of that period,

3.3.b

describe what has been done, in that period, by His Majesty’s Government to
deliver each of those levelling-up missions, and

3.3.c

set out what His Majesty’s Government plans to do in the future to deliver
each of those levelling-up missions.

3.4

The Minister’s assessment under  subsection (3) (a)  must be carried out by
reference to the mission progress methodology and metrics in the current
statement of levelling-up missions as it has effect at the end of the period
to which the report relates.

3.5

If His Majesty’s Government considers that it is no longer appropriate for it
to pursue a levelling-up mission in the current statement of levelling-up
missions, the report may state that His Majesty’s Government no longer intends
to pursue that mission, instead of dealing with the matters mentioned in
subsection (3)  in relation to that mission.

3.6

If a report contains a statement under  subsection (5) , it must also set out
the reasons for the statement being made.

3.7

In the course of preparing a report on the delivery of the levelling-up
missions, a Minister of the Crown must carry out such consultation as the
Minister considers appropriate with the devolved authorities.

3.8

The first report in relation to a statement of levelling-up missions must
relate to the first 12 months of the mission period in the statement.

3.9

Subsequent reports in relation to a statement of levelling-up missions must
relate to—

3.9.a

the 12 month period immediately following the 12 month period in relation to
which the previous report relating to the statement was prepared, or

3.9.b

if shorter, the period—

3.9.b.i

beginning immediately after the 12 month period in relation to which the
previous report relating to the statement was prepared, and

3.9.b.ii

ending at the end of the mission period in the statement.

##### Reports: Parliamentary scrutiny and publication

4

4.1

A report under  section 3  must be laid before each House of Parliament before
the end of the period of 120 days beginning immediately after the last day of
the period to which the report relates.

4.2

After a report has been laid before Parliament under  subsection (1) , a
Minister of the Crown must publish it as soon as is reasonably practicable.

4.3

In calculating the period of 120 days mentioned in  subsection (1) , no
account is to be taken of any time during which—

4.3.a

Parliament is dissolved or prorogued, or

4.3.b

either House of Parliament is adjourned for more than 4 days.

#### Revision of methodology and metrics or target dates

##### Changes to mission progress methodology and metrics or target dates

5

5.1

This section applies if a Minister of the Crown considers that the mission
progress methodology and metrics, or the target date for the delivery of a
levelling-up mission, in the current statement of levelling-up missions should
be changed.

5.2

The Minister—

5.2.a

may revise the current statement of levelling-up missions so as to change the
mission progress methodology and metrics or (as the case may be) target date,
and

5.2.b

as soon as is reasonably practicable after doing so, must—

5.2.b.i

publish a statement setting out the reasons for the mission progress
methodology and metrics, or target date, being changed, and

5.2.b.ii

lay the revised statement of levelling-up missions before each House of
Parliament and then publish it.

5.3

In discharging functions under this section, a Minister of the Crown must have
regard to the needs of rural areas.

5.4

The current statement of levelling-up missions has effect with the revisions
made under  subsection (2)  on and after the day on which it is published
after being laid before each House of Parliament.

5.5

Before making any revisions under  subsection (2) , a Minister of the Crown
must—

5.5.a

have regard to any role of the devolved legislatures and devolved authorities
in connection with the levelling-up mission to which the revision relates, and

5.5.b

carry out such consultation as the Minister considers appropriate with the
devolved authorities.

#### Review of missions

##### Reviews of statements of levelling-up missions

6

6.1

A Minister of the Crown must review the current statement of levelling-up
missions, in accordance with this section.

6.2

The first review of the current statement of levelling-up missions must be
completed, and a report on that review published, within the period of five
years beginning with the first day of the mission period in that statement.

6.3

Subsequent reviews of the current statement of levelling-up missions must be
completed, and the report on the review published, within the period of five
years beginning with the day on which the report on the previous review was
published.

6.4

But a final review of the current statement of levelling-up missions must be
completed, and the report on the review published, before a new statement is
laid before each House of Parliament in accordance with  section 1 (9) .

6.5

The purposes of a review under this section are to—

6.5.a

consider whether His Majesty’s Government pursuing the levelling-up missions
in the current statement of levelling-up missions is effectively contributing
to the reduction of geographical disparities in the United Kingdom,

6.5.b

conclude whether His Majesty’s Government should continue to pursue those
levelling-up missions and, if not, what the levelling-up missions are instead
to be, and

6.5.c

consider whether there are any additional levelling-up missions which His
Majesty’s Government should pursue.

6.6

In the course of carrying out a review under this section, a Minister of the
Crown must—

6.6.a

have regard to any role of the devolved legislatures and devolved authorities
in connection with the levelling-up missions in the statement, and

6.6.b

carry out such consultation as the Minister considers appropriate with the
devolved authorities.

6.7

As soon as is reasonably practicable after the conclusion of a review under
this section, a Minister of the Crown must lay a report on the review before
each House of Parliament and then publish it.

6.8

The report on a review under this section must—

6.8.a

state whether His Majesty’s Government considers that pursuing the levelling-
up missions in the current statement of levelling-up missions is effectively
contributing to the reduction of geographical disparities in the United
Kingdom,

6.8.b

state whether His Majesty’s Government has concluded that it should continue
to pursue those levelling-up missions and, if not, what the levelling-up
missions are instead to be,

6.8.c

state whether there are any additional levelling-up missions which His
Majesty’s Government considers it should pursue, and

6.8.d

set out reasons for the statements under paragraphs  (a)  to  (c) .

6.9

Subsections  (10)  to  (12)  do not apply in relation to a report on the final
review of the current statement of levelling-up missions.

6.10

If the report states that His Majesty’s Government has concluded that it
should not continue to pursue the levelling-up missions in the current
statement of levelling-up missions—

6.10.a

a Minister of the Crown must revise the statement—

6.10.a.i

so that it instead contains the levelling-up missions that His Majesty’s
Government is to pursue for the remaining mission period, and

6.10.a.ii

to make any changes to the mission progress methodology and metrics that the
Minister considers appropriate in consequence of doing so, and

6.10.b

as soon as is reasonably practicable after revising it, the Minister must lay
the revised statement before each House of Parliament and then publish it.

6.11

If the report states that His Majesty’s Government considers that it should
pursue an additional levelling-up mission—

6.11.a

a Minister of the Crown must revise the current statement of levelling-up
missions so as to—

6.11.a.i

add the levelling-up mission, and

6.11.a.ii

make any changes to the mission progress methodology and metrics that the
Minister considers appropriate in consequence of doing so, and

6.11.b

as soon as is reasonably practicable after revising it, the Minister must lay
the revised statement before each House of Parliament and then publish it.

6.12

The current statement of levelling-up missions has effect with the revisions
made under  subsection (10) (a)  or  (11) (a)  on and after the day on which
the revised statement is published after being laid before each House of
Parliament.

6.13

In carrying out functions under this section, a Minister of the Crown must
have regard to—

6.13.a

the importance of the levelling-up missions in the statement of levelling-up
missions (taken as a whole) addressing both economic and social disparities in
opportunities or outcomes, and

6.13.b

the needs of rural areas.

#### Levelling-up funding

##### Levelling Up Fund Round 3

7

7.1

Before the end of the period of three months beginning with the day on which
this Act is passed, a Minister of the Crown must lay before each House of
Parliament a statement on Levelling Up Fund Round 3.

7.2

A “statement on Levelling Up Fund Round 3” is a statement about the allocation
of a third round of funding from the Levelling Up Fund.

7.3

The “Levelling Up Fund” is the programme run by His Majesty’s Government which
is known as the Levelling Up Fund and was announced on 25 November 2020.

#### General

##### Interpretation of 

8

In this Part—

      “ current statement of levelling-up missions ” has the meaning given by
section 1 (12) ;           “ devolved authorities ” means—         the
Scottish Ministers,           the Welsh Ministers, and           the Northern
Ireland departments;                 “ devolved legislatures ” means—
the Scottish Parliament,           Senedd Cymru, and           the Northern
Ireland Assembly;                 “ geographical disparities ” means
geographical disparities in economic, social or other opportunities or
outcomes;           “ His Majesty’s Government ” means His Majesty’s
Government in the United Kingdom;           “ levelling-up mission ” has the
meaning given by  section 1 (2) (a) ;           “ Minister of the Crown ” has
the same meaning as in the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975;           “
mission period ” has the meaning given by  section 1 (2) (a) ;           “
mission progress methodology and metrics ” has the meaning given by  section 1
(2) (b) ;           “ statement of levelling-up missions ” has the meaning
given by  section 1 (2) .

### Local democracy and devolution

#### Combined county authorities

##### CCAs and their areas

###### Combined county authorities and their areas

9

9.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations establish as a body corporate a
combined county authority (a “CCA”) for an area that meets the following
conditions.

9.2

Condition A is that the area is wholly within England and consists of—

9.2.a

the whole of the area of a two-tier county council, and

9.2.b

the whole of one or more of—

9.2.b.i

the area of a two-tier county council,

9.2.b.ii

the area of a unitary county council, or

9.2.b.iii

the area of a unitary district council.

9.3

Condition B is that no part of the area forms part of—

9.3.a

the area of another CCA,

9.3.b

the area of a combined authority, or

9.3.c

the integrated transport area of an Integrated Transport Authority.

9.4

Regulations under subsection  (1)  must specify the name by which the CCA is
to be known.

9.5

In this Chapter—

      “ combined authority ” means a combined authority established under
section 103(1) of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction
Act 2009;           “ economic prosperity board ” means an economic prosperity
board established under section 88(1) of that Act;           “ Integrated
Transport Authority ” means an Integrated Transport Authority for an
integrated transport area;           “ two-tier county council ” means a
county council whose area includes the areas of district councils;           “
unitary county council ” means a county council whose area does not include
the areas of district councils;           “ unitary district council ” means a
district council whose area does not form part of the area of a county
council.

##### Constitution of CCAs

###### Constitutional arrangements

10

10.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the
constitutional arrangements of a CCA.

10.2

“ Constitutional arrangements ” in relation to a CCA means—

10.2.a

the membership of the CCA (including the number and appointment of members of
the CCA and the remuneration of, and pensions or allowances payable to or in
respect of, any member of the CCA);

10.2.b

the voting powers of members of the CCA (including provision for different
weight to be given to the vote of different descriptions of member);

10.2.c

the executive arrangements of the CCA;

10.2.d

the functions of any executive body of the CCA.

10.3

In subsection  (2) (c)  “ executive arrangements ” means—

10.3.a

the appointment of an executive;

10.3.b

the functions of the CCA which are the responsibility of an executive;

10.3.c

the functions of the CCA which are the responsibility of an executive and
which may be discharged by a committee of the CCA or by a body other than the
CCA;

10.3.d

arrangements relating to the review and scrutiny of the discharge of
functions;

10.3.e

access to information on the proceedings of an executive of the CCA;

10.3.f

the disapplication of section 15 of the Local Government and Housing Act 1989
(duty to allocate seats to political groups) in relation to an executive of
the CCA or a committee of such an executive;

10.3.g

the keeping of a record of any arrangements relating to the CCA and falling
within paragraphs  (a)  to  (f) .

10.4

Regulations under subsection  (1)  which, by virtue of subsection  (2) (a) ,
include provision about the number and appointment of members of the CCA must
provide—

10.4.a

for the members of the CCA other than—

10.4.a.i

the mayor (in the case of a mayoral CCA),

10.4.a.ii

the CCA’s non-constituent members (see section  11 ), and

10.4.a.iii

the CCA’s associate members (see section  12 ),

to be appointed by the CCA’s constituent councils, and

10.4.b

for each of the constituent councils to appoint at least one of its elected
members as a member of the CCA.

10.5

The provision which may be made by regulations under subsection  (1)  by
virtue of subsection  (2) (d)  includes—

10.5.a

provision setting up or dissolving an executive body of a CCA, or merging two
or more executive bodies of a CCA;

10.5.b

provision conferring functions on, or removing functions from, an executive
body of a CCA;

10.5.c

provision transferring functions of a CCA to an executive body of the CCA, and
transferring functions of an executive body of a CCA to the CCA.

10.6

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may not provide for the budget of a CCA to
be agreed otherwise than by the CCA.

10.7

The power to make regulations under subsection  (1)  is subject to—

10.7.a

sections  11  and  12  and regulations under  section 13 (1)  (non-constituent
and associate members), and

10.7.b

sections  14 (4)  and  25 (9)  and  (12)  (procedure for CCA consents).

10.8

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may be made in relation to a CCA only with
the consent of—

10.8.a

the constituent councils, and

10.8.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

10.9

If the only provision made under subsection  (1)  in regulations under this
Chapter is provision as a result of regulations under section  25 (1)
(changes to boundaries of a CCA’s area)—

10.9.a

subsection  (8)  does not apply to the regulations under this Chapter, and

10.9.b

subsections  (6)  to  (13)  of section  25  apply in relation to the
regulations as if they contained the provision made by the regulations under
subsection  (1)  of that section.

10.10

If the only provision made under subsection  (1)  in regulations under this
Chapter is provision as a result of regulations to which section  31  applies
(procedure for direct conferral of general functions on mayor)—

10.10.a

subsection  (8)  does not apply to the regulations under this Chapter, and

10.10.b

the regulations may be made only with the consent of the mayor for the CCA.

10.11

In this Chapter “ constituent council ”, in relation to a CCA or proposed CCA,
means—

10.11.a

a county council for an area within the CCA’s area or proposed area, or

10.11.b

a unitary district council for an area within the CCA’s area or proposed area.

###### Non-constituent members of a CCA

11

11.1

A CCA may designate a body other than a constituent council as a nominating
body for the purposes of this Chapter.

11.2

A nominating body may be designated under subsection  (1)  only if the body
consents to the designation.

11.3

A nominating body of a CCA may nominate a representative of the body for
appointment by the CCA as a member (a “non-constituent member”).

11.4

The non-constituent members of a CCA are to be non-voting members of that
authority unless the voting members resolve otherwise.

11.5

A resolution under subsection  (4)  does not permit non-constituent members to
vote on a decision whether the CCA should consent to the making of regulations
under this Chapter.

###### Associate members of a CCA

12

12.1

A CCA may appoint an individual to be a member (“an associate member”) of the
CCA.

12.2

The associate members of a CCA are to be non-voting members of the CCA.

###### Regulations about members

13

13.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about—

13.1.a

constituent members of a CCA;

13.1.b

the mayor for the area of a CCA in the mayor’s capacity as a member of the
CCA;

13.1.c

nominating bodies of a CCA;

13.1.d

non-constituent members of a CCA;

13.1.e

associate members of a CCA.

13.2

The provision that may be made by regulations under subsection  (1)  includes,
in particular, provision about—

13.2.a

the cases in which a decision of a CCA requires a majority, or a particular
kind of majority, of the votes of members of a particular kind;

13.2.b

the process for the designation of a nominating body or the removal of such a
designation;

13.2.c

the number of nominating bodies that may be designated by a CCA;

13.2.d

the number of non-constituent members that may be appointed by a nominating
body of a CCA;

13.2.e

the appointment, disqualification, resignation or removal of a non-constituent
member;

13.2.f

the appointment of a substitute member to act in place of a non-constituent
member;

13.2.g

the maximum number of non-constituent members of a CCA;

13.2.h

the making by a nominating body of a CCA of payments towards the costs of the
CCA;

13.2.i

the things which may or may not be done by, or in relation to, a non-
constituent member;

13.2.j

the appointment, disqualification, resignation or removal of an associate
member;

13.2.k

the appointment of a substitute member to act in place of an associate member;

13.2.l

the maximum number of associate members of a CCA;

13.2.m

the things which may or may not be done by, or in relation to, an associate
member.

13.3

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may confer a discretion on a CCA to
determine any matter.

13.4

In this section “ constituent member ”, in relation to a CCA, means a member
of the CCA (other than any mayor for the area of the CCA) appointed by a
constituent council.

###### Review of CCA’s constitutional arrangements

14

14.1

This section applies if regulations under section  10 (1)  (constitution of
CCA) enable a CCA to make provision about its constitution (“constitutional
provision”).

14.2

An appropriate person may carry out a review of the CCA’s constitutional
provision if—

14.2.a

an appropriate person proposes a review, and

14.2.b

the CCA consents to the review.

14.3

If an appropriate person carries out a review under subsection  (2) , they may
propose changes to the CCA’s constitutional provision as a result of the
review for agreement by the CCA.

14.4

The question of whether to consent under subsection  (2) (b)  or to agree to
changes proposed under subsection  (3)  is to be decided at a meeting of the
CCA by a simple majority of the voting members of the CCA who are present at
the meeting.

14.5

In the case of a mayoral CCA—

14.5.a

a majority in favour of consenting under subsection  (2) (b)  does not need to
include the mayor, but

14.5.b

a majority in favour of changes proposed under subsection  (3)  must include
the mayor.

14.6

The reference in subsection  (4)  to a voting member—

14.6.a

includes a substitute member who may act in place of a voting member;

14.6.b

does not include a non-constituent member.

14.7

In this section “ appropriate person ”, in relation to a CCA, means—

14.7.a

a member of the CCA appointed by a constituent council, or

14.7.b

the mayor for the area of the CCA, if it is a mayoral CCA (see section  27 (8)
).

###### Overview and scrutiny committees

15

15.1

Schedule  1  makes provision for CCAs to have overview and scrutiny committees
and audit committees.

15.2

Provision made by regulations under section  10 (1)  is subject to that
Schedule.

###### Funding

16

16.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

16.1.a

for the costs of a CCA to be met by its constituent councils, and

16.1.b

about the basis on which the amount payable by each constituent council is to
be determined.

16.2

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may be made in relation to a CCA only with
the consent of—

16.2.a

the constituent councils, and

16.2.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

16.3

Subsection  (1)  is subject to regulations under section  13 (1)  (CCA
membership).

###### Change of name

17

17.1

A CCA may, by a resolution in relation to which the requirements mentioned in
subsection  (2)  are met, change the name by which it is known.

17.2

The requirements are—

17.2.a

that the resolution is considered at a meeting of the CCA which is specially
convened for the purpose,

17.2.b

that particulars of the resolution were included in the notice of the meeting,
and

17.2.c

that the resolution is passed at the meeting by not less than two-thirds of
the members of the CCA who vote on it.

17.3

A CCA which changes its name under this section must—

17.3.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State, and

17.3.b

publish the notice in such manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

17.4

A change of name under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of the CCA concerned or any other person, or render defective any legal
proceedings; and any legal proceedings may be commenced or continued as if
there had been no change of name.

##### Functions of CCAs

###### Local authority functions

18

18.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for a function of a county
council or a district council that is exercisable in relation to an area which
is within a CCA’s area to be exercisable by the CCA in relation to the CCA’s
area.

18.2

The Secretary of State may make regulations under subsection  (1)  only if the
Secretary of State considers that the function can appropriately be exercised
by the CCA.

18.3

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may make provision for the function to be
exercisable by the CCA either generally or subject to such conditions or
limitations as may be specified in the regulations.

18.4

Regulations under subsection (1) which provide for a function of a county
council or a unitary district council to be exercisable by a CCA may make
provision for the function to be exercisable by the CCA instead of by the
county council or unitary district council.

18.5

Regulations under subsection (1) which provide for a function of a county
council or a district council to be exercisable by a CCA may make provision—

18.5.a

for the function to be exercisable by the CCA concurrently with the county
council or district council,

18.5.b

for the function to be exercisable by the CCA and the county council or
district council jointly, or

18.5.c

for the function to be exercisable by the CCA jointly with the county council
or district council but also continue to be exercisable by the council alone.

18.6

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may be made in relation to a CCA only with
the consent of—

18.6.a

the constituent councils, and

18.6.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

###### Other public authority functions

19

19.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

19.1.a

make provision for a function of a public authority that is exercisable in
relation to a CCA’s area to be a function of the CCA;

19.1.b

make provision for conferring on a CCA in relation to its area a function
corresponding to a function that a public authority has in relation to another
area.

19.2

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may include further provision about the
exercise of the function including—

19.2.a

provision for the function to be exercisable by the public authority or CCA
subject to conditions or limitations specified in the regulations;

19.2.b

provision as to joint working arrangements between the CCA and public
authority in connection with the function (for example, provision for the
function to be exercised by a joint committee).

19.3

The provision that may be included in regulations under subsection  (1) (a)
includes, in particular, provision—

19.3.a

for the CCA to have the function instead of the public authority,

19.3.b

for the function to be exercisable by the CCA concurrently with the public
authority,

19.3.c

for the function to be exercisable by the CCA and the public authority
jointly, or

19.3.d

for the function to be exercisable by the CCA jointly with the public
authority but also continue to be exercisable by the public authority alone.

19.4

Regulations under subsection  (1) (a)  may, in particular, include provision
to abolish the public authority in a case where, as a result of the
regulations, it will no longer have any functions.

19.5

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may not provide for a regulatory function
that is exercisable by a public authority in relation to the whole of England
to be exercisable by a CCA in relation to its area if the regulated function
is itself exercisable by the CCA by virtue of regulations under this section.

19.6

Subsection  (7)  applies where regulations under subsection  (1)  contain a
reference to a document specified or described in the regulations (for
example, in imposing a condition by virtue of subsection  (2) (a)  for an
authority to have regard to, or to comply with, a statement of policy or
standards set out in the document).

19.7

If it appears to the Secretary of State necessary or expedient for the
reference to the document to be construed—

19.7.a

as a reference to that document as amended from time to time, or

19.7.b

as including a reference to a subsequent document that replaces that document,

the regulations may make express provision to that effect.

19.8

See also section 18 of the Cities and Local Government Devolution Act 2016
(devolving health service functions) which contains further limitations.

19.9

In this section—

      “ function ” (except in subsection  (4) ) does not include a power to
make regulations or other instruments of a legislative character;           “
Minister of the Crown ” has the same meaning as in the Ministers of the Crown
Act 1975;           “ public authority ”—         includes a Minister of the
Crown or a government department;           does not include a county council
or a district council;                 “ regulated function ” means the
function of carrying out an activity to which a regulatory function relates;
“ regulatory function ” has the meaning given by section 32 of the Legislative
and Regulatory Reform Act 2006.

###### Section 

20

20.1

The Secretary of State may make regulations under section  19 (1)  only if—

20.1.a

a proposal for the making of the regulations in relation to the CCA has been
made to the Secretary of State—

20.1.a.i

as part of a proposal under section  45 , or

20.1.a.ii

in accordance with section  47 , or

20.1.b

the appropriate consent is given and the Secretary of State considers that the
making of the regulations is likely to improve the economic, social and
environmental well-being of some or all of the people who live or work in the
area or areas to which the regulations relate.

20.2

For the purposes of subsection  (1) (b) , the appropriate consent is given to
the making of regulations under section  19 (1)  only if—

20.2.a

in the case of regulations relating to an existing CCA, each appropriate
authority consents;

20.2.b

in any other case, each constituent council consents.

20.3

The requirements in subsection  (1)  do not apply where the regulations are
made under sections  19 (1)  and  30 (1)  in relation to an existing mayoral
CCA and provide for a function—

20.3.a

to be a function of the CCA, and

20.3.b

to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.

See section  31  in relation to regulations of this kind.

20.4

The requirement in subsection  (1) (b)  for the appropriate consent to be
given to the making of regulations under section  19 (1)  does not apply
where—

20.4.a

the regulations revoke (in whole or in part), or otherwise amend, previous
regulations under section  19 (1) , and

20.4.b

the only purpose of the regulations is to provide for a health service
function of a CCA to cease to be exercisable by the CCA.

20.5

In subsection  (4) (b)  “ health service function of a CCA ” means a function
which—

20.5.a

relates to the health service, as defined by section 275(1) of the National
Health Service Act 2006, and

20.5.b

is exercisable by the CCA by virtue of regulations under section  19 (1) .

20.6

At the same time as laying a draft of a statutory instrument containing
regulations under section  19 (1)  before Parliament, the Secretary of State
must lay before Parliament a report explaining the effect of the regulations
and why the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to make the
regulations.

20.7

The report must include—

20.7.a

a description of any consultation taken into account by the Secretary of
State,

20.7.b

information about any representations considered by the Secretary of State in
connection with the regulations, and

20.7.c

any other evidence or contextual information that the Secretary of State
considers it appropriate to include.

20.8

For the purposes of this section “the appropriate authorities” are—

20.8.a

each constituent council, and

20.8.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

###### Integrated Transport Authority and Passenger Transport Executive

21

21.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations transfer functions of an Integrated
Transport Authority (an “ITA”) to a CCA.

21.2

Regulations under subsection (1) may only be made in relation to functions
exercisable by the ITA in relation to an area that becomes, or becomes part
of, the CCA’s area by virtue of regulations under this Chapter.

21.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for any function that is
conferred or imposed on a Passenger Transport Executive by any enactment
(whenever passed or made) to be exercisable by a CCA or the executive body of
a CCA in relation to the CCA’s area.

21.4

Regulations under subsection (3) may make provision for any function that—

21.4.a

is conferred or imposed on an ITA by any enactment (whenever passed or made),
and

21.4.b

relates to the functions of a Passenger Transport Executive,

to be exercisable by a CCA in relation to the CCA’s area.

21.5

Regulations under this section may be made in relation to a CCA only with the
consent of—

21.5.a

the constituent councils, and

21.5.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

###### Directions relating to highways and traffic functions

22

22.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations confer on a CCA a power to give a
direction about the exercise of an eligible power.

22.2

An “ eligible power ” means a power of a county council or a unitary district
council which the council has—

22.2.a

as highway authority by virtue of section 1 of the Highways Act 1980, or

22.2.b

as traffic authority by virtue of section 121A of the Road Traffic Regulation
Act 1984.

22.3

In this section references to a power do not include a reference to a duty.

22.4

A power of direction under this section must relate only to the exercise of an
eligible power in—

22.4.a

the area of the CCA, and

22.4.b

the area of the authority subject to the direction.

22.5

A power of direction under this section must relate only to the exercise of an
eligible power in respect of—

22.5.a

a particular road (whether or not specified in the regulations), or

22.5.b

a description of road (whether or not specified in the regulations).

22.6

In subsection  (5)  “road”—

22.6.a

has the meaning given by section 142(1) of the Road Traffic Regulation Act
1984, and

22.6.b

does not include any road which is the subject of a concession agreement under
Part 1 of the New Roads and Street Works Act 1991.

22.7

A power of direction under this section must relate only to any one or more
of—

22.7.a

the provision of information about the exercise of an eligible power which the
authority subject to the direction has or might reasonably be expected to
acquire;

22.7.b

the imposition on such an authority of requirements relating to procedures to
be followed prior to the exercise of an eligible power;

22.7.c

the imposition on such an authority of requirements relating to the obtaining
of consent prior to the exercise of an eligible power;

22.7.d

the imposition on such an authority of conditions subject to which an eligible
power may be exercised (including conditions relating to the times at which,
and the manner in which, an eligible power may be exercised);

22.7.e

a requirement to exercise an eligible power (including a requirement to
exercise an eligible power subject to conditions);

22.7.f

a prohibition on the exercise of an eligible power.

22.8

A power of direction under this section may be conferred subject to
conditions.

22.9

Any direction given by virtue of this section—

22.9.a

must be given in writing and may be varied or revoked by a further direction
in writing, and

22.9.b

may make different provision for different cases and different provision for
different areas.

22.10

If regulations under subsection  (1)  make provision for a direction by virtue
of subsection  (7) (e) , the regulations must make provision for the direction
not to have effect unless the CCA meets the cost of complying with the
direction.

22.11

Except as provided for by  section 24 (7) , regulations under subsection  (1)
may be made in relation to a CCA only with the consent of—

22.11.a

the constituent councils, and

22.11.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

###### Contravention of regulations under section 

23

23.1

Regulations under section  22 (1)  may provide that, if an authority exercises
any power in contravention of a direction under such regulations, the CCA may
take such steps as it considers appropriate to reverse or modify the effect of
the exercise of the power.

23.2

For the purposes of subsection  (1) , the CCA has power to exercise any power
of the authority subject to the direction on behalf of that authority.

23.3

Any reasonable expenses incurred by the CCA in taking any steps under
subsection  (1)  are recoverable from the authority subject to the direction
as a civil debt.

###### Designation of key route network roads

24

24.1

A CCA may designate a highway or proposed highway in its area as a key route
network road, or remove its designation as a key route network road, with the
consent of—

24.1.a

each constituent council in whose area the highway or proposed highway is, and

24.1.b

in the case of a mayoral CCA, the mayor.

24.2

The Secretary of State may designate a highway or proposed highway in the area
of a CCA as a key route network road, or remove its designation as a key route
network road, if requested to do so by—

24.2.a

the CCA,

24.2.b

the mayor (if any) of the CCA, or

24.2.c

a constituent council.

24.3

A designation or removal under this section must be in writing and must state
when it comes into effect.

24.4

The Secretary of State must send a copy of a designation or removal under
subsection (2)  to the CCA in question at least 7 days before the date on
which it comes into effect.

24.5

A CCA must publish each designation or removal under this section of a key
route network road within its area before the date on which it comes into
effect.

24.6

A CCA that has key route network roads in its area must keep a list or map (or
both) accessible to the public showing those roads.

24.7

The requirements in  section 22 (11)  and  section 30 (11) (a)  do not apply
to provision under  section 22 (1)  and  section 30 (1)  contained in the same
instrument so far as that provision—

24.7.a

confers a power of direction on an existing mayoral CCA regarding the exercise
of an eligible power in respect of key route network roads in the area of that
CCA,

24.7.b

provides for that power of direction to be exercisable only by the mayor of
the CCA, and

24.7.c

is made with the consent of the mayor after the mayor has consulted the
constituent councils.

24.8

When a mayor consents under  subsection (7) (c) , the mayor must give the
Secretary of State—

24.8.a

a statement by the mayor that all of the constituent councils agree to the
making of the regulations, or

24.8.b

if the mayor is unable to make that statement, the reasons why the mayor
considers the regulations should be made even though not all of the
constituent councils agree to them being made.

24.9

In this section—

      “ eligible power ” has the meaning given by  section 22 (2) ;
“ key route network road ” means a highway or proposed highway designated for
the time being under this section as a key route network road;           “
proposed highway ” means land on which, in accordance with plans made by a
highway authority, that authority are for the time being constructing or
intending to construct a highway shown in the plans.

##### Changes to CCAs

###### Changes to boundaries of a CCA’s area

25

25.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations change the boundaries of a CCA’s
area by—

25.1.a

adding a relevant local government area to an existing area of a CCA, or

25.1.b

removing a relevant local government area from an existing area of a CCA.

25.2

In this section “ relevant local government area ” means—

25.2.a

the area of a two-tier county council,

25.2.b

the area of a unitary county council, or

25.2.c

the area of a unitary district council.

25.3

Regulations under subsection  (1) (b) —

25.3.a

may transfer functions relating to the relevant local government area from the
CCA to any other public authority;

25.3.b

may provide for any function of the CCA relating to the area to be no longer
exercisable in relation to that area.

25.4

In subsection  (3) (a)  “ public authority ” includes—

25.4.a

a Minister of the Crown within the meaning of the Ministers of the Crown Act
1975,

25.4.b

a government department,

25.4.c

a county council, and

25.4.d

a district council.

25.5

Regulations may be made under subsection  (1)  only if the area to be created
by the regulations meets conditions A and B in section  9 .

25.6

Regulations under subsection  (1)  adding or removing a relevant local
government area to or from an existing area of a mayoral CCA may be made only
if—

25.6.a

the relevant council in relation to the relevant local government area
consents, and

25.6.b

the mayor for the area of the CCA consents.

25.7

Regulations under subsection  (1)  adding or removing a relevant local
government area to or from an existing area of a CCA which is not a mayoral
CCA may be made only if—

25.7.a

the relevant council in relation to the relevant local government area
consents, and

25.7.b

the CCA consents.

25.8

For the purposes of subsections  (6) (a)  and  (7) (a) , the “ relevant
council ” in relation to a relevant local government area is—

25.8.a

if the local government area is the area of a county council, the county
council;

25.8.b

if the local government area is the area of a unitary district council, the
unitary district council.

25.9

The question of whether to consent under subsection  (7) (b)  to regulations
under subsection  (1)  is to be decided at a meeting of the CCA by a simple
majority of the voting members of the authority who are present at the
meeting.

25.10

Where regulations under subsection  (1) (b)  are made as a result of the duty
in section  28 (3) —

25.10.a

subsection  (5)  does not apply, and

25.10.b

neither subsection  (6)  nor subsection  (7)  applies.

25.11

Subsection  (12)  applies if a CCA has made provision about its constitution
under regulations under section  10 (1) .

25.12

A decision about any change to that provision as a result of regulations under
subsection  (1)  is to be decided at a meeting of the CCA by a simple majority
of the voting members of the CCA who are present at the meeting.

25.13

A reference in this section to a voting member—

25.13.a

includes a substitute member who may act in place of a voting member;

25.13.b

does not include a non-constituent member.

###### Dissolution of a CCA’s area

26

26.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

26.1.a

dissolve a CCA’s area, and

26.1.b

abolish the CCA for that area.

26.2

Regulations under subsection  (1) —

26.2.a

may transfer functions from the CCA to any other public authority;

26.2.b

may provide for any function of the CCA to be no longer exercisable in
relation to the CCA’s area.

26.3

In subsection  (2) (a)  “ public authority ” includes—

26.3.a

a Minister of the Crown within the meaning of the Ministers of the Crown Act
1975,

26.3.b

a government department,

26.3.c

a county council, and

26.3.d

a district council.

26.4

Regulations may be made under subsection  (1)  only if—

26.4.a

a majority of the constituent councils consent to the making of the
regulations, and

26.4.b

in the case of regulations made in relation to a mayoral CCA, the mayor for
the area of the CCA also consents to the making of the regulations.

##### Mayors for CCA areas

###### Power to provide for election of mayor

27

27.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for there to be a mayor for
the area of a CCA.

27.2

A mayor for the area of a CCA is to be elected by the local government
electors for that area in accordance with provision made by or under this
Chapter.

27.3

In subsection  (2)  “ local government elector ” has the meaning given by
section 270(1) of the Local Government Act 1972.

27.4

Schedule  2  makes further provision about the election of mayors for areas of
CCAs.

27.5

A mayor for the area of a CCA is entitled to the style of “mayor”.

27.6

A mayor for the area of a CCA is by virtue of that office a member of, and the
chair of, the CCA.

27.7

Regulations under subsection  (1)  providing for there to be a mayor for the
area of a CCA may not be revoked by making further regulations under
subsection  (1) ; but this does not prevent the making of regulations under
section  26 (1)  abolishing the CCA (together with the office of mayor).

27.8

In this Chapter “ mayoral CCA ” means a CCA for an area for which provision is
made in regulations under subsection  (1)  for there to be a mayor.

###### Requirements in connection with regulations under section 

28

28.1

The Secretary of State may make regulations under section  27 (1)  in relation
to a CCA’s area if a proposal for there to be a mayor for the CCA’s area has
been made to the Secretary of State—

28.1.a

as part of a proposal under section  45 , or

28.1.b

in accordance with section  47 .

28.2

Regulations under section  27 (1)  may also be made without any such proposal
having been made if—

28.2.a

the appropriate authorities consent, or

28.2.b

in the case of an existing CCA, there are one or more non-consenting
constituent councils but the CCA and at least two constituent councils
consent.

28.3

Where regulations under section  27 (1)  are made by virtue of subsection  (2)
(b)  of this section, the Secretary of State must make regulations under
section  25 (1) (b)  to remove the area of each non-consenting constituent
council from the existing area of the CCA.

28.4

For the purposes of this section “the appropriate authorities” are—

28.4.a

the constituent councils, and

28.4.b

in the case of regulations in relation to an existing CCA, the CCA.

###### Deputy mayors etc

29

29.1

The mayor for the area of a CCA must appoint one of the members of the
authority to be the mayor’s deputy.

29.2

The deputy mayor holds office until the end of the term of office of the
mayor, subject to subsection  (3) .

29.3

A person ceases to be the deputy mayor if at any time—

29.3.a

the mayor removes the person from office,

29.3.b

the person resigns as deputy mayor, or

29.3.c

the person ceases to be a member of the CCA.

29.4

If a vacancy occurs in the office of deputy mayor, the mayor must appoint
another member of the CCA to be deputy mayor.

29.5

The deputy mayor must act in place of the mayor if for any reason—

29.5.a

the mayor is unable to act, or

29.5.b

the office of mayor is vacant.

29.6

If for any reason—

29.6.a

the mayor is unable to act or the office of mayor is vacant, and

29.6.b

the deputy mayor is unable to act or the office of deputy mayor is vacant,

the other members of the CCA must act together in place of the mayor, taking
decisions by a simple majority.

29.7

In this Chapter “ deputy mayor ”, in relation to a mayoral CCA, means the
person appointed under this section by the mayor for the authority’s area.

29.8

References in this section to a member of a CCA do not include a non-
constituent or associate member.

###### Functions of mayors: general

30

30.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for any function of a
mayoral CCA to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.

30.2

In this Chapter references to “ general functions ”, in relation to a mayor
for the area of a CCA, are to any functions exercisable by the mayor other
than PCC functions (see section  33 (3) ).

30.3

The mayor may arrange—

30.3.a

for the deputy mayor to exercise any general function of the mayor,

30.3.b

for another member or officer of the CCA to exercise any such function,

30.3.c

so far as authorised by regulations made by the Secretary of State—

30.3.c.i

for a person appointed as the deputy mayor for policing and crime by virtue of
regulations under paragraph  3 (1)  of Schedule  3 , or

30.3.c.ii

for a committee of the CCA, consisting of members appointed by the mayor
(whether or not members of the CCA),

to exercise any such function.

30.4

The reference in subsection  (3) (b)  to a member of a CCA does not include a
non-constituent or associate member.

30.5

Regulations under subsection  (3) (c) (ii)  may include provision—

30.5.a

about the membership of the committee;

30.5.b

about the member of the committee who is to be its chair;

30.5.c

about the appointment of members;

30.5.d

about the voting powers of members (including provision for different weight
to be given to the vote of different descriptions of member);

30.5.e

about information held by the CCA that must, or must not, be disclosed to the
committee for purposes connected to the exercise of the committee’s functions;

30.5.f

applying (with or without modifications) sections 15 to 17 of, and Schedule 1
to, the Local Government and Housing Act 1989 (political balance on local
authority committees etc).

30.6

Regulations under subsection  (3) (c)  must provide that the committee must
not consist solely of non-constituent or associate members.

30.7

Provision in regulations under subsection  (1)  for a function to be
exercisable only by the mayor is subject to subsection  (3) ; but the
Secretary of State may by regulations provide that arrangements under
subsection  (3) —

30.7.a

may authorise the exercise of general functions only of a description
specified in the regulations, or

30.7.b

may not authorise the exercise of general functions of a description so
specified.

30.8

Any general function exercisable by the mayor for the area of a CCA by virtue
of this Act is to be taken to be a function of the CCA exercisable—

30.8.a

by the mayor individually, or

30.8.b

in accordance with arrangements made by virtue of this section or section  32
or  34 .

30.9

Regulations under this section may—

30.9.a

include provision for general functions to be exercisable by the mayor subject
to conditions or limitations specified in the regulations (including, for
example, a condition for general functions to be exercisable only with the
consent of the appropriate authorities (as defined by section  28 (4) ));

30.9.b

provide for members or officers of a mayoral CCA to assist the mayor in the
exercise of general functions;

30.9.c

confer ancillary powers on the mayor for the purposes of the exercise of
general functions;

30.9.d

authorise the mayor to appoint one person as the mayor’s political adviser;

30.9.e

provide for the terms and conditions of any such appointment;

30.9.f

provide that functions that the mayoral CCA discharges in accordance with
arrangements under section 101(1)(b) of the Local Government Act 1972
(discharge of local authority functions by another authority) are to be
treated as general functions exercisable by the mayor (so far as authorised by
the arrangements).

30.10

Provision under subsection  (9) (c)  may include provision conferring power on
the mayor that is similar to any power exercisable by the mayoral CCA—

30.10.a

under section  49  (general power of CCA), or

30.10.b

under regulations made under section  52 (1)  (general power of competence),

but the power conferred on the mayor may not include a power to borrow money.

30.11

Except as provided for by  section 24 (7) , regulations under this section may
be made only with the consent of—

30.11.a

the appropriate authorities (as defined by section  28 (4) ), and

30.11.b

in the case of regulations made in relation to an existing mayoral CCA, the
mayor of the CCA.

30.12

Where regulations under this section are contained in the same instrument as
regulations made by virtue of section  28 (2) (b) , a non-consenting
constituent council is not to be treated as an appropriate authority for the
purposes of subsection  (11) .

30.13

The requirement in subsection  (11)  does not apply where the regulations are
made under section  19 (1)  and  subsection (1)  of this section in relation
to an existing mayoral CCA and provide for a function—

30.13.a

to be a function of the CCA, and

30.13.b

to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.

See section  31  in relation to regulations of this kind.

###### Procedure for direct conferral of general functions on mayor

31

31.1

This section applies in relation to regulations which are made under sections
19 (1)  and  30 (1)  in relation to an existing mayoral CCA and provide for a
function—

31.1.a

to be a function of the CCA, and

31.1.b

to be a function exercisable only by the mayor.

31.2

The Secretary of State may make the regulations only if a request for the
making of the regulations has been made to the Secretary of State by the
mayor.

31.3

Before submitting a request under this section, the mayor must consult the
constituent councils.

31.4

A request under this section must contain—

31.4.a

a statement by the mayor that all of the constituent councils agree to the
making of the regulations, or

31.4.b

if the mayor is unable to make that statement, the reasons why the mayor
considers the regulations should be made even though not all of the
constituent councils agree to them being made.

###### Joint exercise of general functions

32

32.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for, or in connection
with, permitting arrangements under section 101(5) of the Local Government Act
1972 to be entered into in relation to general functions of a mayor for the
area of a CCA.

32.2

Provision under subsection  (1)  may include provision—

32.2.a

for the mayor for the area of a CCA to be a party to the arrangements in place
of, or jointly with, the CCA;

32.2.b

about the membership of any joint committee;

32.2.c

about the member of the joint committee who is to be its chair;

32.2.d

about the appointment of members to a joint committee;

32.2.e

about the voting powers of members of a joint committee (including provision
for different weight to be given to the vote of different descriptions of
member).

32.3

Provision under subsection  (2) (b)  to  (d)  may include provision for the
mayor or other persons—

32.3.a

to determine the number of members;

32.3.b

to have the power to appoint members (whether or not members of the CCA or a
local authority that is a party to the arrangements).

32.4

Provision under subsection  (2) (d)  may include provision as to the
circumstances in which appointments to a joint committee need not be made in
accordance with sections 15 to 17 of, and Schedule 1 to, the Local Government
and Housing Act 1989 (political balance on local authority committees etc).

32.5

In this section references to a joint committee are to a joint committee
falling within section 101(5)(a) of the Local Government Act 1972 that is
authorised to discharge, by virtue of regulations under this section, general
functions of a mayor for the area of a CCA.

##### Police and crime and fire and rescue functions

###### Functions of mayors: policing

33

33.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for the mayor for the area
of a CCA to exercise functions of a police and crime commissioner in relation
to that area.

33.2

The reference in subsection  (1)  to functions of a police and crime
commissioner is to any functions conferred on police and crime commissioners
by or under—

33.2.a

Part 1 of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011, or

33.2.b

any other Act (whenever passed).

33.3

In this Chapter references to “ PCC functions ”, in relation to a mayor for
the area of a CCA, are to the functions of a police and crime commissioner
that are exercisable by the mayor by virtue of subsection  (1) .

33.4

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may be made in relation to an existing
mayoral CCA only with the consent of the mayor of the CCA.

33.5

If regulations are made under subsection  (1)  in relation to a CCA’s area—

33.5.a

the Secretary of State must by regulations provide that there is to be no
police and crime commissioner for that area as from a specified date;

33.5.b

the Secretary of State may by regulations provide that any election of a
police and crime commissioner for that area that would otherwise take place
(whether before or after the specified date) by virtue of section 50(1)(b) of
the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011 is not to take place.

33.6

Regulations under subsection  (5)  may include provision—

33.6.a

for the term of office of a police and crime commissioner to continue until
the date specified in regulations under subsection  (5) (a)  (in spite of
section 50(7)(b) of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011);

33.6.b

for an election to fill a vacancy in the office of a police and crime
commissioner, which otherwise would take place under section 51 of that Act,
not to take place if the vacancy occurs within a period of six months ending
with the specified date.

33.7

Schedule  3  contains further provision in connection with regulations under
this section.

33.8

Any PCC function exercisable by the mayor for the area of a CCA by virtue of
this Act is to be taken to be a function of the CCA exercisable—

33.8.a

by the mayor acting individually, or

33.8.b

by a person acting under arrangements with the mayor made in accordance with
provision made under Schedule  3 .

###### Exercise of fire and rescue functions

34

34.1

This section applies to a mayor for the area of a CCA who—

34.1.a

by virtue of section  30 (1) , may exercise functions which are conferred on a
fire and rescue authority in that name (“fire and rescue functions”), and

34.1.b

by virtue of section  33 (1) , may exercise functions of a police and crime
commissioner.

34.2

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

34.2.a

authorising the mayor to arrange for the chief constable of the police force
for the police area which corresponds to the area of the CCA to exercise fire
and rescue functions exercisable by the mayor;

34.2.b

authorising that chief constable to arrange for a person within subsection
(4)  to exercise the chief constable’s fire and rescue functions.

34.3

Regulations under subsection  (2)  may provide that arrangements made under
the regulations—

34.3.a

may authorise the exercise of any functions mentioned in that subsection;

34.3.b

may authorise the exercise of any functions mentioned in that subsection other
than those specified or described in the regulations;

34.3.c

may authorise the exercise of such of the functions mentioned in that
subsection as are specified or described in the regulations.

34.4

The persons mentioned in subsection  (2) (b)  are—

34.4.a

members of the chief constable’s police force;

34.4.b

the civilian staff of that police force, as defined by section 102(4) of the
Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011;

34.4.c

members of staff transferred to the chief constable under a scheme made by
virtue of section  36 (1) ;

34.4.d

members of staff appointed by the chief constable under section  36 (2) .

34.5

Provision in regulations under section  30 (1)  for a function to be
exercisable only by the mayor for the area of a CCA is subject to provision
made by virtue of subsection  (2) .

34.6

This section is subject to—

34.6.a

section  35  (section  34  regulations: procedure), and

34.6.b

section 37 of the Fire and Rescue Services Act 2004 (prohibition on employment
of police in fire-fighting).

34.7

In this section “ fire and rescue functions ”, in relation to a chief
constable, means—

34.7.a

functions which are exercisable by the chief constable by virtue of provision
made under subsection  (2) (a) , and

34.7.b

functions relating to fire and rescue services which are conferred on the
chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment.

###### Section 

35

35.1

Regulations under section  34 (2)  may be made in relation to the mayor for
the area of a CCA only if the mayor has requested the Secretary of State to
make the regulations.

35.2

A request under subsection  (1)  must be accompanied by a report which
contains—

35.2.a

an assessment of why—

35.2.a.i

it is in the interests of economy, efficiency and effectiveness for the
regulations to be made, or

35.2.a.ii

it is in the interests of public safety for the regulations to be made,

35.2.b

a description of any public consultation which the mayor has carried out on
the proposal for the regulations to be made,

35.2.c

a summary of the responses to any such consultation, and

35.2.d

a summary of the representations (if any) which the mayor has received about
that proposal from the constituent members of the CCA.

35.3

Before making the request the mayor must publish, in such manner as the mayor
thinks appropriate, the mayor’s response to the representations made or views
expressed in response to any consultations on the proposal.

35.4

Subsections  (5)  to  (7)  apply if—

35.4.a

the mayor for the area of a CCA makes a request under subsection  (1)  for the
Secretary of State to make regulations under section  34 (2) , and

35.4.b

at least two thirds of the constituent members of the CCA have indicated that
they disagree with the proposal for the regulations to be made.

35.5

The mayor must, in providing the report under subsection  (2) , provide the
Secretary of State with—

35.5.a

copies of the representations (if any) made by the constituent members of the
CCA about that proposal, and

35.5.b

the mayor’s response to those representations and to the responses to any
public consultation which the mayor has carried out on that proposal.

35.6

The Secretary of State must—

35.6.a

obtain an independent assessment of that proposal, and

35.6.b

in deciding whether to make the regulations, have regard to that assessment
and to the material provided under subsection  (5)  (as well as the material
provided under subsection  (2) ).

35.7

The Secretary of State must publish the independent assessment—

35.7.a

as soon as is reasonably practicable after making a determination in response
to the proposal, and

35.7.b

in such manner as the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.

35.8

Regulations under section  34 (2)  may be made only if it appears to the
Secretary of State that—

35.8.a

it is in the interests of economy, efficiency and effectiveness for the
regulations to be made, or

35.8.b

it is in the interests of public safety for the regulations to be made.

35.9

The Secretary of State may not make regulations under section  34 (2)  in a
case within subsection  (8) (a)  of this section if the Secretary of State
thinks that the regulations would have an adverse effect on public safety.

35.10

The Secretary of State may, in making regulations under section  34 (2)  in
relation to the mayor for the area of a CCA, give effect to the mayor’s
proposal for the regulations with such modifications as the Secretary of State
thinks appropriate.

35.11

Before making regulations which give effect to such a proposal with
modifications, the Secretary of State must consult the mayor and the CCA on
the modifications.

35.12

In this section “ constituent member ”, in relation to a CCA, means a member
of the CCA appointed by a constituent council (but does not include the mayor
for the area of the CCA).

###### Section 

36

36.1

Regulations under section  34 (2)  may make provision for the making of a
scheme to transfer property, rights and liabilities (including criminal
liabilities)—

36.1.a

from a fire and rescue authority or the CCA to the chief constable, or

36.1.b

from the chief constable to the CCA,

(including provision corresponding to any provision made by section 17(4) to
(6) of the Localism Act 2011).

36.2

A chief constable to whom regulations under section  34 (2)  apply may appoint
staff for the purpose of the exercise of the chief constable’s fire and rescue
functions.

36.3

A chief constable to whom regulations under section  34 (2)  apply may—

36.3.a

pay remuneration, allowances and gratuities to members of the chief
constable’s fire and rescue staff;

36.3.b

pay pensions to, or in respect of, persons who are or have been such members
of staff;

36.3.c

pay amounts for or towards the provision of pensions to, or in respect of,
persons who are or have been such members of staff.

36.4

In subsection  (3)  “ allowances ”, in relation to a member of staff, means
allowances in respect of expenses incurred by the member of staff in the
course of employment as such a member of staff.

36.5

Subject to subsections  (6)  to  (8) , a person who is employed pursuant to a
transfer by virtue of subsection  (1)  or an appointment under subsection  (2)
may not at the same time be employed pursuant to an appointment by a chief
constable of the police force for a police area under Schedule 2 to the Police
Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011.

36.6

Where regulations under section  34 (2)  are in force in relation to the chief
constable of the police force for a police area, the person who is for the
time being the police force’s chief finance officer is to be responsible for
the proper administration of financial affairs relating to the exercise of the
chief constable’s fire and rescue functions.

36.7

Subsection  (5)  does not prevent a person who is employed as a finance
officer for fire functions from being at the same time employed as a finance
officer for police functions.

36.8

In subsection  (7) —

      “ finance officer for fire functions ” means a member of a chief
constable’s fire and rescue staff who—         is not a chief finance officer
of the kind mentioned in subsection  (6) , and           is employed to carry
out duties relating to the proper administration of financial affairs relating
to the exercise of the chief constable’s fire and rescue functions;
“ finance officer for police functions ” means a member of a chief constable’s
civilian staff within the meaning of the Police Reform and Social
Responsibility Act 2011 who—         is not a chief finance officer of the
kind mentioned in subsection  (6) , and           is employed to carry out
duties relating to the proper administration of a police force’s financial
affairs.

36.9

Where regulations under section  34 (2)  are in force, the CCA to which the
regulations apply must pay—

36.9.a

any damages or costs awarded against the chief constable to whom the
regulations apply in any proceedings brought against the chief constable in
respect of the acts or omissions of a member of the chief constable’s fire and
rescue staff;

36.9.b

any costs incurred by the chief constable in any such proceedings so far as
not recovered by the chief constable in the proceedings;

36.9.c

any sum required in connection with the settlement of any claim made against
the chief constable in respect of the acts or omissions of a member of the
chief constable’s fire and rescue staff, if the settlement is approved by the
CCA.

36.10

Where regulations under section  34 (2)  are in force, the CCA to which the
regulations apply may, in such cases and to such extent as appears to the CCA
to be appropriate, pay—

36.10.a

any damages or costs awarded against a member of the fire and rescue staff of
the chief constable to whom the regulations apply in proceedings for any
unlawful conduct of that member of staff;

36.10.b

costs incurred and not recovered by such a member of staff in such
proceedings;

36.10.c

sums required in connection with the settlement of a claim that has or might
have given rise to such proceedings.

36.11

In this section—

      “ fire and rescue functions ” has the same meaning as in section  34 ;
“ fire and rescue staff ”, in relation to a chief constable to whom
regulations under section  34 (2)  apply, means—         staff transferred to
the chief constable under a scheme made by virtue of subsection  (1) ;
staff appointed by the chief constable under subsection  (2) .

###### Section 

37

37.1

This section applies if—

37.1.a

regulations under section  34 (2)  make provision in relation to the area of a
CCA, and

37.1.b

by virtue of the regulations, fire and rescue functions exercisable by the
mayor for the area of the CCA are exercisable by the chief constable of the
police force for the police area which corresponds to that area.

37.2

The chief constable must secure that good value for money is obtained in
exercising—

37.2.a

functions which are exercisable by the chief constable by virtue of the
regulations, and

37.2.b

functions relating to fire and rescue services which are conferred on the
chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment.

37.3

The chief constable must secure that other persons exercising functions by
virtue of the regulations obtain good value for money in exercising those
functions.

37.4

The mayor must—

37.4.a

secure the exercise of the duties which are exercisable by the chief constable
or another person by virtue of the regulations,

37.4.b

secure the exercise of the duties relating to fire and rescue services which
are imposed on the chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment,

37.4.c

secure that functions which are exercisable by the chief constable or another
person by virtue of the regulations are exercised efficiently and effectively,
and

37.4.d

secure that functions relating to fire and rescue services which are conferred
or imposed on the chief constable by or by virtue of any enactment are
exercised efficiently and effectively.

37.5

The mayor must hold the chief constable to account for the exercise of such
functions.

###### Section 

38

38.1

If regulations are made under section  34 (2)  that enable arrangements to be
made for the exercise of functions by members of a police force or the
civilian staff of a police force, the Secretary of State may by regulations
amend Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002 (persons serving with the police:
complaints and conduct matters etc) in consequence of that provision.

38.2

If regulations are made under section  34 (2)  that enable arrangements to be
made for the exercise of functions by members of staff transferred to a chief
constable under a scheme made by virtue of section  36 (1)  or appointed by a
chief constable under section  36 (2) , the Secretary of State may by
regulations make provision of the type described in subsection  (3)  in
relation to those members of staff.

38.3

The provision referred to in subsection  (2)  is—

38.3.a

provision corresponding or similar to any provision made by or under Part 2 of
the Police Reform Act 2002;

38.3.b

provision applying (with or without modifications) any provision made by or
under Part 2 of that Act.

38.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations, in consequence of any provision
made under subsection  (2) , amend Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002.

38.5

Before making regulations under this section the Secretary of State must
consult—

38.5.a

the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales,

38.5.b

the Director General of the Independent Office for Police Conduct,

38.5.c

such persons as appear to the Secretary of State to represent the views of
police and crime commissioners,

38.5.d

such persons as appear to the Secretary of State to represent the views of
fire and rescue authorities, and

38.5.e

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

###### Section 

39

39.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

39.1.a

apply (with or without modifications) any provision of a fire and rescue
enactment in relation to a person within subsection  (2) ;

39.1.b

make, in relation to a person within subsection  (2) , provision corresponding
or similar to any provision of a fire and rescue enactment.

39.2

Those persons are—

39.2.a

a chief constable of a police force for a police area to whom regulations
under section  34 (2)  apply,

39.2.b

a member of staff transferred to such a chief constable under a scheme made by
virtue of section  36 (1) ,

39.2.c

a member of staff appointed by such a chief constable under section  36 (2) ,

39.2.d

a member of such a chief constable’s police force by whom functions are
exercisable by virtue of section  34 (2) (b) , and

39.2.e

a member of the civilian staff of such a police force (as defined by section
102(4) of the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011) by whom
functions are exercisable by virtue of section  34 (2) (b) .

39.3

The power conferred by subsection  (1) (a)  or  (b)  includes power to apply
(with or without modifications) any provision made under a fire and rescue
enactment or make provision corresponding or similar to any such provision.

39.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend, revoke or repeal a provision
of or made under an enactment in consequence of provision made by virtue of
subsection  (1) .

39.5

In this section “ fire and rescue enactment ” means an enactment relating to a
fire and rescue authority (including, in particular, an enactment relating to
an employee of such an authority or property of such an authority).

39.6

References in this section to an enactment or to provision made under an
enactment are to an enactment whenever passed or (as the case may be) to
provision whenever the instrument containing it is made.

###### Section 

40

40.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

40.1.a

apply (with or without modifications) any provision of a local policing
enactment in relation to a person within subsection  (2) ;

40.1.b

make, in relation to such a person, provision corresponding or similar to any
provision of a local policing enactment.

40.2

Those persons are—

40.2.a

a mayor for the area of a CCA to whom regulations under section  34 (2)
apply,

40.2.b

a chief constable to whom such regulations apply, and

40.2.c

a panel established by virtue of regulations under paragraph  4  of Schedule
3  for such an area.

40.3

The power conferred by subsection  (1) (a)  or  (b)  includes power to apply
(with or without modifications) any provision made under a local policing
enactment or make provision corresponding or similar to any such provision.

40.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend, revoke or repeal a provision
of or made under an enactment in consequence of provision made by virtue of
subsection  (1) .

40.5

In this section “ local policing enactment ” means an enactment relating to a
police and crime commissioner.

40.6

References in this section to an enactment or to provision made under an
enactment are to an enactment whenever passed or (as the case may be) to
provision whenever the instrument containing it is made.

##### Financial matters relating to mayors

###### Mayors for CCA areas: financial matters

41

41.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for the costs of a
mayor for the area of a CCA that are incurred in, or in connection with, the
exercise of mayoral functions to be met from precepts issued by the CCA under
section 40 of the Local Government Finance Act 1992.

41.2

The function of issuing precepts under Chapter 4 of Part 1 of the Local
Government Finance Act 1992 in respect of mayoral functions is to be a
function exercisable only by the mayor acting on behalf of the CCA.

41.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations modify the application of Chapter 4
or 4ZA of Part 1 of the Local Government Finance Act 1992 so far as applying
to cases where the precepting authority in question under that Chapter is a
mayoral CCA.

41.4

Where the mayoral functions of a mayor include PCC functions—

41.4.a

the provision made by virtue of subsection  (3)  must include provision to
ensure that the council tax requirement calculated under section 42A of the
Local Government Finance Act 1992 consists of separate components in respect
of the mayor’s PCC functions and the mayor’s general functions, and

41.4.b

the function of calculating the component in respect of the mayor’s PCC
functions is itself to be treated as a PCC function for the purposes of this
Part.

41.5

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

41.5.a
