requiring the mayor to maintain a fund in relation to receipts arising, and
liabilities incurred, in the exercise of general functions;

41.5.b

about the preparation of an annual budget in relation to the exercise of
general functions.

(For power to make corresponding provision in relation to PCC functions, see
paragraph  7  of Schedule  3 .)

41.6

Provision under subsection  (5) (b)  may in particular include provision for—

41.6.a

the mayor to prepare a draft budget;

41.6.b

the draft to be scrutinised by—

41.6.b.i

the other members of the CCA, and

41.6.b.ii

a committee of the CCA appointed in accordance with paragraph  1 (1)  of
Schedule  1 ;

41.6.c

the making of changes to the draft as a result of such scrutiny;

41.6.d

the approval of the draft by the CCA (including a power to veto the draft in
circumstances specified in the regulations and the consequences of any such
veto);

41.6.e

the basis on which such approval is to be given.

41.7

The reference in subsection  (6) (b) (i)  to a member of a CCA does not
include a non-constituent or associate member.

41.8

In this section “ mayoral functions ”, in relation to a mayor, means—

41.8.a

the mayor’s general functions, and

41.8.b

if the mayor exercises PCC functions, the mayor’s PCC functions.

##### Alternative mayoral titles

###### Alternative mayoral titles

42

42.1

At the first meeting of a mayoral CCA after regulations made under section  27
(1)  come into force, the CCA must, by a resolution in accordance with
subsection  (3) —

42.1.a

provide that the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known by the title of
mayor, or

42.1.b

change the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to
an alternative title mentioned in subsection  (2) .

42.2

The alternative titles are—

42.2.a

county commissioner;

42.2.b

county governor;

42.2.c

elected leader;

42.2.d

governor;

42.2.e

a title that the CCA considers more appropriate than the alternative titles
mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of other
public office holders in the area of the CCA.

42.3

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned
in subsection  (1) —

42.3.a

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

42.3.b

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (2) (e) , the resolution must specify why the CCA considers that
the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned in
subsection  (2) , and

42.3.c

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the CCA who vote on it.

42.4

Subsections  (5)  and  (6)  apply where under this section a mayoral CCA
changes the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to
an alternative title.

42.5

The CCA must—

42.5.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

42.5.b

publish the notice in the area of the CCA in such manner as the CCA considers
appropriate, and

42.5.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

42.6

Where this subsection applies—

42.6.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the
area of the CCA is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as a
reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and

42.6.b

references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “ mayoral CCA ”) and
deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

42.7

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

42.8

In this section a reference to a member of a CCA does not include a non-
constituent member.

42.9

In this section “enactment”—

42.9.a

includes an enactment comprised in subordinate legislation within the meaning
of the Interpretation Act 1978, but

42.9.b

does not include this section or section  43 .

###### Alternative mayoral titles: further changes

43

43.1

This section applies where a mayoral CCA has—

43.1.a

by a resolution under section  42  or by a previous resolution under this
section, changed the title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be
known to an alternative title,

43.1.b

by a resolution under section  42 , provided that the mayor for the area of
the CCA is to be known by the title of mayor, or

43.1.c

by a previous resolution under this section, provided that the mayor for the
area of the CCA is no longer to be known by an alternative title.

43.2

The CCA may, by a resolution in accordance with this section—

43.2.a

in a subsection  (1) (a)  case—

43.2.a.i

provide that the mayor is no longer to be known by the alternative title, or

43.2.a.ii

change the title by which the mayor is to be known to an alternative title
mentioned in subsection  (3) ;

43.2.b

in a subsection  (1) (b)  or  (c)  case, change the title by which the mayor
is to be known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection  (3) .

43.3

The alternative titles mentioned in subsection  (2)  are as follows—

43.3.a

county commissioner;

43.3.b

county governor;

43.3.c

elected leader;

43.3.d

governor;

43.3.e

a title that the CCA considers more appropriate than the alternative titles
mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of other
public office holders in the area of the CCA.

43.4

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned
in subsection  (2) —

43.4.a

the resolution must be considered at a relevant meeting of the CCA,

43.4.b

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

43.4.c

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (3) (e) , the resolution must specify why the CCA considers that
the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned in
subsection  (3) , and

43.4.d

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the CCA who vote on it.

43.5

In subsection  (4) (a)  “ relevant meeting ” means the first meeting of the
CCA held after a qualifying election for the return of the mayor, provided
that the election is at least the third qualifying election since the
resolution mentioned in subsection  (1)  was passed.

43.6

Where under this section an authority provides that the mayor for the area of
the CCA is no longer to be known by an alternative title, the CCA must—

43.6.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

43.6.b

publish the notice in the area of the CCA in such manner as the CCA considers
appropriate,

43.6.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

43.7

Subsections  (8)  and  (9)  apply where under this section a CCA changes the
title by which the mayor for the area of the CCA is to be known to an
alternative title.

43.8

The authority must—

43.8.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State, and

43.8.b

publish the notice in the area of the CCA in such manner as the CCA considers
appropriate,

43.8.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

43.9

Where this subsection applies—

43.9.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the
area of the CCA is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as a
reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and

43.9.b

references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “ mayoral CCA ”) and
deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

43.10

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person, or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

43.11

Where a mayoral CCA to which section  42  applies does not pass a resolution
as required by subsection  (1)  of that section, the authority is to be
treated for the purposes of this section as if, at the meeting mentioned in
that subsection, it had passed the resolution mentioned in section  42 (1) (a)
(providing that the mayor is to be known by the title of mayor).

43.12

In this section a reference to a member of a CCA does not include a non-
constituent member.

43.13

In this section—

      “ enactment ” has the same meaning as in section  42 ;           “
qualifying election ” means an election for the return of the mayor, other
than—         the first election for the return of the mayor, and           an
election caused by a vacancy in the office of the mayor occurring before
expiry of the mayor’s term of office.

###### Power to amend list of alternative titles

44

44.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend section  42 (2)  or  43 (3)
to add, modify or remove a reference to an alternative title or a description
of an alternative title.

44.2

In its application to subsection  (1) , section  252 (1) (c)  (power for
regulations to make consequential etc provision) includes power to make
consequential amendments to section  42  or  43 .

##### Requirements in connection with regulations about CCAs

###### Proposal for new CCA

45

45.1

One or more authorities to which this section applies may—

45.1.a

prepare a proposal for the establishment of a CCA for an area, and

45.1.b

submit the proposal to the Secretary of State.

45.2

This section applies to the following authorities—

45.2.a

a county council whose area is within the proposed area;

45.2.b

a unitary district council whose area is within the proposed area;

45.2.c

an economic prosperity board the whole or any part of whose area is within the
proposed area;

45.2.d

an Integrated Transport Authority the whole or any part of whose area is
within the proposed area;

45.2.e

a combined authority the whole or any part of whose area is within the
proposed area.

45.3

In this section “ the proposed area ” means the area for which the CCA is
proposed to be established.

45.4

Before submitting a proposal under this section to the Secretary of State, the
authority or authorities preparing the proposal must—

45.4.a

carry out a public consultation across the proposed area on the proposal, and

45.4.b

have regard to the results of the consultation in preparing the proposal for
submission to the Secretary of State.

45.5

The requirements in subsection  (4)  may be satisfied by things done before
the coming into force of this section.

45.6

If a proposal under this section is not submitted by all of the authorities to
which this section applies, each authority which does not submit the proposal
must consent to its submission to the Secretary of State.

45.7

A proposal under this section must specify the purposes to be achieved by the
establishment of the CCA.

45.8

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

45.8.a

make further provision about the matters which must be addressed by a proposal
under this section;

45.8.b

make provision about material which must be included in or submitted with a
proposal under this section.

###### Requirements in connection with establishment of CCA

46

46.1

The Secretary of State may make regulations establishing a CCA for an area
only if—

46.1.a

the Secretary of State considers that to do so is likely to improve the
economic, social and environmental well-being of some or all of the people who
live or work in the area,

46.1.b

the Secretary of State considers that to do so is appropriate having regard to
the need—

46.1.b.i

to secure effective and convenient local government, and

46.1.b.ii

to reflect the identities and interests of local communities,

46.1.c

where a proposal for the establishment of the CCA has been submitted under
section  45 , the Secretary of State considers that its establishment will
achieve the purposes specified under subsection  (7)  of that section,

46.1.d

the constituent councils consent, and

46.1.e

any consultation required by subsection  (3)  has been carried out.

46.2

If a proposal for the establishment of the CCA has been submitted under
section  45 , the Secretary of State must have regard to the proposal in
making the regulations.

46.3

The Secretary of State must carry out a public consultation unless—

46.3.a

a proposal has been prepared under section  45 ,

46.3.b

a public consultation has been carried out in connection with the proposal and
the Secretary of State has been provided with a summary of the consultation
responses, and

46.3.c

the Secretary of State considers that no further consultation is necessary.

46.4

Subsection  (5)  applies where the Secretary of State is considering whether
to make regulations establishing a CCA for an area and—

46.4.a

part of the area is separated from the rest of it by one or more local
government areas that are not within the area, or

46.4.b

a local government area that is not within the area is surrounded by local
government areas that are within the area.

46.5

In deciding whether to make the regulations, the Secretary of State must have
regard to the likely effect of the creation of the proposed CCA on the
exercise of functions equivalent to those of the proposed CCA’s functions in
each local government area that is next to any part of the proposed CCA area.

46.6

In this Chapter “ local government area ” means the area of a county council
or a district council.

###### Proposal for changes to existing arrangements relating to CCA

47

47.1

One or more authorities to which this section applies may—

47.1.a

prepare a proposal for the making of regulations under section  10 ,  16 ,  18
,  19 ,  21 ,  22 ,  25 ,  26 ,  27 ,  30  or  33  in relation to an existing
CCA, and

47.1.b

submit the proposal to the Secretary of State.

47.2

This section applies to the following authorities—

47.2.a

the CCA;

47.2.b

a county council whose area is within the area of the CCA;

47.2.c

a unitary district council whose area is within the area of the CCA;

47.2.d

in the case of a proposal for the making of regulations under section  25  to
add the area of a county council to the area of the CCA, that county council;

47.2.e

in the case of a proposal for the making of regulations under section  25  to
add the area of a unitary district council to the area of the CCA, that
unitary district council.

47.3

Before submitting a proposal under this section to the Secretary of State, the
authority or authorities preparing the proposal must—

47.3.a

carry out a public consultation across—

47.3.a.i

the area of the CCA, and

47.3.a.ii

in the case of a proposal for the making of regulations under section  25  to
add a relevant local government area to the area of the CCA, that relevant
local government area, and

47.3.b

have regard to the results of the consultation in preparing the proposal for
submission to the Secretary of State.

47.4

The requirements in subsection  (3)  may be satisfied by things done before
the coming into force of this section.

47.5

Before a proposal under this section for the making of regulations is
submitted to the Secretary of State, each person who would have to consent to
the making of the regulations must consent to the submission of the proposal.

47.6

If a proposal under this section is submitted to the Secretary of State by an
authority, the authority is to be treated as having consented to its
submission for the purposes of subsection  (5) .

47.7

In determining for the purposes of subsection  (6)  who would have to consent
to the making of regulations under section  27 , section  28 (2) (b)  (limited
consent requirements) is to be disregarded.

47.8

A proposal under this section must specify the purposes to be achieved by the
regulations which it proposes should be made.

47.9

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

47.9.a

make further provision about the matters which must be addressed by a proposal
under this section;

47.9.b

make provision about material which must be included in or submitted with a
proposal under this section.

###### Requirements for changes to existing arrangements relating to CCA

48

48.1

The Secretary of State may make regulations under section  10 ,  16 ,  18 ,
19 ,  21 ,  22 ,  25 ,  26 ,  27 ,  30  or  33  in relation to an existing CCA
only if—

48.1.a

the Secretary of State considers that to do so is likely to improve the
economic, social and environmental well-being of some or all of the people who
live or work in the area,

48.1.b

the Secretary of State considers that to do so is appropriate having regard to
the need—

48.1.b.i

to secure effective and convenient local government, and

48.1.b.ii

to reflect the identities and interests of local communities,

48.1.c

where a proposal for the making of the regulations has been submitted under
section  47 , the Secretary of State considers that making the regulations
will achieve the purposes specified under subsection  (8)  of that section,
and

48.1.d

any consultation required by subsection  (3)  has been carried out.

48.2

If a proposal for the making of the regulations has been submitted under
section  47 , the Secretary of State must have regard to the proposal in
making the regulations.

48.3

The Secretary of State must carry out a public consultation unless—

48.3.a

a proposal has been prepared under section  47 ,

48.3.b

a public consultation has been carried out in connection with the proposal and
the Secretary of State has been provided with a summary of the consultation
responses, and

48.3.c

the Secretary of State considers that no further consultation is necessary.

48.4

Subsection  (5)  applies where the Secretary of State is considering whether
to make regulations under section  25  and—

48.4.a

part of the area to be created is separated from the rest of it by one or more
local government areas that are not within the area, or

48.4.b

a local government area that is not within the area to be created is
surrounded by local government areas that are within the area.

48.5

In deciding whether to make the regulations under section  25 , the Secretary
of State must have regard to the likely effect of the change to the CCA’s area
on the exercise of functions equivalent to those of the CCA’s functions in
each local government area that is next to any part of the area to be created
by the regulations.

48.6

This section does not apply to regulations under section  25 (1) (b)  that are
made as a result of the duty in section  28 (3) .

##### General powers of CCAs

###### General power of CCA

49

49.1

A CCA may do—

49.1.a

anything it considers appropriate for the purposes of the carrying-out of any
of its functions (its “functional purposes”),

49.1.b

anything it considers appropriate for purposes incidental to its functional
purposes,

49.1.c

anything it considers appropriate for purposes indirectly incidental to its
functional purposes through any number of removes,

49.1.d

anything it considers to be connected with—

49.1.d.i

any of its functions, or

49.1.d.ii

anything it may do under paragraph  (a) ,  (b)  or  (c) , and

49.1.e

for a commercial purpose anything which it may do under any of paragraphs  (a)
to  (d)  otherwise than for a commercial purpose.

49.2

Where subsection  (1)  confers power on a CCA to do something, it confers
power (subject to section  50 ) to do it anywhere in the United Kingdom or
elsewhere.

49.3

Power conferred on a CCA by subsection  (1)  is in addition to, and is not
limited by, its other powers.

49.4

This section does not apply in relation to a CCA in respect of which
regulations under section  52 (1)  have effect.

###### Boundaries of power under section 

50

50.1

Section  49 (1)  does not enable a CCA to do anything which it is unable to do
by virtue of a relevant limitation which is expressed to apply—

50.1.a

to its power under section  49 (1) ,

50.1.b

to all of its powers, or

50.1.c

to all of its powers but with exceptions that do not include its power under
section  49 (1) .

50.2

If exercise of a relevant power of a CCA is subject to restrictions, those
restrictions apply also to exercise of the power conferred on it by section
49 (1)  so far as that power is overlapped by the relevant power.

50.3

Section  49 (1)  does not authorise a CCA to borrow money.

50.4

Section  49 (1) (a)  to  (d)  does not authorise a CCA to charge a person for
anything done by it otherwise than for a commercial purpose (but see section
93 of the Local Government Act 2003 (power of CCAs and other best value
authorities to charge for discretionary services)).

50.5

Section  49 (1) (e)  does not authorise a CCA to do things for a commercial
purpose in relation to a person if a statutory provision requires it to do
those things in relation to the person.

50.6

Where under section  49 (1) (e)  a CCA does things for a commercial purpose,
it must do them through—

50.6.a

a company within the meaning given by section 1(1) of the Companies Act 2006,

50.6.b

a registered society within the meaning of the Co-operative and Community
Benefit Societies Act 2014, or

50.6.c

a society registered or deemed to be registered under the Industrial and
Provident Societies Act (Northern Ireland) 1969.

50.7

In this section—

      “ relevant limitation ” means a prohibition, restriction or other
limitation imposed by a statutory provision;           “ relevant power ”
means a power conferred by a statutory provision;           “ statutory
provision ” means a provision of an Act or of an instrument made under an Act.

###### Power to make provision supplemental to section 

51

51.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision preventing CCAs from
doing under section  49 (1)  anything which is specified, or is of a
description specified, in the regulations.

51.2

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for the exercise by CCAs of
power conferred by section  49 (1)  to be subject to conditions, whether
generally or in relation to doing anything specified, or of a description
specified, in the regulations.

51.3

The power under subsection  (1)  or  (2)  may be exercised in relation to—

51.3.a

all CCAs,

51.3.b

particular CCAs, or

51.3.c

particular descriptions of CCAs.

51.4

Before making regulations under subsection  (1)  or  (2)  the Secretary of
State must consult—

51.4.a

such representatives of CCAs,

51.4.b

such representatives of local government, and

51.4.c

such other persons (if any),

as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

51.5

Subsection (4) does not apply to regulations under subsection  (1)  or  (2)
which are made only for the purpose of amending earlier such regulations—

51.5.a

so as to extend the earlier regulations, or any provision of the earlier
regulations, to a particular CCA or to CCAs of a particular description, or

51.5.b

so that the earlier regulations, or any provision of the earlier regulations,
ceases to apply to a particular CCA or to CCAs of a particular description.

###### General power of competence

52

52.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for Chapter 1 of Part 1 of
the Localism Act 2011 (which confers a general power of competence on local
authorities) to have effect in relation to a CCA specified in the regulations
as it has effect in relation to a local authority.

52.2

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may be made only with the consent of the
appropriate authorities (as defined by section  28 (4) ).

52.3

Where regulations under subsection  (1)  are contained in the same instrument
as regulations made by virtue of section  28 (2) (b) , a non-consenting
constituent council is not to be treated as an appropriate authority for the
purposes of subsection  (2) .

##### Supplementary

###### Incidental etc provision

53

53.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make incidental, consequential,
transitional, transitory or supplementary provision for the purposes of, or in
consequence of, regulations under this Chapter or for giving full effect to
such regulations.

53.2

Regulations under subsection (1) may not include provision amending or
disapplying sections 15 to 17 of, and Schedule 1 to, the Local Government and
Housing Act 1989 (political balance on local authority committees etc).

###### Transfer of property, rights and liabilities

54

54.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for the transfer of
property, rights and liabilities (including criminal liabilities) for the
purposes of, or in consequence of, regulations under this Chapter or for
giving full effect to such regulations.

54.2

Property, rights and liabilities may be transferred by—

54.2.a

the regulations,

54.2.b

scheme made by the Secretary of State under the regulations, or

54.2.c

a scheme required to be made under the regulations by a person other than the
Secretary of State.

54.3

A transfer by virtue of this section may have effect—

54.3.a

whether or not the property, rights and liabilities would otherwise be capable
of being transferred;

54.3.b

without any instrument or formality being required.

54.4

The rights and liabilities which may be transferred by virtue of this section
include rights and liabilities in relation to a contract of employment.

54.5

The Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (
S.I. 2006/246 ) apply to the transfer by virtue of this section (whether or
not the transfer is a relevant transfer for the purposes of those
regulations).

54.6

Regulations under this section or a scheme made under them may define the
property, rights and liabilities to be transferred by specifying or describing
them.

54.7

Provision for the transfer of property, rights and liabilities made by virtue
of this section may include provision—

54.7.a

for the creation or imposition by the Secretary of State of new rights or
liabilities in respect of anything transferred;

54.7.b

for the shared ownership or use of any property or facilities;

54.7.c

for the management or custody of transferred property;

54.7.d

for bodies to make agreements with respect to any property, income, rights,
liabilities and expenses of, and any financial relations between, the parties
to the agreement.

54.8

Provision for the transfer of property, rights and liabilities made by virtue
of this section may include provision—

54.8.a

for the continuing effect of things done by the transferor in relation to
anything transferred;

54.8.b

for the continuation of things (including legal proceedings) in the process of
being done, by or on behalf of or in relation to the transferor in relation to
anything transferred;

54.8.c

for references to the transferor in any agreement (whether written or not),
instrument or other document in relation to anything transferred to be treated
(so far as necessary for the purposes of or in consequence of the transfer) as
references to the transferee.

###### Guidance

55

55.1

The Secretary of State may give guidance about anything that could be done
under or by virtue of this Chapter by an authority to whom this section
applies.

55.2

An authority to whom this section applies must have regard to any guidance
given under this section in exercising any function conferred or imposed by or
by virtue of this Chapter.

55.3

Any guidance under this section must be given in writing and may be varied or
revoked by further guidance in writing.

55.4

Any such guidance may make different provision for different cases and
different provision for different areas.

55.5

This section applies to—

55.5.a

a county council;

55.5.b

a district council;

55.5.c

an Integrated Transport Authority;

55.5.d

a combined authority;

55.5.e

a CCA.

###### Consequential amendments

56

Schedule 4  (combined county authorities: consequential amendments) has
effect.

###### Interpretation of Chapter

57

In this Chapter—

      “ associate member ” has the meaning given by section  12 (1) ;
“ CCA ” has the meaning given by section  9 (1) ;           “ combined
authority ” has the meaning given by section  9 (5) ;           “ constituent
council ” has the meaning given by section  10 (11) ;           “ deputy mayor
” has the meaning given by section  29 (7) ;           “ economic prosperity
board ” has the meaning given by section  9 (5) ;           “ fire and rescue
authority ” means a fire and rescue authority under the Fire and Rescue
Services Act 2004;           “ general functions ” has the meaning given by
section  30 (2) ;           “ Integrated Transport Authority ” has the meaning
given by section  9 (5) ;           “ local government area ” has the meaning
given by section  46 (6) ;           “ mayor ”, in relation to the area of a
CCA, means the mayor for the area of the CCA by virtue of regulations under
section  27 (1) ;           “ mayoral CCA ” has the meaning given by section
27 (8) ;           “ nominating body ” means a body designated under section
11 (1) ;           “ non-constituent member ” has the meaning given by section
11 (3) ;           “ PCC functions ” has the meaning given by section  33 (3)
;           “ two-tier county council ” has the meaning given by section  9
(5) ;           “ unitary county council ” has the meaning given by section  9
(5) ;           “ unitary district council ” has the meaning given by section
9 (5) .

#### Other provision

##### Combined authorities

###### Review of combined authority’s constitutional arrangements

58

After section 104C of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and
Construction Act 2009 (inserted by section  64 (8) ) insert—

########## Review of combined authority’s constitutional arrangements

58.104D

58.104D.1

This section applies if an order under section 104(1) (constitution of
combined authority) enables a combined authority to make provision about its
constitution (“constitutional provision”).

58.104D.2

An appropriate person may carry out a review of the combined authority’s
constitutional provision if—

58.104D.2.a

an appropriate person proposes a review, and

58.104D.2.b

the combined authority consents to the review.

58.104D.3

If an appropriate person carries out a review under subsection  (2) , they may
propose changes to the combined authority’s constitutional provision as a
result of the review for agreement by the authority.

58.104D.4

The question of whether to consent under subsection  (2) (b)  or to agree to
changes proposed under subsection  (3)  is to be decided at a meeting of the
combined authority by a simple majority of the voting members of the authority
who are present at the meeting.

58.104D.5

In the case of a mayoral combined authority—

58.104D.5.a

a majority in favour of consenting under subsection  (2) (b)  does not need to
include the mayor, but

58.104D.5.b

a majority in favour of changes proposed under subsection  (3)  must include
the mayor.

58.104D.6

The reference in subsection  (4)  to a voting member—

58.104D.6.a

includes a substitute member who may act in place of a voting member;

58.104D.6.b

does not include a non-constituent member.

58.104D.7

Subsection  (4)  applies instead of—

58.104D.7.a

any provision of an order under section 104(1) made before the coming into
force of this section which is about the procedure applying to a decision on a
question of a kind mentioned in subsection  (4) , and

58.104D.7.b

any constitutional provision of a combined authority about such procedure.

58.104D.8

In this section “ appropriate person ”, in relation to a combined authority,
means—

58.104D.8.a

a member of the authority appointed by a county council the whole or any part
of whose area is within the area of the authority,

58.104D.8.b

a member of the authority appointed by a district council whose area is within
the area of the authority, or

58.104D.8.c

the mayor for the area of the authority (if it is a mayoral combined
authority).

###### Changes to mayoral combined authority’s area: additional requirements

60

60.1

An order under section 106 of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and
Construction Act 2009 which adds a local government area to an existing area
of a mayoral combined authority may only be made during the relevant period if
the consultation requirements in subsection (2) are met.

60.2

The consultation requirements are as follows—

60.2.a

the Secretary of State has consulted the Local Government Boundary Commission
for England,

60.2.b

the mayor for the area of the combined authority has consulted the residents
of the local government area which is to be added to that area, and

60.2.c

the mayor has given the Secretary of State a report providing information
about the consultation carried out under paragraph (b), and the Secretary of
State has laid the report before Parliament.

60.3

In this section, “ the relevant period ” means the period of 9 months
beginning with the day on which this Act is passed.

###### Consent to conferral of general functions on mayor

61

61.1

The Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction Act 2009 is amended
as follows.

61.2

In section 104 (constitution of combined authority), after subsection (11A)
(inserted by section  59 (2) ) insert—

61.2.11B

61.2.11B.b

############ Procedure for direct conferral of general functions on mayor

###### Functions in respect of key route network roads

63

63.1

The Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction Act 2009 is amended
as follows.

63.2

In section 104, in subsection (10), for “An” substitute  “Except as provided
for by  section 107ZA (7) , an” .

63.3

In section 107D, in subsection (9), for “An” substitute  “Except as provided
for by  section 107ZA (7) , an” .

63.4

After section 107 insert—

############ Combined authorities: key route network roads

############# Designation of key route network roads

63.4.107ZA

63.4.107ZA.1

A combined authority may designate a highway or proposed highway in its area
as a key route network road, or remove its designation as a key route network
road, with the consent of—

63.4.107ZA.1.a

each constituent council in whose area the highway or proposed highway is, and

63.4.107ZA.1.b

in the case of a mayoral combined authority, the mayor.

63.4.107ZA.2

The Secretary of State may designate a highway or proposed highway in the area
of a combined authority as a key route network road, or remove its designation
as a key route network road, if requested to do so by—

63.4.107ZA.2.a

the combined authority,

63.4.107ZA.2.b

the mayor (if any) of the combined authority, or

63.4.107ZA.2.c

a constituent council.

63.4.107ZA.3

A designation or removal under this section must be in writing and must state
when it comes into effect.

63.4.107ZA.4

The Secretary of State must send a copy of a designation or removal under
subsection (2)  to the combined authority in question at least 7 days before
the date on which it comes into effect.

63.4.107ZA.5

A combined authority must publish each designation or removal under this
section of a key route network road within its area before the date on which
it comes into effect.

63.4.107ZA.6

A combined authority that has key route network roads in its area must keep a
list or map (or both) accessible to the public showing those roads.

63.4.107ZA.7

The requirements in section 104(10) and section 107D(9)(a) do not apply to
provision under section 104(1)(d) and section 107D(1) contained in the same
instrument so far as that provision—

63.4.107ZA.7.a

confers a power of direction on an existing mayoral combined authority
regarding the exercise of an eligible power in respect of key route network
roads in the area of that combined authority,

63.4.107ZA.7.b

provides for that power of direction to be exercisable only by the mayor of
the combined authority, and

63.4.107ZA.7.c

is made with the consent of the mayor after the mayor has consulted the
constituent councils.

63.4.107ZA.8

When a mayor consents under  subsection (7) (c) , the mayor must give the
Secretary of State—

63.4.107ZA.8.a

a statement by the mayor that all of the constituent councils agree to the
making of the order, or

63.4.107ZA.8.b

if the mayor is unable to make that statement, the reasons why the mayor
considers the order should be made even though not all of the constituent
councils agree to it being made.

63.4.107ZA.9

In this section—

      “ constituent council ” has the meaning given in section 104(11);
“ eligible power ” has the meaning given by section 88(2) of the Local
Transport Act 2008;           “ key route network road ” means a highway or
proposed highway designated for the time being under this section as a key
route network road;           “ proposed highway ” means land on which, in
accordance with plans made by a highway authority, that authority are for the
time being constructing or intending to construct a highway shown in the
plans.

After section 104 insert—

############ Non-constituent members of a combined authority

64.8.104A

64.8.104A.1

A combined authority may designate a body other than a constituent council as
a nominating body for the purposes of this Part.

64.8.104A.2

A body may be designated under subsection  (1)  only if the body consents to
the designation.

64.8.104A.3

A nominating body of a combined authority may nominate a representative of the
body for appointment by the authority as a member (a “non-constituent
member”).

64.8.104A.4

The non-constituent members of a combined authority are to be non-voting
members of that authority unless the voting members resolve otherwise.

64.8.104A.5

A resolution under subsection  (4)  does not permit non-constituent members to
vote on a decision whether the combined authority should consent to the making
of an order under this Part.

64.8.104A.6

This section is subject to regulations under section  104C (4)
(disapplication of this section).

64.8.104A.7

In this section “ constituent council ”, in relation to a combined authority,
means—

64.8.104A.7.a

a county council the whole or any part of whose area is within the area of the
authority, or

64.8.104A.7.b

a district council whose area is within the area of the authority.

############ Associate members of a combined authority

64.8.104B

64.8.104B.1

A combined authority may appoint an individual to be a member (“an associate
member”) of the combined authority.

64.8.104B.2

The associate members of a combined authority are to be non-voting members of
the authority.

64.8.104B.3

This section is subject to regulations under section  104C (4)
(disapplication of this section).

############ Regulations about members

64.8.104C

64.8.104C.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about—

64.8.104C.1.a

constituent members of a combined authority;

64.8.104C.1.b

the mayor for the area of a combined authority in the mayor’s capacity as a
member of the authority;

64.8.104C.1.c

nominating bodies of a combined authority;

64.8.104C.1.d

non-constituent members of a combined authority;

64.8.104C.1.e

associate members of a combined authority.

64.8.104C.2

The provision that may be made by regulations under subsection  (1)  includes,
in particular, provision about—

64.8.104C.2.a

the cases in which a decision of a combined authority requires a majority, or
a particular kind of majority, of the votes of members of a particular kind;

64.8.104C.2.b

designation;

64.8.104C.2.c

the number of nominating bodies that may be designated by a combined
authority;

64.8.104C.2.d

the number of non-constituent members that may be appointed by a combined
authority;

64.8.104C.2.e

the appointment, disqualification, resignation or removal of a non-constituent
member;

64.8.104C.2.f

the appointment of a substitute member to act in place of a non-constituent
member;

64.8.104C.2.g

the maximum number of non-constituent members of a combined authority;

64.8.104C.2.h

64.8.104C.2.i

the things which may or may not be done by, or in relation to, a non-
constituent member;

64.8.104C.2.j

the appointment, disqualification, resignation or removal of an associate
member;

64.8.104C.2.k

the appointment of a substitute member to act in place of an associate member;

64.8.104C.2.l

the maximum number of associate members of a combined authority;

64.8.104C.2.m

the things which may or may not be done by, or in relation to, an associate
member.

64.8.104C.3

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may confer a discretion on a combined
authority to determine any matter.

64.8.104C.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide, in relation to a combined
authority established by an order which came into force before the coming into
force of this section—

64.8.104C.4.a

for the relevant provisions about membership not to apply in relation to the
authority, or

64.8.104C.4.b

Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023, and

64.8.104C.5.b

sections 104A and 104B.

64.8.104C.6

Regulations under subsection  (1)  or  (4)  may make incidental,
supplementary, consequential, transitional, transitory or saving provision.

64.8.104C.7

In this section “ constituent member ”, in relation to a combined authority,
means a member of the authority (other than any mayor for the area of the
authority) appointed by—

64.8.104C.7.a

a county council the whole or any part of whose area is within the area of the
authority, or

64.8.104C.7.b

a district council whose area is within the area of the authority.

############ Proposal for new combined authority

65.3.109A

65.3.109A.1

One or more authorities to which this section applies may—

65.3.109A.1.a

65.3.109A.2.a

65.3.109A.2.b

make further provision about the matters which must be addressed by a proposal
under this section;

65.3.109A.8.b

proposal under this section.

65.3.109A.9

consequential, transitional, transitory or saving provision.

############ Proposal for changes to existing combined arrangements

66.3.112A

66.3.112A.1

One or more authorities to which this section applies may—

consent requirements) is to be disregarded.

order which it proposes should be made.

66.3.112A.10

66.3.112A.10.a

make further provision about the matters which must be addressed by a proposal

66.3.112A.10.b

66.3.112A.11

###### Regulations applying to combined authorities

68.1

Section 117 of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction Act
2009 (orders under Part 6) is amended as follows.

68.2

In the heading, after “Orders” insert  “and regulations” .

68.3

In subsection (1), after “Orders” insert  “and regulations” .

68.4

In subsection (1A), after “An order” insert  “or regulations” .

68.5

After subsection (3) insert—

68.5.3A

A statutory instrument that contains (whether alone or with any other
provisions) regulations under section 104C(1), 104C(4), or  107K (1)  may not
be made unless a draft of the instrument containing the regulations has been
laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

68.5.3B

A statutory instrument that—

68.5.3B.a

contains regulations under section  109A (8)  or  112A (10) , and

68.5.3B.b

is not by virtue of subsection (3A) subject to a requirement that a draft of
the instrument be laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of
Parliament,

is subject to annulment by resolution of either House of Parliament.

68.6

In subsection (4), after “Part” insert  “or of regulations under section  104C
(1)  or  (4) ” .

###### Combined authorities and combined county authorities: power to borrow

69

In section 23 of the Local Government Act 2003 (meaning of “ local authority ”
for the purposes of Part 1), after subsection (10) insert—

69.10A

If a draft of a statutory instrument containing regulations under subsection
(5) or  (8A)  would, apart from this subsection, be treated for the purposes
of the standing orders of either House of Parliament as a hybrid instrument,
it is to proceed in that House as if it were not such an instrument.

, and

70.1.b.c

order under paragraph 4 who are members of a constituent council (within the
meaning of paragraph 3 of Schedule 5A).

##### Local authority governance

###### Timing for changes in governance arrangements

71

71.1

The Local Government Act 2000 is amended as follows.

71.2

In section 9KC (resolution of local authority)—

71.2.a

in subsection (4)—

71.2.a.i

the words from “Resolution B is approved” to the end of the subsection become
paragraph (a), and

71.2.a.ii

at the end of that paragraph insert

, or

71.2.a.ii.b

subsection  (4A)  applies and Resolution B is passed in accordance with
subsection  (4E) .

, and

71.2.b

after subsection (4) insert—

71.2.b.4A

This subsection applies where Resolution B—

71.2.b.4A.a

makes a change in governance arrangements—

71.2.b.4A.a.i

under section 9K for the local authority to start to operate executive
arrangements, or

71.2.b.4A.a.ii

under section 9KA for the local authority to vary its executive arrangements
so that they provide for a mayor and cabinet executive, and

71.2.b.4A.b

has not been approved in a referendum held in accordance with this Chapter.

71.2.b.4B

Where subsection  (4A)  applies, the local authority may submit a proposal to
the Secretary of State for consent to pass Resolution B before the end of the
period of 5 years beginning with the date Resolution A is passed.

71.2.b.4C

A proposal must specify—

71.2.b.4C.a

the change in governance arrangements to be made by Resolution B, and

71.2.b.4C.b

how the change is likely to improve the economic, social and environmental
well-being of some or all of the people who live or work in the area of the
local authority.

71.2.b.4D

The Secretary of State may consent to a proposal only if the Secretary of
State considers that the change in governance arrangements is likely to
improve the economic, social and environmental well-being of some or all of
the people who live or work in the area of the local authority.

71.2.b.4E

If the Secretary of State consents to a proposal, the local authority may pass
Resolution B—

71.2.b.4E.a

before the end of the 5 year period beginning with the date Resolution A is
passed, but

71.2.b.4E.b

not later than the end of the 3 year period beginning with the date consent is
given.

71.2.b.4F

The Secretary of State may by regulations make further provision about—

71.2.b.4F.a

the matters which must be addressed by a proposal under this section, and

71.2.b.4F.b

how a proposal is to be considered by the Secretary of State.

71.3

In section 9MF (further provision with respect to referendums)—

71.3.a

in subsection (1)—

71.3.a.i

the words from “subsection (2)” to the end of the subsection become paragraph
(a), and

71.3.a.ii

at the end of that paragraph insert

, or

71.3.a.ii.b

subsection  (3A)  applies and Referendum B is held in accordance with
subsection  (3E) .

, and

71.3.b

after subsection (3) insert—

71.3.b.3A

This subsection applies if Referendum B is held under section 9M to approve a
change in governance arrangements—

71.3.b.3A.a

under section 9K for the local authority to start to operate executive
arrangements, or

71.3.b.3A.b

under section 9KA for the local authority to vary its executive arrangements
so that they provide for a mayor and cabinet executive.

71.3.b.3B

Where subsection  (3A)  applies, the local authority may submit a proposal to
the Secretary of State for consent to hold Referendum B within the period of
10 years beginning with the date of Referendum A.

71.3.b.3C

A proposal must specify—

71.3.b.3C.a

the change in governance arrangements that is subject to approval in
Referendum B, and

71.3.b.3C.b

how the change is likely to improve the economic, social and environmental
well-being of some or all of the people who live or work in the area of the
local authority.

71.3.b.3D

The Secretary of State may consent to a proposal only if the Secretary of
State considers that the change in governance arrangements is likely to
improve the economic, social and environmental well-being of some or all of
the people who live or work in the area of the local authority.

71.3.b.3E

If the Secretary of State consents to a proposal, the local authority may hold
Referendum B—

71.3.b.3E.a

within the 10 year period beginning with the date of Referendum A, but

71.3.b.3E.b

not later than the end of the 3 year period beginning with the date consent is
given.

71.3.b.3F

The Secretary of State may by regulations make further provision about—

71.3.b.3F.a

the matters which must be addressed by a proposal under this section, and

71.3.b.3F.b

how a proposal is to be considered by the Secretary of State.

###### Transfer of functions: changes in governance arrangements

72

72.1

The Local Government Act 2000 is amended in accordance with subsections  (2)
to  (5) .

72.2

In section 9KC (resolution of local authority), after subsection (5) insert—

72.2.6

See sections  9NC  and  9ND  (transfer of functions: changes in governance
arrangements) for further provision about when a resolution under this section
may be passed.

72.3

In section 9MB (requirement to hold and give effect to referendum)—

72.3.a

in subsection (4)—

72.3.a.i

the words from “within the period” to the end of the subsection become
paragraph (a), and

72.3.a.ii

at the end of that paragraph insert

, or

72.3.a.ii.b

where  paragraph (b)  of section  9ND (7)  (transfer of functions: changes in
governance arrangements) applies, within the period of 28 days beginning with
the day when the regulations mentioned in that subsection are amended or
revoked.

, and

72.3.b

after subsection (5) insert—

72.3.b.6

See section  9ND  for further provision about referendums under section 9M.

72.4

In section 9MF (further provision with respect to referendums), after
subsection (6) insert—

72.4.7

See section  9ND  (transfer of functions: changes in governance arrangements)
for further provision about referendums under section 9MC.

72.5

After section 9NB insert—

############ Transfer of functions: changes in governance arrangements

############# Transfer of functions: changes in governance arrangements not subject to a referendum

72.5.9NC

72.5.9NC.1

This section applies where—

72.5.9NC.1.a

the Secretary of State has made regulations under section 16 of the Cities and
Local Government Devolution Act 2016 (power to transfer etc public authority
functions to certain local authorities) that provide for a function to be
exercisable by a local authority,

72.5.9NC.1.b

the local authority proposes to pass a resolution under section 9KC to make a
relevant change in governance arrangements, and

72.5.9NC.1.c

that change is not—

72.5.9NC.1.c.i

subject to approval in a referendum under section 9M, or

72.5.9NC.1.c.ii

required to be implemented by the local authority in accordance with section
9MF(4) (referendums under sections 9MC to 9ME).

72.5.9NC.2

The local authority may not pass the resolution unless the local authority
complies with this section.

72.5.9NC.3

The local authority must notify the Secretary of State of the proposed change
in governance arrangements.

72.5.9NC.4

Where the Secretary of State receives such a notification, the Secretary of
State must consider whether, as a result of the proposed change in governance
arrangements, the regulations mentioned in subsection  (1) (a)  should be
amended or revoked (see section 17(1) of the Cities and Local Government
Devolution Act 2016).

72.5.9NC.5

The Secretary of State must notify the local authority of the decision under
subsection  (4) .

72.5.9NC.6

If the Secretary of State considers that the regulations should be amended or
revoked, the local authority may not pass the resolution until the regulations
have been so amended or revoked.

72.5.9NC.7

If the Secretary of State considers that the regulations should not be amended
or revoked, the local authority may pass the resolution.

72.5.9NC.8

In this section—

      “ function ” has the same meaning as in section 16 of the Cities and
Local Government Devolution Act 2016;           “ relevant change in
governance arrangements ” means—         a change under section 9K for the
local authority to cease to operate executive arrangements, or           a
change under section 9KA for the local authority to vary its executive
arrangements so that they provide for a leader and cabinet executive.

72.5.9NC.9

This section is subject to section 9KC(3) and (4) (timing of change in
governance arrangements).

############# Transfer of functions: changes in governance arrangements subject to a referendum

72.5.9ND

72.5.9ND.1

This section applies where—

72.5.9ND.1.a

the Secretary of State has made regulations under section 16 of the Cities and
Local Government Devolution Act 2016 (power to transfer etc public authority
functions to certain local authorities) that provide for a function to be
exercisable by a local authority,

72.5.9ND.1.b

the local authority proposes to pass a resolution under section 9KC to make a
relevant change in governance arrangements, and

72.5.9ND.1.c

that change is subject to approval in a referendum under section 9M.

72.5.9ND.2

This section also applies where—

72.5.9ND.2.a

the Secretary of State has made regulations under section 16 of the Cities and
Local Government Devolution Act 2016 that provide for a function to be
exercisable by a local authority, and

72.5.9ND.2.b

the local authority is required by regulations under section 9MC (referendum
following petition) to hold a referendum on whether the authority should make
a relevant change in governance arrangements.

72.5.9ND.3

The local authority may not—

72.5.9ND.3.a

hold the referendum mentioned in subsection  (1) (c)  or  (2) (b) , or

72.5.9ND.3.b

pass a resolution which makes the proposed change in governance arrangements,

unless the local authority complies with this section.

72.5.9ND.4

The local authority must notify the Secretary of State of the proposed change
in governance arrangements.

72.5.9ND.5

Where the Secretary of State receives such a notification, the Secretary of
State must consider whether, as a result of the proposed change in governance
arrangements, the regulations mentioned in subsection  (1) (a)  or  (2) (a)
should be amended or revoked (see section 17(1) of the Cities and Local
Government Devolution Act 2016).

72.5.9ND.6

The Secretary of State must notify the local authority of the decision under
subsection  (5) .

72.5.9ND.7

If the Secretary of State considers that the regulations should be amended or
revoked—

72.5.9ND.7.a

the local authority may hold the referendum mentioned in subsection  (1) (c)
or  (2) (b) , but

72.5.9ND.7.b

if the result of the referendum is to approve the proposals, the local
authority may not pass a resolution which makes the proposed change in
governance arrangements until the regulations have been so amended or revoked.

72.5.9ND.8

If the Secretary of State considers that the regulations should not be amended
or revoked, the local authority may hold the referendum mentioned in
subsection  (1) (c)  or  (2) (b)  and (if the result of the referendum is to
approve the proposals) pass the resolution.

72.5.9ND.9

In this section “ function ” and “ relevant change in governance arrangements
” have the same meaning as in section  9NC .

72.5.9ND.10

This section is subject to sections 9KC(3) and (4), 9MB and 9MF (timing of
change in governance arrangements etc).

72.6

In section 17 of the Cities and Local Government Devolution Act 2016 (section
16: procedure etc)—

72.6.a

in subsection (1)—

72.6.a.i

omit the “and” at the end of paragraph (a), and

72.6.a.ii

after paragraph (b) insert

, and

72.6.a.ii.c

where subsection  (4A)  applies to the regulations, the Secretary of State has
had regard to the matters in subsection  (4B) .

, and

72.6.b

after subsection (4) insert—

72.6.b.4A

This subsection applies to regulations under section 16 that—

72.6.b.4A.a

revoke or otherwise amend previous regulations under that section, and

72.6.b.4A.b

are made in response to a notification from a local authority under section
9NC (3)  or  9ND (4)  of the Local Government Act 2000 (transfer of functions:
changes in governance arrangements) of a proposed change in governance
arrangements.

72.6.b.4B

The matters mentioned in subsection (1) (c)  are—

72.6.b.4B.a

the circumstances of the area of the local authority, and

72.6.b.4B.b

the likely impact of the change in governance arrangements on—

72.6.b.4B.b.i

the economic, social and environmental well-being of some or all of the people
who live or work in the area of the local authority, and

72.6.b.4B.b.ii

the accountability and decision-making of the local authority.

The requirement in subsection (1)(b) does not apply to the making of

##### Alternative mayoral titles

###### Combined authorities: alternative mayoral titles

76

After section 107G of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and
Construction Act 2009 insert—

########## Alternative mayoral titles: new mayoral combined authorities

76.107H

76.107H.1

This section applies to a mayoral combined authority where the order made
under section 107A (power to provide for election of mayor) in relation to the
authority comes into force on or after the date on which this section comes
into force.

76.107H.2

At the first meeting of the authority after the order made under section 107A
comes into force, the authority must, by a resolution in accordance with
subsection  (4) —

76.107H.2.a

provide that the mayor for the area of the authority is to be known by the
title of mayor, or

76.107H.2.b

change the title by which the mayor for the area of the authority is to be
known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection  (3) .

76.107H.3

The alternative titles are—

76.107H.3.a

county commissioner;

76.107H.3.b

county governor;

76.107H.3.c

elected leader;

76.107H.3.d

governor;

76.107H.3.e

a title that the authority considers more appropriate than the alternative
titles mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of
other public office holders in the area of the authority.

76.107H.4

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned
in subsection  (2) —

76.107H.4.a

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

76.107H.4.b

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (3) (e) , the resolution must specify why the authority considers
that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned
in subsection  (3) , and

76.107H.4.c

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the authority who vote on it.

76.107H.5

Subsections  (6)  and  (7)  apply where under this section a mayoral combined
authority changes the title by which the mayor for the area of the authority
is to be known to an alternative title.

76.107H.6

The authority must—

76.107H.6.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

76.107H.6.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

76.107H.6.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

76.107H.7

Where this subsection applies—

76.107H.7.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the
area of the authority is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as
a reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and

76.107H.7.b

references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “ mayoral combined
authority ”) and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

76.107H.8

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

76.107H.9

In this section a reference to a member of a combined authority does not
include a non-constituent member.

76.107H.10

In this section “enactment”—

76.107H.10.a

includes an enactment comprised in subordinate legislation within the meaning
of the Interpretation Act 1978, but

76.107H.10.b

does not include this section or sections  107I  and  107J .

########## Alternative mayoral titles: existing mayoral combined authorities

76.107I

76.107I.1

This section applies to a mayoral combined authority where the order made
under section 107A (power to provide for election of mayor) in relation to the
authority comes into force before the date on which this section comes into
force.

76.107I.2

The authority may, by a resolution in accordance with subsection  (3) , change
the title by which the mayor for the area of the authority is to be known to
one of the following alternative titles—

76.107I.2.a

county commissioner;

76.107I.2.b

county governor;

76.107I.2.c

elected leader;

76.107I.2.d

governor;

76.107I.2.e

a title that the authority considers more appropriate than the alternative
titles mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of
other public office holders in the area of the authority.

76.107I.3

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution—

76.107I.3.a

the resolution must be considered at the first meeting of the authority held
after a qualifying election for the return of the mayor,

76.107I.3.b

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

76.107I.3.c

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (2) (e) , the resolution must specify why the authority considers
that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned
in subsection  (2) , and

76.107I.3.d

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the authority who vote on it.

76.107I.4

Subsections  (5)  and  (6)  apply where under this section a mayoral combined
authority changes the title by which the mayor for the area of the authority
is to be known to an alternative title.

76.107I.5

The authority must—

76.107I.5.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

76.107I.5.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

76.107I.5.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

76.107I.6

Where this subsection applies—

76.107I.6.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the
area of the authority is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as
a reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and

76.107I.6.b

references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “ mayoral combined
authority ”) and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

76.107I.7

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

76.107I.8

In this section a reference to a member of a combined authority does not
include a non-constituent member.

76.107I.9

In this section—

      “ enactment ” has the same meaning as in section  107H ;           “
qualifying election ” means an election for the return of the mayor, other
than—         the first election for the return of the mayor, and           an
election caused by a vacancy in the office of the mayor occurring before
expiry of the mayor’s term of office.

76.107I.10

This section is subject to section  107J .

########## Alternative mayoral titles: further changes

76.107J

76.107J.1

This section applies where a mayoral combined authority has—

76.107J.1.a

by a resolution under section  107H  or  107I  or by a previous resolution
under this section, changed the title by which the mayor for the area of the
authority is to be known to an alternative title,

76.107J.1.b

by a resolution under section  107H , provided that the mayor for the area of
the authority is to be known by the title of mayor, or

76.107J.1.c

by a previous resolution under this section, provided that the mayor for the
area of the authority is no longer to be known by an alternative title.

76.107J.2

The authority may, by a resolution in accordance with subsection  (4) —

76.107J.2.a

in a subsection  (1) (a)  case—

76.107J.2.a.i

provide that the mayor is no longer to be known by the alternative title, or

76.107J.2.a.ii

change the title by which the mayor is to be known to an alternative title
mentioned in subsection  (3) ;

76.107J.2.b

in a subsection  (1) (b)  or  (c)  case, change the title by which the mayor
is to be known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection  (3) .

76.107J.3

The alternative titles are—

76.107J.3.a

county commissioner;

76.107J.3.b

county governor;

76.107J.3.c

elected leader;

76.107J.3.d

governor;

76.107J.3.e

a title that the authority considers more appropriate than the alternative
titles mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of
other public office holders in the area of the authority.

76.107J.4

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned
in subsection  (2) —

76.107J.4.a

the resolution must be considered at a relevant meeting of the authority,

76.107J.4.b

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

76.107J.4.c

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (3) (e) , the resolution must specify why the authority considers
that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned
in subsection  (3) , and

76.107J.4.d

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the authority who vote on it.

76.107J.5

In subsection  (4) (a)  “ relevant meeting ” means the first meeting of the
authority held after a qualifying election for the return of the mayor,
provided that the election is at least the third qualifying election since the
resolution mentioned in subsection  (1)  was passed.

76.107J.6

Where under this section an authority provides that the mayor for the area of
the authority is no longer to be known by an alternative title, the authority
must—

76.107J.6.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

76.107J.6.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

76.107J.6.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

76.107J.7

Subsections  (8)  and  (9)  apply where under this section an authority
changes the title by which the mayor for the area of the authority is to be
known to an alternative title.

76.107J.8

The authority must—

76.107J.8.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

76.107J.8.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

76.107J.8.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

76.107J.9

Where this subsection applies—

76.107J.9.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the mayor for the
area of the authority is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as
a reference to the alternative title by which the mayor is to be known, and

76.107J.9.b

references to mayor, mayoral (except in the expression “ mayoral combined
authority ”) and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

76.107J.10

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person, or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

76.107J.11

Where a combined authority to which section  107H  applies does not pass a
resolution as required by subsection  (2)  of that section, the authority is
to be treated for the purposes of this section as if, at the meeting mentioned
in that subsection, it had passed the resolution mentioned in section  107H
(2) (a)  (providing that the mayor is to be known by the title of mayor).

76.107J.12

In this section a reference to a member of a combined authority does not
include a non-constituent member.

76.107J.13

In this section—

      “ enactment ” has the same meaning as in section  107H ;           “
qualifying election ” has the same meaning as in section  107I .

########## Power to amend list of alternative titles

76.107K

76.107K.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend section  107H (3) ,  107I (2)
or  107J (3)  to add, modify or remove a reference to an alternative title or
a description of an alternative title.

76.107K.2

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may make incidental, supplementary,
consequential, transitional, transitory or saving provision, including
provision which makes consequential amendments to section  107H ,  107I  or
107J .

###### Local authorities in England: alternative mayoral titles

77

77.1

The Local Government Act 2000 is amended as follows.

77.2

After section 9HE insert—

############ Alternative mayoral titles

77.2.9HF

77.2.9HF.1

A local authority within subsection  (8)  may, by a resolution in accordance
with subsection  (2) , change the title by which the elected mayor of the
authority is to be known to one of the following alternative titles—

77.2.9HF.1.a

county commissioner;

77.2.9HF.1.b

county governor;

77.2.9HF.1.c

elected leader;

77.2.9HF.1.d

governor;

77.2.9HF.1.e

a title that the authority considers more appropriate than the alternative
titles mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of
other public office holders in the area of the authority.

77.2.9HF.2

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution—

77.2.9HF.2.a

the resolution must be considered at a relevant meeting of the authority,

77.2.9HF.2.b

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

77.2.9HF.2.c

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (1) (e) , the resolution must specify why the authority considers
that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned
in subsection  (1) , and

77.2.9HF.2.d

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the authority who vote on it.

77.2.9HF.3

In subsection  (2) (a)  “ relevant meeting ” means—

77.2.9HF.3.a

in the case of a local authority within subsection  (8) (a) , the first
meeting of the authority held after a qualifying election for the return of
the elected mayor,

77.2.9HF.3.b

in the case of a local authority within subsection  (8) (b) , the meeting of
the authority at which the resolution under section 9KC (resolution of local
authority) is passed, and

77.2.9HF.3.c

in the case of a local authority within subsection  (8) (c) , the first
meeting of the authority held after the referendum mentioned in section 9N is
held.

77.2.9HF.4

Subsections  (5)  and  (6)  apply where under this section a local authority
changes the title by which the elected mayor of the authority is to be known
to an alternative title.

77.2.9HF.5

The authority must—

77.2.9HF.5.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

77.2.9HF.5.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

77.2.9HF.5.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

77.2.9HF.6

Where this subsection applies—

77.2.9HF.6.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the elected mayor of
the authority is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as a
reference to the alternative title by which the elected mayor is to be known,
and

77.2.9HF.6.b

references to mayor, mayoral and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

77.2.9HF.7

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

77.2.9HF.8

A local authority is within this subsection if—

77.2.9HF.8.a

it operates a mayor and cabinet executive,

77.2.9HF.8.b

it passes a resolution in accordance with section 9KC (resolution of local
authority) to make a change in governance arrangements which provides for the
authority to operate a mayor and cabinet executive, or

77.2.9HF.8.c

it holds a referendum by virtue of an order under section 9N (referendum on
change to mayor and cabinet executive) and the proposal for the authority to
operate a mayor and cabinet executive is approved in that referendum.

77.2.9HF.9

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend subsection  (1)  to add,
modify or remove a reference to an alternative title or a description of an
alternative title.

77.2.9HF.10

In this section—

      “ enactment ”—         includes an enactment comprised in subordinate
legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978, but
does not include this section or section  9HG ;                 “ qualifying
election ” means an election for the return of the elected mayor, other than—
the first election for the return of the elected mayor, and           an
election caused by a vacancy in the office of the elected mayor occurring
before expiry of the elected mayor’s term of office.

77.2.9HF.11

This section is subject to section  9HG .

############ Alternative mayoral titles: further changes

77.2.9HG

77.2.9HG.1

This section applies where a local authority has—

77.2.9HG.1.a

by a resolution under section  9HF  or by a previous resolution under this
section, changed the title by which the elected mayor of the authority is to
be known to an alternative title, or

77.2.9HG.1.b

by a previous resolution under this section, provided that the elected mayor
of the authority is no longer to be known by an alternative title.

77.2.9HG.2

The authority may, by a resolution in accordance with subsection  (4) —

77.2.9HG.2.a

in a subsection  (1) (a)  case—

77.2.9HG.2.a.i

provide that the elected mayor is no longer to be known by the alternative
title, or

77.2.9HG.2.a.ii

change the title by which the elected mayor is to be known to an alternative
title mentioned in subsection  (3) ;

77.2.9HG.2.b

in a subsection  (1) (b)  case, change the title by which the elected mayor is
to be known to an alternative title mentioned in subsection  (3) .

77.2.9HG.3

The alternative titles are—

77.2.9HG.3.a

county commissioner;

77.2.9HG.3.b

county governor;

77.2.9HG.3.c

elected leader;

77.2.9HG.3.d

governor;

77.2.9HG.3.e

a title that the authority considers more appropriate than the alternative
titles mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  to  (d) , having regard to the title of
other public office holders in the area of the authority.

77.2.9HG.4

The following requirements must be met in relation to the resolution mentioned
in subsection  (2) —

77.2.9HG.4.a

the resolution must be considered at a relevant meeting of the authority,

77.2.9HG.4.b

particulars of the resolution must be included in the notice of the meeting,

77.2.9HG.4.c

where the resolution includes a proposed alternative title mentioned in
subsection  (3) (e) , the resolution must specify why the authority considers
that the title is more appropriate than the other alternative titles mentioned
in subsection  (3) , and

77.2.9HG.4.d

the resolution must be passed at the meeting by a simple majority of the
members of the authority who vote on it.

77.2.9HG.5

In subsection  (4) (a)  “ relevant meeting ” means the first meeting of the
authority held after a qualifying election for the return of the elected
mayor, provided that the election is at least the third qualifying election
since the resolution mentioned in subsection  (1)  was passed.

77.2.9HG.6

Where under this section a local authority provides that the elected mayor of
the authority is no longer to be known by an alternative title, the authority
must—

77.2.9HG.6.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

77.2.9HG.6.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

77.2.9HG.6.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

77.2.9HG.7

Subsections  (8)  and  (9)  apply where under this section a local authority
changes the title by which the elected mayor of the authority is to be known
to an alternative title.

77.2.9HG.8

The authority must—

77.2.9HG.8.a

send notice of the change to the Secretary of State,

77.2.9HG.8.b

publish the notice in the area of the authority in such manner as the
authority considers appropriate, and

77.2.9HG.8.c

publish the notice in such other manner as the Secretary of State may direct.

77.2.9HG.9

Where this subsection applies—

77.2.9HG.9.a

a reference in any enactment (whenever passed or made) to the elected mayor of
the authority is, unless the context otherwise requires, to be read as a
reference to the alternative title by which the elected mayor is to be known,
and

77.2.9HG.9.b

references to mayor, mayoral and deputy mayor are to be construed accordingly.

77.2.9HG.10

A change of title under this section does not affect the rights or obligations
of any person, or render defective any legal proceedings; and any legal
proceedings may be commenced or continued as if there had been no change of
title.

77.2.9HG.11

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend subsection  (3)  to add,
modify or remove a reference to an alternative title or a description of an
alternative title.

77.2.9HG.12

In this section “ enactment ” and “ qualifying election ” have the same
meaning as in section  9HF .
