##### Local government capital finance

###### Capital finance risk management

78

78.1

The Local Government Act 2003 is amended as follows.

78.2

After section 12 (power to invest) insert—

############ Risk management: England

############# Risk-mitigation directions

78.2.12A

78.2.12A.1

The Secretary of State may give one or more risk-mitigation directions to a
local authority in England, for the purpose of reducing or mitigating the
financial risk to the authority, if—

78.2.12A.1.a

a trigger event has occurred in relation to the local authority, and

78.2.12A.1.b

the Secretary of State is satisfied that the direction is, or (as the case may
be) directions are, appropriate and proportionate to the level of that
financial risk.

78.2.12A.2

A “trigger event” occurs if (and when)—

78.2.12A.2.a

a risk threshold is breached by the local authority (see  section 12B );

78.2.12A.2.b

a report is made by the chief finance officer of the local authority under
section 114(3) of the Local Government Finance Act 1988 (report to effect that
authority’s expenditure is likely to exceed available resources); or

78.2.12A.2.c

the Secretary of State—

78.2.12A.2.c.i

gives a direction under section 16(2)(b) (request for expenditure to be, or
not be, treated as capital) in respect of the local authority, or

78.2.12A.2.c.ii

makes a grant to the local authority under an enactment,

for the purpose of preventing circumstances arising that would require such a
report to be made.

78.2.12A.3

The following are “risk-mitigation directions”—

78.2.12A.3.a

a direction that sets limits in relation to the borrowing of money by the
local authority;

78.2.12A.3.b

a direction that requires the local authority to take action specified in the
direction.

78.2.12A.4

A direction under  subsection (3) (a) —

78.2.12A.4.a

may set different limits in relation to different kinds of borrowing;

78.2.12A.4.b

must specify the period for which any limit has effect.

78.2.12A.5

A direction under  subsection (3) (b) —

78.2.12A.5.a

may (amongst other things) require the local authority to take action to
divest itself of a specified asset;

78.2.12A.5.b

must specify the time by which any specified action must be taken.

78.2.12A.6

In deciding whether or not to exercise a power to give a direction under this
section, the Secretary of State must have regard to—

78.2.12A.6.a

the likely impact of the direction on the provision of services to the public
by or on behalf of the local authority;

78.2.12A.6.b

the duty imposed on the local authority by section 3(1) of the Local
Government Act 1999 (best value duty).

78.2.12A.7

In deciding whether or not to exercise a power to give a direction under this
section, the Secretary of State may, in particular, take account of the likely
impact of that decision on the implementation of any central government
policy, project or programme.

78.2.12A.8

The Secretary of State may not give a risk-mitigation direction unless the
Secretary of State—

78.2.12A.8.a

has given the local authority notice of the proposed direction, and of the
right of the local authority to make written representations to the Secretary
of State about it within the period specified in the notice, and

78.2.12A.8.b

has considered any representations made by the local authority to the
Secretary of State within that period.

78.2.12A.9

In this section, “ financial risk ”, in relation to a local authority, means
the risk that the expenditure of the local authority (including expenditure it
proposes to incur) in the current or any future financial year is likely to
exceed, or further exceed, the resources (including sums borrowed) available
to it to meet that expenditure.

78.2.12A.10

This section is subject to  section 12C  (restriction of power to give risk-
mitigation directions).

############# Risk thresholds

78.2.12B

78.2.12B.1

For the purposes of  section 12A (2) (a) , a risk threshold is breached by a
local authority in England if (and when) a capital risk metric for the local
authority breaches the specified threshold for that metric.

78.2.12B.2

Each of the following is a “capital risk metric”—

78.2.12B.2.a

the total of a local authority’s debt (including credit arrangements) as
compared to the financial resources at the disposal of the authority;

78.2.12B.2.b

the proportion of the total of a local authority’s capital assets which is
investments made, or held, wholly or mainly in order to generate financial
return;

78.2.12B.2.c

the proportion of the total of a local authority’s debt (including credit
arrangements) in relation to which the counter-party is not central government
or a local authority;

78.2.12B.2.d

the amount of minimum revenue provision charged by a local authority to a
revenue account for a financial year;

78.2.12B.2.e

any other metric specified by regulations made by the Secretary of State.

78.2.12B.3

The Secretary of State may, by regulations, make further provision—

78.2.12B.3.a

specifying whether the specified threshold for a particular metric is breached
by a failure to reach that threshold or by that threshold being exceeded;

78.2.12B.3.b

about how the metrics specified in, or under,  subsection (2)  are to be
calculated for the purpose of determining whether the specified threshold for
that metric has been breached.

78.2.12B.4

Before making regulations under  subsection (2) (e) , the Secretary of State
must consult all local authorities in England.

78.2.12B.5

In this section—

      “ capital asset ” has the meaning given by section 9;           “
minimum revenue provision ” has the meaning given by regulation 27 of the
Local Authorities (Capital Finance and Accounting)(England) Regulations 2003 (
S.I. 2003/3146 );           “ specified ” means specified, or determined in a
manner specified, in regulations made by the Secretary of State.

78.2.12B.6

Regulations may require a specified threshold to be determined having regard
to guidance issued under section 21(1A) (accounting practices).

############# Restriction of power to give risk-mitigation directions

78.2.12C

78.2.12C.1

If, after the power to give risk-mitigation directions becomes exercisable
under  section 12A (1)  in relation to a local authority—

78.2.12C.1.a

at least 12 months have elapsed since the Secretary of State last became aware
of a trigger event having occurred in relation to the authority,

78.2.12C.1.b

any risk-mitigation direction given to the authority has been complied with or
revoked, and

78.2.12C.1.c

the Secretary of State is satisfied no further risk-mitigation direction is
likely to be required in the foreseeable future for the purpose of reducing or
mitigating the financial risk to the authority,

the Secretary of State must give the local authority a notice to that effect
(“a cessation notice”).

78.2.12C.2

Where a cessation notice is given, the power conferred by  section 12A (1)  is
no longer exercisable, in relation to that authority, by reason of any trigger
event of which the Secretary of State was aware at the time that notice was
given.

78.2.12C.3

In this section “ risk-mitigation direction ”, “ trigger event ” and “
financial risk ” have the same meaning as in  section 12A .

############# Duty to cooperate with independent expert

78.2.12D

78.2.12D.1

This section applies where—

78.2.12D.1.a

a trigger event has occurred in relation to a local authority in England,

78.2.12D.1.b

section 12C (2)  does not apply to prevent the power conferred by  section 12A
(1)  being exercisable, in relation to that authority, by reason of that
event, and

78.2.12D.1.c

the Secretary of State has appointed an independent expert to review the level
of the financial risk to the local authority.

78.2.12D.2

The local authority must, so far as reasonably practicable, co-operate with
the independent expert in any way that the independent expert considers
necessary or expedient for the purposes of the conduct of the review.

78.2.12D.3

In this section—

      “ financial risk ” has the same meaning as in  section 12A ;           “
independent expert ” means a person—         who is independent of the local
authority and the Secretary of State, and           who has relevant
experience or knowledge which is relevant to the matter in question;
“ trigger event ” has the same meaning as in  section 12A .

78.3

In section 2 (control of borrowing), in subsection (1)—

78.3.a

after paragraph (b) insert  “, or” , and

78.3.b

after that paragraph insert—

78.3.b.c

any limit for the time being applicable to it under section 12A.

78.4

In section 5 (temporary borrowing)—

78.4.a

in subsection (1), after “section 4” insert  “or 12A” , and

78.4.b

in subsection (2), after “section 4(2)” insert  “or 12A” .

78.5

In section 8 (control of credit arrangements), in subsection (1)—

78.5.a

after paragraph (b) insert  “, or” , and

78.5.b

after that paragraph insert—

78.5.b.c

any limit for the time being applicable to it under section 12A.

78.6

In section 12 (power to invest), at the end insert—

This is subject to a direction under section 12A (risk-mitigation directions).

78.7

In section 19 (application to parish and community councils), in subsection
(1) for “9 to 13” substitute  “9 to 12, 13” .

78.8

In section 23 (meaning of “ local authority ” in Chapter 3 of Part 1), in
subsection (4), after “1 to 8,” insert  “ 12A  to  12D ,” .

###### Dwellings occupied periodically: England

80

80.1

The Local Government Finance Act 1992 is amended in accordance with
subsections (2)  and  (3) .

80.2

After section 11B (higher amount for long-term empty dwellings: England)
insert—

############ Higher amount for dwellings occupied periodically: England

80.2.11C

80.2.11C.1

For any financial year, a billing authority in England may by determination
provide in relation to its area, or such part of its area as it may specify in
the determination, that if on any day the conditions mentioned in  subsection
(2)  are satisfied in respect of a dwelling—

80.2.11C.1.a

the discount under section 11(2)(a) does not apply, and

80.2.11C.1.b

the amount of council tax payable in respect of that dwelling and that day is
increased by such percentage of not more than 100 as it may specify in the
determination.

80.2.11C.2

The conditions are—

80.2.11C.2.a

there is no resident of the dwelling, and

80.2.11C.2.b

the dwelling is substantially furnished.

80.2.11C.3

A billing authority’s first determination under this section must be made at
least one year before the beginning of the financial year to which it relates.

80.2.11C.4

In exercising its functions under this section a billing authority must have
regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State.

80.2.11C.5

Where a determination under this section has effect in relation to a class of
dwellings—

80.2.11C.5.a

the billing authority may not make a determination under section 11A(3), (4)
or (4A) in relation to that class, and

80.2.11C.5.b

any determination that has been made under section 11A(3), (4) or (4A) ceases
to have effect in relation to that class.

80.2.11C.6

A billing authority may make a determination varying or revoking a
determination under this section for a financial year, but only before the
beginning of the year.

80.2.11C.7

Where a billing authority makes a determination under this section it must
publish a notice of the determination in at least one newspaper circulating in
the area.

80.2.11C.8

The notice must be published before the end of the period of 21 days beginning
with the date of the determination.

80.2.11C.9

The validity of the determination is not affected by a failure to comply with
subsection (7)  or  (8) .

############ Section 11C: regulations

80.2.11D

80.2.11D.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations prescribe one or more classes of
dwelling in relation to which a billing authority may not make a determination
under  section 11C .

80.2.11D.2

A class of dwellings may be prescribed under  subsection (1)  by reference to
such factors as the Secretary of State thinks fit and may, amongst other
factors, be prescribed by reference to—

80.2.11D.2.a

the physical characteristics of, or other matters relating to, dwellings;

80.2.11D.2.b

the circumstances of, or other matters relating to, any person who is liable
to the amount of council tax concerned.

80.2.11D.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations specify a different percentage limit
for the limit which is for the time being specified in  section 11C (1) (b) .

80.2.11D.4

A statutory instrument containing regulations made under  subsection (3)  may
not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been approved by resolution
of the House of Commons.

80.3

In consequence of the amendment made by subsection (2)—

80.3.a

in section 11 (discounts), in subsection (2), after “11B” insert  “, 11C” ;

80.3.b

in section 11A (discounts: special provision for England), in subsection (4C),
at the end insert  “and 11C(5)” ;

80.3.c

in section 13 (reduced amounts), in subsection (3), after “11B” insert  “,
11C” ;

80.3.d

in section 66 (judicial review), in subsection (2)(b), after “11B” insert  “,
11C” ;

80.3.e

in section 67 (functions to be discharged only by authority), in subsection
(2)(a), after “11B insert  “, 11C” ;

80.3.f

in section 113 (orders and regulations), in subsection (3), after “under
section” insert  “11D(3),” ;

80.3.g

in Schedule 2 (administration), in paragraph 4(7), after “: England),” insert
“11C(1)(b) (higher amount for dwellings occupied periodically: England),” .

80.4

A determination for the purposes of section 11C of the Local Government
Finance Act 1992 as inserted by  subsection (2)  may not relate to a financial
year beginning before 1 April 2024 (but this does not affect the requirement
for the determination to be made at least one year before the beginning of the
financial year to which it relates).

##### Street names

###### Alteration of street names: England

81

81.1

In this section “ local authority ” means—

81.1.a

a district council in England;

81.1.b

a county council in England for an area for which there is no district
council;

81.1.c

a London borough council;

81.1.d

the Common Council of the City of London.

81.2

A local authority within  subsection (1) (a)  or  (b)  may, by order, alter
the name of a street, or any part of a street, in its area if the alteration
has the necessary support.

81.3

Where a local authority has altered the name of a street, or any part of a
street, under  subsection (2) , it may cause the altered name to be painted or
otherwise marked on a conspicuous part of any building or other erection.

81.4

Any person who then wilfully, and without the consent of the local authority,
obliterates, defaces, obscures, removes or alters the altered name painted or
otherwise marked under  subsection (3)  is liable to a penalty not exceeding
level 1 on the standard scale.

81.5

A local authority within  subsection (1) (c)  or  (d)  may exercise the power
conferred by section 6(1) of the London Building Acts (Amendment) Act 1939
(assigning of names to streets etc) to make an order altering the name of a
street, or any part of a street, in its area only if the alteration has the
necessary support.

81.6

An alteration has the necessary support for the purposes of this section only
if—

81.6.a

it has sufficient local support, and

81.6.b

where it is an alteration of a specified kind, it has any other support
specified as a pre-condition for alterations of that kind.

81.7

Regulations may provide that sufficient local support, or support of a kind
specified under  subsection (6) (b) , can only be established in the way, or
in one of the alternative ways, specified in the regulations.

81.8

Regulations under  subsection (7)  may (amongst other things)—

81.8.a

make provision enabling a referendum to be held by a local authority, on a
question determined by it in accordance with the regulations, for the purposes
of establishing whether an alteration has sufficient local support, including
provision about the conduct and timing of a referendum and who is entitled to
vote;

81.8.b

provide that, where a local authority holds a referendum in accordance with
regulations made by virtue of  paragraph (a) , the alteration may not be made
unless one or both of the following apply—

81.8.b.i

a specified percentage or number of those entitled to vote in the referendum
exercise that right;

81.8.b.ii

a specified majority of those who vote indicate their support for the
alteration;

81.8.c

provide that, where a local authority has run a process (“the first process”)
for the purposes of this section which failed to establish that an alteration
of the name of a street (or a part of a street) had sufficient local support,
the local authority may not run another such process within a specified period
in respect of—

81.8.c.i

if the first process related to the name of a whole street, an alteration of
the name of the same street or any part of it;

81.8.c.ii

if the first process related to the name of a part of a street (“the original
part”), an alteration of the name of the whole street, of the original part or
of any other part which includes some or all of the original part.

81.9

A local authority must have regard to any guidance published by the Secretary
of State about—

81.9.a

the things to be done before a local authority decides to take steps to
establish if an alteration has the necessary support for the purposes of this
section;

81.9.b

the exercise of other functions conferred on a local authority by or under
this section.

81.10

No local Act operates to enable a local authority within  subsection (1) (a)
or  (b)  to alter the name of a street, or part of a street, in its area.

81.11

In this section—

      “ regulations ” means regulations made by the Secretary of State;
“ specified ” means specified in regulations;           “ street ” has the
meaning given by section 48(1) of the New Roads and Street Works Act 1991.

81.12

Schedule 5  contains amendments which are consequential on this section.

### Planning

#### Planning data

##### Power in relation to the processing of planning data

84

84.1

Regulations made by an appropriate authority under this Chapter (“ planning
data regulations ”) may make provision requiring a relevant planning
authority, in processing such of its planning data as is specified or
described in the regulations, to comply with any approved data standards which
are applicable.

84.2

“ Planning data ”, in relation to a relevant planning authority, means any
information which is provided to, or processed by, the authority—

84.2.a

for the purposes of a function under a relevant planning enactment, or

84.2.b

for any other purpose relating to planning or development in England.

84.3

“ Approved data standards ”, in relation to planning data, are such written
standards, containing technical specifications or other requirements in
relation to the data, or in relation to providing or processing the data, as
may be published by an appropriate authority from time to time.

84.4

A devolved authority may only publish approved data standards in relation to
planning data about which the devolved authority acting alone could make
planning data regulations.

##### Power in relation to the provision of planning data

85

85.1

A relevant planning authority may by publishing a notice require a person, or
persons of a particular description, in providing to the authority such
planning data as is specified or described in planning data regulations, to
provide the data—

85.1.a

in any form and manner, or

85.1.b

in a particular form and manner,

which complies with any approved data standards which are applicable.

85.2

A relevant planning authority may not impose a requirement under  subsection
(1) —

85.2.a

on the Crown,

85.2.b

on a court or tribunal, or

85.2.c

in relation to the provision of planning data for the purposes of, or in
contemplation of, legal proceedings before a court or tribunal.

85.3

If a relevant planning authority imposes a requirement under  subsection (1)
on a person, provision in a relevant planning enactment does not apply to the
extent that it requires or permits the person to provide the planning data to
the authority in a form or manner which is inconsistent with the requirement
imposed under  subsection (1) .

85.4

Subsections  (5)  to  (7)  apply if—

85.4.a

in providing planning data to a relevant planning authority, a person fails to
comply with a requirement imposed under  subsection (1) , and

85.4.b

the authority does not consider that the person has a reasonable excuse for
the failure.

85.5

The authority may serve a notice on the person rejecting for such purposes as
may be specified in the notice—

85.5.a

all or any part of the planning data, and

85.5.b

if the authority considers it appropriate to do so, any other information
provided with the planning data or any document in or with which the planning
data is provided.

85.6

Any planning data, other information or document rejected under subsection
(5)  is to be treated as not having been provided to the authority for the
purposes specified in the notice.

85.7

If the planning data, other information or document is subsequently provided
to the authority in a form and manner which complies with the requirement
under subsection  (1) , the authority may treat the planning data, other
information or document as having been provided at the time that it would have
been provided had it not been rejected under subsection  (5) .

85.8

Planning data regulations may include provision about how the powers in this
section are to be exercised, including provision about—

85.8.a

the provision or publication of notices or other documents;

85.8.b

the form and content of notices or other documents (and, for these purposes,
the regulations may confer a discretion on a relevant planning authority);

85.8.c

time limits;

85.8.d

any other procedural matters.

##### Power to require certain planning data to be made publicly available

86

86.1

Planning data regulations may make provision requiring a relevant planning
authority to make such of its planning data as is specified or described in
the regulations available to the public under an approved open licence.

86.2

The power under  subsection (1)  does not include power to require a relevant
planning authority to make planning data available in breach of—

86.2.a

any obligation of confidence owed by the authority, or

86.2.b

any other restriction on making the planning data available (however imposed).

86.3

An “ approved open licence ”, in relation to a planning authority’s planning
data, means a licence—

86.3.a

which sets out terms and conditions under which the planning data may be used
by the public free of charge, and

86.3.b

which is in such form and has such content as is, for the time being,
specified or described in a document published by the Secretary of State.

##### Power to require use of approved planning data software in England

87

87.1

Planning data regulations made by the Secretary of State may make provision
restricting or preventing a relevant planning authority in England from using
or creating, or having any right in relation to, planning data software which—

87.1.a

is specified or described in the regulations for the purposes of this
subsection, but

87.1.b

is not approved in writing by the Secretary of State.

87.2

“ Planning data software ” means software which is capable of being used for
the purposes of enabling or facilitating the provision of planning data to, or
the processing of planning data by, relevant planning authorities.

##### Disclosure of planning data does not infringe copyright in certain cases

88

88.1

A relevant planning authority that makes planning data available to a person
does not, in doing so, infringe copyright if making the data available is
necessary for the purposes of enabling or facilitating—

88.1.a

the development of planning data software which is to be submitted for
approval under  section 87 (1) , or

88.1.b

the upgrade, modification or maintenance of, or the provision of technical
support in respect of, planning data software which is approved under  section
87 (1) .

88.2

The person to whom the planning data is made available does not infringe any
copyright by using it for the purpose mentioned in subsection (1) for which it
is made available.

##### Requirements to consult devolved administrations

89

89.1

The Secretary of State may only make planning data regulations which contain
provision—

89.1.a

within Scottish devolved legislative competence, or

89.1.b

which could be made by the Scottish Ministers,

with the consent of the Scottish Ministers, unless that provision is merely
incidental to, or consequential on, provision that would be outside that
devolved legislative competence.

89.2

The Secretary of State may only make planning data regulations which contain
provision that confers a function on, or modifies or removes a function of,
the Scottish Ministers after consulting the Scottish Ministers, unless—

89.2.a

that provision is contained in regulations which require the consent of the
Scottish Ministers by virtue of subsection (1), or

89.2.b

that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that
would be outside Scottish devolved legislative competence.

89.3

Provision is “within Scottish devolved legislative competence” where, if the
provision were included in an Act of the Scottish Parliament, it would be
within the legislative competence of that Parliament.

89.4

The Secretary of State may only make planning data regulations which contain
provision within Welsh devolved legislative competence with the consent of the
Welsh Ministers, unless that provision is merely incidental to, or
consequential on, provision that would be outside that devolved legislative
competence.

89.5

The Secretary of State may only make planning data regulations which contain
provision that could be made by the Welsh Ministers or that confers a function
on, or modifies or removes a function of, the Welsh Ministers or a devolved
Welsh authority after consulting the Welsh Ministers, unless—

89.5.a

that provision is contained in regulations which require the consent of the
Welsh Ministers by virtue of subsection  (4) , or

89.5.b

that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that
would be outside Welsh devolved legislative competence.

89.6

“ Devolved Welsh authority ” has the same meaning as in the Government of
Wales Act 2006 (see section 157A of that Act).

89.7

Provision is “within Welsh devolved legislative competence” where, if the
provision were included in an Act of Senedd Cymru, it would be within the
legislative competence of the Senedd (including any provision that could be
made only with the consent of a Minister of the Crown).

89.8

The Secretary of State may only make planning data regulations which contain
provision within Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence with the
consent of the relevant Northern Ireland department, unless that provision is
merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that would be outside
that devolved legislative competence.

89.9

The Secretary of State may only make planning data regulations which contain
provision that could be made by a Northern Ireland department or that confers
a function on, or modifies or removes a function of, a Northern Ireland
department after consulting the relevant Northern Ireland department, unless—

89.9.a

that provision is contained in regulations which require the consent of the
relevant Northern Ireland department by virtue of subsection  (8) , or

89.9.b

that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that
would be outside Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence.

89.10

The “relevant Northern Ireland department” is such Northern Ireland department
as the Secretary of State considers appropriate having regard to the provision
which is to be contained in the regulations concerned.

89.11

Provision is within “Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence” where
the provision—

89.11.a

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly,
if contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

89.11.b

would not, if contained in a Bill for an Act of the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State.

89.12

In this section “ Minister of the Crown ” has the same meaning as in the
Ministers of the Crown Act 1975.

##### Planning data regulations made by devolved authorities

90

Schedule 13  contains restrictions on the exercise of the powers under this
Chapter by devolved authorities.

##### Interpretation of Chapter

91

In this Chapter—

      “ appropriate authority ” means—         the Secretary of State,
a devolved authority, or           the Secretary of State acting jointly with
one or more devolved authorities;                 “ approved data standards ”
has the meaning given in  section 84 (3) ;           “ devolved authority ”
means—         the Scottish Ministers,           the Welsh Ministers, or
a Northern Ireland department;                 “ planning data ” has the
meaning given in  section 84 (2) ;           “ planning data regulations ” has
the meaning give in  section 84 (1) ;           “ planning data software ” has
the meaning given in  section 87 (2) ;           “ process ”, in relation to
information, means to perform an operation or set of operations on
information, or on sets of information, such as—         collection,
recording, organisation, structuring or storage,           adaptation or
alteration,           retrieval, consultation or use,           disclosure by
transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available,           alignment
or combination, or           restriction, erasure or destruction;
“ provided ” includes submitted, issued, served, notified and published (and
related expressions are to be construed accordingly);           “ public
authority ” means any person certain of whose functions are of a public
nature;           “ relevant planning authority ” means—         a local
planning authority (within the meaning given in  section 15LH  of PCPA 2004),
a minerals and waste planning authority (within the meaning given in  section
15LH  of PCPA 2004),           a hazardous substances authority (within the
meaning given in the Hazardous Substances Act) in relation to land in England,
a combined authority established under section 103 of the Local Democracy,
Economic Development and Construction Act 2009,           a combined county
authority established under section  9  of this Act,           the Greater
London Authority,           the Mayor of London,           a Mayoral
development corporation in relation to which a decision of the Mayor under any
of subsections (2) to (5) of section 202 of the Localism Act 2011 has effect,
an urban development corporation established, for an area in England, under
section 135 of the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980,           a
development corporation established, in relation to a site in England, under
section 3 of the New Towns Act 1981,           the Secretary of State when
exercising a function under a relevant planning enactment,           a Panel
or person who, pursuant to a decision of the Secretary of State under section
61(2) of the Planning Act 2008, is to handle an application for an order
granting development consent,           a public authority that has functions
under  Part 6  of this Act, or           any other public authority prescribed
by planning data regulations that has functions relating to—         planning
or development in England, or           nationally significant infrastructure
projects (within the meaning given in the Planning Act 2008);
“ relevant planning enactment ” means any enactment comprised in or made
under—         the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980, so far as
relating to planning or development in England,           the New Towns Act
1981, so far as relating to planning or development in England,           TCPA
1990,           the Listed Buildings Act,           the Hazardous Substances
Act,           the Planning (Consequential Provisions) Act 1990,
Part 8 of GLAA 1999,           PCPA 2004,           the Planning Act 2008,
the Localism Act 2011, so far as relating to planning or development in
England,           this Part or Part  4  or  6  of this Act, or           any
other enactment prescribed by planning data regulations to the extent that it
confers functions on a public authority relating to—         planning or
development in England, or           nationally significant infrastructure
projects (within the meaning given in the Planning Act 2008).

###### Role of development plan and national policy in England

93

93.1

Section 38 of PCPA 2004 (development plan) is amended as follows.

93.2.5A

For the purposes of any area in England, subsections  (5B)  and  (5C)  apply
if, for the purposes of any determination to be made under the planning Acts,
regard is to be had to—

93.2.5A.a

the development plan, and

93.2.5A.b

any national development management policies.

93.2.5B

Subject to subsections (5) and  (5C) , the determination must be made in
accordance with the development plan and any national development management
policies, taken together, unless material considerations strongly indicate
otherwise.

93.2.5C

If to any extent the development plan conflicts with a national development
management policy, the conflict must be resolved in favour of the national
development management policy.

section 38ZA .

93.5

that, in making a determination, regard is to be had to the development plan
and any national development management policies.

###### National development management policies: meaning

94

After section 38 of PCPA 2004 insert—

########## Meaning of “national development management policy”

94.38ZA

94.38ZA.1

A “national development management policy” is a policy (however expressed) of
the Secretary of State in relation to the development or use of land in
England, or any part of England, which the Secretary of State by direction
designates as a national development management policy.

94.38ZA.2

The Secretary of State may—

94.38ZA.2.a

revoke a direction under  subsection (1) ;

94.38ZA.2.b

modify a national development management policy.

94.38ZA.3

The Secretary of State must have regard to the need to mitigate, and adapt to,
climate change—

94.38ZA.3.a

in preparing a policy which is to be designated as a national development
management policy, or

94.38ZA.3.b

in modifying a national development management policy.

94.38ZA.4

Before making or revoking a direction under  subsection (1) , or modifying a
national development management policy, the Secretary of State must ensure
that such consultation with, and participation by, the public or any bodies or
persons as the Secretary of State thinks appropriate takes place.

94.38ZA.5

The only cases in which no consultation or participation need take place under
subsection (4)  are those where the Secretary of State thinks that none is
appropriate because—

94.38ZA.5.a

a proposed modification of a national development management policy does not
materially affect the policy or only corrects an obvious error or omission, or

94.38ZA.5.b

it is necessary, or expedient, for the Secretary of State to act urgently.

##### Spatial development strategy for London

###### Contents of the spatial development strategy

95

95.1

Section 334 of GLAA 1999 (the spatial development strategy) is amended as
follows.

95.2

For subsections (2) to (6) substitute—

95.2.2A

The spatial development strategy must include a statement of the Mayor’s
policies (however expressed), in relation to the development and use of land
in Greater London, which are—

95.2.2A.a

of strategic importance to Greater London, and

95.2.2A.b

designed to achieve objectives that relate to the particular characteristics
or circumstances of Greater London.

95.2.2B

The spatial development strategy may specify or describe infrastructure the
provision of which the Mayor considers to be of strategic importance to
Greater London for the purposes of—

95.2.2B.a

supporting or facilitating development in Greater London,

95.2.2B.b

mitigating, or adapting to, climate change, or

95.2.2B.c

promoting or improving the economic, social or environmental well-being of
Greater London.

95.2.2C

The spatial development strategy may specify or describe affordable housing
the provision of which the Mayor considers to be of strategic importance to
Greater London.

95.2.2D

For the purposes of subsections  (2A)  to  (2C)  a matter—

95.2.2D.a

may be of strategic importance to Greater London if it does not affect the
whole area of Greater London, but

95.2.2D.b

is not to be regarded as being of strategic importance to Greater London,
unless it is of strategic importance to more than one London borough.

95.2.2E

The Secretary of State may, by regulations under section 343 below, prescribe
further matters the spatial development strategy may, or must, deal with.

95.3

After subsection (8) insert—

95.3.9

The spatial development strategy must be designed to secure that the use and
development of land in Greater London contribute to the mitigation of, and
adaptation to, climate change.

95.3.10

The spatial development strategy must take account of any local nature
recovery strategy, under section 104 of the Environment Act 2021, that relates
to an area in Greater London, including in particular—

95.3.10.a

the areas identified in the strategy as areas which—

95.3.10.a.i

are, or could become, of particular importance for biodiversity, or

95.3.10.a.ii

are areas where the recovery or enhancement of biodiversity could make a
particular contribution to other environmental benefits,

95.3.10.b

the priorities set out in the strategy for recovering or enhancing
biodiversity, and

95.3.10.c

the proposals set out in the strategy as to potential measures relating to
those priorities.

95.3.11

The spatial development strategy must not—

95.3.11.a

include anything that is not permitted or required by or under subsections
(2A)  to (8),

95.3.11.b

specify particular sites where development should take place, or

95.3.11.c

be inconsistent with or (in substance) repeat any national development
management policy.

###### Neighbourhood development plans and orders: basic conditions

99

99.1

In paragraph 8(2) of Schedule 4B to TCPA 1990 (basic conditions for making
neighbourhood development order or neighbourhood plan)—

99.1.a

for paragraph (e) substitute—

99.1.a.ea

the making of the order would not have the effect of preventing development
from taking place which—

99.1.a.ea.i

is proposed in the development plan for the area of the authority (or any part
of that area), and

99.1.a.ea.ii

if it took place, would provide housing,

;

insert—

99.1.b.fa

any requirements imposed in relation to the order by or under  Part 6  of the
Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023 (environmental outcomes reports) have
been complied with,

.

99.2

In section 38C(5) of PCPA 2004 (neighbourhood development plans: modifications
of Schedule 4B to TCPA 1990), in paragraph (d), for the words from “if” to the
end substitute

if—

99.2.i

sub-paragraphs (2)(b) and (c) were omitted,

99.2.ii

in sub-paragraph (2), for paragraph (ea) there were substituted—

99.2.ii.ea

the making of the neighbourhood development plan would not result in the
development plan for the area of the authority proposing that less housing is
provided by means of development taking place in that area than if the
neighbourhood development plan were not to be made,

, and

99.2.iii

sub-paragraphs (3) to (5) were omitted.

99.3

In paragraph 11(2) of Schedule A2 to PCPA 2004 (modification of neighbourhood
development plans: basic conditions)—

99.3.a

for paragraph (c) substitute—

99.3.a.ca

the making of the plan would not result in the development plan for the area
of the authority proposing that less housing is provided by means of
development taking place in that area than if the draft plan were not to be
made,

;

99.3.b

after paragraph (d) (but before the “and” at the end of that paragraph)
insert—

99.3.b.da

any requirements imposed in relation to the plan by or under  Part 6  of the
Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023 (environmental outcomes reports) have
been complied with,

.

##### Requirement to assist with plan making

###### Requirement to assist with certain plan making

100

In Part 3 of PCPA 2004 (development), after section 39 (sustainable
development) insert—

########## Assistance with certain parts of development plan etc

########### Power to require assistance with certain plan making

100.39A

100.39A.1

Subsection  (2)  applies if a plan-making authority notifies a prescribed
public body in writing that the authority requires the body, under this
section, to assist the authority in relation to the preparation or revision of
a relevant plan by the authority.

100.39A.2

The prescribed public body must do everything that the plan-making authority
reasonably requires of the body to assist the authority in relation to the
preparation or revision of the relevant plan.

100.39A.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision as to—

100.39A.3.a

what a plan-making authority must, may or may not require a prescribed public
body to do under  subsection (2) ;

100.39A.3.b

the procedure to be followed in doing anything under this section;

100.39A.3.c

the determination of the time by or at which anything must be done under this
section;

100.39A.3.d

the form and content of a notification under  subsection (1)  or of any other
document or information provided under this section.

100.39A.4

A “plan-making authority” is a body which, or other person who, is to prepare
or revise (whether acting alone or jointly) a relevant plan.

100.39A.5

Each of the following is a “relevant plan”—

100.39A.5.a

a local plan, a minerals and waste plan, a supplementary plan or policies map
under Part 2;

100.39A.5.b

a spatial development strategy under Part 8 of the Greater London Authority
Act 1999 or Part 2 of this Act;

100.39A.5.c

an infrastructure delivery strategy under Part 10A of the Planning Act 2008;

100.39A.5.d

a marine plan under the Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009 for the English
inshore region, the English offshore region or any part of either of those
regions.

100.39A.6

A “prescribed public body” is a body which, or other person who, is prescribed
or of a prescribed description and certain of whose functions are of a public
nature.

100.39A.7

References in this section to the preparation or revision of a relevant plan
include any activities that could reasonably be considered to prepare the way
for the preparation or revision of the plan.

100.39A.8

In this section—

      “ the English inshore region ” and “the English offshore region” have
the same meaning as in the Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009;           “
revision ”, in relation to a relevant plan, includes any alteration,
amendment, replacement or other modification (and related expressions are to
be read accordingly).

#### Heritage

##### Regard to certain heritage assets in exercise of planning functions

102

102.1

After section 58A of TCPA 1990 insert—

########### Regard to certain heritage assets

############ Duty of regard to certain heritage assets in granting permissions

102.1.58B

102.1.58B.1

In considering whether to grant planning permission or permission in principle
for the development of land in England which affects a relevant asset or its
setting, the local planning authority or (as the case may be) the Secretary of
State must have special regard to the desirability of preserving or enhancing
the asset or its setting.

102.1.58B.2

For the purposes of subsection  (1) , preserving or enhancing a relevant asset
or its setting includes preserving or enhancing any feature, quality or
characteristic of the asset or setting that contributes to the significance of
the asset.

102.1.58B.3

For the purposes of this section—

102.1.58B.3.a

anything within an entry in the first column of the following table is a
“relevant asset”, and

102.1.58B.3.b

“ significance ”, in relation to a relevant asset, has the meaning given by
the corresponding entry in the second column of the table.

TABLE “relevant asset” “significance” a scheduled monument within the meaning
of the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979 (see section 1(11)
of that Act) the national importance referred to in section 1(3) of that Act a
garden or other area of land included in a register maintained by the Historic
Buildings and Monuments Commission for England under section 8C of the
Historic Buildings and Ancient Monuments Act 1953 the special historic
interest referred to in subsection (1) of that section a site designated as a
restricted area under section 1 of the Protection of Wrecks Act 1973 the
historical, archaeological or artistic importance referred to in subsection
(1)(b) of that section a World Heritage Site (that is to say, a property
appearing on the World Heritage List kept under paragraph (2) of article 11 of
the UNESCO Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and
Natural Heritage adopted at Paris on 16 November 1972) the outstanding
universal value referred to in that paragraph

102.1.58B.4

The reference in subsection  (1)  to a local planning authority includes the
Mayor of London in relation to the grant of planning permission by Mayoral
development order.

102.1.58B.5

Nothing in this section applies in relation to neighbourhood development
orders (except as provided in Schedule 4B) or street vote development orders
(except as provided by SVDO regulations within the meaning given by section
61QM).

102.2

In paragraph 8 of Schedule 4B to TCPA 1990 (matters to be considered in
examining draft neighbourhood development order)—

102.2.a

in sub-paragraph (2)—

102.2.a.i

in paragraph (b), after “preserving” insert  “or enhancing” ;

102.2.a.ii

after paragraph (c) insert—

102.2.a.ii.ca

having special regard to the desirability of preserving or enhancing anything
that is a relevant asset for the purposes of section  58B  or its setting, it
is appropriate to make the order,

;

102.2.b

after sub-paragraph (4) insert—

102.2.b.4A

Sub-paragraph (2) (ca)  applies in relation to anything that is a relevant
asset for the purposes of section  58B  only in so far as the order grants
planning permission for development that affects the asset or its setting.

102.2.b.4B

Subsections  (2)  and  (3) (b)  of section  58B  apply for the purposes of
sub-paragraphs (2) (ca)  and  (4A)  as they apply for the purposes of that
section.

102.3

In section 16 of the Listed Buildings Act (decisions on applications for
listed building consent),   in subsection (2), after “preserving” insert “or
enhancing”.

102.4

In section 66 of the Listed Buildings Act (duty to have regard to listed
buildings in the exercise of certain planning functions)—

102.4. 

in subsection (1), after “preserving” insert  “or enhancing” ;

102.4.a

after subsection (1) insert—

102.4.a.1A

The reference in subsection (1) to a local planning authority includes the
Mayor of London in relation to the grant of planning permission by Mayoral
development order.

;

102.4.b

in subsection (2), after “preserving” insert  “or enhancing” .

##### Temporary stop notices in relation to listed buildings

103

103.1

The Listed Buildings Act is amended as follows.

103.2

After section 44A insert—

########### Temporary stop notices in England

103.2.44AA

103.2.44AA.1

This section applies where it appears to a local planning authority in England
that—

103.2.44AA.1.a

works have been or are being executed to a listed building in their area, and

103.2.44AA.1.b

the works are such as to involve a contravention of section 9(1) or (2).

103.2.44AA.2

The authority may issue a temporary stop notice if, having regard to the
effect of the works on the character of the building as one of special
architectural or historic interest, they consider it is expedient that the
works (or part of them) be stopped immediately.

103.2.44AA.3

A temporary stop notice must be in writing and must—

103.2.44AA.3.a

specify the works in question,

103.2.44AA.3.b

prohibit execution of the works (or so much of them as is specified in the
notice),

103.2.44AA.3.c

set out the authority’s reasons for issuing the notice, and

103.2.44AA.3.d

include a statement of the effect of section 44AB.

103.2.44AA.4

A temporary stop notice may be served on a person who appears to the
authority—

103.2.44AA.4.a

to be executing the works or causing them to be executed,

103.2.44AA.4.b

to have an interest in the building, or

103.2.44AA.4.c

to be an occupier of the building.

103.2.44AA.5

The authority must display a copy of the notice on the building; and the copy
must specify the date on which it is first displayed.

103.2.44AA.6

A temporary stop notice takes effect when the copy of it is first displayed in
accordance with subsection  (5) .

103.2.44AA.7

A temporary stop notice ceases to have effect—

103.2.44AA.7.a

at the end of the period of 56 days beginning with the day on which the copy
of it is first displayed in accordance with subsection  (5) , or

103.2.44AA.7.b

if the notice specifies a shorter period beginning with that day, at the end
of that period.

103.2.44AA.8

But if the authority withdraws the notice before the time when it would
otherwise cease to have effect under subsection  (7) , the notice ceases to
have effect on its withdrawal.

103.2.44AA.9

A local planning authority may not issue a subsequent temporary stop notice in
relation to the same works unless the authority have, since issuing the
previous notice, taken other enforcement action in relation to the
contravention referred to in subsection  (1) (b) .

103.2.44AA.10

The reference in subsection  (9)  to taking other enforcement action includes
a reference to obtaining an injunction under section 44A.

103.2.44AA.11

A temporary stop notice does not prohibit the execution of works of such
description, or the execution of works in such circumstances, as the Secretary
of State may by regulations prescribe.

########### Temporary stop notices in England: offence

103.2.44AB

103.2.44AB.1

A person is guilty of an offence if the person contravenes, or causes or
permits a contravention of, a temporary stop notice—

103.2.44AB.1.a

which has been served on the person under section  44AA (4) , or

103.2.44AB.1.b

a copy of which has been displayed in accordance with section  44AA (5) .

103.2.44AB.2

An offence under this section may be charged by reference to a day or to some
longer period; and accordingly, a person may, in relation to the same
temporary stop notice, be convicted of more than one offence under this
section by reference to different periods.

103.2.44AB.3

In proceedings against a person for an offence under this section, it is a
defence for the person to show that the person did not know, and could not
reasonably have been expected to know, of the existence of the temporary stop
notice.

103.2.44AB.4

In proceedings against a person for an offence under this section, it is also
a defence for the person to show—

103.2.44AB.4.a

that works to the building were urgently necessary in the interests of safety
or health or for the preservation of the building,

103.2.44AB.4.b

that it was not practicable to secure safety or health or, as the case may be,
the preservation of the building by works of repair or works for affording
temporary support or shelter,

103.2.44AB.4.c

that the works carried out were limited to the minimum measures immediately
necessary, and

103.2.44AB.4.d

that notice in writing justifying in detail the carrying out of the works was
given to the local planning authority as soon as reasonably practicable.

103.2.44AB.5

A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary
conviction, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine.

103.2.44AB.6

In determining the amount of a fine to be imposed on a person convicted under
this section, the court must in particular have regard to any financial
benefit which has accrued or appears likely to accrue to the person in
consequence of the offence.

########### Temporary stop notices in England: compensation

103.2.44AC

103.2.44AC.1

A person who, on the day when a temporary stop notice is first displayed in
accordance with section  44AA (5) , has an interest in the building is, on
making a claim to the local planning authority within the prescribed time and
in the prescribed manner, entitled to be paid compensation by the authority in
respect of any loss or damage directly attributable to the effect of the
notice.

103.2.44AC.2

But subsection  (1)  applies only if—

103.2.44AC.2.a

the works specified in the notice are not such as to involve a contravention
of section 9(1) or (2), or

103.2.44AC.2.b

the authority withdraws the notice other than following the grant of listed
building consent, after the day mentioned in subsection  (1) , which
authorises the works.

103.2.44AC.3

The loss or damage in respect of which compensation is payable under this
section includes a sum payable in respect of a breach of contract caused by
the taking of action necessary to comply with the notice.

103.2.44AC.4

No compensation is payable under this section in the case of loss or damage
suffered by a claimant if—

103.2.44AC.4.a

the claimant was required to provide information under a relevant provision,
and

103.2.44AC.4.b

the loss or damage could have been avoided if the claimant had provided the
information or had otherwise co-operated with the planning authority when
responding to the notice.

103.2.44AC.5

In subsection  (4) (a) , each of the following is a relevant provision—

103.2.44AC.5.a

section 16 of the Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976, and

103.2.44AC.5.b

section 330 of the principal Act.

.

103.12

In Schedule 2 (lapse of building preservation notices)—

103.12.a

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

#### Grant and implementation of planning permission

##### Street votes

106

106.1

TCPA 1990 is amended in accordance with subsection  (2) .

106.2

After section 61Q (community right to build orders) insert—

########### Street vote development orders

############ Street vote development orders

106.2.61QA

106.2.61QA.1

A process may be initiated by or on behalf of a qualifying group for the
purpose of requiring the Secretary of State to make a street vote development
order.

106.2.61QA.2

A “street vote development order” is an order which grants planning permission
in relation to a particular street area specified in the order—

106.2.61QA.2.a

for development specified in the order, or

106.2.61QA.2.b

for development of any description or class specified in the order.

############ Qualifying groups

106.2.61QB

106.2.61QB.1

A “ qualifying group ”, in relation to a street vote development order, is a
group of individuals—

106.2.61QB.1.a

each of whom on the prescribed date meet the conditions in subsection  (2) ,
and

106.2.61QB.1.b

comprised of at least—

106.2.61QB.1.b.i

the prescribed number, or

106.2.61QB.1.b.ii

the prescribed proportion of persons of a prescribed description.

106.2.61QB.2

The conditions are that the individual—

106.2.61QB.2.a

is entitled to vote in—

106.2.61QB.2.a.i

an Authority election, where any part of the street area to which the street
vote development order would relate is within the City of London, or

106.2.61QB.2.a.ii

an election of councillors of any relevant council (other than the City of
London) any part of whose area is within the street area to which the street
vote development order would relate,

106.2.61QB.2.b

has a qualifying address for that election which is in the street area that
the street vote development order would relate to, and

106.2.61QB.2.c

does not have an anonymous entry in the register of local government electors.

106.2.61QB.3

A “ relevant council ” means—

106.2.61QB.3.a

a district council,

106.2.61QB.3.b

a London borough council,

106.2.61QB.3.c

a metropolitan district council, or

106.2.61QB.3.d

a county council in relation to any area in England for which there is no
district council.

106.2.61QB.4

For the purposes of this section—

106.2.61QB.4.a

“ anonymous entry ” is to be construed in accordance with section 9B of the
Representation of the People Act 1983;

106.2.61QB.4.b

“ Authority election ” has the meaning given by section 203(1) of the
Representation of the People Act 1983;

106.2.61QB.4.c

the Inner Temple and the Middle Temple are to be treated as forming part of
the City of London;

106.2.61QB.4.d

“ qualifying address ” has the meaning given by section 9 of the
Representation of the People Act 1983.

############ Meaning of “street area”

106.2.61QC

106.2.61QC.1

A “ street area ” means an area in England—

106.2.61QC.1.a

which is of a prescribed description, and

106.2.61QC.1.b

no part of which is within an excluded area.

106.2.61QC.2

An “ excluded area ” means—

106.2.61QC.2.a

a National Park or the Broads;

106.2.61QC.2.b

an area comprising a world heritage property and its buffer zone as identified
in accordance with the Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the
World Heritage Convention as published from time to time;

106.2.61QC.2.c

an area notified as a site of special scientific interest under section 28 of
the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981;

106.2.61QC.2.d

an area designated as an area of outstanding natural beauty under section 82
of the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000;

106.2.61QC.2.e

an area identified as green belt land, local green space or metropolitan open
land in a development plan;

106.2.61QC.2.f

a European site within the meaning given by regulation 8 of the Conservation
of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 );

106.2.61QC.2.g

such other area as may be specified or described in regulations made by the
Secretary of State.

106.2.61QC.3

In this section, “ a world heritage property ” means a property appearing on
the World Heritage List (published in accordance with Article 11 of the UNESCO
Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural
Heritage adopted on 16 November 1972).

############ Process for making street vote development orders

106.2.61QD

106.2.61QD.1

The Secretary of State must make regulations (“ SVDO regulations ”) which make
provision about the preparation and making of a street vote development order.

106.2.61QD.2

SVDO regulations must, in particular, make provision—

106.2.61QD.2.a

for the appointment by the Secretary of State of a person to—

106.2.61QD.2.a.i

handle proposals made under  section 61QA (1)  (“street vote proposals”) or
specified aspects of those proposals,

106.2.61QD.2.a.ii

carry out the independent examination of such proposals, and

106.2.61QD.2.a.iii

to make street vote development orders on the Secretary of State’s behalf,

(and for the above purposes the same or different persons may be appointed);

106.2.61QD.2.b

as to the circumstances in which a street vote development order may be made
and in particular must make provision requiring a referendum under section
61QE  to be held before an order may be made.

106.2.61QD.3

SVDO regulations may, in particular, include provision as to—

106.2.61QD.3.a

the functions of a qualifying group in relation to a street vote proposal and
how those functions are to be discharged (including provision for a member of
the group or another prescribed person to be responsible for discharging
them);

106.2.61QD.3.b

the form and content of a street vote proposal;

106.2.61QD.3.c

the information and documents (if any) which must accompany a street vote
proposal;

106.2.61QD.3.d

the circumstances and the way in which a proposal may be withdrawn;

106.2.61QD.3.e

the steps that must be taken, and the conditions that must be met, before a
proposal falls to be considered by an appointed person;

106.2.61QD.3.f

the circumstances in which an appointed person may or must decline to consider
or reject a proposal;

106.2.61QD.3.g

the steps that must be taken, and the conditions that must be met, before a
proposal falls to be independently examined;

106.2.61QD.3.h

the functions of the independent examination in relation to the proposal;

106.2.61QD.3.i

the circumstances in which an appointed person may terminate the independent
examination (including provision as to the procedure for doing so);

106.2.61QD.3.j

the procedure to be followed at an examination (including provision regarding
the procedure to be followed at any hearing or inquiry or provision
designating the hearing or inquiry as a statutory inquiry for the purposes of
section 9 of the Tribunals and Inquiries Act 1992);

106.2.61QD.3.k

the power to summons witnesses at any inquiry (including by applying, with or
without modifications, section 250(3) and (4) of the Local Government Act
1972);

106.2.61QD.3.l

the award of costs in connection with an examination;

106.2.61QD.3.m

the steps to be taken following the independent examination (including
provision for prescribed modifications to be made to the draft street vote
development order);

106.2.61QD.3.n

the payment by a local planning authority of remuneration and expenses
relating to the examination;

106.2.61QD.3.o

the functions of local planning authorities, or other authorities, in
connection with street vote development orders (including provision regulating
the arrangements of authorities for the discharge of those functions);

106.2.61QD.3.p

cases where there are two or more local planning authorities any of whose area
falls within the area of the street area that the proposal relates to
(including provision modifying functions of the local planning authorities
under the regulations in such cases or provision applying, with or without
modifications, any provision of Part 6 of the Local Government Act 1972 in
cases where the provision would not otherwise apply);

106.2.61QD.3.q

requirements about the giving of notice and publicity;

106.2.61QD.3.r

the information and documents that are to be made available to the public;

106.2.61QD.3.s

consultation with and participation by the public or prescribed persons;

106.2.61QD.3.t

the making and consideration of representations;

106.2.61QD.3.u

the determination of the time by or at which anything must be done in
connection with street vote development orders;

106.2.61QD.3.v

the provision by any person of prescribed information or documents or
prescribed descriptions of information or documents in connection with a
street vote development order;

106.2.61QD.3.w

the making of reasonable charges for anything done in connection with street
vote development orders;

106.2.61QD.3.x

when a court may entertain proceedings for questioning prescribed decisions to
act or any other prescribed matter.

############ Referendums

106.2.61QE

106.2.61QE.1

SVDO regulations may make provision about referendums held in connection with
street vote development orders and may, in particular, include provision—

106.2.61QE.1.a

as to the circumstances in which an appointed person or the Secretary of State
may direct relevant councils to carry out a referendum in relation to a street
vote development order;

106.2.61QE.1.b

the functions of such councils in relation to the referendum;

106.2.61QE.1.c

dealing with any case where there are two or more relevant councils any of
whose area falls within the area in which a referendum is to take place
(including provision for only one council to carry out functions in relation
to the referendum in such a case);

106.2.61QE.1.d

prescribing a date by which the referendum must be held or before which it
cannot be held;

106.2.61QE.1.e

as to the question to be asked in the referendum and any explanatory material
in relation to that question;

106.2.61QE.1.f

as to voter eligibility for the referendum;

106.2.61QE.1.g

as to the publicity to be given in connection with the referendum;

106.2.61QE.1.h

as to the provision of prescribed information to voters in connection with the
referendum (including information about any infrastructure levy or community
infrastructure levy which is chargeable in respect of development under a
street vote development order);

106.2.61QE.1.i

about the limitation of expenditure in connection with the referendum;

106.2.61QE.1.j

as to the conduct of the referendum;

106.2.61QE.1.k

as to when, where and how voting in the referendum is to take place;

106.2.61QE.1.l

as to how the votes cast are to be counted;

106.2.61QE.1.m

about certification as to the number of persons voting in the referendum and
as to the number of those persons voting in favour of a street vote
development order;

106.2.61QE.1.n

about the combination of polls at the referendum with polls at another
referendum or at any election;

106.2.61QE.1.o

as to the threshold of votes that must be met before a street vote development
order may be made.

106.2.61QE.2

For the purposes of making provision within subsection  (1) , SVDO regulations
may apply or incorporate (with or without modifications) any provision made by
or under any enactment relating to elections or referendums.

106.2.61QE.3

But where the regulations apply or incorporate (with or without modifications)
any provision that creates an offence, the regulations may not impose a
penalty greater than is provided for in respect of that provision.

106.2.61QE.4

Before making provision within this section, the Secretary of State must
consult the Electoral Commission.

106.2.61QE.5

In this section “ enactment ” means an enactment, whenever passed or made.

############ Regulations: general provision

106.2.61QF

SVDO regulations may—

106.2.61QF.a

provide for exemptions (including exemptions which are subject to prescribed
conditions);

106.2.61QF.b

confer a function, including a function involving the exercise of a
discretion, on any person.

############ Provision that may be made by a street vote development order

106.2.61QG

106.2.61QG.1

A street vote development order may make provision in relation to—

106.2.61QG.1.a

all land in the street area specified in the order,

106.2.61QG.1.b

any part of that land, or

106.2.61QG.1.c

a site in that area specified in the order.

106.2.61QG.2

A street vote development order may only provide for the granting of planning
permission for any development that—

106.2.61QG.2.a

is prescribed development or development of a prescribed description or class,

106.2.61QG.2.b

is not excluded development, and

106.2.61QG.2.c

satisfies any further prescribed conditions.

106.2.61QG.3

A street vote development order may make different provision for different
purposes.

############ Meaning of “excluded development”

106.2.61QH

The following development is excluded development for the purposes of  section
61QG (2) (b)  —

106.2.61QH.a

development of a scheduled monument within the meaning given by section 1(11)
of the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979;

106.2.61QH.b

Schedule 1 development as defined by regulation 2 of the Town and Country
Planning (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/571 );

106.2.61QH.c

development that consists (whether wholly or partly) of a nationally
significant infrastructure project (within the meaning of the Planning Act
2008);

106.2.61QH.d

development of a listed building within the meaning given by section 1(5) of
the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation) Areas Act 1990;

106.2.61QH.e

development consisting of the winning and working of minerals;

106.2.61QH.f

such other development as may be specified or described in regulations made by
the Secretary of State.

############ Permission granted by street vote development orders

106.2.61QI

106.2.61QI.1

The granting of planning permission by a street vote development order is
subject to—

106.2.61QI.1.a

any prescribed conditions or limitations or conditions or limitations of a
prescribed description, and

106.2.61QI.1.b

such other conditions or limitations as may be specified in the order (but see
subsections  (4)  and  (5) ).

106.2.61QI.2

The conditions that may be specified include a condition that unless a
relevant obligation is entered into—

106.2.61QI.2.a

the development authorised by the planning permission or any description of
such development must not be begun, or

106.2.61QI.2.b

anything created in the course of the development authorised by the planning
permission may not be occupied or used for any purpose.

106.2.61QI.3

A relevant obligation for the purposes of subsection  (2)  includes an
obligation which involves the payment of money or affects any estate or
interest in, or rights over, land.

106.2.61QI.4

But an order may only specify a condition that a person enter into an
obligation under section 106 if the obligation—

106.2.61QI.4.a

is necessary to make the development specified in the order acceptable in
planning terms,

106.2.61QI.4.b

is directly related to the development,

106.2.61QI.4.c

is fairly and reasonably related in scale and kind to the development, and

106.2.61QI.4.d

satisfies such other requirements as may be specified in regulations made by
the Secretary of State.

106.2.61QI.5

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide that—

106.2.61QI.5.a

conditions or limitations of a prescribed description may not be imposed under
subsection  (1) (b) ,

106.2.61QI.5.b

conditions or limitations of a prescribed description may only be imposed
under subsection  (1) (b)  in circumstances of a prescribed description, or

106.2.61QI.5.c

no conditions or limitations may be imposed under subsection  (1) (b)  in
circumstances of a prescribed description.

106.2.61QI.6

A condition or limitation prescribed under subsection  (1) (a)  may confer a
function on any person, including a function involving the exercise of a
discretion.

106.2.61QI.7

If—

106.2.61QI.7.a

planning permission granted by a street vote development order for any
development is withdrawn by the revocation of the order under  section 61QJ ,
and

106.2.61QI.7.b

the revocation is made after the development has begun but before it has been
completed,

the development may, despite the withdrawal of the permission, be completed.

106.2.61QI.8

But an order under  section 61QJ  revoking a street vote development order may
provide that  subsection (7)  is not to apply in relation to development
specified in the order under that section.

106.2.61QI.9

In this section “ relevant obligation ” means—

106.2.61QI.9.a

an obligation under section 106 (planning obligations), or

106.2.61QI.9.b

an agreement under section 278 of the Highways Act 1980 (agreements as to
execution of works).

############ Revocation or modification of street vote development orders

106.2.61QJ

106.2.61QJ.1

The Secretary of State may by order revoke or modify a street vote development
order.

106.2.61QJ.2

A local planning authority may, with the consent of the Secretary of State, by
order revoke a street vote development order relating to a street area any
part of which falls within the area of that authority.

106.2.61QJ.3

If a street vote development order is revoked, the person revoking the order
must state the reasons for the revocation.

106.2.61QJ.4

An appointed person may at any time by order modify a street vote development
order for the purpose of correcting errors.

106.2.61QJ.5

A modification of a street vote development order is to be done by replacing
the order with a new one containing the modification.

106.2.61QJ.6

Regulations may make provision in connection with the revocation or
modification of a street vote development order.

106.2.61QJ.7

The regulations may, in particular, include provision as to—

106.2.61QJ.7.a

the giving of notice and publicity in connection with a revocation or
modification;

106.2.61QJ.7.b

the information and documents relating to a revocation or modification that
are to be made available to the public;

106.2.61QJ.7.c

the making of reasonable charges for anything provided as a result of the
regulations;

106.2.61QJ.7.d

consultation with and participation by the public in relation to a revocation
or modification;

106.2.61QJ.7.e

the making and consideration of representations about a revocation or
modification (including the time by which representations must be made).

############ Financial assistance in relation to street votes

106.2.61QK

106.2.61QK.1

The Secretary of State may do anything that the Secretary of State considers
appropriate—

106.2.61QK.1.a

for the purpose of publicising or promoting the making of street vote
development orders and the benefits expected to arise from their making, or

106.2.61QK.1.b

for the purpose of giving advice or assistance to anyone in relation to the
making of street vote proposals or the doing of anything else for the purposes
of, or in connection with, such proposals or street vote development orders.

106.2.61QK.2

The things that the Secretary of State may do under this section include, in
particular—

106.2.61QK.2.a

the provision of financial assistance (or the making of arrangements for its
provision) to any body or other person, and

106.2.61QK.2.b

the making of agreements or other arrangements with any body or other person
(under which payments may be made to the person).

106.2.61QK.3

In this section—

106.2.61QK.3.a

the reference to giving advice or assistance includes providing training or
education;

106.2.61QK.3.b

any reference to the provision of financial assistance is to the provision of
financial assistance by any means (including the making of a loan and the
giving of a guarantee or indemnity).

############ Street votes: connected modifications

106.2.61QL

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision modifying the
application of Schedule 7A (biodiversity gain in England) in relation to
planning permission granted by a street vote development order.

############ Interpretation

106.2.61QM

In sections  61QA  to  61QL —

      “ an appointed person ” means a person appointed in accordance with
section 61QD (2) (a) ;           “ excluded development ” has the meaning
given by  section 61QH ;           “ qualifying group ” has the meaning given
by  section 61QB ;           “ relevant council ” has the meaning given by
section 61QB (3) ;           “ street area ” has the meaning given by  section
61QC ;           “ street vote development order ” has the meaning given by
section 61QA (2) ;           “ street vote proposal ” has the meaning given by
section 61QD (2) (a) (i) ;           “ SVDO regulations ” has the meaning
given by  section 61QD (1) .

106.3

Schedule 9  contains minor and consequential amendments in connection with
this section.

charging schedule.”

Where the only provision made by a charging schedule or a revision of a

sections 212 to 213 and 214(1) and (2) do not apply in relation to the

107.3.11.b

CIL regulations may make provision about procedural requirements that must be

########### Secretary of State: power to require review of certain charging schedules

107.8.214A

107.8.214A.1

This section applies where—

107.8.214A.1.a

a charging schedule makes provision for the purpose of determining the amount
of CIL chargeable in respect of street vote development, and

107.8.214A.1.b

section 211(11) applied in relation to the charging schedule or the revision
of the charging schedule in connection with making such provision.

107.8.214A.2

The Secretary of State may direct a charging authority to review the charging
schedule if the Secretary of State considers that—

107.8.214A.2.a

the economic viability of street vote development in the charging authority’s
area is significantly impaired, or

107.8.214A.2.b

there is a substantial risk that it will become significantly impaired,

as a result of the CIL which is or will be chargeable in respect of street
vote development in that area.

107.8.214A.3

If a charging authority is directed to review its charging schedule under
subsection  (2) , it must—

107.8.214A.3.a

consider whether to revise the charging schedule under section 211(9), and

107.8.214A.3.b

notify the Secretary of State of its decision with reasons.

107.8.214A.4

If the charging authority decides to revise the charging schedule, it must do
so within a reasonable time.

107.8.214A.5

If a charging authority has not complied with a direction given under
subsection  (2)  within a reasonable time and to a standard which the
Secretary of State considers adequate, the Secretary of State may appoint a
person to do so on behalf of the charging authority.

107.8.214A.6

If a person appointed under subsection  (5)  decides that the charging
schedule should be revised, the charging authority must revise the schedule
accordingly within a reasonable time.

107.8.214A.7

If the charging authority fails to revise the charging schedule in accordance
with subsection  (4)  or  (6) , the Secretary of State may appoint a person to
do so on behalf of the charging authority.

107.8.214A.8

CIL regulations may make provision about—

107.8.214A.8.a

procedures for appointing a person under subsection  (5)  or  (7) ,

107.8.214A.8.b

conditions which must be met before such an appointment may be made,

107.8.214A.8.c

procedures which must be followed by the person in complying with a direction
given under subsection  (2)  or revising the charging schedule under
subsection  (7) ,

107.8.214A.8.d

circumstances in which the person may be replaced,

107.8.214A.8.e

duties of a charging authority where a person is appointed to act on its
behalf under subsection  (5)  or  (7) ,

107.8.214A.8.f

liability for costs incurred as a result of the appointment of the person, and

107.8.214A.8.g

what constitutes a reasonable time under subsections  (4)  to  (6) .

107.8.214A.9

In this section “ street vote development ” has the meaning given by section
211(12).

107.9

In section 216(2) (application), after paragraph (f) insert—

107.9.fa

where the CIL is chargeable in respect of street vote development, affordable
housing.

107.10

After section 216(7) insert—

107.10.8

In this section—

      “ affordable housing ” means—         social housing within the meaning
of Part 2 of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008, and           any other
description of housing that CIL regulations may specify;                 “
street vote development ” has the meaning given by section 211(12).

108

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision modifying the
