permission by a street vote development order.

##### Crown development

109

109.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

109.2

After section 293A insert—

########### Urgent Crown development: applications to the Secretary of State

109.2.293B

109.2.293B.1

This section applies where—

109.2.293B.1.a

the appropriate authority intends to make a relevant application, and

109.2.293B.1.b

the authority considers—

109.2.293B.1.b.i

that the development to which the application relates is of national
importance, and

109.2.293B.1.b.ii

that it is necessary that the development is carried out as a matter of
urgency.

109.2.293B.2

The appropriate authority may make the application to the Secretary of State
under this section.

109.2.293B.3

In this section, “ relevant application ” means—

109.2.293B.3.a

an application for planning permission for the development of land in England,
or

109.2.293B.3.b

an application for approval of a matter that, as defined in section 92, is a
reserved matter in the case of an outline planning permission for the
development of land in England,

but does not include an application of the kind described in section 73(1) or
an application of a description excluded by regulations.

109.2.293B.4

An application under this section must include—

109.2.293B.4.a

such information, documents or other matters as may be required by a
development order, and

109.2.293B.4.b

a statement of the appropriate authority’s grounds for making the application.

109.2.293B.5

As soon as practicable after receiving the application, the Secretary of State
must give notice to the appropriate authority either agreeing or refusing to
determine the application.

109.2.293B.6

The Secretary of State may only agree to determine the application if the
Secretary of State considers that—

109.2.293B.6.a

the development to which the application relates is of national importance,
and

109.2.293B.6.b

it is necessary that the development is carried out as a matter of urgency.

109.2.293B.7

The Secretary of State must send a copy of a notice given under subsection
(5)  to the local planning authority to whom the application could otherwise
have been made.

109.2.293B.8

The Secretary of State may by notice require the appropriate authority to
provide such further information as is necessary for the purposes of—

109.2.293B.8.a

deciding whether to agree or to refuse to determine the application;

109.2.293B.8.b

determining the application.

109.2.293B.9

A development order may make provision—

109.2.293B.9.a

as to the form and manner in which an application must be made;

109.2.293B.9.b

requiring notice to be given of an application;

109.2.293B.9.c

as to the form, content and service of a notice required under  paragraph (b)
;

109.2.293B.9.d

requiring that an application be publicised in such manner as the order may
specify.

109.2.293B.10

A development order which makes provision under subsection  (9)  may include
provision to ensure that the imposition of any requirement under that
subsection does not result in the public disclosure of sensitive information.

109.2.293B.11

For the purposes of subsection  (10) , information is “sensitive” if the
Secretary of State directs that—

109.2.293B.11.a

it relates to matters of national security or measures taken or to be taken to
ensure the security of any premises or property, and

109.2.293B.11.b

its public disclosure would be contrary to the national interest.

109.2.293B.12

A development order making any provision by virtue of this section may make
different provision for different cases or different classes of development.

109.2.293B.13

The Secretary of State may give directions requiring a local planning
authority to do things in relation to an application made under  section 293B
that could otherwise have been made to that authority.

109.2.293B.14

Directions under subsection  (13) —

109.2.293B.14.a

may relate to a particular application or to applications more generally;

109.2.293B.14.b

may be given to a particular authority or to authorities more generally.

########### Urgent Crown development: determination of applications by the Secretary of State

109.2.293C

109.2.293C.1

This section applies where —

109.2.293C.1.a

the appropriate authority has made a relevant application to the Secretary of
State under  section 293B , and

109.2.293C.1.b

the Secretary of State has given notice under  section 293B (5)  agreeing to
determine the application.

109.2.293C.2

Before determining the application, the Secretary of State must consult the
following persons about the application—

109.2.293C.2.a

the local planning authority to which the application could otherwise have
been made, and

109.2.293C.2.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

109.2.293C.3

A development order may make provision as to the consultation required by
subsection  (2)  including—

109.2.293C.3.a

provision requiring the Secretary of State to consult other specified persons
(or persons of a specified description);

109.2.293C.3.b

provision as to the manner in which persons may be consulted;

109.2.293C.3.c

different provision for different cases or classes of development.

109.2.293C.4

The Secretary of State may—

109.2.293C.4.a

grant the application, either unconditionally or subject to such conditions as
the Secretary of State thinks fit, or

109.2.293C.4.b

refuse it.

109.2.293C.5

The Secretary of State must notify the local planning authority to whom the
application could otherwise have been made of the Secretary of State’s
decision on the application.

109.2.293C.6

The decision of the Secretary of State on the application is final.

109.2.293C.7

Section 73A applies, with any necessary modifications, to an application for
planning permission under  section 293B  as it applies to an application for
planning permission which is to be determined by the local planning authority
under Part 3.

109.2.293C.8

The following provisions do not apply for the purposes of determining an
application for planning permission under  section 293B —

109.2.293C.8.a

section  58B (1)  of this Act;

109.2.293C.8.b

sections 66(1) and 72(1) of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation
Areas) Act 1990.

########### Crown development: applications to the Secretary of State

109.2.293D

109.2.293D.1

This section applies where—

109.2.293D.1.a

the appropriate authority intends to make a relevant application, and

109.2.293D.1.b

the authority considers that the development to which it relates is of
national importance.

109.2.293D.2

The appropriate authority may make the application to the Secretary of State
under this section.

109.2.293D.3

In this section and section  293E , “ relevant application ” means—

109.2.293D.3.a

an application for planning permission, or permission in principle, for the
development of land in England, or

109.2.293D.3.b

an application for approval of a matter that, as defined by section 92, is a
reserved matter in the case of an outline planning permission for the
development of land in England,

but does not include an application of the kind described in section 73(1) or
an application of a description excluded by regulations.

109.2.293D.4

After receiving the application, the Secretary of State must give a notice to
the appropriate authority stating whether the Secretary of State considers the
development to be of national importance.

109.2.293D.5

If the Secretary of State considers the development to be of national
importance, the Secretary of State must proceed to determine the application.

109.2.293D.6

If the Secretary of State considers that the development is not of national
importance, the Secretary of State may take the steps referred to in either
subsection  (7)  or, where it applies, subsection  (9) .

109.2.293D.7

The Secretary of State may—

109.2.293D.7.a

refer the application to the local planning authority to whom it could
otherwise have been made, and

109.2.293D.7.b

direct that the application—

109.2.293D.7.b.i

is to be treated as having been made to the authority (and not to the
Secretary of State under this section), and

109.2.293D.7.b.ii

is to be determined by that authority accordingly.

109.2.293D.8

Subsection  (9)  applies where—

109.2.293D.8.a

the application could otherwise have been made to the Secretary of State under
section 62A, and

109.2.293D.8.b

the appropriate authority has given notice to the Secretary of State that the
authority consents to the application being treated as having been made to the
Secretary of State under that section.

109.2.293D.9

The Secretary of State may—

109.2.293D.9.a

direct that the application is to be treated as having been made to the
Secretary of State under section 62A (and not to the Secretary of State under
this section), and

109.2.293D.9.b

determine the application accordingly.

########### Crown development: connected applications to the Secretary of State

109.2.293E

109.2.293E.1

This section applies where—

109.2.293E.1.a

the appropriate authority makes an application to the Secretary of State under
section  293D , and

109.2.293E.1.b

the Secretary of State gives a notice to the appropriate authority under
section 293D (4)  stating that the development to which it relates is
considered by the Secretary of State to be of national importance.

109.2.293E.2

The appropriate authority may make an application (“a connected application”)
under the planning Acts to the Secretary of State where the requirements of
subsection  (3)  are met.

109.2.293E.3

The requirements are that—

109.2.293E.3.a

the application is—

109.2.293E.3.a.i

for listed building consent under the Planning (Listed Buildings and
Conservation Areas) Act 1990,

109.2.293E.3.a.ii

for hazardous substances consent under the Planning (Hazardous Substances) Act
1990, or

109.2.293E.3.a.iii

of a prescribed description,

109.2.293E.3.b

it is considered by the person making the application to be connected to an
application under section  293D ,

109.2.293E.3.c

it is neither a relevant application nor an application of the kind described
in section 73(1), and

109.2.293E.3.d

it relates to land in England.

109.2.293E.4

If a connected application is made under subsection  (2) , but the Secretary
of State considers that it is not connected with the relevant application
concerned, the Secretary of State may—

109.2.293E.4.a

refer the connected application to the local planning authority, or hazardous
substances authority, to whom it could otherwise have been made, and

109.2.293E.4.b

direct that the connected application—

109.2.293E.4.b.i

is to be treated as having been made to that authority (and not to the
Secretary of State under this section), and

109.2.293E.4.b.ii

is to be determined by that authority accordingly.

########### Applications under section 

109.2.293F

109.2.293F.1

The decision of the Secretary of State on an application made under section
293D  or  293E  is final.

109.2.293F.2

The Secretary of State may give directions requiring a local planning
authority or hazardous substances authority to do things in relation to an
application made under section  293D  or  293E  that could otherwise have been
made to that authority.

109.2.293F.3

Directions under subsection  (2) —

109.2.293F.3.a

may relate to a particular application or to applications more generally;

109.2.293F.3.b

may be given to a particular authority or to authorities more generally.

########### Notifying parish councils of applications under section 

109.2.293G

109.2.293G.1

If an application is made to the Secretary of State under section  293D (2)
and a parish council would be entitled under paragraph 8 of Schedule 1 to be
notified of the application were it made to the local planning authority, the
Secretary of State must notify the council of—

109.2.293G.1.a

the application, and

109.2.293G.1.b

any alteration of the application accepted by the Secretary of State.

109.2.293G.2

Paragraph 8(4) and (5) of Schedule 1 apply in relation to duties of the
Secretary of State under  subsection (1)  as they apply to duties of a local
planning authority under paragraph 8(1) or (3B) of that Schedule.

########### Provisions applying to applications made under section 

109.2.293H

109.2.293H.1

Sections 62(3) and (4), 65(5), 70 to 70C, 72(1) and (5) and 73A apply, with
any necessary modifications, to an application for planning permission made to
the Secretary of State under section  293D  as they apply to an application
for planning permission which is to be determined by the local planning
authority.

109.2.293H.2

Any requirements imposed by a development order by virtue of section 62, 65 or
71 or paragraph 8(6) of Schedule 1, or by regulations under paragraph 14(3) or
16 of Schedule 7A, may be applied by a development order, with or without
modifications, to an application for planning permission made to the Secretary
of State under section  293D .

109.2.293H.3

Sections 65(5) and 70 to 70C apply, with any necessary modifications, to an
application for permission in principle made to the Secretary of State under
section  293D  as they apply to an application for permission in principle
which is to be determined by the local planning authority.

109.2.293H.4

Any requirements imposed by a development order by virtue of section 62(1),
(2) or (8), 65 or 71 or paragraph 8(6) of Schedule 1 may be applied by a
development order, with or without modifications, to an application for
permission in principle made to the Secretary of State under section  293D .

109.2.293H.5

Where an application is made to the Secretary of State under section  293E
instead of to the authority to whom it could otherwise have been made, a
development order may (with or without modifications) apply to the application
any enactment that relates to applications of that kind when made to that
authority.

109.2.293H.6

A development order which makes provision under this section to apply to an
application under section  293D  or  293E  (with or without modifications) any
requirement to disclose information may include provision to secure that the
requirement would not result in the public disclosure of sensitive
information.

109.2.293H.7

For the purposes of subsection  (6) , information is “sensitive” if the
Secretary of State directs that—

109.2.293H.7.a

it relates to matters of national security or measures taken or to be taken to
ensure the security of any premises or property, and

109.2.293H.7.b

its public disclosure would be contrary to the national interest.

########### Deciding applications made under section 

109.2.293I

109.2.293I.1

An application made to the Secretary of State under section  293D  or  293E
(“a direct application”) is to be determined by a person appointed by the
Secretary of State for the purpose instead of by the Secretary of State,
subject to section  293J .

109.2.293I.2

Where a person has been appointed under subsection  (1)  or this subsection to
determine a direct application then, at any time before the person has
determined the application, the Secretary of State may—

109.2.293I.2.a

revoke the person’s appointment;

109.2.293I.2.b

appoint another person to determine the application instead.

109.2.293I.3

A person appointed under this section to determine a direct application has
the same powers and duties that the Secretary of State has under section  293H
.

109.2.293I.4

Where a direct application is determined by a person appointed under this
section, the person’s decision is to be treated as that of the Secretary of
State.

109.2.293I.5

Except as provided by Part 12, the validity of that decision is not to be
questioned in any proceedings whatsoever.

109.2.293I.6

It is not a ground of application to the High Court under section 288 that a
direct application ought to have been determined by the Secretary of State and
not by a person appointed under this section unless the applicant challenges
the person’s power to determine the direct application before the person’s
decision on the direct application is given.

109.2.293I.7

Where any enactment (other than this section and section 319A)—

109.2.293I.7.a

refers (or is to be read as referring) to the Secretary of State in a context
relating to or capable of relating to a direct application (otherwise than by
referring to the application having been made to the Secretary of State), or

109.2.293I.7.b

refers (or is to be read as referring) to anything (other than the making of
the application) done or authorised or required to be done by, to or before
the Secretary of State in connection with any such application,

then, so far as the context permits, the enactment is to be read, in relation
to an application determined or to be determined by a person appointed under
this section, as if the reference to the Secretary of State were or included a
reference to that person.

########### Applications under section 

109.2.293J

109.2.293J.1

The Secretary of State may direct that an application made to the Secretary of
State under section  293D  or  293E  (“a direct application”) is to be
determined by the Secretary of State instead of by a person appointed under
section  293I .

109.2.293J.2

Where a direction is given under subsection  (1) , the Secretary of State must
serve a copy of the direction on—

109.2.293J.2.a

the person, if any, appointed under section  293I  to determine the
application concerned,

109.2.293J.2.b

the applicant, and

109.2.293J.2.c

the local planning authority.

109.2.293J.3

Where a direct application is to be determined by the Secretary of State in
consequence of a direction under subsection  (1) —

109.2.293J.3.a

in determining the application, the Secretary of State may take into account
any report made to the Secretary of State by any person previously appointed
to determine the application, and

109.2.293J.3.b

subject to that, the provisions of the planning Acts which are relevant to the
application apply to it as if section  293I  had never applied to it.

109.2.293J.4

The Secretary of State may by a further direction revoke a direction under
subsection  (1)  at any time before the determination of the direct
application concerned.

109.2.293J.5

Where a direction is given under subsection  (4) , the Secretary of State must
serve a copy of the direction on—

109.2.293J.5.a

the person, if any, previously appointed under section  293I  to determine the
application concerned,

109.2.293J.5.b

the applicant, and

109.2.293J.5.c

the local planning authority.

109.2.293J.6

Where a direction is given under subsection  (4)  in relation to a direct
application—

109.2.293J.6.a

anything done by or on behalf of the Secretary of State in connection with the
application which might have been done by a person appointed under section
293I  to determine the application is, unless the person appointed under
section  293I  to determine the application directs otherwise, to be treated
as having been done by that person, and

109.2.293J.6.b

subject to that, section  293I  applies to the application as if no direction
under subsection (1) had been given in relation to the application.

109.3

Schedule 10  contains consequential amendments.

##### Material variations in planning permission

110

110.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

110.2

After section 73A insert—

########### Applications for permission not substantially different from existing permission

110.2.73B

110.2.73B.1

An application for planning permission in respect of land in England is to be
determined in accordance with this section if the applicant—

110.2.73B.1.a

requests that it be so determined,

110.2.73B.1.b

makes a proposal as to the conditions (if any) subject to which permission
should be granted, and

110.2.73B.1.c

identifies an existing planning permission by reference to which the
application is to be considered (“the existing permission”).

110.2.73B.2

The existing permission must not have been granted—

110.2.73B.2.a

under section 73, section 73A or this section, or

110.2.73B.2.b

other than on application.

110.2.73B.3

The applicant may also identify, for the purposes of an application to be
determined in accordance with this section, a planning permission—

110.2.73B.3.a

that was granted under section 73 or this section by reference to the existing
permission, or

110.2.73B.3.b

that forms part of a sequence of planning permissions granted under section 73
or this section, the first of which was granted by reference to the existing
permission.

110.2.73B.4

A development order must set out how an applicant is to do as mentioned in
subsections  (1)  and  (3) .

110.2.73B.5

Planning permission may be granted in accordance with this section only if the
local planning authority is satisfied that its effect will not be
substantially different from that of the existing permission.

110.2.73B.6

Planning permission may not be granted in accordance with this section in a
way that differs from the existing permission as to the time by which a
condition requires—

110.2.73B.6.a

development to be started, or

110.2.73B.6.b

an application for approval of reserved matters (within the meaning of section
92) to be made.

110.2.73B.7

In determining an application in accordance with this section, the local
planning authority must limit its consideration to those respects in which the
permission being applied for would, if granted in accordance with the proposal
under subsection  (1) (b) , differ in effect from—

110.2.73B.7.a

the existing permission, and

110.2.73B.7.b

each planning permission (if any) identified in accordance with subsection
(3) .

Section 70(2) is subject to this subsection.

110.2.73B.8

If the local planning authority decides not to grant planning permission in
accordance with this section, it must refuse the application.

110.2.73B.9

For the purposes of this section, the effect of a planning permission is to be
assessed by reference to both the development it authorises and any conditions
to which it is subject.

110.2.73B.10

In assessing the effect of an existing planning permission for the purposes of
subsection  (5)  (but not for the purposes of subsection  (7) ), any change to
the permission made under section 96A is to be disregarded.

110.2.73B.11

The following provisions apply in relation to the condition under paragraph 13
of Schedule 7A (biodiversity gain condition)—

110.2.73B.11.a

nothing in this section authorises the disapplication of the condition;

110.2.73B.11.b

the condition is to be disregarded for the purposes of subsections  (1) (b) ,
(5)  and  (7) ;

110.2.73B.11.c

where—

110.2.73B.11.c.i

the existing planning permission is subject to the condition,

110.2.73B.11.c.ii

a biodiversity gain plan (“the earlier biodiversity gain plan”) was approved
for the purposes of the condition as it attaches to that permission,

110.2.73B.11.c.iii

planning permission is granted in accordance with this section, and

110.2.73B.11.c.iv

that planning permission is consistent with the post-development biodiversity
value of the onsite habitat as specified in the earlier biodiversity gain
plan,

the earlier biodiversity gain plan is to be regarded as approved for the
purposes of the condition as it attaches to the planning permission granted in
accordance with this section.

110.2.73B.12

Nothing in this section authorises the disapplication of the condition under
section 90B (condition relating to development progress reports in England).

110.2.73B.13

In relation to an application for planning permission that is made to, or is
to be determined by, the Secretary of State, a reference in this section to
the local planning authority is to be read as a reference to the Secretary of
State.

110.2.73B.14

The preceding provisions of this section apply in relation to an application
for permission in principle as if—

110.2.73B.14.a

each reference to planning permission were a reference to permission in
principle, and

110.2.73B.14.b

the provisions of this section relating to conditions were omitted.

110.2.73B.15

Permission in principle granted in accordance with this section is to be
taken, for the purposes of section 70(2ZZC), as having come into force when
the existing permission in principle identified under subsection  (1) (c)
came into force.

110.3

In section 62A (applications that may be made directly to the Secretary of
State)—

110.3.a

in subsection (2), after “73(1)” insert  “, an application that is to be
determined in accordance with section  73B ” ;

110.3.b

in subsection (3)(d), after “73(1)” insert  “nor an application that is to be
determined in accordance with section  73B ” .

110.4

In section 70A (power to decline to determine application similar to an
earlier one)—

110.4.a

in subsection (8), for “subsection (9)” substitute  “subsections (9) to (11)”
;

110.4.b

at the end insert—

110.4.b.10

An application that is to be determined in accordance with section  73B  is
not similar to an earlier application that was not determined in accordance
with that section.

110.4.b.11

An application that is to be determined in accordance with section  73B  is
similar to an earlier application that was determined in accordance with that
section only if the local planning authority think that the difference of
effect referred to in subsection  (7)  of that section is (both in kind and in
degree) the same or substantially the same in the case of both applications.

110.5

In section 70B (power to decline to determine application similar to a pending
one)—

110.5.a

in subsection (5), at the beginning insert  “Subject to subsections  (5A)  and
(5B) ,” ;

110.5.b

after subsection (5) insert—

110.5.b.5A

An application that is to be determined in accordance with section  73B  is
not similar to another application that is not to be determined in accordance
with that section.

110.5.b.5B

An application that is to be determined in accordance with section  73B  is
similar to another application that is to be determined in accordance with
that section only if the local planning authority think that the difference of
effect referred to in subsection  (7)  of that section is (both in kind and in
degree) the same or substantially the same in the case of both applications.

##### Development commencement notices

111

111.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

111.2

After section 93 insert—

########### Commencement of development: England

############ Commencement notices

111.2.93G

111.2.93G.1

This section applies where—

111.2.93G.1.a

planning permission has been granted under section 70 or 73 for the
development of any land in England, and

111.2.93G.1.b

the development is of a prescribed description.

111.2.93G.2

Before the development is begun, the person proposing to carry it out must
give a notice (a “commencement notice”) to the local planning authority
specifying the date on which the person expects the development to be begun.

111.2.93G.3

Once a person has given a commencement notice, the person—

111.2.93G.3.a

may give a further commencement notice substituting a new date for the date
previously given, and

111.2.93G.3.b

must do so if the development is not commenced on the date previously given.

111.2.93G.4

A commencement notice must—

111.2.93G.4.a

include such information as may be prescribed, and

111.2.93G.4.b

be in such form and be given in such manner as may be prescribed.

111.2.93G.5

Where it appears to the local planning authority that a person has failed to
comply with the requirements of subsection  (2)  or  (3) (b) , they may serve
a notice on any relevant person requiring the relevant person to give the
authority such of the information prescribed under subsection  (4) (a)  as the
notice may specify.

111.2.93G.6

In subsection  (5)  “ relevant person ” means—

111.2.93G.6.a

the person to whom the requirements of subsection  (2)  or  (3) (b)  applied,
and

111.2.93G.6.b

any person who is the owner or occupier of the land to which the planning
permission relates or who has any other interest in that land.

111.2.93G.7

A person on whom a notice under subsection  (5)  is served is guilty of an
offence if they fail to give the information required by the notice within the
period of 21 days beginning with the day on which it was served.

111.2.93G.8

It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection  (7)  to
prove that they had a reasonable excuse for failing to provide the information
required.

111.2.93G.9

A person guilty of an offence under subsection  (7)  is liable on summary
conviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.

111.2.93G.10

When granting planning permission under section 70 or 73 for the development
of any land in England, a local planning authority must by notice inform the
applicant of—

111.2.93G.10.a

the requirements of subsections  (2)  and  (3) (b) , and

111.2.93G.10.b

the consequences of non-compliance with those requirements.

111.3

In section 56 (time when development begins), in subsection (3), after “92,”
insert  “ 93G ,” .

111.4

In section 69 (register of applications etc)—

111.4.a

in subsection (1), after paragraph (f) (inserted by  section 114 (4) (a) )
insert—

111.4.a.g

commencement notices under section  93G .

;

111.4.b

in subsection (2), after paragraph (c) (inserted by  section 114 (4) (b) )
insert—

111.4.b.d

such information as is prescribed with respect to commencement notices under
section  93G  that are given to the local planning authority.

##### Completion notices

112

112.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

112.2

After section 93G insert—

########### Termination of planning permission: England

############ Completion notices

112.2.93H

112.2.93H.1

This section applies where—

112.2.93H.1.a

a planning permission relating to land in England is by virtue of section 91
or 92 subject to a condition that the development to which the permission
relates must begin before the expiration of a particular period, and
development has been begun within that period but has not been completed,

112.2.93H.1.b

development has begun in accordance with a simplified planning zone scheme in
England but has not been completed by the time the area ceases to be a
simplified planning zone,

112.2.93H.1.c

development has begun in accordance with planning permission under an
enterprise zone scheme in England but has not been completed by the time the
area ceases to be an enterprise zone,

112.2.93H.1.d

a planning permission under a neighbourhood development order is subject to a
condition that the development to which the permission relates must begin
before the expiration of a particular period, and development has begun within
that period but has not been completed, or

112.2.93H.1.e

a planning permission under a street vote development order is subject to a
condition that the development to which the permission relates must begin
before the expiration of a particular period, and development has begun within
that period but has not been completed.

112.2.93H.2

If the local planning authority are of the opinion that the development will
not be completed within a reasonable period, they may serve a notice (a
“completion notice”) stating that the planning permission will cease to have
effect at a specified time (the “completion notice deadline”).

112.2.93H.3

The completion notice deadline must be—

112.2.93H.3.a

at least 12 months after the completion notice was served, and

112.2.93H.3.b

if the notice was served in a case within subsection  (1) (a)  or  (d)  before
the end of the period referred to in that provision, at least 12 months after
the end of that period.

112.2.93H.4

A completion notice must include—

112.2.93H.4.a

prescribed information in relation to the right of appeal against the notice,
and

112.2.93H.4.b

any other prescribed information.

112.2.93H.5

A completion notice must be served on—

112.2.93H.5.a

the owner of the land,

112.2.93H.5.b

if different, the occupier of the land, and

112.2.93H.5.c

a person not falling within paragraph  (a)  or  (b)  with an interest in the
land, being an interest which, in the opinion of the local planning authority,
is materially affected by the notice.

112.2.93H.6

The local planning authority may withdraw a completion notice at any time
before the completion notice deadline.

112.2.93H.7

If they do so they must immediately give notice of the withdrawal to every
person who was served with the completion notice.

112.2.93H.8

If it appears to the Secretary of State to be expedient that a completion
notice should be served in respect of any land in England, the Secretary of
State may, after consulting the local planning authority, serve such a notice.

############ Appeals against completion notices

112.2.93I

112.2.93I.1

Where a completion notice is served by a local planning authority under
section  93H , any of the following may appeal to the Secretary of State
against it (whether or not the notice was served on them)—

112.2.93I.1.a

the owner of the land,

112.2.93I.1.b

a person not within paragraph  (a)  with an interest in the land, and

112.2.93I.1.c

a person who occupies the land by virtue of a licence.

112.2.93I.2

An appeal may be brought on any of the following grounds—

112.2.93I.2.a

that the appellant considers that the development will be completed within a
reasonable period;

112.2.93I.2.b

that the completion notice deadline is an unreasonable one;

112.2.93I.2.c

that the notice was not served on the persons on whom it was required to be
served under section  93H (5) .

112.2.93I.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations prescribe the procedure which is to
be followed on appeals under this section.

112.2.93I.4

The regulations may in particular include provision—

112.2.93I.4.a

as to the period within which an appeal must be brought;

112.2.93I.4.b

as to how an appeal is made;

112.2.93I.4.c

as to the information to be supplied by the appellant;

112.2.93I.4.d

as to how a local planning authority must respond to an appeal and the
information to be supplied by the authority;

112.2.93I.4.e

for the purpose of securing that the appeal is brought to the attention of
persons in the locality of the development.

112.2.93I.5

On an appeal under this section the Secretary of State may—

112.2.93I.5.a

quash the completion notice,

112.2.93I.5.b

vary the completion notice by substituting a later completion notice deadline,
or

112.2.93I.5.c

uphold the notice with the original completion notice deadline.

112.2.93I.6

On an appeal under this section the Secretary of State may also correct any
defect, error or misdescription in the completion notice if satisfied that the
correction will not cause injustice to the appellant or the local planning
authority.

112.2.93I.7

If, on an appeal made on the ground referred to in subsection  (1) (c) , the
Secretary of State determines that the completion notice was not served on a
person on whom it should have been served, the notice need not be quashed if
it appears to the Secretary of State that neither that person nor the
appellant has been substantially prejudiced by that fact.

112.2.93I.8

Subsection (5) of section 250 of the Local Government Act 1972 (which
authorises a Minister holding an inquiry under that section to make orders
with respect to the costs of the parties) applies in relation to any
proceedings before the Secretary of State on an appeal under this section as
if those proceedings were an inquiry held by the Secretary of State under
section 250.

############ Effect of completion notices

112.2.93J

112.2.93J.1

The planning permission to which a completion notice relates becomes invalid
at the completion notice deadline (whether as originally specified or
substituted on appeal under section  93I ).

112.2.93J.2

Where an appeal is brought under section  93H  the completion notice is of no
effect pending the final determination or withdrawal of the appeal.

112.2.93J.3

Subsection  (1)  does not affect any planning permission so far as relating to
development carried out under it before the completion notice deadline.

112.3

Schedule 11  contains consequential amendments.

112.4

The amendments made by this section and  Schedule 11  apply in relation to
planning permission granted before, as well as to planning permission granted
after, the coming into force of this section.

112.5

But a completion notice may not be served under section 93H of TCPA 1990 in a
case where—

112.5.a

before the coming into force of this section, a completion notice was served
under section 94(2) of TCPA 1990, and

112.5.b

that completion notice is awaiting confirmation under section 95 of TCPA 1990.

##### Power to decline to determine applications in cases of earlier non-implementation etc

113

113.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

113.2

After section 70C insert—

########### Power to decline to determine applications in cases of earlier non-implementation etc

113.2.70D

113.2.70D.1

A local planning authority in England may decline to determine an application
for planning permission for the development of any land if—

113.2.70D.1.a

the development is development of a prescribed description,

113.2.70D.1.b

the application is made by—

113.2.70D.1.b.i

a person who has previously made an application for planning permission for
development of land all or any part of which is in the local planning
authority’s area at the time the current application is made (“ the earlier
application ”), or

113.2.70D.1.b.ii

a person who has a connection of a prescribed description with the development
to which the earlier application related (“the earlier development”),

113.2.70D.1.c

the earlier development was of a description prescribed under paragraph  (a) ,
and

113.2.70D.1.d

subsection  (2)  or  (3)  applies to the earlier development.

113.2.70D.2

This subsection applies to the earlier development if the earlier development
has not begun.

113.2.70D.3

This subsection applies to the earlier development if—

113.2.70D.3.a

the earlier development has begun but has not been substantially completed,
and

113.2.70D.3.b

the local planning authority is of the opinion that the carrying out of the
earlier development has been unreasonably slow.

113.2.70D.4

In forming an opinion as to whether the carrying out of the earlier
development has been unreasonably slow, the local planning authority must have
regard to all the circumstances, including in particular—

113.2.70D.4.a

in a case where a commencement notice under section 93G has been given,
whether the development—

113.2.70D.4.a.i

was begun by the date specified in the notice, and

113.2.70D.4.a.ii

was carried out in accordance with any timescales specified in it,

113.2.70D.4.b

whether a completion notice was served in respect of the earlier development
under section 93H or (before the coming into force of section 93H) section 94
or 96 and, if so, whether the permission granted became invalid under section
93J or (as the case may be) section 95, and

113.2.70D.4.c

any prescribed circumstances.

113.2.70D.5

Where a person applies to a local planning authority for planning permission
for development of a description prescribed under subsection  (1) (a) , the
authority may by notice require the person to provide such information, being
information of a prescribed description, as the authority may specify in the
notice for the purpose of its functions under this section.

113.2.70D.6

If a person does not comply with a notice under subsection  (5)  within the
period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the notice was served, the
local planning authority may decline to determine the application.

113.2.70D.7

If a person to whom a notice under subsection  (5)  is given—

113.2.70D.7.a

makes a statement purporting to comply with the notice which the person knows
to be false or misleading in a material particular, or

113.2.70D.7.b

recklessly makes such a statement which is false or misleading in a material
particular,

the person is guilty of an offence.

113.2.70D.8

A person guilty of an offence under subsection (7) is liable on summary
conviction to a fine.

113.2.70D.9

Subsection  (1)  does not permit a local planning authority to decline to
determine an application for planning permission to which section 73, 73A or
73B applies.

113.3

In section 56 (time when development begins), in subsection (3), after “61D(5)
and (7),” insert  “70D,” .

113.4

In section 76C (provisions applying to applications under section 62A), in
subsection (1), for “70C” substitute  “70D” .

113.5

In section 78 (right to appeal), in subsection (2)(aa), after “or 70C” insert
“or 70D” .

113.6

In section 174 (appeal against enforcement notice), in subsection (2AA)(b) (as
substituted by  section 118  of this Act), for  “or 70C”  substitute “, 70C or
70D”.

##### Condition relating to development progress reports

114

114.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

114.2

In section 56(3) (time when development begun), after “89,” insert  “90B,” .

114.3

Before section 91 (including the italic heading before that section) insert—

########### Development progress reports

############ Condition relating to development progress reports in England

114.3.90B

114.3.90B.1

This section applies where relevant planning permission is granted for
relevant residential development in England.

114.3.90B.2

The relevant planning permission must be granted subject to a condition that a
development progress report must be provided to the local planning authority
in whose area the development is to be carried out for each reporting period.

114.3.90B.3

The first reporting period in relation to the development is to be a period—

114.3.90B.3.a

beginning at a prescribed time or by reference to a prescribed event, and

114.3.90B.3.b

during which the development is begun.

114.3.90B.4

A new reporting period is to begin immediately after the end of a reporting
period which is not the last reporting period.

114.3.90B.5

A reporting period which is not the last reporting period is to be a period of
12 months.

114.3.90B.6

The last reporting period is to be a period ending with the day on which the
development is completed (subject to any provision made under  subsection (9)
).

114.3.90B.7

A “ development progress report ”, in relation to relevant residential
development, means a report which sets out—

114.3.90B.7.a

the progress that has been made, and that remains to be made, towards
completing the dwellings the creation of which the development is to involve,
as at the end of the reporting period to which the report relates,

114.3.90B.7.b

the progress which is predicted to be made towards completing those dwellings
over each subsequent reporting period up to and including the last reporting
period, and

114.3.90B.7.c

such other information as may be prescribed in regulations under  subsection
(9) .

114.3.90B.8

If relevant planning permission is granted without the condition required by
subsection (2) , it is to be treated as having been granted subject to that
condition.

114.3.90B.9

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

114.3.90B.9.a

about the form and content of development progress reports;

114.3.90B.9.b

about when and how development progress reports are to be provided to local
planning authorities;

114.3.90B.9.c

about who may or must provide development progress reports to local planning
authorities;

114.3.90B.9.d

about the provision of development progress reports and other information to
local planning authorities where there is a change in circumstances in
connection with relevant residential development, such as (for example) where
the development is no longer intended to be completed in accordance with—

114.3.90B.9.d.i

the relevant planning permission;

114.3.90B.9.d.ii

a previous development progress report;

114.3.90B.9.d.iii

any timescales specified in a commencement notice given under section 93G;

114.3.90B.9.e

about when a condition under  subsection (2)  is to be treated as being
discharged;

114.3.90B.9.f

about when relevant residential development is to be treated as being
completed for the purposes of this section.

114.3.90B.10

In this section—

      “ relevant planning permission ” means planning permission other than—
planning permission granted by a development order;           planning
permission granted for development carried out before the grant of that
permission;           planning permission granted for a limited period;
planning permission granted by an enterprise zone scheme;           planning
permission granted by a simplified planning zone scheme;                 “
relevant residential development ” means development which—         involves
the creation of one or more dwellings, and           is of a prescribed
description.

114.4

114.4.a

114.4.a.f

development progress reports under section 90B;

;

114.4.b

########### Enforcement warning notice: England

##### Restriction on appeals against enforcement notices

118

In section 174 of TCPA 1990 (appeal against enforcement notice), for
subsections (2A) and (2B) substitute —

118.2A

An appeal may not be brought on the ground specified in subsection (2)(a) if—

118.2A.a

the land to which the enforcement notice relates is in England, and

118.2A.b

the enforcement notice was issued at a time after the making of an application
for planning permission that was related to the enforcement notice.

118.2AA

For the purposes of  subsection (2A) —

118.2AA.a

an application for planning permission for the development of any land is
related to an enforcement notice if granting planning permission for the
development would involve granting planning permission in respect of the
matters specified in the enforcement notice as constituting a breach of
planning control;

118.2AA.b

an application for planning permission that the local planning authority or
the Secretary of State declined to determine under section 70A, 70B or 70C is
to be ignored.

118.2AB

But  subsection (2A)  does not apply if—

118.2AB.a

the application for planning permission has ceased to be under consideration,
and

118.2AB.b

the enforcement notice was issued after the end of the period of two years
beginning with the day on which the application ceased to be under
consideration.

118.2AC

For the purposes of  subsection (2AB) , an application for planning permission
has ceased to be under consideration if—

118.2AC.a

the application was refused, or granted subject to conditions, and, in the
case of an application determined by the local planning authority, the
applicant did not appeal under section 78(1)(a);

118.2AC.b

the applicant did not appeal in the circumstances mentioned in section 78(2)
and the application was not subsequently refused;

118.2AC.c

the applicant appealed under section 78(1)(a) or section 78(2) and—

118.2AC.c.i

the appeal was dismissed,

118.2AC.c.ii

the application was on appeal granted subject to conditions, or subject to
different conditions, or

118.2AC.c.iii

the Secretary of State declined under section 79(6) to determine the appeal.

118.2B

For the purposes of  subsection (2AB) , the day on which the application
ceased to be under consideration is—

118.2B.a

in a case within  subsection (2AC) (a) , the day on which the right to appeal
arose;

118.2B.b

in a case within subsection (2AC)(b), the day after the end of the prescribed
period referred to in section 78(2);

118.2B.c

in a case within  subsection (2AC) (c) (i) , the day on which the appeal was
dismissed;

118.2B.d

in a case within  subsection (2AC) (c) (ii) , the day on which the appeal was
determined;

118.2B.e

in a case within subsection  (2AC) (c) (iii)  relating to an appeal under
section 78(1)(a), the day on which the right to appeal arose;

118.2B.f

in a case within subsection  (2AC) (c) (iii)  relating to an appeal under
section 78(2), the day after the end of the prescribed period referred to in
section 78(2).

##### Power to provide relief from enforcement of planning conditions

121

After section 196D of TCPA 1990 insert—

######### Relief from enforcement

########## Power to provide relief from enforcement of planning conditions

121.196E

121.196E.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide that a local planning
authority in England may not take, or is subject to specified restrictions in
how it may take, relevant enforcement measures in relation to any actual or
apparent failure to comply with a relevant planning condition.

121.196E.2

The Secretary of State may make regulations under subsection  (1)  only if the
Secretary of State considers that it is appropriate to make the regulations
for the purposes of national defence or preventing or responding to civil
emergency or significant disruption to the economy of the United Kingdom or
any part of the United Kingdom.

121.196E.3

The power in  subsection (1)  may only be exercised in respect of an actual or
apparent failure which occurs during a specified period of not more than one
year (the “relief period”) or which is apprehended during the relief period to
so occur (but see subsections  (7)  and  (8) ).

121.196E.4

A “relevant enforcement measure” is anything which may be done by a local
planning authority in England for the purposes of investigating, preventing,
remedying or penalising an actual or apparent failure to comply with a
relevant planning condition.

121.196E.5

A relevant enforcement measure includes, in particular—

121.196E.5.a

the exercise of a power under—

121.196E.5.a.i

section 171BA (power to apply for planning enforcement order);

121.196E.5.a.ii

section 187B (power to apply to court for injunction);

121.196E.5.a.iii

section 196A (power to enter without a warrant);

121.196E.5.a.iv

section 196B (power to apply for, and enter under, warrant);

121.196E.5.b

the issue of—

121.196E.5.b.i

a planning contravention notice under section 171C,

121.196E.5.b.ii

a temporary stop notice under section 171E,

121.196E.5.b.iii

an enforcement notice under section 172,

121.196E.5.b.iv

an enforcement warning notice under section 172ZA,

121.196E.5.b.v

a stop notice under section 183, or

121.196E.5.b.vi

a breach of condition notice under section 187A.

121.196E.6

A “relevant planning condition” is a condition or limitation subject to which
planning permission for development of land in England is granted, but does
not include a condition under—

121.196E.6.a

section 90A and Schedule 7A (condition relating to biodiversity gain);

121.196E.6.b

section 90B (condition relating to development progress reports);

121.196E.6.c

section 91 (condition limiting duration of planning permission);

121.196E.6.d

section 92 (conditions for outline planning permission).

121.196E.7

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may make provision as to the treatment of
an actual or apparent failure to comply with a relevant planning condition,
which—

121.196E.7.a

starts before, but continues after, the start of the relief period, or

121.196E.7.b

starts during, but continues after, that period.

121.196E.8

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may provide that an actual or apparent
failure to comply with a relevant planning condition is not to be treated as
occurring during the relief period, if the failure—

121.196E.8.a

occurs wholly during the period, and

121.196E.8.b

is not remedied by a specified time after the period.

121.196E.9

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may make provision that, where anything
relating to the taking of a relevant enforcement measure is to be or may be
done by a time during the relief period, it is to be or may be instead done by
a specified time after that period.

121.196E.10

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may—

121.196E.10.a

apply in relation to all, or only specified, local planning authorities in
England;

121.196E.10.b

apply in relation to all, or only specified, relevant planning conditions;

121.196E.10.c

apply in relation to all, or only specified, relevant enforcement measures;

121.196E.10.d

prevent the taking of relevant enforcement measures indefinitely or only for a
specified period of time.

121.196E.11

In this section, “ specified ” means specified or described in regulations
under  subsection (1) .

##### Powers as to form and content of planning applications

124

124.1

Before section 327A of TCPA 1990 insert—

########### Planning applications in England: powers as to form and content

124.1.327ZA

124.1.327ZA.1

Subsections  (2)  to  (3)  apply to a relevant power to make provision about—

124.1.327ZA.1.a

the form or manner in which a planning application is to be made, or

124.1.327ZA.1.b

the form or manner in which an associated document is to be provided.

124.1.327ZA.2

The power includes power to make provision requiring or allowing the
application to be made, or the associated document to be provided—

124.1.327ZA.2.a

by particular electronic means, or

124.1.327ZA.2.b

by electronic means that satisfy particular technical standards or
specifications.

124.1.327ZA.3

The power includes power to make provision requiring or allowing the authority
to which a planning application is (or is to be) made to waive a requirement
of a sort described in subsection  (2) .

124.1.327ZA.4

Subsection  (5)  applies to a relevant power to make provision about the
content of a planning application or associated document.

124.1.327ZA.5

The power includes power to make provision requiring the application or
associated document, or any particular content of it, to be prepared or
endorsed by a person with particular qualifications or experience.

124.1.327ZA.6

Subsection  (7)  applies to any power within subsection  (1)  or  (4) .

124.1.327ZA.7

The power may be exercised by making provision referring (and giving effect)
to such material of a particular description as is published from time to time
by the Secretary of State on a government website together with a statement
that it has effect for the purposes of the provision in question.

124.1.327ZA.8

Provision that may be made by virtue of subsection  (7)  includes, for
example, provision requiring or allowing a planning application to be made (or
an associated document to be provided) using such a form, or in accordance
with such specifications, as are published from time to time as mentioned in
that subsection.

124.1.327ZA.9

In this section, a “relevant power to make provision” about a certain matter
is a power of the Secretary of State under this Act to make subordinate
provision about that matter, if and so far as the power is exercisable in
relation to England.

124.1.327ZA.10

It is irrelevant for the purposes of subsection  (9)  in what terms a power is
conferred (and, in particular, whether it relates specifically to the matter
in question or is a more general power capable of exercise in relation to that
matter).

124.1.327ZA.11

In this section—

      “ associated document ” means any document or other material that—

prepared, submitted, issued, served, notified and published;           “

##### Pre-consolidation amendment of planning, development and compulsory purchase legislation

132

132.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make such amendments and
modifications of the relevant enactments as in the Secretary of State’s
opinion facilitate, or are otherwise desirable in connection with, the
consolidation of some or all of those enactments.

132.2

“ Relevant enactments ” means—

132.2.a

the enactments listed in  subsection (3) , and

132.2.b

any other enactments, whenever passed or made, so far as relating to—

132.2.b.i

planning or development, or

132.2.b.ii

the compulsory purchase of land (including compensation for such purchases).

132.3

The enactments referred to in  subsection (2) (a)  are—

      the Land Clauses Consolidation Act 1845;           the Railway Clauses
Consolidation Act 1845;           sections 9, 13, 76 and 77 of the National
Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949;           the Land Compensation
Act 1961;           the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965;           the
Agriculture Act 1967;           the Civic Amenities Act 1967;           the
Land Compensation Act 1973;           sections 13 to 16 of (and Schedule 1 to)
the Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976;           Parts 13,
14, 16 and 18 of the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980;
the Compulsory Purchase (Vesting Declarations) Act 1981;           the
Acquisition of Land Act 1981;           the New Towns Act 1981;           Part
3 of the Housing Act 1988;           TCPA 1990;           the Listed Buildings
Act;           the Hazardous Substances Act;           the Planning and
Compensation Act 1991;           Part 3 and section 96 of (and Schedule 14 to)
the Environment Act 1995;           GLAA 1999;           PCPA 2004;
the Planning Act 2008;           the Planning and Energy Act 2008;
Chapter 3 of Part 5, Part 6 and Chapter 2 of Part 8 of the Localism Act 2011;
Parts 6 and 7 of the Housing and Planning Act 2016;           section 15 of
the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017;           Parts  3  to  9  of this Act.

132.4

For the purposes of this section, “ amend ” includes repeal and revoke (and
similar terms are to be read accordingly).

132.5

Subsection  (6)  applies where, in the Secretary of State’s opinion, an
amendment or modification made by regulations under this section facilitates
or is otherwise desirable in connection with the consolidation of certain
relevant enactments.

132.6

The regulations must provide that the amendment or modification comes into
force immediately before an Act consolidating those relevant enactments comes
into force.

132.7

Regulations under this section must not make any provision which is within—

132.7.a

Scottish devolved legislative competence,

132.7.b

Welsh devolved legislative competence, or

132.7.c

Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence,

unless that provision is a restatement of provision or is merely incidental
to, or consequential on, provision that would be outside that legislative
competence.

132.8

For the purposes of  subsection (7) —

132.8.a

provision is within “Scottish devolved legislative competence” where, if it
were included in an Act of the Scottish Parliament, it would be within the
legislative competence of that Parliament;

132.8.b

provision is within “Welsh devolved legislative competence” where, if it were
included in an Act of Senedd Cymru, it would be within the legislative
competence of the Senedd (including any provision that could be made only with
the consent of a Minister of the Crown);

132.8.c

provision is within “Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence” where
the provision—

132.8.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly,
if it were included in an Act of that Assembly, and

132.8.c.ii

would not, if it were included in a Bill for an Act of the Northern Ireland
Assembly, result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State.

132.9

In this section “ Minister of the Crown ” has the same meaning as in the
Ministers of the Crown Act 1975.

##### Participation in certain proceedings conducted by, or on behalf of, the Secretary of State

133

133.1

The Secretary of State may, to the extent not otherwise able to do so, require
or permit a person who takes part in relevant proceedings conducted by the
Secretary of State to do so (wholly or partly) remotely.

133.2

The references in  subsection (1)  to the Secretary of State include
references to a person appointed by the Secretary of State.

133.3

“ Relevant proceedings ” means any inquiry, hearing, examination, meeting or
other proceedings under an Act (whenever passed or made) which relate to
planning, development or the compulsory purchase of land.

133.4

Relevant proceedings include, in particular—

133.4.a

any proceedings to which section 319A of TCPA 1990 applies (see subsections
(7) to (10) of that section);

133.4.b

any proceedings under section 20 of, or paragraph 6 of Schedule 3 to, the
Listed Buildings Act;

133.4.c

any proceedings under section 21 of, or paragraph 6 of the Schedule to, the
Hazardous Substances Act;

133.4.d

any proceedings under section 13A of, or paragraph 4A of Schedule 1 to, the
Acquisition of Land Act 1981;

133.4.e

any proceedings under Part 10A or Part 11 of the Planning Act 2008;

133.4.f

an examination under Part 2 of PCPA 2004;

133.4.g

an examination under Chapter 2 or 3 of Part 6 of the Planning Act 2008
(including any meetings under Chapter 4 of that Part) in relation to an
application for an order granting development consent;

133.4.h

an examination under Schedule 4B to the TCPA 1990 in relation to a draft
neighbourhood development order.

133.5

For the purposes of this section a person takes part in relevant proceedings
remotely if they take part through—

133.5.a

a live telephone link,

133.5.b

a live television link, or

133.5.c

any other arrangement which does not involve the person attending the
proceedings in person.

##### Power of certain bodies to charge fees for advice in relation to applications under the Planning Acts

134

After section 303ZA of the TCPA 1990 (fees for appeals) insert—

######### Power of certain bodies to charge fees for advice in relation to applications under the planning Acts

134.303ZB

134.303ZB.1

A prescribed body may charge fees for the provision of advice, information or
assistance (including the provision of a response to a consultation) in
connection with an application within  subsection (2)  that relates to land in
England.

134.303ZB.2

An application is within this subsection if it is an application, proposed
application or proposal for a permission, approval or consent under, or for
the purposes of, the planning Acts.

134.303ZB.3

A prescribed body may not charge fees under  subsection (1)  in respect of—

134.303ZB.3.a

a response to a consultation that a qualifying neighbourhood body is required
to carry out under an enactment;

134.303ZB.3.b

the provision of prescribed advice, information or assistance or advice,
information or assistance of a prescribed description.

134.303ZB.4

In subsection  (3) (a) , a “ qualifying neighbourhood body ” means—

134.303ZB.4.a

a qualifying body within the meaning given by section 61E(6) (and includes a
community organisation which is to be regarded as such a qualifying body by
virtue of paragraph 4(2) of Schedule 4C), or

134.303ZB.4.b

a qualifying body within the meaning given by section 38A(12) of the Planning
and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

134.303ZB.5

A prescribed body may charge fees under  subsection (1)  only in accordance
with a statement published on its website which—

134.303ZB.5.a

describes the advice, information or assistance in respect of which fees are
charged,

134.303ZB.5.b

sets out the fees (or, if applicable, the method by which the fees are to be
calculated), and

134.303ZB.5.c

refers to any provision in an enactment pursuant to which the advice,
information or assistance is provided.

134.303ZB.6

Subsections  (7)  and  (8)  apply where a prescribed body decides to charge
fees under  subsection (1)  for advice, information or assistance which the
body provides pursuant to a provision in an enactment.

134.303ZB.7

If a person fails to pay the fee charged under  subsection (1) , the
prescribed body may, notwithstanding any requirement to provide the advice,
information or assistance, withhold the advice, information or assistance
until the fee is paid.

134.303ZB.8

The prescribed body must secure that, taking one financial year with another,
the income from the fees charged under  subsection (1)  does not exceed the
cost of providing the advice, information or assistance.

134.303ZB.9

A financial year is the period of 12 months beginning with 1 April.

134.303ZB.10

Before making regulations under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult—

134.303ZB.10.a

any body likely to be affected by the regulations, and

134.303ZB.10.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

134.303ZB.11

In this section, “fees” include charges (however described).

##### Biodiversity net gain: pre-development biodiversity value and habitat enhancement

135

In Schedule 7A to the TCPA 1990 (biodiversity gain in England)—

135.a

in paragraph 5(4), after “6” insert  “, 6A, 6B” ;

135.b

after paragraph 6 insert—

135.b.6A

If—

135.b.6A.a

a person carries on activities on land on or after 25 August 2023 in
accordance with a planning permission (other than the planning permission
referred to in paragraph 5(1)),

135.b.6A.b

on the relevant date, development for which that other planning permission was
granted—

135.b.6A.b.i

has not been begun, or

135.b.6A.b.ii

has been begun but has not been completed, and

135.b.6A.c

as a result of the activities the biodiversity value of the onsite habitat
referred to in paragraph 5(1) is lower on the relevant date than it would
otherwise have been,

the pre-development biodiversity value of the onsite habitat is to be taken to
be its biodiversity value immediately before the carrying on of the
activities.

135.b.6B

135.b.6B.1

This paragraph applies where there is insufficient evidence of the
biodiversity value of an onsite habitat immediately before the carrying on of
the activities referred to in paragraph 6 or 6A.

135.b.6B.2

The biodiversity value of the onsite habitat immediately before the carrying
on of the activities referred to in paragraph 6 or 6A is to be taken to be the
highest biodiversity value of the onsite habitat which is reasonably supported
by any available evidence relating to the onsite habitat.

;

135.c

in paragraph 10—

135.c.i

in sub-paragraph (1), after “habitat enhancement” insert  “of an offsite
habitat” ;

135.c.ii

after sub-paragraph (1) insert—

135.c.ii.1A

For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1) (and without prejudice to paragraphs 3
and 4(1)), a habitat enhancement is calculated as the amount by which the
projected value of the offsite habitat as at the end of the maintenance period
referred to in section 100(2)(b) of the Environment Act 2021 exceeds its pre-
enhancement biodiversity value.

135.c.ii.1B

The pre-enhancement biodiversity value of an offsite habitat is the
biodiversity value of the offsite habitat on the relevant date.

135.c.ii.1C

The relevant date is—

135.c.ii.1C.a

the date on which the application is made to register the land subject to the
habitat enhancement in the biodiversity gain site register, or

135.c.ii.1C.b

such other date as may be specified in the conservation covenant or planning
obligation.

135.c.ii.1D

But if—

135.c.ii.1D.a

a person carries on activities on an offsite habitat on or after 25 August
2023 otherwise than in accordance with—

135.c.ii.1D.a.i

planning permission, or

135.c.ii.1D.a.ii

any other permission of a kind specified by the Secretary of State by
regulations, and

135.c.ii.1D.b

as a result of the activities the biodiversity value of the offsite habitat is
lower on the relevant date than it would otherwise have been,

the pre-enhancement biodiversity value of the offsite habitat is to be taken
to be its biodiversity value immediately before the carrying on of the
activities.

;

135.d

in paragraph 12(1), after the definition of “onsite habitat” insert—

      “ offsite habitat ” means habitat which is not onsite habitat.

##### Development affecting ancient woodland

136

136.1

Before the end of the period of three months beginning with the day on which
this Act is passed, the Secretary of State must vary the Town and Country
Planning (Consultation) (England) Direction 2021 (“the 2021 Direction”) so
that it applies in relation to applications for planning permission for
development affecting ancient woodland.

136.2

In subsection (1) “ ancient woodland ” means an area in England which has been
continuously wooded since at least the end of the year 1600 A.D.

136.3

This section does not affect whether or how the Secretary of State may
withdraw or vary the 2021 Direction after it has been varied as mentioned in
subsection (1).
