### Community land auction pilots

#### Community land auction arrangements

##### Community land auction arrangements and their purpose

141

141.1

In making CLA regulations the Secretary of State must aim to ensure that the
overall purpose of community land auction arrangements is to ensure that costs
incurred in—

141.1.a

supporting the development of an area, and

141.1.b

achieving any purpose specified under  section 143 (7) , section  144 (3)  or
section 145 (3) ,

can be funded (wholly or partly) by owners or developers of land.

141.2

“ CLA regulations ” means regulations made under this Part by the Secretary of
State.

141.3

A “ community land auction arrangement ” means an arrangement provided for in
CLA regulations under which—

141.3.a

a local planning authority is to invite anyone who has a freehold or leasehold
interest in land in the authority’s area to offer to grant a CLA option over
the land, with a view to the land being allocated for development in the next
local plan for the authority’s area,

141.3.b

any CLA option granted under the arrangement ceases to have effect if the land
subject to the option is not so allocated when that plan is adopted or
approved (unless the option has already been exercised or been withdrawn or
otherwise ceased to have effect), and

141.3.c

the local planning authority may—

141.3.c.i

exercise the CLA option and dispose of the interest in the land to a person
who proposes to develop the land,

141.3.c.ii

exercise the CLA option with a view to developing the land itself, or

141.3.c.iii

dispose of the CLA option to a person who proposes to exercise it and then
develop the land.

141.4

A “ CLA option ”, in relation to land, means an option to acquire a freehold
or leasehold interest in the land which—

141.4.a

subject to CLA regulations under paragraph  (c) , can be—

141.4.a.i

exercised by the local planning authority in whose area the land is situated,
or

141.4.a.ii

disposed of by that authority to any other person, on such terms as the
authority considers appropriate,

141.4.b

is granted under a community land auction arrangement, and

141.4.c

meets any requirements imposed by CLA regulations.

141.5

CLA regulations under subsection  (4) (c)  may, in particular, include
provision about—

141.5.a

how long a CLA option must be capable of being exercised for;

141.5.b

when, or the circumstances in which, a CLA option may or must be capable of
being exercised;

141.5.c

when, or the circumstances in which, a CLA option may or must cease to have
effect;

141.5.d

when, or the circumstances in which, a CLA option may or must be withdrawn;

141.5.e

when, the circumstances in which or the terms on which, a CLA option may or
must be disposed of;

141.5.f

sums that are to be paid under or in connection with a CLA option (including
provision permitting or requiring such sums to be adjusted to reflect changes
in the value of money);

141.5.g

the form and content of a CLA option.

##### Power to permit community land auction arrangements

142

142.1

This section applies where—

142.1.a

CLA regulations provide that a local planning authority which is to prepare a
local plan may put in place a community land auction arrangement in relation
to that plan,

142.1.b

the local planning authority resolves to do so (and that resolution has not
been rescinded), and

142.1.c

the community land auction arrangement has not come to an end.

142.2

The local plan may only allocate land in the authority’s area for development—

142.2.a

if the land is subject to a CLA option or a CLA option has already been
exercised in relation to it, or

142.2.b

in circumstances which are prescribed by CLA regulations.

142.3

Any financial benefit that the local planning authority has derived, or will
or could derive, from a CLA option may be taken into account—

142.3.a

in deciding whether to allocate land which is subject to the option, or in
relation to which the option has been exercised, for development in the local
plan;

142.3.b

in deciding whether the local plan is sound in an examination under Part 2 of
PCPA 2004.

142.4

CLA regulations may make provision about how, or to what extent, any financial
benefit may be taken into account under subsection  (3)  (including provision
about how any financial benefit is to be weighed against any other
considerations which may be relevant to whether the land should be allocated
for development in the local plan or to whether the plan is sound).

142.5

References in this section to a local plan do not include references to a
joint local plan (but see  section 147  in relation to the application of this
Part in relation to joint local plans).

#### CLA receipts

##### Application of CLA receipts

143

143.1

CLA regulations must require a local planning authority which receives sums
that represent financial benefit derived from CLA options over land in its
area (“CLA receipts”) to apply them, or cause them to be applied, to—

143.1.a

support the development of an area by funding the provision, improvement,
replacement, operation or maintenance of infrastructure, or

143.1.b

fund the operation of community land auction arrangements in relation to its
area.

143.2

Subsection  (1)  is subject to the following provisions of this section and
sections  144 (1)  to  (3)  and  145 (2)  and  (3) .

143.3

CLA regulations may make provision about the extent to which the CLA receipts
received by a local planning authority may or must be applied to funding the
provision, improvement, replacement, operation or maintenance of
infrastructure of a particular description.

143.4

In this section (except subsection  (6) ) and sections  144 (2) ,  145 (2)
and  146  “infrastructure” includes—

143.4.a

roads and other transport facilities,

143.4.b

flood defences,

143.4.c

schools and other educational facilities,

143.4.d

medical facilities,

143.4.e

sporting and recreational facilities,

143.4.f

open spaces, 

143.4.g

affordable housing,

143.4.h

facilities and equipment for emergency and rescue services,

143.4.i

facilities and spaces which—

143.4.i.i

preserve or improve the natural environment, or

143.4.i.ii

enable or facilitate enjoyment of the natural environment, and

143.4.j

facilities and spaces for the mitigation of, and adaptation to, climate
change.

143.5

In  subsection (4) (g)  “ affordable housing ” means—

143.5.a

social housing within the meaning of Part 2 of the Housing and Regeneration
Act 2008, and

143.5.b

any other description of housing that CLA regulations may specify.

143.6

CLA regulations may amend this section so as to—

143.6.a

add, remove or vary an entry in the list of matters included within the
meaning of “infrastructure”;

143.6.b

list matters excluded from the meaning of “infrastructure”.

143.7

CLA regulations may make provision about circumstances in which local planning
authorities may apply a specified amount of CLA receipts, or cause a specified
amount of CLA receipts to be applied, towards specified purposes which are not
mentioned in subsection  (1) .

143.8

CLA regulations may specify—

143.8.a

works, installations and other facilities whose provision, improvement or
replacement may or is to be, or may not be, funded by CLA receipts,

143.8.b

maintenance activities and operational activities (including operational
activities of a promotional kind) in connection with infrastructure that may
or are to be, or may not be, funded by CLA receipts,

143.8.c

things within  subsection (1) (b)  that may or are to be, or may not be,
funded by CLA receipts,

143.8.d

things within  section 144 (2)  that may or are to be, or may not be, funded
by CLA receipts passed to a person in discharge of a duty under  section 144
(1) ,

143.8.e

things within  section 145 (2)  that may or are to be, or may not be, funded
by CLA receipts to which provision under  section 145 (2)  relates,

143.8.f

criteria for determining the areas that may benefit from funding by CLA
receipts, and

143.8.g

what is to be, or not to be, treated as funding.

143.9

The regulations may—

143.9.a

require local planning authorities in relation to which  section 142  applies
to prepare and publish a list of what is to be, or may be, wholly or partly
funded by CLA receipts;

143.9.b

include provision about the procedure to be followed in preparing a list
(which may include provision for consultation or for the appointment of an
independent person or both);

143.9.c

include provision about the circumstances in which a local planning authority
may and may not apply CLA receipts to anything not included on the list;

143.9.d

permit or require the list to be prepared and published as part of a CLA
infrastructure delivery strategy (see  section 146 ).

143.10

In making provision about funding the regulations may, in particular—

143.10.a

permit CLA receipts to be used to reimburse expenditure already incurred;

143.10.b

permit CLA receipts to be reserved for expenditure that may be incurred in the
future;

143.10.c

permit CLA receipts to be applied (either generally or subject to limits set
by or determined in accordance with the regulations) to administrative
expenses in connection with infrastructure or anything within  section 144 (2)
(a) (ii)  or  section 145 (2) (b)  or otherwise in connection with a community
land auction arrangement;

143.10.d

include provision for the giving of loans, guarantees or indemnities;

143.10.e

make provision about the application of CLA receipts where anything to which
they were to be applied no longer requires funding.

143.11

The regulations may—

143.11.a

require a local planning authority to account separately, and in accordance
with the regulations, for CLA receipts received or due;

143.11.b

require a local planning authority to monitor the use made and to be made of
CLA receipts in its area;

143.11.c

require a local planning authority to report on actual or expected collection
and application of CLA receipts;

143.11.d

permit a local planning authority to cause money to be applied in respect of
things done outside its area;

143.11.e

permit a local planning authority or other body to spend or retain money;

143.11.f

permit a local planning authority to pass money to another body (and in
paragraphs  (a)  to  (e)  a reference to a local planning authority includes a
reference to a body to which a local planning authority passes money in
reliance on this paragraph).

143.12

For the purposes of  subsection (1)  a financial benefit is derived from a CLA
option if it arises as a consequence of the local planning authority—

143.12.a

exercising the option and developing or disposing of the land which was
subject to it, or

143.12.b

disposing of the option.

##### Duty to pass CLA receipts to other persons

144

144.1

CLA regulations may require a local planning authority that receives CLA
receipts in respect of development in an area to pass them to a person other
than the authority.

144.2

CLA regulations imposing a duty under  subsection (1)  must contain provision
to secure that any CLA receipts passed to a person in discharge of the duty
are used to—

144.2.a

support the development of the area to which the duty relates, or of any part
of that area, by funding—

144.2.a.i

the provision, improvement, replacement, operation or maintenance of
infrastructure, or

144.2.a.ii

anything else that is concerned with addressing demands that development
places on an area, or

144.2.b

fund the operation of community land auction arrangements in relation to land
in the local planning authority’s area.

144.3

CLA regulations may make provision about circumstances in which a specified
amount of the CLA receipts may be used for specified purposes which are not
mentioned in  subsection (2) .

144.4

A duty under subsection  (1)  may relate to—

144.4.a

the whole of a local planning authority’s area or the whole of the combined
area of two or more local planning authorities, or

144.4.b

part only of such an area or combined area.

144.5

CLA regulations may make provision about the persons to whom CLA receipts may
or must, or may not, be passed in discharge of a duty under subsection  (1) .

144.6

A duty under subsection  (1)  may relate—

144.6.a

to all CLA receipts (if any) received in respect of the area to which the duty
relates, or

144.6.b

such part of those CLA receipts as is specified in, or determined under or in
accordance with, CLA regulations.

144.7

CLA regulations may make provision in connection with the timing of payments
in discharge of a duty under  subsection (1) .

144.8

CLA regulations may, in relation to CLA receipts passed to a person in
discharge of a duty under  subsection (1) , make provision about—

144.8.a

accounting for the CLA receipts,

144.8.b

monitoring their use,

144.8.c

reporting on their use,

144.8.d

responsibilities of local planning authorities for things done by the person
in connection with the CLA receipts,

144.8.e

recovery of the CLA receipts, and any income or profits accruing in respect of
them or from their application, in cases where—

144.8.e.i

anything to be funded by them has not been provided, or

144.8.e.ii

they have been misapplied,

including recovery of sums or other assets representing them or any such
income or profits, and

144.8.f

use of anything recovered in cases where—

144.8.f.i

anything to be funded by the CLA receipts has not been provided, or

144.8.f.ii

the CLA receipts have been misapplied.

144.9

This section does not limit  section 143 (11) (f) .

##### Use of CLA receipts in an area to which section 

145

145.1

Subsection  (2)  applies where—

145.1.a

there is an area to which a particular duty under  section 144 (1)  relates,
and

145.1.b

there is also an area to which that duty does not relate (“the uncovered
area”).

145.2

CLA regulations may provide that the local planning authority that receives
CLA receipts in respect of development in the uncovered area may apply the CLA
receipts, or cause them to be applied, to—

145.2.a

support development by funding the provision, improvement, replacement,
operation or maintenance of infrastructure,

145.2.b

support development of the uncovered area, or of any part of that area, by
funding anything else that is concerned with addressing demands that
development places on an area, or

145.2.c

funding the operation of community land auction arrangements in relation to
the local planning authority’s area.

145.3

The regulations may make provision about circumstances in which the authority
may apply a specified amount of CLA receipts, or cause a specified amount of
CLA receipts to be applied, towards specified purposes which are not mentioned
in  subsection (2) .

145.4

Provision under subsection  (2) (a)  or  (b)  may relate to the whole, or part
only, of the uncovered area.

145.5

Provision under  subsection (2)  may relate—

145.5.a

to all CLA receipts (if any) received in respect of the area to which the
provision relates, or

145.5.b

such part of those CLA receipts as is specified in, or determined under or in
accordance with, CLA regulations.

##### CLA infrastructure delivery strategy

146

146.1

CLA regulations may require a local planning authority in relation to which
section 142  applies to prepare and publish a CLA infrastructure delivery
strategy.

146.2

A CLA infrastructure delivery strategy is a document which—

146.2.a

sets out the strategic plans (however expressed) of the local planning
authority in relation to the application of CLA receipts, and

146.2.b

includes such other information as may be prescribed by CLA regulations.

146.3

A CLA infrastructure delivery strategy may and, if required by CLA
regulations, must set out the plans (however expressed) of the local planning
authority in relation to the provision, improvement, replacement, operation
and maintenance of infrastructure in the authority’s area.

146.4

A local planning authority may at any time prepare and publish a revision to,
or replacement of, its CLA infrastructure delivery strategy.

146.5

CLA regulations may make provision for the independent examination of—

146.5.a

CLA infrastructure delivery strategies, and

146.5.b

revisions to, or replacements of, such strategies.

146.6

The regulations may make provision for an examination to be combined with—

146.6.a

an examination under Part 2 of PCPA 2004 in relation to a local plan, or

146.6.b

an examination under Part 10A of the Planning Act 2008 in relation to an
infrastructure delivery strategy under that Part.

146.7

The regulations may, in particular, make provision—

146.7.a

about who is to carry out the examination;

146.7.b

about what the examiner must, may or may not consider;

146.7.c

about the procedure to be followed;

146.7.d

about recommendations, or other consequences, arising from or in connection
with the examination;

146.7.e

about circumstances in which an examination is not required;

146.7.f

applying, or corresponding to, any provision made by or under Part 10A of the
Planning Act 2008 relating to an examination in relation to a charging
schedule or infrastructure delivery strategy under that Part (with or without
modifications).

146.8

A local planning authority which is required to prepare and publish a CLA
infrastructure delivery strategy must have regard to any guidance published by
the Secretary of State in relation to the preparation, publication, revision
or replacement of CLA infrastructure delivery strategies.

146.9

CLA regulations may make provision about—

146.9.a

the form and content of CLA infrastructure delivery strategies;

146.9.b

the publication of CLA infrastructure delivery strategies and any related
documents;

146.9.c

the procedures to be followed in relation to the preparation, revision or
replacement of CLA infrastructure delivery strategies;

146.9.d

the timing of any steps in connection with the preparation, publication,
revision or replacement of CLA infrastructure delivery strategies;

146.9.e

the evidence required to inform the preparation of CLA infrastructure delivery
strategies;

146.9.f

consultation in connection with CLA infrastructure delivery strategies;

146.9.g

the preparation of joint CLA infrastructure delivery strategies;

146.9.h

the period of time for which CLA infrastructure delivery strategies are valid.

#### General

##### Power to provide for authorities making joint local plans

147

147.1

CLA regulations may make provision applying any provision made by or under
this Part in relation to local planning authorities whose next local plan is
to be a joint local plan, with or without modifications.

147.2

Where CLA regulations make provision under subsection  (1)  which permits
local planning authorities that are to make a joint local plan to put in place
a community land auction arrangement jointly, it must include provision about
how CLA receipts deriving from that arrangement are to be shared between the
authorities.

##### Parliamentary scrutiny of pilot

148

148.1

The Secretary of State must prepare a report which—

148.1.a

assesses the effectiveness of the operation of this Part in delivering the
overall purpose mentioned in  section 141 (1) , and

148.1.b

contains such other information about, or assessments as to the effect of,
community land auction arrangements as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate.

148.2

The Secretary of State must lay the report before each House of Parliament
before the later of—

148.2.a

the end of the period of 24 months beginning with the day on which this Part
expires in accordance with  section 150 , and

148.2.b

the end of the period of 24 months beginning with the day on which the final
community land auction arrangement comes to an end.

148.3

The “ final community land auction arrangement ” means the last community land
auction arrangement to come to an end.

148.4

After the report has been laid before each House of Parliament under
subsection (2) , the Secretary of State must publish it as soon as is
reasonably practicable.

148.5

In calculating a period of 24 months mentioned in  subsection (2) , no account
is to be taken of any time during which—

148.5.a

Parliament is dissolved or prorogued, or

148.5.b

either House of Parliament is adjourned for more than 4 days.

##### CLA regulations: further provision and guidance

149

149.1

CLA regulations may make provision—

149.1.a

about the leasehold interests in relation to which a community land auction
arrangement may, may not or must be capable of applying;

149.1.b

permitting a local planning authority to exclude land from a community land
auction arrangement and disapply  section 142 (2)  in relation to that land;

149.1.c

about the procedures to be followed under, or in connection with, a community
land auction arrangement;

149.1.d

about the provision or publication of information under, or in connection
with, a community land auction arrangement;

149.1.e

about how, when or the circumstances in which anything must be done under, or
in connection with, a community land auction arrangement;

149.1.f

about the treatment of anyone who has an interest in or over land which is
subject to a CLA option;

149.1.g

about when a community land auction arrangement is to be taken to be put in
place or to come to an end;

149.1.h

about how section 106 of TCPA 1990 (planning obligations) is to be used, or is
not to be used, where  section 142  applies or has applied (including
provision about the circumstances in which a planning obligation under that
section may constitute a reason for granting planning permission);

149.1.i

about the exercise of any other power relating to planning or development;

149.1.j

about anything else relating to planning or development.

149.2

The Secretary of State may give guidance to a local planning authority or
other authority about, or in connection with, community land auction
arrangements (including guidance about how any power relating to planning or
development is to be exercised in circumstances which include, or may include,
a community land auction arrangement); and authorities must have regard to the
guidance.

149.3

Provision may be made under  subsection (1) (h)  to  (j) , and guidance may be
given under  subsection (2) , only if the Secretary of State thinks it
necessary or expedient for—

149.3.a

delivering the overall purpose mentioned in  section 141 (1) ,

149.3.b

enhancing the effectiveness, or increasing the use, of CLA regulations or
community land auction arrangements,

149.3.c

preventing agreements, undertakings or other transactions from being used to
undermine or circumvent CLA regulations or community land auction
arrangements,

149.3.d

preventing agreements, undertakings or other transactions from being used to
achieve a purpose that the Secretary of State thinks would better be achieved
through the application of CLA regulations or community land auction
arrangements, or

149.3.e

preventing or restricting the imposition of burdens, the making of agreements
or the giving of undertakings, in addition to those in connection with CLA
regulations or community land auction arrangements.

149.4

CLA regulations may—

149.4.a

confer functions on any person, including functions involving the exercise of
a discretion;

149.4.b

make consequential, supplementary or incidental provision under  section 252
(1) (c)  which disapplies, or modifies the effect of, any provision made by or
under an Act of Parliament (whenever passed or made).

##### Expiry of Part 

150

150.1

This Part, other than  section 148  and this section, expires at the end of
the period of 10 years beginning with the date on which CLA regulations are
first made.

150.2

Subsection  (1)  does not affect—

150.2.a

any community land auction arrangement which is put in place before the expiry
of this Part (whether or not it comes to an end before this Part expires);

150.2.b

any CLA option, or allocation of land for development in a local plan, that is
made under a community land auction arrangement which is put in place before
the expiry of this Part (whether or not it comes to an end before this Part
expires);

150.2.c

the treatment of any CLA receipts after the expiry of this Part.

150.3

Subsections  (1)  and  (2)  are subject to such transitional, transitory or
saving provision as may be made by CLA regulations in connection with the
expiry of this Part.

##### Interpretation of Part 5

151

In this Part—

      “ CLA option ” has the meaning given by  section 141 (4) ;           “
CLA receipts ” has the meaning given by  section 143 (1) ;           “ CLA
regulations ” has the meaning given by  section 141 (2) ;           “
community land auction arrangement ” has the meaning given by  section 141 (3)
;           “ joint local plan ” and “local plan” have the same meaning as in
Part 2 of PCPA 2004 (see, in particular, section 15LH of that Act);
“ local planning authority ” means a local planning authority for the purposes
of Part 2 of PCPA 2004 (see, in particular,  section 15LF  of that Act) other
than—         a joint committee constituted under  section 15J  of that Act,
an urban development corporation, a development corporation established under
the New Towns Act 1981 or a Mayoral development corporation, or           the
Homes and Communities Agency,         and references to the area of a local
planning authority are to the area for which the authority is the local
planning authority in accordance with Part 2 of PCPA 2004.

### Environmental outcomes reports

#### Setting environmental outcomes

##### Power to specify environmental outcomes

152

152.1

Regulations made by an appropriate authority under this Part (“ EOR
regulations ”) may specify outcomes relating to environmental protection in
the United Kingdom or a relevant offshore area that are to be “ specified
environmental outcomes ” for the purposes of this Part.

152.2

“ Environmental protection ” means—

152.2.a

protection of the natural environment, cultural heritage and the landscape
from the effects of human activity (including, amongst other things, the
protection of chalk streams from abstraction and pollution);

152.2.b

protection of people from the effects of human activity on the natural
environment, cultural heritage and the landscape;

152.2.c

maintenance, restoration or enhancement of the natural environment, cultural
heritage or the landscape;

152.2.d

monitoring, assessing, considering, advising or reporting on anything in
paragraphs  (a)  to  (c) .

152.3

The “ natural environment ” means—

152.3.a

plants, wild animals and other living organisms,

152.3.b

their habitats (including, amongst other things, chalk streams),

152.3.c

land (except buildings or other structures), air and water,

and the natural systems, cycles and processes through which they interact.

152.4

“ Cultural heritage ” means any building, structure, other feature of the
natural or built environment or site, which is of historic, architectural,
archaeological or artistic interest.

152.5

Before making any EOR regulations which contain provision about what the
specified environmental outcomes are to be, an appropriate authority must have
regard to—

152.5.a

in the case of regulations made by the Secretary of State acting alone or
jointly with a devolved authority, the current environmental improvement plan
(within the meaning of Part 1 of the Environment Act 2021),

152.5.b

in the case of regulations made by the Scottish Ministers acting alone, the
current environmental policy strategy (within the meaning of section 47 of the
UK Withdrawal from the European Union (Continuity) (Scotland) Act  2021 (asp
4) ),

152.5.c

in the case of regulations made by the Welsh Ministers acting alone, the
current national natural resources policy (within the meaning of section 9 of
the Environment (Wales) Act 2016), or

152.5.d

in the case of regulations made by a Northern Ireland department acting alone,
the current environmental improvement plan (within the meaning of Schedule 2
to the Environment Act 2021).

#### Power to require environmental outcomes reports

##### Environmental outcomes reports for relevant consents and relevant plans

153

153.1

EOR regulations may make provision requiring an environmental outcomes report
to be prepared in relation to a proposed relevant consent or a proposed
relevant plan.

153.2

Where an environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared in relation
to a proposed relevant consent—

153.2.a

the proposed relevant consent may not be given, unless an environmental
outcomes report has been prepared in relation to it, and

153.2.b

that report must be taken into account or given effect, in accordance with EOR
regulations, in determining whether and on what terms the proposed consent is
to be given.

153.3

Where an environmental outcomes report is required to be prepared in relation
to a proposed relevant plan—

153.3.a

no step may be taken which would have the effect of bringing the proposed
relevant plan into effect, unless an environmental outcomes report has been
prepared in relation to it, and

153.3.b

that report must be taken into account or given effect, in accordance with EOR
regulations, in determining whether and on what terms the proposed relevant
plan is to have effect.

153.4

An “ environmental outcomes report ”, in relation to a proposed relevant
consent or proposed relevant plan, means a written report which assesses—

153.4.a

the extent to which the proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan
would, or is likely to, impact on the delivery of specified environmental
outcomes,

153.4.b

any proposals for increasing the extent to which a specified environmental
outcome is delivered,

153.4.c

any steps that may be proposed for the purposes of—

153.4.c.i

avoiding the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered
to any extent;

153.4.c.ii

so far as the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered
to any extent cannot be avoided, mitigating those effects;

153.4.c.iii

so far as the effects of a specified environmental outcome not being delivered
to any extent cannot be avoided or mitigated, compensating for the specified
environmental outcome not being delivered, and

153.4.d

any proposals about how—

153.4.d.i

the impact of the proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan on the
delivery of a specified environmental outcome, or

153.4.d.ii

the taking of any proposed steps of the kind mentioned in  paragraph (c) ,

should be monitored or secured.

153.5

The reference in  subsection (4) (c)  to steps includes—

153.5.a

reasonable alternatives to the relevant consent, to the project to which the
relevant consent relates or to any element of either, or (as the case may be)

153.5.b

reasonable alternatives to the relevant plan or any element of it.

153.6

Subsection  (2)  does not apply in relation to a relevant consent where—

153.6.a

the requirement for the consent is imposed under  subsection (4)  of  section
154 , and

153.6.b

the consent is to be given or refused in an environmental outcomes report in
accordance with provision under  subsection (5)  of that section.

153.7

EOR regulations may include provision about or in connection with—

153.7.a

what is to be taken to constitute the giving of a relevant consent for the
purposes of  subsection (2) ;

153.7.b

the proposed relevant consents and proposed relevant plans for which an
environmental outcomes report is, or may be, required;

153.7.c

in relation to proposed relevant consents and proposed relevant plans for
which an environmental outcomes report may be required, the circumstances in
which a report is required;

153.7.d

an environmental outcomes report not needing to assess the extent to which a
proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan would, or is likely to,
impact on the delivery of a specified environmental outcome, where an adequate
assessment of the impact on delivery of the outcome has in effect already
been, or is to be, carried out in a different environmental outcomes report;

153.7.e

what proposals an environmental outcomes report may or must deal with under
subsection (4) (b) ,  (c)  and  (d) ;

153.7.f

how any of the assessments mentioned in  subsection (4)  are to be carried
out;

153.7.g

the information to be included in, and the content and form of, an
environmental outcomes report, including provision requiring, or permitting a
public authority to require, a report to deal with matters in addition to
those provided for in  subsection (4) ;

153.7.h

how, and to what extent, environmental outcomes reports are to be taken into
account or given effect by public authorities in considering, and making
decisions in relation to, relevant consents or relevant plans;

153.7.i

the carrying out of any proposals assessed in an environmental outcomes report
under  subsection (4) (b) ,  (c)  and  (d) .

#### Defining the consents and plans to which this Part applies

##### Power to define “relevant consent” and “relevant plan” etc

154

154.1

EOR regulations may provide that a consent of a description specified in the
regulations (a “category 1 consent”) is to be a “ relevant consent ” for the
purposes of this Part in all cases.

154.2

EOR regulations may provide that a consent of a description specified in the
regulations (a “category 2 consent”) is to be a “ relevant consent ” for the
purposes of this Part only if certain criteria specified in EOR regulations
are met.

154.3

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how, when and
by whom it is to be determined whether criteria are met, such that a category
2 consent is a relevant consent.

154.4

EOR regulations may impose a requirement for a consent in relation to a
project, which is to be a category 1 consent or a category 2 consent.

154.5

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how a consent
which is required under  subsection (4)  is to be given, including provision
for it to be given (or refused) by an environmental outcomes report.

154.6

“ Relevant plan ” means a plan or programme which—

154.6.a

relates, or may relate, to a project or to environmental protection in the
United Kingdom or a relevant offshore area, and

154.6.b

is specified or described in EOR regulations for the purposes of this
subsection.

154.7

References in this Part to a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant
plan include references to a proposed variation or modification of, or
revision to, a relevant consent or relevant plan (however described).

154.8

“ Consent ” means any consent, approval, permission, authorisation,
confirmation or decision (however described, given or made) that is required,
or otherwise provided for, by or under any enactment in relation to a project.

154.9

“ Project ” means a project in the United Kingdom or a relevant offshore area
involving—

154.9.a

construction, engineering, demolition, dismantling or decommissioning,

154.9.b

the installation, depositing or removal of any thing,

154.9.c

the exploitation of natural resources by any means,

154.9.d

a change in the use of land, a building or other structure, or

154.9.e

any other activity capable of affecting the natural environment, cultural
heritage or landscape.

#### Assessment and monitoring

##### Assessing and monitoring impact on outcomes etc

155

155.1

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how the
extent to which a relevant consent or relevant plan actually affects the
delivery of a specified environmental outcome is to be assessed or monitored.

155.2

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, how the
carrying out of any proposals assessed in an environmental outcomes report
under  section 153 (4) (b) ,  (c)  or  (d) , or requirements under  subsection
(3) , is to be assessed or monitored.

155.3

EOR regulations may make provision requiring action to be taken, if an
assessment or monitoring under  subsection (1)  or  (2)  determines that is
appropriate for the purposes of—

155.3.a

increasing the extent to which a specified environmental outcome is delivered,

155.3.b

mitigating or remedying the effects of a specified environmental outcome not
being delivered to any extent, or

155.3.c

compensating for a specified environmental outcome not being delivered to any
extent.

#### Safeguards, devolution and exemptions

##### Safeguards: non-regression, international obligations and public engagement

156

156.1

An appropriate authority may make EOR regulations only if satisfied that
making the regulations will not result in environmental law providing an
overall level of environmental protection that is less than that provided by
environmental law at the time this Act is passed.

156.2

EOR regulations may not contain provision that is inconsistent with the
implementation of the international obligations of the United Kingdom relating
to the assessment of the environmental impact of relevant plans and relevant
consents.

156.3

In exercising functions under this Part, an appropriate authority must seek to
ensure that (so far as would not otherwise be the case) arrangements will
exist under which the public will be informed of any proposed relevant consent
or proposed relevant plan in sufficient detail, and at a sufficiently early
stage, to enable adequate public engagement to take place.

156.4

In this section—

      “ adequate public engagement ” means such engagement with the public, in
relation to a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan, as the
appropriate authority considers appropriate;           “ environmental law ”
means environmental law (within the meaning of Part 1 of the Environment Act
2021 but disregarding section 46(3) and (4) of that Act), whether or not the
environmental law is in force.

##### Requirements to consult devolved administrations

157

157.1

The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision—

157.1.a

within Scottish devolved legislative competence, or

157.1.b

which could be made by the Scottish Ministers,

with the consent of the Scottish Ministers, unless that provision is merely
incidental to, or consequential on, provision that would be outside that
devolved legislative competence.

157.2

The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision
that confers a function on, or modifies or removes a function of, the Scottish
Ministers after consulting the Scottish Ministers, unless—

157.2.a

that provision is contained in regulations which require the consent of the
Scottish Ministers by virtue of subsection (1), or

157.2.b

that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that
would be outside Scottish devolved legislative competence.

157.3

Provision is “within Scottish devolved legislative competence” where, if the
provision were included in an Act of the Scottish Parliament, it would be
within the legislative competence of that Parliament.

157.4

The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision
within Welsh devolved legislative competence with the consent of the Welsh
Ministers, unless that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on,
provision that would be outside that devolved legislative competence.

157.5

The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision
that could be made by the Welsh Ministers or that confers a function on, or
modifies or removes a function of, the Welsh Ministers or a devolved Welsh
authority after consulting the Welsh Ministers, unless—

157.5.a

that provision is contained in regulations which require the consent of the
Welsh Ministers by virtue of subsection  (4) , or

157.5.b

that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that
would be outside Welsh devolved legislative competence.

157.6

“ Devolved Welsh authority ” has the same meaning as in the Government of
Wales Act 2006 (see section 157A of that Act).

157.7

Provision is “within Welsh devolved legislative competence” where, if the
provision were included in an Act of Senedd Cymru, it would be within the
legislative competence of the Senedd (including any provision that could be
made only with the consent of a Minister of the Crown).

157.8

The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision
within Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence with the consent of
the relevant Northern Ireland department, unless that provision is merely
incidental to, or consequential on, provision that would be outside that
devolved legislative competence.

157.9

The Secretary of State may only make EOR regulations which contain provision
that could be made by a Northern Ireland department or that confers a function
on, or modifies or removes a function of, a Northern Ireland department after
consulting the relevant Northern Ireland department, unless—

157.9.a

that provision is contained in regulations which require the consent of the
relevant Northern Ireland department by virtue of subsection  (8) , or

157.9.b

that provision is merely incidental to, or consequential on, provision that
would be outside Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence.

157.10

The “relevant Northern Ireland department” is such Northern Ireland department
as the Secretary of State considers appropriate having regard to the provision
which is to be contained in the regulations concerned.

157.11

Provision is within “Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence” where
the provision—

157.11.a

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly,
if contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

157.11.b

would not, if contained in a Bill for an Act of the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State.

157.12

In this section “ Minister of the Crown ” has the same meaning as in the
Ministers of the Crown Act 1975.

##### EOR regulations: devolved authorities

158

Schedule 13  contains restrictions on the exercise of the powers under this
Part by devolved authorities.

##### Exemptions for national defence and civil emergency etc

159

159.1

The Secretary of State may direct that no environmental outcomes report is
required to be prepared in relation to a proposed relevant consent which is
solely for the purposes of national defence or preventing or responding to
civil emergency.

159.2

EOR regulations may provide for further circumstances in which the Secretary
of State is to be able to direct that no environmental outcomes report is
required to be prepared.

159.3

A direction under this section may provide that provision in EOR regulations
specified in the direction applies (subject to any modifications specified in
the direction), despite the fact that no environmental outcomes report is
required to be prepared.

159.4

The Secretary of State may modify or revoke a direction under this section.

#### Enforcement

##### Enforcement

160

160.1

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, the
enforcement of requirements imposed by or under this Part.

160.2

EOR regulations under this section may, in particular, include provision—

160.2.a

creating a criminal offence (but may not create a criminal offence punishable
with imprisonment);

160.2.b

conferring a power on any court or tribunal;

160.2.c

for the imposition of civil sanctions and appeals against such sanctions;

160.2.d

conferring a power of entry (whether or not on the authority of a warrant);

160.2.e

conferring a power of inspection, search, seizure or detention (whether or not
on the authority of a warrant);

160.2.f

authorising, or making provision for the authorisation of, the use of
reasonable force in connection with a power mentioned in paragraph  (d)  or
(e) ;

160.2.g

applying, or corresponding to, any provision, made by or under any enactment,
relating to enforcement in connection with a category 1 consent or a category
2 consent (with or without modifications).

160.3

EOR regulations under  subsection (2) (c)  may make provision for the
imposition of civil sanctions whether or not the conduct in respect of which
the sanction is imposed constitutes an offence.

160.4

In this section “ civil sanction ” means a sanction of a kind for which
provision may be made under Part 3 of the Regulatory Enforcement and Sanctions
Act 2008 (fixed monetary penalties, discretionary requirements, stop notices,
enforcement undertakings).

#### Reporting

##### Reporting

161

161.1

EOR regulations may make provision requiring a public authority to report on,
or provide information in relation to, the delivery of specified environmental
outcomes.

161.2

EOR regulations may, in particular, include provision about or in connection
with—

161.2.a

the information to be included in, and the content and form of, a report
required under  subsection (1) ;

161.2.b

the content and form of information required to be provided under  subsection
(1) ;

161.2.c

when, or the circumstances in which, the information or report must be
provided;

161.2.d

the publication of the information or report;

161.2.e

who the information or report is to be provided to;

161.2.f

a report being combined with another document which is to be prepared under
any enactment.

#### General

##### Public consultation etc

162

162.1

An appropriate authority must consult the public before making EOR regulations
which contain provision—

162.1.a

under  section 152 (1)  (specified environmental outcomes);

162.1.b

amending, repealing or revoking relevant existing environmental assessment
legislation.

162.2

An appropriate authority must consult such persons as the appropriate
authority considers appropriate—

162.2.a

before making EOR regulations which contain provision under—

162.2.a.i

section 154 (1)  to  (6)  (consents and plans subject to this Part);

162.2.a.ii

section 159 (2)  (power to provide for further exemptions by Secretary of
State direction);

162.2.a.iii

section 160  (enforcement);

162.2.a.iv

section 164  (interaction with existing environmental assessment legislation
and the Habitats Regulations);

162.2.b

before issuing, modifying or withdrawing any guidance under section  163 ,
which relates to—

162.2.b.i

how the likely impact of a proposed relevant consent or proposed relevant plan
on the delivery of a specified environmental outcome should be assessed, or

162.2.b.ii

how the extent to which a relevant consent or relevant plan actually affects
the delivery of a specified environmental outcome should be assessed or
monitored.

162.3

EOR regulations may require a public authority to respond, or to respond in a
particular way or by a particular time, to a consultation under  subsection
(1)  or  (2) .

162.4

The requirements to consult in subsections  (1)  and  (2)  may be met by
consultation carried out before the subsection concerned comes into force.

##### Guidance

163

163.1

A public authority carrying out a function under this Part, other than under
regulations made by a devolved authority acting alone, must have regard to any
guidance issued by the Secretary of State in relation to the function.

163.2

A public authority carrying out a function under regulations made under this
Part by the Secretary of State acting jointly with one or more devolved
authorities must have regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State
or any of those devolved authorities in relation to the function.

163.3

Before issuing guidance under subsection  (2) —

163.3.a

the Secretary of State must—

163.3.a.i

obtain the consent of the Scottish Ministers so far as the guidance relates to
a matter provision about which would be within Scottish devolved legislative
competence by virtue of section  157 (3)  or which could be made by the
Scottish Ministers;

163.3.a.ii

obtain the consent of the Welsh Ministers so far as the guidance relates to a
matter provision about which would be within Welsh devolved legislative
competence (see section  157 (7) );

163.3.a.iii

obtain the consent of the relevant Northern Ireland department so far as the
guidance relates to a matter provision about which would be within Northern
Ireland devolved legislative competence (see section  157 (11) );

163.3.b

the Scottish Ministers must obtain the consent of the Secretary of State so
far as the guidance relates to a matter provision about which would not be
within Scottish devolved legislative competence by virtue of section  157 (3)
or which could not be made by the Scottish Ministers;

163.3.c

the Welsh Ministers must obtain the consent of the Secretary of State so far
as the guidance relates to a matter provision about which would be outside
Welsh devolved legislative competence (see section  157 (7) );

163.3.d

a Northern Ireland department must obtain the consent of the Secretary of
State so far as the guidance relates to a matter provision about which would
be outside Northern Ireland devolved legislative competence (see section  157
(11) ).

163.4

The “relevant Northern Ireland department” is such Northern Ireland department
as the Secretary of State considers appropriate having regard to the material
which is to be contained in the guidance concerned.

163.5

A public authority carrying out a function under regulations made under this
Part by a devolved authority acting alone must have regard to any guidance
issued by the devolved authority in relation to the function.

163.6

A public authority carrying out a function under existing environmental
assessment legislation listed in  Part 1  of  Schedule 14  (other than a
function under Schedule 3 to the Harbours Act 1964 so far as relating to
environmental impact assessments in Scotland) must have regard to any guidance
issued by the Secretary of State in relation to the function.

163.7

A public authority carrying out a function under existing environmental
assessment legislation listed in  Part 2  of  Schedule 14  must have regard to
any guidance issued by the Scottish Ministers in relation to the function.

163.8

A public authority carrying out a function under existing environmental
assessment legislation listed in  Part 3  of  Schedule 14  must have regard to
any guidance issued by the Welsh Ministers in relation to the function.

163.9

A public authority carrying out a function under existing environmental
assessment legislation listed in  Part 4  of  Schedule 14  must have regard to
any guidance issued by a Northern Ireland department in relation to the
function.

163.10

EOR regulations may require any person carrying out a function under EOR
regulations to have regard to guidance issued by an appropriate authority in
relation to the function, failing which the function is not to be regarded as
having been validly carried out.

##### Interaction with existing environmental assessment legislation and the Habitats Regulations

164

164.1

EOR regulations may make provision about, or in connection with, the
interaction of this Part with existing environmental assessment legislation or
the Habitats Regulations.

164.2

EOR regulations under this section may, in particular, include provision—

164.2.a

treating anything done, or omitted to be done, in relation to an environmental
outcomes report as satisfying or failing to satisfy a requirement under
relevant existing environmental assessment legislation or the relevant
Habitats Regulations;

164.2.b

treating anything done, or omitted to be done, under existing environmental
assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations as satisfying or failing to
satisfy a requirement imposed by or under this Part;

164.2.c

about the co-ordination of things done under this Part and things done under
existing environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations;

164.2.d

disapplying or otherwise modifying any provision of relevant existing
environmental assessment legislation or the relevant Habitats Regulations
where preparation of an environmental outcomes report is required under this
Part;

164.2.e

disapplying or otherwise modifying any provision of this Part or EOR
regulations where something is done, or required to be done, under existing
environmental assessment legislation or the Habitats Regulations.

164.3

EOR regulations under this section may amend, repeal or revoke relevant
existing environmental assessment legislation.

164.4

In this section—

      “ the Habitats Regulations ” means—         regulation 5 of the Offshore
Petroleum Activities (Conservation of Habitats) Regulations 2001 ( S.I.
2001/1754 );           regulation 24 and Part 6 of the Conservation of
Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 );
regulations 27 to 37 of the Conservation of Offshore Marine Habitats and
Species Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1013 );           the Conservation
(Natural Habitats, &c.) Regulations 1994 ( S.I. 1994/2716 );           the
Conservation (Natural Habitats, etc.) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1995 (
S.R. (N.I.) 1995/380 );                 “ the relevant Habitats Regulations ”
means—         in relation to EOR regulations made by the Secretary of State
acting alone or jointly with one or more devolved authorities, the legislation
listed in the definition of “the Habitats Regulations”;           in relation
to EOR regulations made by the Scottish Ministers acting alone, the
legislation listed in paragraph (d) of that definition;           in relation
to EOR regulations made by the Welsh Ministers acting alone, the legislation
listed in the definition of “the Habitats Regulations” so far as it applies in
relation to Wales;           in relation to EOR regulations made by a Northern
Ireland department acting alone, the legislation listed in paragraph (e) of
that definition.

165

165.1

TCPA 1990 is amended as follows.

Omit section 71A (assessment of environmental effects).
