In section 293A (urgent Crown development: application), in subsection (4),
omit paragraph (a).

##### EOR regulations: further provision

166

166.1

EOR regulations may make provision about or in connection with—

166.1.a

the procedure to be followed in relation to anything done under this Part,
including the time by which anything must be done;

166.1.b

who is to prepare an environmental outcomes report, including provision
permitting a public authority to determine who is to do so or the
qualifications or experience a person must have to do so;

166.1.c

requiring a public authority to assist with any assessment or monitoring under
this Part;

166.1.d

the publication of, and consultation and public engagement in connection with,
environmental outcomes reports and other relevant documents;

166.1.e

the information to be included in, and the content and form of, any relevant
document;

166.1.f

the persons to whom an environmental outcomes report or other relevant
document is to be given, and how it is to be given;

166.1.g

the collection or provision of information in connection with this Part;

166.1.h

the rejection of a relevant document, or information provided in connection
with this Part, if it is not provided in accordance with  Chapter 1  of  Part
3  (planning data), including provision requiring a document or information to
be rejected;

166.1.i

how, and to what extent, any failure to comply with a requirement imposed by
or under this Part is to be taken into account by public authorities in
considering, and making decisions in relation to, relevant consents or
relevant plans;

166.1.j

appeals against, or reviews of, decisions of a public authority about matters
for, or in respect of, which provision is made by EOR regulations or existing
environmental assessment legislation.

166.2

EOR regulations may—

166.2.a

provide for the charging of fees or other charges;

166.2.b

confer a function, including a function involving the exercise of a
discretion, on any person;

166.2.c

make consequential, supplementary or incidental provision under  section 252
(1) (c)  which amends, repeals or revokes any legislation (whenever passed or
made).

166.3

In  subsection (2) (c)  “ legislation ” means any provision made by or under—

166.3.a

an Act,

166.3.b

an Act or Measure of Senedd Cymru,

166.3.c

an Act of the Scottish Parliament,

166.3.d

Northern Ireland legislation, or

166.3.e

  assimilated direct legislation .

##### Interpretation of 

167

167.1

“ Existing environmental assessment legislation ” means the legislation listed
in  Schedule 14 .

167.2

“ Relevant existing environmental assessment legislation ” means—

167.2.a

in relation to EOR regulations made by the Secretary of State acting alone or
jointly with one or more devolved authorities, the legislation listed in
Schedule 14 ;

167.2.b

in relation to EOR regulations made by the Scottish Ministers acting alone,
the legislation listed in  Part 2  of that Schedule;

167.2.c

in relation to EOR regulations made by the Welsh Ministers acting alone, the
legislation listed in  Part 3  of that Schedule;

167.2.d

in relation to EOR regulations made by a Northern Ireland department acting
alone, the legislation listed in  Part 4  of that Schedule.

167.3

In this Part—

      “ appropriate authority ” means—         the Secretary of State,
a devolved authority, or           the Secretary of State acting jointly with
one or more devolved authorities;                 “ category 1 consent ” and
“category 2 consent” have the meaning given by  section 154 (1)  and  (2) ;
“ cultural heritage ” has the meaning given by  section 152 (4) ;           “
devolved authority ” means—         the Scottish Ministers,           the
Welsh Ministers, or           a Northern Ireland department;                 “
environmental outcomes report ” has the meaning given by  section 153 (4) ;
“ environmental protection ” has the meaning given by  section 152 (2) ;
“ EOR regulations ” has the meaning given by  section 152 (1) ;           “
existing environmental assessment legislation ” has the meaning given by
subsection (1) ;           “ natural environment ” has the meaning given by
section 152 (3) ;           “ project ” has the meaning given by  section 154
(9) ;           “ proposed ”, in relation to a relevant consent or relevant
plan, is to be construed in accordance with  section 154 (7) ;           “
public authority ” means—         any person with functions under, or
functions in respect of which provision is made by, existing environmental
assessment legislation when this Act is passed;           any public authority
within the meaning of section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998, other than a
court or tribunal;                 “ relevant consent ” has the meaning given
by  section 154 ;           “ relevant document ” means a document or
information for, or in respect of, which provision is made by EOR regulations
or existing environmental assessment legislation;           “ relevant
existing environmental assessment legislation ” has the meaning given by
subsection  (2) ;           “ relevant offshore area ” means any area in—
the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom,           any area
designated by Order in Council under section 1(7) of the Continental Shelf Act
1964, or           any area designated by Order in Council under section 41(3)
of the Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009;                 “ relevant plan ”
has the meaning given by  section 154 (6) ;           “ specified
environmental outcome ” has the meaning given by  section 152 (1) .

### Nutrient pollution standards

#### Nutrient pollution standards to apply to certain sewage disposal works

168

168.1

After section 96A of the Water Industry Act 1991 insert—

########## Nutrient pollution standards to apply to certain sewage disposal works

168.1.96B

168.1.96B.1

A sewerage undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England must—

168.1.96B.1.a

in the case of each nitrogen significant plant comprised in its sewerage
system—

168.1.96B.1.a.i

secure that, by the upgrade date, the plant will be able to meet the nitrogen
nutrient pollution standard, and

168.1.96B.1.a.ii

on and after the upgrade date, secure that the plant meets that standard;

168.1.96B.1.b

in the case of each phosphorus significant plant comprised in its sewerage
system—

168.1.96B.1.b.i

secure that, by the upgrade date, the plant will be able to meet the
phosphorus nutrient pollution standard, and

168.1.96B.1.b.ii

on and after the upgrade date, secure that the plant meets that standard.

168.1.96B.2

In carrying out the duty under subsection  (1) , a sewerage undertaker must
consider whether nature-based solutions, technologies and facilities relating
to sewerage and water could be used to meet the standard.

168.1.96B.3

“ Nitrogen significant plant ” means a plant in England that—

168.1.96B.3.a

discharges treated effluent into a nitrogen sensitive catchment area, and

168.1.96B.3.b

is not an exempt plant in relation to the nitrogen nutrient pollution
standard.

168.1.96B.4

“ Phosphorus significant plant ” means a plant in England that—

168.1.96B.4.a

discharges treated effluent into a phosphorus sensitive catchment area, and

168.1.96B.4.b

is not an exempt plant in relation to the phosphorus nutrient pollution
standard.

########## Sensitive catchment areas

168.1.96C

168.1.96C.1

Where the Secretary of State considers that a habitats site that is wholly or
partly in England is in an unfavourable condition by virtue of pollution from
nutrients in water comprising nitrogen or compounds of nitrogen, the Secretary
of State may designate the catchment area for the habitats site as a nitrogen
sensitive catchment area.

168.1.96C.2

Where the Secretary of State considers that a habitats site that is wholly or
partly in England is in an unfavourable condition by virtue of pollution from
nutrients in water comprising phosphorus or compounds of phosphorus, the
Secretary of State may designate the catchment area for the habitats site as a
phosphorus sensitive catchment area.

168.1.96C.3

In determining—

168.1.96C.3.a

whether a habitats site is in an unfavourable condition by virtue of pollution
from nutrients comprising nitrogen, phosphorus or compounds of nitrogen or
phosphorus,

168.1.96C.3.b

the catchment area for a habitats site, or

168.1.96C.3.c

whether to exercise the power in subsection  (4) (e) ,

the Secretary of State may take into account, in particular, advice from, or
guidance published by, Natural England, the Environment Agency or the Joint
Nature Conservation Committee.

168.1.96C.4

A designation under subsection  (1)  or  (2) —

168.1.96C.4.a

must be in writing,

168.1.96C.4.b

must be published as soon as practicable after being made,

168.1.96C.4.c

takes effect—

168.1.96C.4.c.i

on the day specified in the designation, or

168.1.96C.4.c.ii

if none is specified, on the day on which it is made,

(the “designation date”),

168.1.96C.4.d

if it takes effect after the end of the initial period, must specify the
upgrade date (see section  96E (1) (b) ), and

168.1.96C.4.e

may specify the concentration that applies to a plant (which discharges into
the catchment area) in relation to a nutrient pollution standard instead of
the standard concentration.

168.1.96C.5

A date specified under subsection  (4) (d)  as the upgrade date must be at
least 7 years after the designation date.

168.1.96C.6

Before specifying a concentration under subsection  (4) (e) , the Secretary of
State must consult the Environment Agency.

168.1.96C.7

A concentration specified under subsection  (4) (e)  ceases to have effect if,
after the day on which the designation is made, the plant becomes an exempt
plant.

168.1.96C.8

A designation under this section may not be revoked; and it is immaterial for
the purposes of the continued designation of an area whether subsection  (1)
or  (2)  continues to be satisfied in relation to it.

168.1.96C.9

In this section “ catchment area ”, in relation to a habitats site, means the
area where water, if released, would drain into the site.

########## Exempt sewage disposal works

168.1.96D

168.1.96D.1

A plant is exempt in relation to a nutrient pollution standard if—

168.1.96D.1.a

it has a capacity of less than a population equivalent of 2000 when the
designation of the associated catchment area takes effect,

168.1.96D.1.b

it has been designated by the Secretary of State as exempt in relation to the
standard, or

168.1.96D.1.c

it is exempt in relation to the standard under regulations under subsection
(8) .

This is subject to subsection  (2) .

168.1.96D.2

The Secretary of State may designate a plant as not being exempt in relation
to a nutrient pollution standard, unless—

168.1.96D.2.a

the plant has a capacity of less than a population equivalent of 250, and

168.1.96D.2.b

the designation takes effect after the designation of the associated catchment
area takes effect.

168.1.96D.3

A designation under subsection  (1) (b)  or  (2) —

168.1.96D.3.a

must be in writing,

168.1.96D.3.b

must be published as soon as practicable after being made, and

168.1.96D.3.c

takes effect—

168.1.96D.3.c.i

on the day specified in the designation, or

168.1.96D.3.c.ii

if none is specified, on the day on which it is made.

168.1.96D.4

A designation under subsection  (2)  that takes effect after the designation
of the associated catchment area takes effect must specify the upgrade date
(see section  96E (2) (a) ).

The upgrade date must be at least 7 years after the designation under
subsection  (2)  takes effect.

168.1.96D.5

A designation under subsection  (2)  may specify the concentration that
applies to a plant in relation to a nutrient pollution standard instead of the
standard concentration.

168.1.96D.6

Before specifying a concentration under subsection  (5) , the Secretary of
State must consult the Environment Agency.

168.1.96D.7

A concentration specified under subsection  (5)  ceases to have effect if,
after the day on which the designation is made, the plant again becomes an
exempt plant.

168.1.96D.8

The Secretary of State may by regulations specify plants or descriptions of
plant that are to be exempt in relation to a nutrient pollution standard.

168.1.96D.9

Subsections  (10)  and  (11)  apply where a plant that is exempt under
regulations under subsection  (8)  can, by virtue of the regulations, cease to
be exempt.

168.1.96D.10

The regulations must specify or provide for determining the upgrade date (see
section  96E (2) (b) ) in relation to any plant that ceases, by virtue of the
regulations, to be an exempt plant in relation to a standard after the
designation of the associated catchment area takes effect.

The upgrade date must be at least 7 years after the plant ceases to be exempt
in relation to the standard.

168.1.96D.11

The regulations may provide for the Secretary of State to specify the
concentration that applies to a plant that ceases, by virtue of the
regulations, to be an exempt plant in relation to a nutrient pollution
standard instead of the standard concentration; and, if such provision is
made, the regulations must—

168.1.96D.11.a

require that the Secretary of State consult the Environment Agency before
specifying a concentration;

168.1.96D.11.b

provide for any specified concentration to cease to have effect if, after the
day on which the plant ceases to be an exempt plant, the plant again becomes
an exempt plant.

168.1.96D.12

A designation under subsection  (2)  in relation to a plant and a nutrient
pollution standard is of no effect if the plant ceases, by virtue of
regulations under subsection  (8) , to be exempt in relation to the standard
before, or at the same time as, the designation would otherwise take effect.

168.1.96D.13

In this section “ population equivalent ” has the meaning given by regulation
2(1) of the Urban Waste Water Treatment (England and Wales) Regulations 1994 (
S.I. 1994/2841 ).

168.1.96D.14

References in this section to the designation of an associated catchment area
are to its designation as a sensitive catchment area.

########## Upgrade date

168.1.96E

168.1.96E.1

The upgrade date, in relation to a nutrient significant plant, is, unless
subsection  (2)  or  (3)  applies—

168.1.96E.1.a

1 April 2030, if the designation of the associated catchment area takes effect
during the initial period;

168.1.96E.1.b

the date specified under section  96C (4) (d) , if the designation of the
associated catchment area takes effect after the end of the initial period.

168.1.96E.2

But, if the plant becomes a nutrient significant plant after the designation
of the associated catchment area takes effect, the upgrade date is—

168.1.96E.2.a

the date specified under section  96D (4) , where it becomes a nutrient
significant plant by virtue of a designation under section  96D (2) ;

168.1.96E.2.b

the date specified by or determined under provision made by virtue of section
96D (10) , where it becomes a nutrient significant plant on ceasing, by virtue
of regulations under section  96D (8) , to be exempt.

168.1.96E.3

Where the associated catchment area has ceased to be a catchment permitting
area and a date has been specified under section  96H (4) (c) , that date is
the upgrade date.

168.1.96E.4

“ The initial period ” means the period of 3 months beginning with the date on
which the Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023 is passed.

168.1.96E.5

References in this section to the designation of an associated catchment area
are to its designation as a sensitive catchment area.

########## Nutrient pollution standards

168.1.96F

168.1.96F.1

A nitrogen significant plant meets the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard
if—

168.1.96F.1.a

where the associated catchment area is not a catchment permitting area (see
section  96G ), the concentration of total nitrogen in treated effluent that
the plant discharges is not more than—

168.1.96F.1.a.i

10 mg/l, or

168.1.96F.1.a.ii

where a different concentration applies to the plant under section  96C (4)
(e)  or  96D (5)  or by virtue of regulations made under section  96D (11) ,
that concentration;

168.1.96F.1.b

where the associated catchment area is a catchment permitting area, the
sewerage undertaker is complying with any condition in the environmental
permit for the plant imposed in pursuance of section  96G (3) (b) .

168.1.96F.2

A phosphorus significant plant meets the phosphorus nutrient pollution
standard if—

168.1.96F.2.a

where the associated catchment area is not a catchment permitting area, the
concentration of total phosphorus in treated effluent that the plant
discharges is not more than—

168.1.96F.2.a.i

0.25 mg/l, or

168.1.96F.2.a.ii

where a different concentration applies to the plant under section  96C (4)
(e)  or  96D (5)  or by virtue of regulations made under section  96D (11) ,
that concentration;

168.1.96F.2.b

where the associated catchment area is a catchment permitting area, the
sewerage undertaker is complying with any condition in the environmental
permit for the plant imposed in pursuance of section  96G (3) (b) .

168.1.96F.3

“ Treated effluent ”, in relation to a plant, means any effluent discharged by
the plant, other than anything discharged—

168.1.96F.3.a

from a storm overflow, or

168.1.96F.3.b

by an emergency discharge.

168.1.96F.4

For the purposes of subsection  (3) , in relation to a plant—

168.1.96F.4.a

“ storm overflow ” means any structure or apparatus comprised in the plant
which, when the capacity of relevant parts of the sewerage system is exceeded,
relieves them by discharging the excess contents into inland waters,
underground strata or the sea, where—

      “ relevant parts of the sewerage system ” means—         storage tanks
at the plant, and           other parts of the sewerage system downstream of
the plant;                 “ the sewerage system ” means the undertaker’s
sewerage system of which the plant forms part;

168.1.96F.4.b

“ emergency discharge ” means a discharge in circumstances where the plant’s
normal treatment process has failed because of—

168.1.96F.4.b.i

electrical power failure, or

168.1.96F.4.b.ii

mechanical breakdown of duty and standby pumps.

168.1.96F.5

Regulations made by the Secretary of State may specify how the concentration
of total nitrogen or concentration of total phosphorus in treated effluent is
to be determined.

168.1.96F.6

Regulations under subsection  (5)  may, in particular—

168.1.96F.6.a

make provision for requiring regular sampling of the treated effluent that a
plant discharges to ascertain the concentration of total nitrogen or
concentration of total phosphorus;

168.1.96F.6.b

make provision for regarding a nutrient pollution standard as being met by a
plant if, for example—

168.1.96F.6.b.i

it is met, with at least the frequency specified in the regulations, in
samples taken in accordance with the regulations, or

168.1.96F.6.b.ii

the average concentration, calculated in accordance with the regulations, of
total nitrogen or of total phosphorus in samples taken in accordance with the
regulations would meet the standard;

168.1.96F.6.c

make provision for determining generally, or in a particular case, whether
anything is, or is not, to be regarded as treated effluent discharged by a
plant;

168.1.96F.6.d

make provision in relation to section  96G , including—

168.1.96F.6.d.i

the determination of compliance with conditions in environmental permits
imposed in pursuance of section  96G (3) (b) ;

168.1.96F.6.d.ii

in connection with any kind of plant;

168.1.96F.6.e

confer any function on the Secretary of State, the Authority, the Environment
Agency, statutory undertakers or any other person;

168.1.96F.6.f

make different provision for different purposes or different areas (including
different plants within an area).

########## Nutrient pollution standards determined through environmental permitting

168.1.96G

168.1.96G.1

The Secretary of State may designate a sensitive catchment area as a catchment
permitting area.

168.1.96G.2

In determining whether to make a designation under  subsection (1)  or to
revoke such a designation under section  96H (3) (c) , the Secretary of State
may take into account, in particular, advice from, or guidance published by,
the Environment Agency or Natural England.

168.1.96G.3

Where the Secretary of State makes a designation under subsection  (1) , the
Environment Agency must—

168.1.96G.3.a

review the environmental permits for the plants that discharge treated
effluent into the catchment permitting area that are—

168.1.96G.3.a.i

nutrient significant plants, and

168.1.96G.3.a.ii

such other plants that the Environment Agency considers appropriate (including
such plants within an area that may be determined by the Environment Agency),
and

168.1.96G.3.b

impose conditions on those permits relating to nutrients in treated effluent
discharged by those plants—

168.1.96G.3.b.i

under Chapter 3 of Part 2 of the Environmental Permitting (England and Wales)
Regulations 2016, and

168.1.96G.3.b.ii

for the relevant purpose.

168.1.96G.4

The “relevant purpose” is ensuring that, on and after the applicable date, the
overall effect on the habitats site associated with the catchment permitting
area of nutrients in treated effluent discharged by all the plants that
discharge treated effluent into the catchment permitting area is less
significant or the same as the overall effect on the site of nutrients in
treated effluent that would be discharged by those plants if—

168.1.96G.4.a

the standard concentration applied to nutrient significant plants, and

168.1.96G.4.b

the nutrient significant plants were (on that basis) meeting the nutrient
pollution standard on and after the applicable date.

168.1.96G.5

For that purpose, a condition imposed on an environmental permit in pursuance
of subsection  (3) (b)  may, in particular—

168.1.96G.5.a

require, or have the effect of requiring, that the concentration of nutrients
in treated effluent discharged by a plant is higher or lower than, or equal
to, the standard concentration;

168.1.96G.5.b

relate to any or all of the plants mentioned in subsection  (3) (a) ,
including the concentration of nutrients in treated effluent discharged by
those plants.

168.1.96G.6

In subsection  (4) —

168.1.96G.6.a

the “ applicable date ” means—

168.1.96G.6.a.i

where the designation under section  96C (1)  or  (2)  of the area that is the
catchment permitting area takes effect during the initial period, 1 April
2030, or

168.1.96G.6.a.ii

where that designation takes effect after the initial period, the date
specified under section  96C (4) (d)  in that designation;

168.1.96G.6.b

a habitats site is “associated” with a catchment permitting area if water
released into the area would drain into the site.

168.1.96G.7

The duty in subsection  (3)  applies in relation to the grant of an
environmental permit for a plant that discharges (or will discharge) treated
effluent into the catchment permitting area as if—

168.1.96G.7.a

paragraph  (a)  were omitted, and

168.1.96G.7.b

in paragraph  (b) —

168.1.96G.7.b.i

for “those permits” there were substituted  “the permit” ;

168.1.96G.7.b.ii

for “those plants” there were substituted  “the plant” ;

168.1.96G.7.b.iii

for “Chapter 3” there were substituted  “Chapter 2” .

168.1.96G.8

It is for the Environment Agency to determine the overall effect on a habitats
site of nutrients in treated effluent.

168.1.96G.9

Regulations made by the Secretary of State may specify how such determinations
are to be made.

168.1.96G.10

In this section “ nutrients ”, in relation to an area designated under—

168.1.96G.10.a

section  96C (1) , means nutrients in water comprising nitrogen or compounds
of nitrogen;

168.1.96G.10.b

section  96C (2) , means nutrients in water comprising phosphorus or compounds
of phosphorus.

########## Section 

168.1.96H

168.1.96H.1

A designation under section  96G (1)  or revocation of such a designation
under subsection  (3) (c) —

168.1.96H.1.a

must be in writing,

168.1.96H.1.b

must be published as soon as practicable after being made, and

168.1.96H.1.c

takes effect in accordance with subsection  (3)  or  (4)  (as appropriate).

168.1.96H.2

A designation under section  96G (1)  may be made at the same time, or at any
time after the time, that the designation under section  96C (1)  or  (2)  of
the area as a sensitive catchment area is made.

168.1.96H.3

A designation under section  96G (1) —

168.1.96H.3.a

if made before the time that the designation under section  96C (1)  or  (2)
takes effect, takes effect at the same time as that designation;

168.1.96H.3.b

if made after the time that the designation under section  96C (1)  or  (2)
takes effect, takes effect on the day specified in it;

168.1.96H.3.c

may be revoked.

168.1.96H.4

A revocation under subsection  (3) (c) —

168.1.96H.4.a

takes effect—

168.1.96H.4.a.i

on the day specified in the revocation, or

168.1.96H.4.a.ii

if none is specified, on the day on which it is made;

168.1.96H.4.b

has no effect in relation to the designation of the area under section  96C
(1)  or  (2) ;

168.1.96H.4.c

may specify the upgrade date that is to apply in relation to nutrient
significant plants (see section  96E (3) ).

168.1.96H.5

In determining whether an upgrade date should be specified under subsection
(4) (c) , the Secretary of State may take into account, in particular, advice
from, or guidance published by, Natural England or the Environment Agency.

########## Information about catchment areas and nutrient significant plants

168.1.96I

168.1.96I.1

The Secretary of State must maintain and publish online a map showing—

168.1.96I.1.a

all the nitrogen sensitive catchment areas, and

168.1.96I.1.b

all the phosphorus sensitive catchment areas.

168.1.96I.2

As soon as practicable after making a designation under section  96C
(sensitive catchment areas), the Secretary of State must publish the revised
map online.

168.1.96I.3

The Secretary of State must maintain and publish online a document listing—

168.1.96I.3.a

all plants that are or have been—

168.1.96I.3.a.i

nitrogen significant plants, or

168.1.96I.3.a.ii

phosphorus significant plants;

168.1.96I.3.b

in relation to each plant listed under paragraph  (a) —

168.1.96I.3.b.i

the upgrade date that applies for the time being;

168.1.96I.3.b.ii

if the plant becomes, or ceases to be, an exempt plant in relation to the
related nutrient pollution standard, that fact and the date on which it
occurred;

168.1.96I.3.b.iii

where the associated catchment area for a plant is not a catchment permitting
area, the figure specified in section  96F (1) (a) (i)  or  (2) (a) (i) ,
under section  96C (4) (e)  or  96D (5)  or by virtue of regulations made
under section  96D (11)  (total nitrogen concentration or total phosphorus
concentration) that applies to the plant;

168.1.96I.3.b.iv

where a direction relating to the plant and the related nutrient pollution
standard is made or revoked under regulation 85C or 110B of the Conservation
of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 ) (disapplication of
assumption that the plant will meet the standard on and after the upgrade date
or applicable date), that fact and the date on which the direction or
revocation takes effect;

168.1.96I.3.c

all catchment permitting areas.

168.1.96I.4

Where any change occurs in the information required to be listed, the
Secretary of State must, as soon as practicable, publish a revised document
online.

########## Section 

168.1.96J

168.1.96J.1

The duty of a sewerage undertaker under section  96B  is enforceable under
section 18—

168.1.96J.1.a

by the Secretary of State, or

168.1.96J.1.b

with the consent of, or in accordance with a general authorisation given by,
the Secretary of State, by the Authority.

168.1.96J.2

The Environment Agency must exercise its functions (whether under
environmental permitting regulations or otherwise) so as to secure compliance
by sewerage undertakers with the duty imposed by section  96B ; those
functions include, in particular, functions of determining—

168.1.96J.2.a

whether to grant or vary any permit under environmental permitting
regulations, or

168.1.96J.2.b

any conditions to be included in any such permit.

168.1.96J.3

The Environment Agency must exercise its functions under the Environmental
Damage (Prevention and Remediation) (England) Regulations 2015 ( S.I. 2015/810
) so as to secure compliance by sewerage undertakers with the duties imposed
by those regulations to prevent and remediate environmental damage (within the
meaning of those regulations) that is treated as occurring by regulation 9A of
those regulations (nutrient significant sewage disposal works: environmental
damage).

168.1.96J.4

Nothing in section  96B  or  96G  or this section affects—

168.1.96J.4.a

any other obligation of a sewerage undertaker relating to nutrient levels in
treated effluent of a plant, or any remedy available in respect of
contravention of any such obligation;

168.1.96J.4.b

any power to impose an obligation relating to nutrient levels in treated
effluent of a plant (including by means of a condition included in a permit
under environmental permitting regulations); and, in particular, nothing in
those sections or this section is to be taken to preclude any such power being
exercised so as to require a lower concentration of total nitrogen or lower
concentration of total phosphorus in treated effluent of a plant than section
96B  requires.

########## Powers to amend sections 

168.1.96K

168.1.96K.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend any plant capacity for the
time being specified in section  96D (1) (a)  or  (2) (a) .

168.1.96K.2

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may not have effect in relation to an area
that is a sensitive catchment area when the regulations are made.

168.1.96K.3

Subject to that, regulations under subsection  (1) —

168.1.96K.3.a

may, in particular, amend section  96D  so that different plant capacities are
specified in relation to the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard and the
phosphorus nutrient pollution standard;

168.1.96K.3.b

may, where different plant capacities will apply for different purposes or
different areas as a result of regulations under subsection  (1) , amend
section  96D  so as to specify those capacities and the purposes or areas for
which they apply.

168.1.96K.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

168.1.96K.4.a

amend section  96F (1) (a) (i)  so as to substitute a different concentration
of total nitrogen;

168.1.96K.4.b

amend section  96F (2) (a) (i)  so as to substitute a different concentration
of total phosphorus.

168.1.96K.5

Regulations under subsection  (4)  may not have effect in relation to an area
that is a sensitive catchment area when the regulations are made.

168.1.96K.6

Where, as a result of the regulations, different concentrations will apply for
different purposes or different areas (including different plants within an
area), the regulations may amend section  96F (1) (a) (i)  or  (2) (a) (i)  to
specify those concentrations and the purposes or areas for (or plants within
an area to) which they apply.

168.1.96K.7

A statutory instrument containing regulations under subsection  (1)  or  (4)
may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before and
approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament.

168.1.96K.8

If a draft of a statutory instrument containing regulations under subsection
(1)  or  (4)  would, apart from this subsection, be treated for the purposes
of the standing orders of either House of Parliament as a hybrid instrument,
it is to proceed in that House as if it were not a hybrid instrument.

########## Sections 

168.1.96L

168.1.96L.1

This section applies for the purposes of sections  96B  to  96K ,  96M  and
96N .

168.1.96L.2

In those sections (and this section)—

      “ associated catchment area ”—         in relation to a plant that is a
nitrogen significant plant or is exempt in relation to the nitrogen nutrient
pollution standard, means the nitrogen sensitive catchment area into which it
discharges;           in relation to a plant that is a phosphorus significant
plant or is exempt in relation to the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard,
means the phosphorus sensitive catchment area into which it discharges;
“ catchment permitting area ” means a sensitive catchment area designated
under section  96G (1)  for the time being;           “ environmental permit ”
means a permit granted under Chapter 2 of Part 2 of the Environmental
Permitting (England and Wales) Regulations 2016; and a reference to a
condition imposed on such a permit is to be construed in accordance with those
regulations;           “ environmental permitting regulations ” means—
the Environmental Permitting (England and Wales) Regulations 2016 ( S.I.
2016/1154 ) (as they have effect from time to time), or           any other
provision made after the Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023 is passed that
is, or could have been, made under section 2 of the Pollution Prevention and
Control Act 1999;                 “ exempt plant ”, in relation to a nutrient
pollution standard, has the meaning given by section  96D ;           “
habitats site ” means a European site within the meaning of the Conservation
of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 ) (see regulation
8);           “ the initial period ” has the meaning given by section  96E (4)
;           “ nitrogen nutrient pollution standard ”, in relation to
references to a nitrogen significant plant meeting the standard, has the
meaning given by section  96F (1) ;           “ nitrogen sensitive catchment
area ” means an area designated under section  96C (1) ;           “ nitrogen
significant plant ” has the meaning given by section  96B (3) ;           “
nutrient pollution standard ” means the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard
or the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard;           “ nutrient
significant plant ” means—         a nitrogen significant plant, or
a phosphorus significant plant;                 “ phosphorus nutrient
pollution standard ”, in relation to references to a phosphorus significant
plant meeting the standard, has the meaning given by section  96F (2) ;
“ phosphorus sensitive catchment area ” means an area designated under section
96C (2) ;           “ phosphorus significant plant ” has the meaning given by
section  96B (4) ;           “ plant ” means a sewage disposal works;
“ related nutrient pollution standard ”, in relation to a sensitive catchment
area or a plant, means—         if (or so far as) the area is a nitrogen
sensitive catchment area or the plant is a nitrogen significant plant, the
nitrogen nutrient pollution standard;           if (or so far as) the area is
a phosphorus sensitive catchment area or the plant is a phosphorus significant
plant, the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard;                 “ sensitive
catchment area ” means—         a nitrogen sensitive catchment area, or
a phosphorus sensitive catchment area;                 “ standard
concentration ”, in relation to the nutrient pollution standard that applies
to a plant, means the concentration specified in section  96F (1) (a) (i)  or
(2) (a) (i)  on the date that the designation of the associated catchment area
as a sensitive catchment area takes effect;           “ treated effluent ” has
the meaning given by section  96F (3) ;           “ upgrade date ”, in
relation to a plant that discharges into a sensitive catchment area, has the
meaning given by section  96E .

168.1.96L.3

References to a plant discharging into a sensitive catchment area are to the
plant discharging treated effluent into the area.

168.1.96L.4

References to the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker have the meaning
given by section 17BA(7).

########## New and altered plants: modifications

168.1.96M

168.1.96M.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for sections  96B  to  96L
to apply with prescribed modifications in relation to any plant that, after
the Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023 is passed—

168.1.96M.1.a

operates for the first time, or

168.1.96M.1.b

is altered.

This is subject to subsection  (3) .

168.1.96M.2

Regulations under this section may in particular provide for sections  96C (5)
and  96D (4)  and  (10)  to apply as if they specified periods other than 7
years.

168.1.96M.3

But regulations under this section may not modify section  96F (1)  or  (2)
or section  96G (4)  so as to apply a higher concentration of total nitrogen
or higher concentration of total phosphorus than would otherwise apply.

########## Setting and enforcing nutrient pollution standards

168.1.96N

168.1.96N.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the setting and
enforcing of nutrient pollution standards.

168.1.96N.2

The Secretary of State may only exercise the power under subsection  (1)  if
the Secretary of State considers that the provisions about the setting and
enforcing of nutrient pollution standards will be at least as effective as the
provision already in force under sections  96B  to  96M , the Environmental
Damage (Prevention and Remediation) (England) Regulations 2015 ( S.I. 810/2015
) or this section as a result of the exercise of this power, including in
relation to—

168.1.96N.2.a

overall environmental protection (within the meaning of section 45 of the
Environment Act 2021),

168.1.96N.2.b

nutrient pollution levels discharged by plants or across catchment areas,

168.1.96N.2.c

enforcement, or

168.1.96N.2.d

costs.

168.1.96N.3

The regulations may, in particular—

168.1.96N.3.a

amend, repeal, revoke or otherwise modify—

168.1.96N.3.a.i

sections  96B  to  96M ,

168.1.96N.3.a.ii

the Environmental Damage (Prevention and Remediation) (England) Regulations
2015, or

168.1.96N.3.a.iii

provision made under this section;

168.1.96N.3.b

#### Planning: assessments of effects on certain sites

169

Schedule 15  amends the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017
( S.I. 2017/1012 ) to require certain assumptions to be made in certain
circumstances about nutrient pollution standards (see  section 168 ).

#### Remediation

170

170.1

The Environmental Damage (Prevention and Remediation) (England) Regulations
2015 ( S.I. 2015/810 ) are amended as follows.

170.2

After regulation 9 insert—

########## Nutrient significant sewage disposal works: environmental damage

170.2.9A

170.2.9A.1

This regulation applies where a sewerage undertaker whose sewerage system
includes a nutrient significant plant fails to secure that the plant is able
to meet the related nutrient pollution standard by the upgrade date.

170.2.9A.2

Any excess nutrient pollution is to be treated for the purposes of these
regulations as damage to the related habitats site that is environmental
damage caused by an activity of the sewerage undertaker that—

170.2.9A.2.a

requires a permit under the Environmental Permitting (England and Wales)
Regulations 2016, and

170.2.9A.2.b

falls within Schedule 2.

170.2.9A.3

In paragraph  (2) —

      “ excess nutrient pollution ”, in relation to a nutrient significant
plant and a related nutrient pollution standard, means the amount by which the
total nutrient pollution discharged in treated effluent by the plant during
the period—         beginning with the upgrade date, and           ending with
the day the plant first meets the related nutrient pollution standard,
exceeds the total nutrient pollution that it would have discharged in treated
effluent during that period had it met the related nutrient pollution standard
on and after the upgrade date;           “ total nutrient pollution ” means—
in relation to the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard, total nitrogen, and
in relation to the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard, total phosphorus.

170.2.9A.4

Where—

170.2.9A.4.a

the nutrient significant plant referred to in paragraph  (1)  is a plant that
discharges treated effluent into a catchment permitting area (see section  96G
of the Water Industry Act 1991), and

170.2.9A.4.b

the sewerage undertaker has failed to comply with a condition in the
environmental permit for the plant imposed in pursuance of subsection  (3) (b)
of that section,

the definition of “excess nutrient pollution” in paragraph  (3)  is subject to
the following modifications.

170.2.9A.5

In a case where the condition relates to the total nutrient pollution
discharged by the plant specifically, references in that definition to the
“upgrade date” are to be read as the “applicable date”.

170.2.9A.6

In a case where the condition relates to the total nutrient pollution
discharged by all plants that discharge into the associated catchment area,
that definition is to be read as if—

170.2.9A.6.a

in the words before paragraph (a), after “by the plant” there were inserted
“and all other plants that discharged into the associated catchment area for
that plant” ,

170.2.9A.6.b

in paragraph (a), for “upgrade date” there were substituted  “applicable date”
, and

170.2.9A.6.c

in the words after paragraph (b)—

170.2.9A.6.c.i

for “that it” there were substituted  “that both it and those other plants” ,
and

170.2.9A.6.c.ii

for “upgrade date” there were substituted  “applicable date” .

170.2.9A.7

For the purposes of paragraph  (3)  as modified by paragraph  (5)  or  (6) ,
the “applicable date” is to be determined in accordance with section  96G (6)
(a)  of the Water Industry Act 1991.

170.2.9A.8

It is for the Environment Agency to determine the excess nutrient pollution
discharged by a plant and in doing so the Environment Agency may have regard
to—

170.2.9A.8.a

the concentration of total nitrogen or concentration of total phosphorus
determined for the purposes of section  96F  of the Water Industry Act 1991
(see in particular subsection  (5)  of that section), and

170.2.9A.8.b

the volume of treated effluent discharged by the plant, as determined by the
Environment Agency.

170.2.9A.9

Schedule 2ZA  sets out modifications of these regulations that apply where
this regulation applies.

170.2.9A.10

In this regulation—

      “ related habitats site ”, in relation to a nutrient significant plant,
means the habitats site by reference to which the associated catchment area is
designated under section  96C  of the Water Industry Act 1991;           “
sewerage system ”, in relation to a sewerage undertaker, has the meaning given
by section 17BA(7) of the Water Industry Act 1991.

170.2.9A.11

For the purposes of this regulation, the following terms have the meanings
given by section  96L  of the Water Industry Act 1991—

      “associated catchment area”;           “catchment permitting area”;
“environmental permit”;           “habitats site”;           “nitrogen
nutrient pollution standard”;           “nutrient significant plant”;
“phosphorus nutrient pollution standard”;           “plant”;
“related nutrient pollution standard”;           “sensitive catchment area”;
“treated effluent”;           “upgrade date”;

and references to a nutrient significant plant meeting the related nutrient
pollution standard are to be read in accordance with section  96F (1)  or  (2)
of that Act.

170.3

After Schedule 2 insert—

  Modifications where regulation  9A  applies

Regulation  9A

170.3.1

In relation to anything that is treated as environmental damage by regulation
9A , these regulations apply with the following modifications.

170.3.2

Regulation 17 does not apply.

170.3.3

Regulation 18 applies as if—

170.3.3.a

the opening words of paragraph (1) provided “Where excess nutrient pollution
is treated as environmental damage by regulation  9A (2) , the enforcing
authority must notify the responsible operator—”;

170.3.3.b

for paragraph (a) there were substituted—

170.3.3.b.a

of the environmental damage;

.

170.3.4

Regulation 18A applies with the omission of paragraph (2).

170.3.5

Regulation 19(3) applies as if for paragraphs (a) to (e) (but not the “or”
immediately following paragraph (e)) there were substituted—

170.3.5.a

the responsible operator did not fail to secure that the nutrient significant

the upgrade date;

170.3.5.b

the determination by the Environment Agency of the excess nutrient pollution
mentioned in regulation  9A (2)  was unreasonable;

.

### Development corporations

#### Local authority proposals and oversight

##### Locally-led urban development corporations

171

171.1

Section 134 of the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980 (urban
development areas) is amended as set out in subsections  (2)  and  (3) .

171.2

After subsection (1A) insert—

171.2.1B

The Secretary of State may, by order made by statutory instrument, designate
any area of land in England as an urban development area if—

171.2.1B.a

a proposal has been made to the Secretary of State under section  134A (1)  in
relation to the area of land, and

171.2.1B.b

the Secretary of State is satisfied that it would be expedient in the local
interest—

171.2.1B.b.i

to designate the area of land as an urban development area, and

171.2.1B.b.ii

to establish a development corporation for the area in consequence of the
proposal.

171.3

After section 134 of the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980 insert—

########### Local authority proposal for designation of locally-led urban development area in England

171.3.134A

171.3.134A.1

A local authority in England, or two or more local authorities in England
acting jointly, may propose to the Secretary of State that the Secretary of
State should designate an area of land (the “proposal area”) as an urban
development area under section 134 (1B) .

171.3.134A.2

A proposal under subsection  (1)  (a “locally-led proposal”) must—

171.3.134A.2.a

state the proposing authority’s proposals as to—

171.3.134A.2.a.i

the name of the development corporation that would be established as a result
of the proposal, and

171.3.134A.2.a.ii

which local authority or local authorities should be designated as the
oversight authority for that development corporation, and

171.3.134A.2.b

include a map of the proposal area.

171.3.134A.3

A locally-led proposal may also include proposals about any other matter about
which the Secretary of State would be able to make provision in respect of the
development corporation by order or regulations under this Part.

171.3.134A.4

A locally-led proposal may relate to separate parcels of land.

171.3.134A.5

A local authority may make a locally-led proposal only if—

171.3.134A.5.a

the proposal area falls wholly within the area of the local authority, or

171.3.134A.5.b

where it makes the proposal jointly with one or more other local authorities,
the proposal area falls—

171.3.134A.5.b.i

wholly or partly within the area of each of them, and

171.3.134A.5.b.ii

wholly within their combined areas.

171.3.134A.6

A proposing authority may make a locally-led proposal only if—

171.3.134A.6.a

the proposing authority has consulted the persons mentioned in subsection  (7)
,

171.3.134A.6.b

the proposing authority has had regard to any comments made in response by the
consultees, and

171.3.134A.6.c

if those comments include comments by a local authority or the Greater London
Authority that the proposing authority does not accept, the proposing
authority has published a statement giving the reasons for the non-acceptance.

171.3.134A.7

The persons referred to in subsection  (6) (a)  are—

171.3.134A.7.a

persons who appear to the proposing authority to represent those living in, or
in the vicinity of, the proposal area;

171.3.134A.7.b

persons who appear to the proposing authority to represent businesses with any
premises in, or in the vicinity of, the proposal area;

171.3.134A.7.c

each Member of Parliament whose parliamentary constituency includes any part
of the proposal area;

171.3.134A.7.d

each local authority for an area which falls wholly or partly within the
proposal area (other than the proposing authority or a constituent council of
the proposing authority);

171.3.134A.7.e

in relation to an area in Greater London, the Greater London Authority;

171.3.134A.7.f

any other person whom the proposing authority considers it appropriate to
consult.

171.3.134A.8

A local authority may be proposed as an oversight authority under subsection
(2) (a) (ii)  only if the proposal area is wholly or partly within the area of
the local authority.

171.3.134A.9

Where the proposing authority proposes, under subsection  (2) (a) (ii) , that
two or more local authorities should be designated as the oversight authority,
it may also propose—

171.3.134A.9.a

that a specified function of an oversight authority should be exercisable by
one of those local authorities, or

171.3.134A.9.b

that a specified function of an oversight authority should be exercisable by
two or more of those local authorities jointly.

For this purpose, “ specified ” means specified in the proposal.

171.3.134A.10

In this section—

      “ local authority ” means—         a district council,           a
county council,           a London borough council, or           the Common
Council;                 “ locally-led proposal ” has the meaning given by
subsection  (2) ;           “ proposing authority ” means—         the local
authority which makes a locally-led proposal, or           if two or more
local authorities make such a proposal, those authorities acting jointly;
and where the proposing authority consists of two or more authorities acting
jointly, each is a “constituent council” of the proposing authority.

171.4

Section 135 (urban development corporations) is amended as set out in
subsections  (5)  and  (6) .

171.5

In subsection (1A), after “in England” insert  “designated under section
134(1)” .

171.6

After subsection (4) insert—

171.6.4A

Subsections  (4B)  and  (4C)  apply where the Secretary of State makes an
order under this section establishing a locally-led urban development
corporation in consequence of a proposal under section  134A (1) .

171.6.4B

The order must—

171.6.4B.a

establish the corporation with the proposed name,

171.6.4B.b

give effect to any proposal made by virtue of section  134A (3)  as to the
number of members to be prescribed under paragraph  1A (2)  of Schedule 26,

171.6.4B.c

designate as the oversight authority the local authority or local authorities
proposed as such, and

171.6.4B.d

give effect to any proposal made by virtue of section  134A (9)  (allocation
of functions where oversight authority consists of more than one local
authority).

171.6.4C

The Secretary of State must exercise other functions under this Act so as to
give effect to any other proposals made by virtue of section  134A (3) .

171.7

After section 135 insert—

########### Oversight of locally-led urban development area

171.7.135A

171.7.135A.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about how an
oversight authority is to oversee the regeneration of a locally-led urban
development area.

171.7.135A.2

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may, for example—

171.7.135A.2.a

provide that an oversight authority is to exercise specified functions under
this Part of this Act, other than a power to make regulations or other
instruments of a legislative character, which would otherwise be exercisable
by the Secretary of State, the Treasury or any other Minister of the Crown;

171.7.135A.2.b

provide that an oversight authority is to exercise such functions subject to
specified conditions or limitations;

171.7.135A.2.c

provide that specified functions under this Part of this Act may be exercised
only with the consent of an oversight authority;

171.7.135A.2.d

make provision about the membership of a locally-led urban development
corporation;

171.7.135A.2.e

modify provisions of this Part of this Act;

171.7.135A.2.f

make different provision for different purposes;

171.7.135A.2.g

make incidental, supplementary or consequential provision.

171.7.135A.3

In this section “ specified ” means specified by regulations under this
section.

171.7.135A.4

Regulations under this section are to be made by statutory instrument.

171.7.135A.5

A statutory instrument containing regulations under this section may not be
made until approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament.

172.2.1ZB

174.3.149A.3

174.3.149A.3.a

174.3.149A.3.b

174.3.149A.4

prevent the urban development corporation from exercising the function.

174.3.149A.5

Subsection  (6)  applies in relation to any function that an urban development
corporation has by virtue of an order under section 149 (1A)  or  (2A) .

174.3.149A.6

function from the council (if any) which would have the function but for the
order; and that council may give such assistance.

174.3.149A.7

London borough council or the Common Council.

##### Planning functions of new town development corporations

175

175.1

The New Towns Act 1981 is amended as follows.

175.2

After section 7 insert—

########### Development corporation as planning authority in England

175.2.7A

175.2.7A.1

This section applies in relation to a development corporation established for
the purposes of a new town in England.

175.2.7A.2

The Secretary of State may provide by order for the corporation to be the
local planning authority for the specified area—

175.2.7A.2.a

for such purposes of Part 3 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, and in
relation to such kinds of development, as are specified, or

175.2.7A.2.b

for such purposes of Part 2 or 3 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act
2004 as are specified.

175.2.7A.3

An order under subsection  (2)  may provide—

175.2.7A.3.a

that any enactment relating to local planning authorities is not to apply to
the corporation, or

175.2.7A.3.b

that any such enactment which applies to the corporation is to apply to it
subject to such modifications as are specified.

175.2.7A.4

The Secretary of State may provide by order—

175.2.7A.4.a

for the corporation to have, in the specified area, the functions conferred by
such of the enactments mentioned in Part 1 of Schedule 29 to the Local
Government, Planning and Land Act 1980 as are specified;

175.2.7A.4.b

for such of the enactments mentioned in Part 2 of that Schedule as are
specified in the order to have effect, in relation to the corporation and to
land in the specified area, subject to the modifications set out in that Part;

175.2.7A.4.c

for such of the provisions of that Part 2 as apply for the purposes of the
order to be read, for those purposes, as if—

175.2.7A.4.c.i

any reference to an urban development corporation were a reference to a
development corporation established under section 3 of this Act, and

175.2.7A.4.c.ii

any reference to regenerating an area were a reference to developing a new
town.

175.2.7A.5

An order under subsection  (4)  may provide—

175.2.7A.5.a

that any enactment relating to local planning authorities applies to the
corporation for the purposes of any enactment specified in Schedule 29 to the
Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980 which relates to land in the
specified area by virtue of the order;

175.2.7A.5.b

that any enactment so applied to the corporation applies to it subject to
modifications specified in the order.

175.2.7A.6

The Secretary of State may, if the corporation is not a locally-led
development corporation, provide by order for the corporation to be the
minerals and waste planning authority for the specified area for the purposes
of Part 2 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

175.2.7A.7

The Secretary of State may provide by order that the corporation is to have,
in the specified area, the functions conferred on the relevant planning
authority by Schedule 8 to the Electricity Act 1989 so far as it applies to
applications for consent under section 37 of that Act.

175.2.7A.8

The area specified under any of the preceding subsections must be the whole,
or part, of the area of the new town.

175.2.7A.9

An order under this section may include supplementary or transitional
provision or savings.

175.2.7A.10

In this section “ specified ” means specified in an order under this section.

########### Arrangements for discharge of, or assistance with, planning functions in England

175.2.7B

175.2.7B.1

Subsection  (2)  applies in relation to any function that a development
corporation has by virtue of an order under section  7A (2) (a) .

175.2.7B.2

The corporation may make arrangements for the discharge of the function by the
council (if any) which would have the function but for the order.

175.2.7B.3

Where arrangements are in force under subsection  (2)  for the discharge of a
function by a council—

175.2.7B.3.a

the council may arrange for the discharge of the function by a committee, sub-
committee or officer of the council, and

175.2.7B.3.b

section 101(2) of the Local Government Act 1972 (delegation by committees and
sub-committees) applies in relation to the function as it applies in relation
to functions of the council.

175.2.7B.4

Arrangements under subsection  (2)  for the discharge of a function do not
prevent the development corporation from exercising the function.

175.2.7B.5

Subsection  (6)  applies in relation to any function that a development
corporation has by virtue of an order under section  7A (2) (b)  or  (6) .

175.2.7B.6

The corporation may seek assistance in connection with the discharge of the
function from the council (if any) which would have the function but for the
order; and that council may give such assistance.

175.2.7B.7

In this section, “ council ” means a county council, district council or
London borough council.

175.3

In Schedule 3 (constitution and proceedings of development corporations),
after paragraph 10 insert—

########### Delegation of planning functions

175.3.10A

175.3.10A.1

This paragraph applies in relation to any function conferred on the
corporation by virtue of an order under section  7A  (planning functions of
corporations in England).

175.3.10A.2

The corporation may appoint committees and such committees may appoint sub-
committees.

175.3.10A.3

Anything which is authorised or required to be done by the corporation—

175.3.10A.3.a

may be done by any member of the corporation or of its staff who is authorised
for the purpose either generally or specifically;

175.3.10A.3.b

may be done by a committee or sub-committee which is so authorised.

175.3.10A.4

The corporation may—

175.3.10A.4.a

determine the quorum of a committee or sub-committee;

175.3.10A.4.b

make such arrangements as it thinks appropriate relating to the meetings and
procedure of a committee or sub-committee.

175.3.10A.5

Anything done for the purposes of sub-paragraph  (4)  is subject to directions
given by the Secretary of State.

175.3.10A.6

The validity of anything done by a committee or sub-committee is not affected
by—

175.3.10A.6.a

any vacancy among its members;

175.3.10A.6.b

any defect in the appointment of any of its members.

175.3.10B

175.3.10B.1

This paragraph has effect in relation to the membership of committees and sub-
committees appointed under paragraph  10A .

175.3.10B.2

A committee may consist of—

175.3.10B.2.a

such members of the corporation as it appoints;

175.3.10B.2.b

such other persons as the corporation (with the consent of the Secretary of
State) appoints.

175.3.10B.3

A sub-committee of a committee may consist of—

175.3.10B.3.a

such members of the committee as it appoints;

175.3.10B.3.b

such persons who are members of another committee of the corporation (whether
or not they are members of the corporation) as the committee appoints;

175.3.10B.3.c

such other persons as the corporation (with the consent of the Secretary of
State) appoints.

175.3.10B.4

The membership of a committee or sub-committee—

175.3.10B.4.a

must always include at least one person who is a member of the corporation;

175.3.10B.4.b

must not include any person who is a member of the staff of the corporation.

##### Confirmation proceedings

182

182.1

The Acquisition of Land Act 1981 is amended as follows.

182.2

In section 13A (confirmation proceedings for contested orders), for
subsections (2) to (6) substitute—

182.2.1A

The confirming authority must cause a public local inquiry to be held if—

182.2.1A.a

the order is subject to special parliamentary procedure, or

182.2.1A.b

in the case of an order to which section 16 applies, a certificate has been
given under subsection (2) of that section.

182.2.1B

If subsection  (1A)  does not apply, the confirming authority must either—

182.2.1B.a

cause a public local inquiry to be held, or

182.2.1B.b

follow the representations procedure.

182.2.1C

In deciding between those options, the confirming authority must have regard
to the scale and complexity of what is proposed by the order.

182.2.1D

The representations procedure is a procedure to be prescribed.

182.2.1E

The regulations prescribing the procedure must include—

182.2.1E.a

provision enabling each person who has made a remaining objection to make
representations—

182.2.1E.a.i

in writing to the confirming authority, or

182.2.1E.a.ii

if the person so requests, at a hearing, and

182.2.1E.b

provision enabling the acquiring authority, and any other person the
confirming authority thinks appropriate, to make representations—

182.2.1E.b.i

in writing to the confirming authority, or

182.2.1E.b.ii

if applicable, at a hearing held as mentioned in paragraph  (a) (ii) .

182.2.1F

The regulations may provide for hearings to be held by the confirming
authority or by a person appointed by the confirming authority.

182.2.1G

In subsection  (1E) , “ representations ” means representations as to whether
the order should be confirmed.

182.2.1H

Before confirming the order, the confirming authority must consider—

182.2.1H.a

each remaining objection;

182.2.1H.b

if a public local inquiry was held, the report of the person who held it;

182.2.1H.c

if the representations procedure was followed and the confirming authority
held a hearing, the representations made at the hearing;

182.2.1H.d

if the representations procedure was followed and a person appointed by the
confirming authority held a hearing, the report of that person;

182.2.1H.e

if the representations procedure was followed and written representations were
made, those representations.

182.2.1I

The confirming authority may confirm the order with or without modifications.

##### Conditional confirmation

183

183.1

The Acquisition of Land Act 1981 is amended as set out in subsections  (2)
and  (3) .

183.2

After section 13B insert—

########### Conditional confirmation

183.2.13BA

183.2.13BA.1

The confirming authority may confirm a compulsory purchase order
conditionally.

183.2.13BA.2

The effect of conditional confirmation is that the order—

183.2.13BA.2.a

does not become operative until the confirming authority has decided, on an
application by the acquiring authority, that certain conditions have been met,
and

183.2.13BA.2.b

expires if the confirming authority—

183.2.13BA.2.b.i

has not received an application for the purposes of subsection  (2) (a)  by a
certain time, or

183.2.13BA.2.b.ii

having received such an application by that time, decides that the conditions
have not been met.

183.2.13BA.3

The conditions and the time are to be specified by the confirming authority
when it confirms the order.

183.2.13BA.4

The procedure to be followed in relation to an application under this section
is to be prescribed.

183.2.13BA.5

The regulations prescribing the procedure must include provision for each
relevant objector—

183.2.13BA.5.a

to be given notice of the application (or for steps to be taken with a view to
notifying them), and

183.2.13BA.5.b

to have the opportunity to make written representations in response to the
application.

183.2.13BA.6

In subsection  (5) , “ relevant objector ” means a person who made an
objection to the order that—

183.2.13BA.6.a

was a remaining objection for the purposes of section 13A, and

183.2.13BA.6.b

had not been withdrawn by the time the order was confirmed.

183.2.13BA.7

The regulations may include provision as to the giving of reasons for the
decision on the application.

183.2.13BA.8

Subsections (2) to (6) of section 13B apply to proceedings on an application
under this section as they apply to the representations procedure.

183.3

In section 15 (notices after confirmation of compulsory purchase order)—

183.3.a

in subsection (2)(b), for “date when the order becomes operative” substitute
“day on which the authority takes the final step needed to comply with
subsection (1)(a)” ;

183.3.b

in subsection (3), at the beginning insert  “Unless the order was confirmed
conditionally,” ;

183.3.c

in subsection (4), after paragraph (b) insert—

183.3.c.ba

if the order was confirmed conditionally, stating the conditions and time
specified under section  13BA (3) ;

;

183.3.d

after subsection  (4A)  (inserted by section  181 (6) ) insert—

183.3.d.4B

If the order was confirmed conditionally and the confirming authority decides
under section  13BA  that the conditions have been met, the acquiring
authority must serve—

183.3.d.4B.a

a copy of the order, and

183.3.d.4B.b

a fulfilment notice,

on each person on whom a notice was required to be served under section 12.

183.3.d.4C

Where subsection  (4B)  applies, the acquiring authority must also—

183.3.d.4C.a

affix a fulfilment notice to a conspicuous object or objects on or near the
land comprised in the order, and

183.3.d.4C.b

publish a fulfilment notice—

183.3.d.4C.b.i

in one or more local newspapers circulating in the locality in which the land
comprised in the order is situated, and

183.3.d.4C.b.ii

on an appropriate website, until the end of the period of 6 weeks beginning
with the day on which the acquiring authority takes the final step needed to
comply with subsection  (4B) .

183.3.d.4D

The acquiring authority must comply with subsections  (4B)  and  (4C) (a)  and
(b) (i)  before the end of—

183.3.d.4D.a

the period of 6 weeks beginning with the day on which the decision under
section  13BA  is made, or

183.3.d.4D.b

such longer period beginning with that day as may be agreed in writing between
the acquiring authority and the confirming authority.

183.3.d.4E

If the acquiring authority fails to comply with those provisions before the
end of that period, or fails to comply with subsection  (4C) (b) (ii) , the
confirming authority may—

183.3.d.4E.a

take any steps that the acquiring authority was required but has failed to
take to comply, and

183.3.d.4E.b

recover the reasonable costs of doing so from the acquiring authority

183.3.d.4F

A fulfilment notice is a notice—

183.3.d.4F.a

stating that the conditions subject to which the order was confirmed have been
met and that the order will therefore become operative, and

183.3.d.4F.b

annexing the information that was contained in the confirmation notice.

;

183.3.e

in subsection (5), after “notice” insert  “or fulfilment notice” ;

183.3.f

in subsection (6)—

183.3.f.i

after “notice” insert  “, and any fulfilment notice,” ;

183.3.f.ii

for “it” substitute  “each such notice” .

183.4

Schedule 18  contains, and makes provision in connection with, amendments in
consequence of this section and paragraph  3  of  Schedule 19 .

##### Common standards for compulsory purchase data

187

187.1

The Secretary of State may, by regulations, make provision requiring an
acquiring authority, in preparing, holding or providing such of its relevant
compulsory purchase data as is specified or described in the regulations, to
comply with any approved data standards which are applicable.

187.2

“ Acquiring authority ” means any person who is, or may be, authorised under
an enactment to acquire land compulsorily.

187.3

“ Approved data standards ”, in relation to relevant compulsory purchase data,
are such written standards, containing technical specifications or other
requirements in relation to the data, or in relation to preparing, holding or
providing the data, as may be published by the Secretary of State from time to
time.

187.4

“ Relevant compulsory purchase data ” means information that is, or is to be,
contained in relevant compulsory purchase documentation.

187.5

“ Relevant compulsory purchase documentation ” means an order or notice or any
other documentation that is, or is to be, prepared by an acquiring authority
(acting as such) under or for the purposes of relevant compulsory purchase
legislation.

187.6

“ Relevant compulsory purchase legislation ” means provision made by or under—

187.6.a

the Land Compensation Act 1961,

187.6.b

the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965,

187.6.c

the Land Compensation Act 1973,

187.6.d

sections 10 to 16 of, and Schedules 4 and 5 to, the New Towns Act 1981,

187.6.e

the Compulsory Purchase (Vesting Declarations) Act 1981,

187.6.f

the Acquisition of Land Act 1981,

187.6.g

section 9 of the Tribunals and Inquiries Act 1992,

187.6.h

Part 7 of the Housing and Planning Act 2016, or

187.6.i

Chapter 1 of Part 2 of the Neighbourhood Planning Act 2017.

187.7

“Providing”, in subsection  (1) , includes submitting, issuing, serving,
notifying and publishing.

##### Power to require prospects of planning permission to be ignored

190

190.1

190.1.b.2A

;

190.1.c

after section 15 insert—

############# Special provision about compensation

############## Directions applying section 

190.1.c.15A

190.1.c.15A.1

Subsection  (2)  applies if—

190.1.c.15A.1.a

an acquiring authority submits a compulsory purchase order for confirmation,
and

190.1.c.15A.1.b

the authorising enactment is listed in  Schedule 2A .

190.1.c.15A.2

The acquiring authority may include in the order a direction that compensation
is to be assessed in accordance with section  14A  of the Land Compensation
Act 1961 (cases where prospect of planning permission to be ignored); and if
it does so the following provisions of this section apply.

190.1.c.15A.3

The acquiring authority must submit to the confirming authority a statement of
commitments together with the order.

190.1.c.15A.4

A “statement of commitments” is a statement of the acquiring authority’s
intentions as to what will be done with the project land should the
acquisition proceed, so far as the authority relies on those intentions in
contending that the direction is justified in the public interest.

190.1.c.15A.5

If the authorising enactment is listed in any of paragraphs  2  to  7  of
Schedule 2A , those intentions must include the provision of a certain number
of units of affordable housing.

190.1.c.15A.6

The statement under section 12(1)(a) must include a statement of the effect of
the direction; and paragraphs  (ba)  and  (bb)  of the same subsection apply
in respect of the statement of commitments as they apply in respect of the
compulsory purchase order.

190.1.c.15A.7

The confirming authority may permit the acquiring authority to amend the
statement of commitments before the decision whether to confirm the order is
made.

190.1.c.15A.8

But the confirming authority may do so—

190.1.c.15A.8.a

only if satisfied that the amendment would not be unfair to any person who
made or could have made a relevant objection for the purposes of section 13,
and

190.1.c.15A.8.b

if the authorising enactment is listed in any of paragraphs  2  to  7  of
Schedule 2A , only if the statement of commitments as amended will still
comply with subsection  (5) .

190.1.c.15A.9

If the confirming authority decides to confirm the order in accordance with
the applicable provisions of this Part—

190.1.c.15A.9.a

it may confirm the order with the direction included if satisfied that the
direction is justified in the public interest;

190.1.c.15A.9.b

otherwise, it must modify the order so as to remove the direction.

190.1.c.15A.10

If the order is confirmed with the direction included, a confirmation notice
under section 15 must (in addition to the matters set out in subsection (4) of
that section)—

190.1.c.15A.10.a

state the effect of the direction,

190.1.c.15A.10.b

explain how the statement of commitments may be viewed, and

190.1.c.15A.10.c

explain that additional compensation may become payable if the statement of
commitments is not fulfilled.

190.1.c.15A.11

In this section—

      “ the authorising enactment ” means the enactment that confers the power
to make the compulsory purchase to which the order in question relates;
“ the project land ” means—         the land proposed to be acquired further
to the compulsory purchase order, and           any other land that the
acquiring authority intends to be used in connection with that land;
“ unit of affordable housing ” means a building or part of a building that is
constructed or adapted for use as a separate dwelling and—         in the case
of a building in England, is to be used as—         social housing within the
meaning of Part 2 of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008, or
housing of any other description that is prescribed, or                 in the
case of a building in Wales, is to be used as housing of a description that is
prescribed.

;

190.1.d

after Schedule 2 insert—
