190.2

In the Land Compensation Act 1961—

190.2.a

after section 14 insert—

############# Cases where prospect of planning permission to be ignored

190.2.a.14A

190.2.a.14A.1

The following provisions apply in relation to an acquisition if the compulsory
purchase order authorising the acquisition directs that compensation is to be
assessed in accordance with this section.

190.2.a.14A.2

Section 14 does not apply.

190.2.a.14A.3

In assessing the value of land in accordance with rule (2) in section 5, it is
to be assumed that no planning permission would be granted for development on
the relevant land (whether alone or together with other land).

190.2.a.14A.4

Subsection  (3)  does not prevent account being taken of planning permission
that has already been granted.

190.2.a.14A.5

Subsection  (3)  does not apply in relation to development consisting of the
use as two or more separate dwellings of any building previously used as a
single dwelling.

190.2.a.14A.6

Schedule 2A  provides for the payment of additional compensation in respect of
the acquisition in certain circumstances.

;

190.2.b

in section 32 (interest from entry on land), after subsection (2) insert—

190.2.b.3

This section does not apply in relation to additional compensation payable
under  Schedule 2A .

;

190.2.c

after the second Schedule insert—

  Additional compensation where section  14A  applied

Section  14A (6)

############### Directions for additional compensation

190.2.c.1

190.2.c.1.1

This paragraph applies if—

190.2.c.1.1.a

an interest in land has been acquired further to a compulsory purchase order,
and

190.2.c.1.1.b

the order directed that compensation was to be assessed in accordance with
section  14A .

190.2.c.1.2

The confirming authority must, on an application by an eligible person, make a
direction for additional compensation if it appears to the confirming
authority that the following conditions are met.

190.2.c.1.3

Those conditions are—

190.2.c.1.3.a

that the statement of commitments has not been fulfilled,

190.2.c.1.3.b

either—

190.2.c.1.3.b.i

that the period of 10 years beginning with the date on which the compulsory
purchase order became operative has expired, or

190.2.c.1.3.b.ii

that there is no longer any realistic prospect of the statement of commitments
being fulfilled within that period, and

190.2.c.1.3.c

that the initial direction would not have been confirmed on the basis of a
statement of commitments reflecting what has in fact been done with the
project land since its acquisition.

190.2.c.1.4

In sub-paragraph  (3) —

      “ the statement of commitments ” means the statement of commitments
submitted in connection with the compulsory purchase order under section  15A
(3)  of the Acquisition of Land Act 1981 (and if the statement was amended
after its submission, means the statement as amended);           “ the initial
direction ” means the direction referred to in sub-paragraph  (1) (b)  (and
that direction was “confirmed” when the compulsory purchase order was
confirmed with the inclusion of the direction);           “ the project land ”
means the land treated as the project land for the purposes of the statement
of commitments;

and that statement is “fulfilled” if what is done with that land after its
acquisition is materially in accordance with the statement.

190.2.c.1.5

The effect of a direction for additional compensation is that each eligible
person may make a claim to the acquiring authority for any additional
compensation in respect of the acquisition payable to the person under this
Schedule.

190.2.c.1.6

A person is an “ eligible person ” for the purposes of this Schedule if the
person was entitled to compensation in respect of the acquisition (and see
also paragraph  4 (1) ).

############### Amount of additional compensation

190.2.c.2

190.2.c.2.1

Additional compensation in respect of an acquisition is payable to an eligible
person only if, in relation to that person, the alternative amount is greater
than the original amount.

190.2.c.2.2

The amount payable is the difference between the two amounts.

190.2.c.2.3

The “original amount” is the amount of compensation awarded or agreed to be
paid to the person in respect of the acquisition.

190.2.c.2.4

The “alternative amount” is the amount of compensation that would have been
assessed as due to the person in respect of the acquisition had compensation
been assessed without the application of section  14A .

190.2.c.2.5

If the original amount was agreed, the relevant valuation date for the
purposes of the assessment imagined under sub-paragraph  (4)  is the date on
which the agreement was concluded.

190.2.c.2.6

In relation to the determination of an amount of additional compensation under
this Schedule, section 17(2)(b) applies as if its reference to the amount of
compensation were to the amount of additional compensation.

190.2.c.2.7

A certificate issued under section 17 (or 18) after the award or agreement
referred to in sub-paragraph  (3)  is to have effect for the purposes of the
assessment imagined under sub-paragraph  (4)  as if it had been issued before
that assessment.

190.2.c.2.8

Any amount of compensation that is or would be attributable to disturbance,
severance or injurious affection is to be ignored for the purposes of sub-
paragraphs  (3)  and  (4) .

############### Time limit for application for direction

190.2.c.3

An application under paragraph  1 (2)  may not be made after the expiry of the
period of 13 years beginning with the date on which the compulsory purchase
order became operative.

############### Mortgages

190.2.c.4

190.2.c.4.1

For the purposes of this Schedule an “ eligible person ” includes a person who
would have been entitled to compensation in respect of the acquisition but for
the existence of a mortgage (but the mortgage is in that case still to be
taken into account in determining the original and alternative amounts under
paragraph  2 ).

190.2.c.4.2

An amount agreed or awarded to be paid to a mortgagee under section 15 or 16
of the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965 in respect of the acquisition is to be
treated for the purposes of this Schedule as compensation in respect of the
acquisition.

190.2.c.4.3

The reference in sub-paragraph  (2)  to an amount paid under section 15 or 16
of the Compulsory Purchase Act 1965 (“the applicable section”) includes an
amount paid under section 52ZA or 52ZB of the Land Compensation Act 1973 and
taken into account by virtue of section 52ZC(7)(d) of that Act for the
purposes of the applicable section.

190.2.c.4.4

Additional compensation payable under this Schedule to a person in the
person’s capacity as a mortgagee (or to a person exercising rights of a
mortgagee) is to be applied towards the discharge of the sums secured by the
mortgage.

190.2.c.4.5

If there is no remaining sum secured by the mortgage, the additional
compensation that would be payable as described in sub-paragraph  (4)  is
instead payable to the person who is an eligible person by virtue of the
interest that was subject to the mortgage.

190.2.c.4.6

If the additional compensation that would be payable as described in sub-
paragraph  (4)  exceeds the total of the remaining sums secured by the
mortgage, the amount of the excess is instead payable to the person who is an
eligible person by virtue of the interest that was subject to the mortgage.

############### Successors-in-title

190.2.c.5

190.2.c.5.1

This paragraph applies if, had the compensation to which an eligible person
was entitled in respect of the acquisition remained unpaid, the right to be
paid it would now vest in some other person (assuming that it remained
enforceable and any obligations in respect of the right had been complied
with).

190.2.c.5.2

If the eligible person is still alive or in existence, the rights that the
eligible person would have under this Schedule are exercisable by the other
person and not by the eligible person.

190.2.c.5.3

If the eligible person is no longer alive or in existence, the rights that the
eligible person would have under this Schedule if that person were still alive
or in existence are exercisable by the other person.

190.2.c.5.4

The right exercisable by the other person under sub-paragraph  (2)  or  (3)
is subject to any restriction, condition or other incident to which the right
vested in that person as imagined under sub-paragraph  (1)  would be subject.

190.2.c.5.5

Additional compensation paid to the other person by virtue of sub-paragraph
(2)  or  (3)  must be dealt with by the person in any way in which the person
would have to deal with compensation paid to that person further to the right
vested in that person as imagined under sub-paragraph  (1) .

190.2.c.5.6

If a person is an eligible person by virtue of paragraph  4 (1) , the
reference in sub-paragraph  (1)  to compensation to which the person was
entitled is to be read as a reference to the compensation to which the person
would have been entitled but for the mortgage.

############### Consequential losses

190.2.c.6

190.2.c.6.1

The relevant authority may by regulations provide for additional compensation
payable on a claim under paragraph  1 (5)  to include (in addition to any
amount payable under paragraph  2 ) an amount to make good qualifying losses.

190.2.c.6.2

“Qualifying losses” are financial losses shown to have been suffered by an
eligible person, or a person entitled to exercise the rights of the eligible
person under paragraph  5 , as a result of the compensation initially payable
to the eligible person in respect of the acquisition being of the original
amount rather than the alternative amount.

190.2.c.6.3

In the case of an eligible person who is so by virtue of an interest that was
subject to a mortgage, the reference in sub-paragraph  (2)  to compensation
payable to the eligible person is to be taken to include compensation payable
to the mortgagee of that interest.

190.2.c.6.4

Regulations under this paragraph may limit the qualifying losses in respect of
which additional compensation is payable under the regulations by reference
to—

190.2.c.6.4.a

a description of loss,

190.2.c.6.4.b

an amount, or

190.2.c.6.4.c

any other circumstance.

############### Procedure etc

190.2.c.7

190.2.c.7.1

The relevant authority may by regulations make provision—

190.2.c.7.1.a

about the procedure for applications under paragraph  1 (2)  or claims under
paragraph  1 (5)  (including provision about the costs of such applications or
claims);

190.2.c.7.1.b

about steps that must be taken by the acquiring authority or the confirming
authority for the purposes of publicising or giving notice of a direction for
additional compensation;

190.2.c.7.1.c

for interest to be applied to amounts of additional compensation that are
payable;

190.2.c.7.1.d

about how or when additional compensation (and any interest) is to be paid.

190.2.c.7.2

Regulations under this paragraph about costs of claims under paragraph  1 (5)
—

190.2.c.7.2.a

may modify or disapply section 29 of the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act
2007 (costs or expenses) or provisions in Tribunal Procedure Rules relating to
costs;

190.2.c.7.2.b

may apply (with or without modifications) section 4 of this Act;

and section 4 of this Act does not apply in relation to such a claim unless so
applied.

############### Regulations

190.2.c.8

190.2.c.8.1

For the purposes of this Schedule “the relevant authority” is—

190.2.c.8.1.a

the Secretary of State, in relation to England;

190.2.c.8.1.b

the Welsh Ministers, in relation to Wales.

190.2.c.8.2

Regulations under this Schedule may make—

190.2.c.8.2.a

consequential, supplementary, incidental, transitional or saving provision;

190.2.c.8.2.b

different provision for different purposes.

190.2.c.8.3

Regulations under this Schedule are to be made by statutory instrument.

190.2.c.8.4

A statutory instrument containing such regulations is subject to annulment in
pursuance of—

190.2.c.8.4.a

a resolution of either House of Parliament, in the case of regulations made by
the Secretary of State, or

190.2.c.8.4.b

a resolution of Senedd Cymru, in the case of regulations made by the Welsh
Ministers.

############### Interpretation

190.2.c.9

190.2.c.9.1

In this Schedule—

190.2.c.9.1.a

“ the confirming authority ” means—

190.2.c.9.1.a.i

the person who confirmed the compulsory purchase order, or

190.2.c.9.1.a.ii

any successor to that person’s function of confirming compulsory purchase
orders of the type in question;

190.2.c.9.1.b

references to “the acquisition” or “the compulsory purchase order” are to the
acquisition or order by virtue of which paragraph  1  applies;

190.2.c.9.1.c

references to the acquisition of an interest in land include—

190.2.c.9.1.c.i

the creation of such an interest, and

190.2.c.9.1.c.ii

the acquisition or creation of a right in or over land;

and references to interests in land are to be read accordingly.

190.2.c.9.2

In the case of a compulsory purchase order made under section 10(1) of, and
Part 1 of Schedule 4 to, the New Towns Act 1981 (compulsory acquisition by new
town development corporation in usual cases), the reference in paragraph  1
(4)  to section  15A (3)  of the Acquisition of Land Act 1981 is to be read as
a reference to paragraph  5A (2)  of Schedule 4 to the New Towns Act 1981.

190.2.c.9.3

In the case of a compulsory purchase order made under section 13(1)(a) of, and
Part 1 of Schedule 5 to, the New Towns Act 1981 (compulsory acquisition by new
town development corporation of statutory undertakers’ operational land)—

190.2.c.9.3.a

the reference in paragraph  1 (4)  to section  15A (3)  of the Acquisition of
Land Act 1981 is to be read as a reference to paragraph  5A (2)  of Schedule 5
to the New Towns Act 1981, and

190.2.c.9.3.b

the references in paragraph  1 (4)  and sub-paragraph  (1) (a)  to the
confirmation of the order are to be read as references to the making of the
order.

190.2.c.9.4

In the case of a compulsory purchase order made under section 21A(1)(b) or
(2)(b) of the Welsh Development Agency Act 1975 (compulsory acquisition by
Welsh Ministers of land in Wales for Welsh development purposes)—

190.2.c.9.4.a

the reference in paragraph  1 (4)  to submission under section  15A (3)  of
the Acquisition of Land Act 1981 is to be read as a reference to preparation
under paragraph  3B (2)  of Schedule 4 to the Welsh Development Agency Act
1975, and

190.2.c.9.4.b

the references in paragraph  1 (4)  and sub-paragraph  (1) (a)  to the
confirmation of the order are to be read as references to the making of the
order.

190.2.c.9.5

If—

190.2.c.9.5.a

an interest in land is acquired further to section 154(2) of the Town and
Country Planning Act 1990 (deemed compulsory acquisition further to blight
notice), and

190.2.c.9.5.b

the land falls within paragraph 22 of Schedule 13 to that Act (land blighted
by compulsory purchase order),

the interest is to be treated for the purposes of this Schedule as having been
acquired further to the compulsory purchase order by virtue of which the land
falls within that paragraph.

190.3

In the New Towns Act 1981—

190.3.a.5A

190.3.a.5A.1

A development corporation submitting an order to the Secretary of State under

190.3.a.5A.3

190.3.a.5A.7

190.3.a.5A.9.a

of a building in England, is to be used as—         social housing within the
meaning of Part 2 of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008, or

;

### Letting by local authorities of vacant high-street premises

#### Significant concepts

##### Designated high streets and town centres

191

191.1

A local authority may designate a street in its area as a high street for the
purposes of this Part if it considers that the street is important to the
local economy because of a concentration of high-street uses of premises on
the street.

191.2

A local authority may designate an area within its area as a town centre for
the purposes of this Part if—

191.2.a

the built environment of the area is characterised principally by a network of
streets, and

191.2.b

the authority considers that the area is important to the local economy
because of a concentration of high-street uses of premises in the area.

191.3

A street or area is not to be designated, however, if the authority considers
that its importance derives principally from goods or services purchased in
the course of business.

191.4

A designation under this section may be varied or withdrawn at any time.

191.5

A local authority must maintain and make available to the public a list
describing, and a map showing, any designations under this section that are in
force in its area.

191.6

A designation under this section is a local land charge.

191.7

In this Part—

      “ designated high street ” means a street for the time being designated
under subsection  (1) ;           “ designated town centre ” means an area for
the time being designated under subsection  (2) .

##### High-street uses and premises

192

192.1

For the purposes of this Part, any use of premises that falls within any of
the following sub-paragraphs is a “high-street use”—

192.1.a

use as a shop or office;

192.1.b

use for the provision of services to persons who include visiting members of
the public;

192.1.c

use as a restaurant, bar, public house, café or other establishment selling
food or drink for immediate consumption;

192.1.d

use for public entertainment or recreation;

192.1.e

use as a communal hall or meeting-place;

192.1.f

use for manufacturing or other industrial processes of a sort that can (in
each case) reasonably be carried on in proximity to, and compatibly with, the
preceding uses.

192.2

For the purposes of this Part, premises are “qualifying high-street premises”
if—

192.2.a

they are situated on a designated high street or in a designated town centre,
and

192.2.b

the local authority considers them to be suitable for a high-street use.

192.3

But premises are not “qualifying high-street premises” if they are, or when
last used were, used wholly or mainly as a warehouse.

192.4

For the purposes of this Part, “ suitable high-street use ”, in relation to
premises, means a high-street use for which the local authority considers the
premises to be suitable.

192.5

In considering the uses for which premises are suitable, a local authority is
to have regard to any works that it expects—

192.5.a

the landlord would be required to carry out, or

192.5.b

the tenant would be permitted to, and likely to, carry out,

if a contract was entered into under section  204  and a tenancy was granted
further to it.

##### Vacancy condition

193

193.1

For the purposes of this Part, the “vacancy condition” is satisfied in
relation to premises on a given day if—

193.1.a

the premises are unoccupied on that day, and

193.1.b

either—

193.1.b.i

the premises were unoccupied for the whole of the period of one year ending
with the previous day, or

193.1.b.ii

during the period of two years ending with the previous day, the premises were
unoccupied on at least 366 days.

193.2

For the purposes of subsection  (1) , premises are occupied on a day during
which they begin or cease to be occupied.

193.3

Days before the day on which this section comes into force are to count for
the purposes of subsection  (1) (b) .

193.4

Occupation by a person living in premises that are not designed or adapted for
residential use is not to count as occupation for the purposes of this
section.

193.5

Regulations may amend this section so as to alter the circumstances in which
the “vacancy condition” is satisfied in relation to premises.

193.6

Those circumstances must relate to the time during which premises are or have
been unoccupied.

193.7

A state of affairs does not amount to the occupation of premises for the
purposes of this section unless it involves the use of the premises for
activity that—

193.7.a

is substantial,

193.7.b

is sustained, and

193.7.c

involves the regular presence of people at the premises.

##### Local benefit condition

194

For the purposes of this Part, the “local benefit condition” is satisfied in
relation to premises if the local authority considers that the occupation of
the premises for a suitable high-street use would be beneficial to the local
economy, society or environment.

#### Procedure preliminary to letting

##### Initial notice

195

195.1

On any day on which it appears to a local authority that the vacancy condition
and the local benefit condition are met in relation to qualifying high-street
premises in its area, the authority may serve a notice under this section (an
“initial letting notice”) on the landlord of the premises.

195.2

An initial letting notice expires (if it has not been withdrawn)—

195.2.a

when a final letting notice in relation to the premises takes effect, or

195.2.b

at the end of the period of ten weeks beginning with the day on which the
initial letting notice takes effect.

##### Restriction on letting while initial notice in force

196

196.1

While an initial letting notice is in force in relation to premises, the
landlord of the premises may not—

196.1.a

grant, or agree to grant, a tenancy of, or licence to occupy, the premises, or

196.1.b

enter into any other agreement resulting in another person becoming entitled
to possess or occupy the premises (except as a result of the transfer or
extinction of the landlord’s interest),

without the written consent of the local authority that served the notice.

196.2

The local authority must give or refuse consent under subsection  (1)  within
a reasonable time after it is sought.

196.3

Subsection  (1)  does not apply to the grant of a tenancy pursuant to an
obligation that bound the landlord before the initial letting notice took
effect.

196.4

An obligation that is conditional on the service of an initial letting notice
in relation to the premises is to be disregarded for the purposes of
subsection  (3) .

196.5

A tenancy or licence granted, or other agreement entered into, without consent
required by subsection  (1)  is void.

196.6

But subsection  (5)  is to be treated as never having applied to a tenancy,
licence or agreement if—

196.6.a

either—

196.6.a.i

the initial letting notice expires without a final letting notice having taken
effect, or

196.6.a.ii

a final letting notice served further to the initial letting notice expires
without a contract having been entered into under section  204 , and

196.6.b

the parties to the tenancy, licence or agreement have, until the expiry,
conducted themselves towards each other on the basis that the tenancy, licence
or agreement is valid.

##### Circumstances in which letting to be permitted

197

197.1

The local authority must give consent under section  196 (1)  to—

197.1.a

the grant of, or an agreement to grant, a tenancy, or

197.1.b

the grant of a licence to occupy the premises,

if the conditions in subsection  (2)  are met.

197.2

The conditions are that—

197.2.a

the term of the proposed tenancy, or the period of occupation under the
proposed licence, would begin within the period of eight weeks beginning with
the day on which the initial letting notice took effect,

197.2.b

that term or period would be at least one year, and

197.2.c

the local authority is satisfied that the tenancy or licence would be likely
to lead to the occupation of the premises for a high-street use.

197.3

For the purposes of subsection  (2) (b) , a term or period is to be taken to
be less than one year if the lessor or licensor has a right to terminate it
within the period of one year beginning with the day on which it starts,
unless that right arises only on default by the tenant or licensee.

197.4

Consent granted further to the duty in subsection  (1)  is to be treated as
not having been given if—

197.4.a

the proposed tenancy or licence is not granted, or

197.4.b

the term of the tenancy, or period of occupation under the licence, does not
begin,

within the period referred to in subsection  (2) (a) .

##### Final notice

198

198.1

A local authority may serve a notice under this section (a “final letting
notice”) on the landlord of qualifying high-street premises on any day on
which—

198.1.a

an initial letting notice served by the authority is in force in relation to
the premises,

198.1.b

the period of eight weeks beginning with the day on which that notice took
effect has elapsed, and

198.1.c

either—

198.1.c.i

no tenancy or licence has been granted, or other agreement entered into, with
the consent of the authority under section  196  or in circumstances where
consent was not needed because of subsection  (3)  of that section, or

198.1.c.ii

the authority is satisfied that any tenancy, licence or agreement so granted
or entered into is consistent with the contemplated exercise of its powers
under section  204 .

198.2

But the notice must be served in time for it to take effect before the initial
letting notice expires.

198.3

A final letting notice expires (if it has not been withdrawn or revoked on
appeal, and subject to sections  201 (6)  and  202 (6) ) at the end of the
period of 14 weeks beginning with the day on which it takes effect.

##### Restriction on letting while final notice in force

199

199.1

While a final letting notice is in force in relation to premises, the landlord
of the premises may not—

199.1.a

grant, or agree to grant, a tenancy of, or licence to occupy, the premises, or

199.1.b

enter into any other agreement resulting in another person becoming entitled
to possess or occupy the premises (except as a result of the transfer or
extinction of the landlord’s interest),

without the written consent of the local authority that served the notice.

199.2

The local authority must give or refuse consent under subsection  (1)  within
a reasonable time after it is sought.

199.3

Subsection  (1)  does not apply to the grant of a tenancy pursuant to an
obligation that bound the landlord before the initial letting notice preceding
the final letting notice took effect.

199.4

An obligation that is conditional on the service of an initial letting notice
or final letting notice in relation to the premises is to be disregarded for
the purposes of subsection  (3) .

199.5

A tenancy granted, or agreement entered into, without consent required by
subsection  (1)  is void.

199.6

But subsection  (5)  is to be treated as never having applied to a tenancy,
licence or agreement if—

199.6.a

the final letting notice expires without a contract having been entered into
under section  204 , and

199.6.b

the parties to the tenancy, licence or agreement have, until that expiry,
conducted themselves towards each other on the basis that the tenancy, licence
or agreement is valid.

##### Restriction on works while final notice in force

200

200.1

While a final letting notice is in force in relation to premises, the landlord
of the premises may not carry out, or permit the carrying out of, any works to
the premises without the written consent of the local authority that served
the notice.

200.2

In subsection  (1) , “works to the premises” include the alteration or removal
of any fixtures or fittings on the premises.

200.3

Subsection  (1)  does not apply to works that are—

200.3.a

urgently necessary for repair or preservation, or

200.3.b

necessary to fulfil an obligation of the landlord, other than one voluntarily
assumed after the initial letting notice preceding the final letting notice
took effect.

200.4

The local authority must—

200.4.a

give or refuse consent under subsection  (1)  within a reasonable time after
it is sought, and

200.4.b

must give such consent unless there are reasonable grounds for refusing it,
concerning the exercise or contemplated exercise of the authority’s powers
under the following provisions of this Part in relation to the premises.

200.5

A person who contravenes subsection  (1)  without reasonable excuse commits an
offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on
the standard scale.

##### Counter-notice

201

201.1

The landlord of premises in relation to which a final letting notice has been
served may give a counter-notice to the local authority that served the final
letting notice.

201.2

A counter-notice must be received by the local authority before the end of the
period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the final letting notice
takes effect.

201.3

A counter-notice must—

201.3.a

state that, if the final letting notice is not withdrawn, the landlord intends
to appeal against it, and

201.3.b

specify the ground (which must be a permissible ground) on which the appeal
would be brought.

201.4

The permissible grounds of appeal are set out in Part 1 of  Schedule 20  (and
they are to be interpreted and applied in accordance with Part 2 of that
Schedule).

201.5

Regulations may amend that Schedule so as to—

201.5.a

add a ground of appeal;

201.5.b

make provision about the interpretation or application of a ground so added;

201.5.c

amend or remove a ground so added or provision so made.

201.6

The period referred to in section  198 (3) , as it applies to a particular
final letting notice, is extended by 28 days if a counter-notice is served in
relation to the final letting notice.

##### Appeals

202

202.1

This section applies if—

202.1.a

a counter-notice is given under section  201 , and

202.1.b

the landlord of the premises to which it relates is not, within the period of
14 days beginning with the day on which the counter-notice was received by the
local authority, notified by the authority of the withdrawal of the final
letting notice.

202.2

The landlord may appeal against the final letting notice to the county court.

202.3

An appeal must be brought on the ground specified in the counter-notice.

202.4

An appeal must be brought within the period of 28 days beginning with the day
on which the counter-notice was received by the local authority.

202.5

In disposing of an appeal under this section, the county court must either
revoke or confirm the final letting notice.

202.6

The period referred to in section  198 (3) , as it applies to a particular
final letting notice, is extended by one day (in addition to those referred to
in section  201 (6) ) for each day in the period—

202.6.a

beginning with the day on which an appeal against the notice is brought, and

202.6.b

ending with the day on which the appeal is finally determined, withdrawn or
abandoned.

202.7

For the purposes of subsection  (6) (b) , an appeal is not finally determined
until the decision on the appeal, or on any further appeal, may not be
overturned on a further appeal (ignoring the possibility of an appeal out of
time with permission).

#### Procedure for letting

##### Rental auctions

203

203.1

A local authority may arrange for a rental auction to be carried out in
respect of qualifying high-street premises if—

203.1.a

a final letting notice served by the authority is in force in relation to the
premises,

203.1.b

it is no longer possible for that notice to be revoked on appeal (whether
because of the expiry of the period referred to in section  201 (2)  or  202
(4)  or the final determination, withdrawal or abandonment of an appeal), and

203.1.c

either—

203.1.c.i

no tenancy or licence has been granted, or other agreement entered into, with
the consent of the authority under section  199  or in circumstances where
consent was not needed because of subsection  (3)  of that section, or

203.1.c.ii

the authority is satisfied that any tenancy, licence or agreement so granted
or entered into is consistent with the contemplated exercise of its powers
under section  204 .

203.2

A “rental auction” is a process for finding persons who would be willing to
take a tenancy of the premises further to a contract under section  204  and
ascertaining the consideration that they would be willing to give in order to
do so.

203.3

Regulations must make provision about the process.

203.4

The regulations must provide for the suitable high-street use of the premises
to be specified by the local authority ahead of the auction.

203.5

The regulations must provide for the identification of a person as the
“successful bidder” following a rental auction, except in cases where the
regulations provide for there to be no successful bidder.

203.6

The regulations may, in particular, provide for a person who took part in the
auction but would not otherwise be the successful bidder to be treated as the
successful bidder if—

203.6.a

the landlord of the premises so proposes or agrees, or

203.6.b

it appears to the local authority that it will not be reasonably practicable
to enter into a contract under section  204  with the person who would
otherwise be the successful bidder.

203.7

The regulations may include provision about with whom, and on what terms, the
local authority can enter into arrangements for the auction.

203.8

The regulations may allow local authorities to make choices as to procedure.

203.9

To the extent that the local authority has a choice as to procedure, the local
authority must have regard to any representations made by the landlord.

##### Power to contract for tenancy

204

204.1

Subsection  (2)  applies if—

204.1.a

a final letting notice served by the authority is in force in relation to the
premises,

204.1.b

the period of 42 days beginning with the day on which that notice took effect
has elapsed,

204.1.c

a rental auction has been carried out in respect of qualifying high-street
premises, and

204.1.d

the condition in section  203 (1) (c)  is still met.

204.2

The local authority that served the notice may enter into a tenancy contract
with the successful bidder in the auction (as identified in accordance with
regulations under section  203 ).

204.3

A “tenancy contract” is a contract under which—

204.3.a

the landlord of the premises agrees to grant, and

204.3.b

the successful bidder agrees to take,

a short-term tenancy of the premises (including a contract under which those
things are agreed subject to conditions).

204.4

A contract entered into under this section has effect as if it was entered
into by the landlord of the premises instead of the local authority.

204.5

A local authority is to act under this section in its own name, but with an
indication that it is acting so as to bind the landlord rather than itself.

204.6

As soon as possible after entering into a contract under this section, the
local authority must provide a signed copy of it to the landlord.

##### Terms of contract for tenancy

205

205.1

This section applies in relation to a contract entered into under section  204
.

205.2

The contract must set out the terms of the agreed tenancy (as to which see
section  206 ).

205.3

The contract may identify the physical extent of the premises in greater
detail than that in which the premises were identified for the purposes of
sections  195  to  203 .

205.4

The contract may (subject to regulations under subsection  (6) ) include—

205.4.a

provision allowing the tenant to carry out pre-tenancy works (and to enter
land for the purpose);

205.4.b

provision making that ability subject to the consent of the landlord (and
about the giving of such consent);

205.4.c

provision requiring the landlord to carry out pre-tenancy works (whether in or
outside the premises) before the term of the agreed tenancy begins;

205.4.d

provision about the remedies available to the tenant if the landlord fails to
carry out pre-tenancy works as so required.

205.5

“ Pre-tenancy works ” means works carried out (whether in or outside the
premises) before the term of the agreed tenancy begins in contemplation of the
use of the premises by the tenant once the term begins.

205.6

Regulations may—

205.6.a

impose restrictions or conditions on the ability to include provision within
subsection  (4)  in the contract;

205.6.b

provide for circumstances in which provision within subsection  (4)  must be
included in the contract;

205.6.c

make other provision about the terms of the contract.

205.7

In making regulations under subsection  (6) , the Secretary of State must have
regard to the terms on which contracts for the grant of short-term tenancies
are typically entered into on a commercial basis.

205.8

In deciding (so far as it has discretion to do so) on the terms of the
contract, the local authority must have regard to any representations made by
the landlord.

205.9

In this section—

      “ the agreed tenancy ” means the tenancy the grant of which is agreed in
the contract;           “ the premises ” means the premises that are to be
demised by the agreed tenancy;           “ the tenant ” means the prospective
tenant under the agreed tenancy;           “ the landlord ” means the landlord
of the premises.

##### Terms of tenancy

206

206.1

This section applies in relation to a tenancy the grant of which is agreed in
a contract entered into under section  204 .

206.2

If the interest of the landlord in the premises is such that the landlord
could not grant a tenancy the term of which ended after a particular time, the
term of the tenancy must not end after that time.

206.3

The tenancy must include terms requiring that the premises be used wholly or
mainly for the suitable high-street use specified by the local authority ahead
of the rental auction that preceded the contract.

206.4

If the rental auction involved the successful bidder indicating the amount of
premium or rent that the successful bidder would be willing to pay, the
premium or rent payable under the tenancy must, unless the landlord agrees
otherwise, be of the amount indicated (subject to any term of the tenancy
about review or deduction of rent).

206.5

The terms of the tenancy may include provision granting to the tenant
interests or rights in or over land outside the premises in connection with
tenant’s use of the premises.

206.6

The terms of the tenancy must include provision satisfying each of the
descriptions set out in  Schedule 21 .

206.7

Regulations may—

206.7.a

provide exceptions from subsection  (6) ;

206.7.b

provide further detail about the provision that is to be included in the terms
of the tenancy by virtue of subsection  (6) ;

206.7.c

make other provision about the terms of the tenancy.

206.8

In making regulations under subsection  (7) , the Secretary of State must have
regard to the terms on which short-term tenancies are typically granted on a
commercial basis.

206.9

In deciding (so far as it has discretion to do so) on the terms of the
tenancy, the local authority must have regard to any representations made by
the landlord.

206.10

In this section—

      “ the premises ” means the premises which are to be demised by the
tenancy;           “ the landlord ” means the landlord of the premises.

##### Power to grant tenancy in default

207

207.1

This section applies if—

207.1.a

a local authority has entered into a contract under section  204 , and

207.1.b

the landlord of the premises to which the contract relates fails to grant a
tenancy as required by the contract.

207.2

The local authority may grant the tenancy that the landlord should have
granted.

207.3

A tenancy granted under this section has effect as if it was granted by the
landlord instead of the local authority; and the local authority may do
anything that the landlord could do in order to make an effective grant.

207.4

A local authority is to act under this section in its own name, but with an
indication that it is acting so as to bind the landlord rather than itself.

207.5

As soon as possible after granting a tenancy under this section, the local
authority must provide a signed copy of the instrument by which the tenancy
was granted to the landlord.

##### Deemed consent of superior lessor or mortgagee

208

A contract entered into under section  204 , and a tenancy granted further to
such a contract, are deemed to have been entered into or granted with the
express consent of—

208.a

any person who is (or will be when the tenancy is granted) a superior lessor
of the land in which the premises in question are comprised, and

208.b

any mortgagee of that land.

##### Exclusion of security of tenure

209

A tenancy granted further to a contract entered into under section  204  is
excluded from sections 24 to 28 of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954.

#### Powers to obtain information

##### Power to require provision of information

210

210.1

This section applies in relation to premises that are situated on a designated
high street or within a designated town centre.

210.2

The local authority for the area in which the premises are situated may, in
writing, require any interested person to give information about the premises
to the authority.

210.3

In subsection  (2) , “ interested person ” means a person who appears to the
local authority to have an interest in the land in which the premises are
comprised.

210.4

For the purposes of subsection  (2) , information about premises includes
information about—

210.4.a

the occupation of the premises,

210.4.b

matters affecting the premises,

210.4.c

persons interested in the premises, and

210.4.d

their interests in the premises.

210.5

A requirement under subsection  (2)  must state the time by which and manner
in which the information is required to be given.

210.6

The power conferred by subsection  (2)  may be exercised only for the purpose
of obtaining information about the premises that the local authority thinks is
likely to be necessary or expedient for the exercise of its functions under
this Part in relation to the premises.

210.7

A person commits an offence if the person—

210.7.a

fails without reasonable excuse to comply with a requirement under subsection
(2) , or

210.7.b

in response to such a requirement, gives information that—

210.7.b.i

is false, and

210.7.b.ii

the person knows or should reasonably know to be false.

210.8

A person who commits an offence under subsection  (7)  is liable on summary
conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale.

##### Power to enter and survey land

211

211.1

This section applies in relation to premises that are situated on a designated
high street or within a designated town centre.

211.2

A person authorised in writing by the local authority for the area in which
the premises are situated may—

211.2.a

enter and survey the premises, and

211.2.b

enter on any other land in order to gain access to the premises for the
purposes of paragraph  (a) .

211.3

In the following provisions of this section, “ the power ” means the power
conferred by subsection  (2) .

211.4

The power may be exercised only for the purpose of obtaining information about
the premises that the authority thinks is likely to be necessary or expedient
for the exercise of its functions under this Part in relation to the premises.

211.5

The power may be exercised only if the local authority has given, or made all
reasonable efforts to give, written notice to—

211.5.a

the landlord of the premises, for the purposes of subsection  (2) (a) , or

211.5.b

the person who appears to the local authority to be in possession of, or
entitled to possession of, the land, for the purposes of subsection  (2) (b) ,

at least 14 days before the day on which the power is first exercised in
relation to the premises or other land in question.

211.6

The power may be exercised only at a reasonable time.

211.7

The power may not be exercised in a way that involves the use of force, except
on the authority of a warrant issued by a justice of the peace.

211.8

Such a warrant—

211.8.a

may be issued only on an application supported by evidence given on oath,

211.8.b

may be issued only if the justice of the peace is satisfied that reasonable
efforts have been made to exercise the power without the use of force, and

211.8.c

must specify the number of occasions on which it can be relied.

211.9

A person exercising the power must produce—

211.9.a

evidence of the authorisation referred to in subsection  (2) , and

211.9.b

a copy of any warrant issued under subsection  (7) ,

if so requested by any person who appears to have control over the premises or
other land.

211.10

If no person who appears to have control over the premises or other land is
present when the power is exercised, the person exercising the power must
leave the premises or land as secure against trespassers as when the person
entered.

##### Offences in connection with section 

212

212.1

A person who, without reasonable excuse, obstructs a person in the exercise of
the power conferred by section  211 (2)  is guilty of an offence.

212.2

A person who commits an offence under subsection  (1)  is liable on summary
conviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.

212.3

A person commits an offence if the person discloses confidential information,
obtained in the exercise of the power conferred by section  211 (2) , for
purposes other than those for which the power was exercised.

212.4

A person who commits an offence under subsection  (3)  is liable—

212.4.a

on summary conviction, to a fine, or

212.4.b

on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two
years or to a fine, or both.

212.5

In subsection  (3) , “ confidential information ” means information—

212.5.a

which constitutes a trade secret, or

212.5.b

the disclosure of which would or would be likely to prejudice the commercial
interests of any person.

##### Power to extend time limits

213

213.1

Subsection  (2)  applies if it appears to the county court that, because of—

213.1.a

a failure to comply with a requirement under section  210 (2) ,

213.1.b

the giving of false information in response to such a requirement, or

213.1.c

obstruction of a person in the exercise of the power conferred by section  211
(2) ,

a local authority has been impeded in deciding whether or how to exercise its
functions under this Part in relation to premises in respect of which an
initial letting notice or final letting notice is in force.

213.2

The court may order that the period referred to in section  195 (2) (b)  or
198 (3) , as applicable in relation to the notice, is to be extended by such
number of days as appears to the court to be appropriate in view of the
impediment.

213.3

The court may act under this section only on an application by the local
authority.

#### General and supplementary provision

##### Further provision about letting notices

214

214.1

In this section, references to letting notices are to initial letting notices
and final letting notices.

214.2

Regulations must make provision about—

214.2.a

the form and content of letting notices,

214.2.b

the service of letting notices, and

214.2.c

when letting notices take effect.

214.3

In making regulations under subsection  (2) (a) , the Secretary of State must
seek to secure that letting notices—

214.3.a

identify the premises to which they relate and their suitable high-street use,

214.3.b

explain the reasons for the service of the notice, and

214.3.c

explain the consequences under this Part of the notice having been served,

in such detail as is adequate in order for the recipient of the notice to be
able to decide how to act in response to it.

214.4

For the purposes of this Part, an authority serves a letting notice on the day
on which it takes the last step that it needs to take in order for the notice
to be served in accordance with regulations under subsection  (2) (b) .

214.5

In making regulations under subsection  (2) (c) , the Secretary of State must
seek to secure that, in the ordinary course of events (taking into account the
method of service employed), it is likely that the landlord will become aware
of the notice by the time it takes effect.

214.6

A letting notice served by a local authority may be withdrawn by the authority
at any time.

214.7

A letting notice—

214.7.a

is not affected by any change in the landlord of the premises in relation to
which it has been served, and

214.7.b

is a local land charge.

214.8

Regulations may provide for copies of letting notices to be served on—

214.8.a

persons with interests in the affected premises that are superior to the
landlord’s interest;

214.8.b

mortgagees of the affected premises.

##### Other formalities

215

Regulations may make provision about the manner of, or procedure to be
followed in connection with—

215.a

making, varying or withdrawing a designation under section  191 ;

215.b

seeking, giving or refusing consent under section  196  or  199 ;

215.c

giving a counter-notice under section  201 ;

215.d

making representations under section  203 (9) ,  205 (8)  or  206 (9) ;

215.e

making a requirement under section  210 ;

215.f

giving notice under section  211 (5) .

##### Compensation

216

216.1

A person interested in land is entitled to compensation for damage as a result
of the exercise of the power conferred by section  211 .

216.2

Such compensation is payable by the local authority that authorised the
exercise of the power.

216.3

Any disputes relating to compensation under this section are to be determined
by the Upper Tribunal.

216.4

The provisions of section 4 of the Land Compensation Act 1961 apply to the
determination of such disputes, with any necessary modifications.

216.5

Except as provided by subsection  (1) , no compensation is payable in respect
of the exercise of the powers conferred by this Part.

##### Power to modify or disapply enactments applicable to letting

217

217.1

Subsection  (2)  applies to an enactment which imposes obligations on a lessor
or prospective lessor of premises in relation to—

217.1.a

the letting of the premises, or

217.1.b

the premises while let.

217.2

Regulations may provide for the enactment to—

217.2.a

apply with modifications, or

217.2.b

not to apply,

in relation to a tenancy granted (or to be granted) further to a contract
entered into under section  204 , or the premises demised by such a tenancy.

217.3

In this section “ enactment ” includes an enactment comprised in subordinate
legislation, within the meaning given by section 21(1) of the Interpretation
Act 1978.

##### Interpretation of 

218

218.1

The following provisions apply for the purposes of this Part.

218.2

Each of the following is a local authority—

218.2.a

a district council in England,

218.2.b

a county council in England for any area for which there is no district
council,

218.2.c

a London borough council,

218.2.d

the Common Council of the City of London, and

218.2.e

the Council of the Isles of Scilly.

218.3

“ Premises ” means—

218.3.a

the whole of a building that is designed or adapted to be used as a whole, or

218.3.b

any part of a building that—

218.3.b.i

is designed or adapted to be used separately from the other parts, or

218.3.b.ii

could with reasonable adaptation be so used.

218.4

Premises are situated on a street if the building comprising or containing the
premises—

218.4.a

directly adjoins the street, or

218.4.b

is separated from the street only by the curtilage of the building.

218.5

“ Street ” means a street, within the meaning given by section 48(1) of the
New Roads and Street Works Act 1991, to which the public have access on foot
(whether by right or permission); and includes any part of a street.

218.6

“ The landlord ”, in relation to premises, means a person who—

218.6.a

is entitled to possession of the premises, and

218.6.b

has sufficient interest in the premises to be capable of granting a tenancy of
the premises of at least one year in duration.

218.7

For the purposes of subsection  (6)  as it applies in relation to—

218.7.a

the service of a final letting notice in the circumstances described in
section  198 (1) (c) (ii) , and

218.7.b

the operation of this Part following the service of such a notice,

the tenancy, licence or agreement referred to in section  198 (1) (c) (ii)  is
to be ignored.

218.8

“ Short-term tenancy ” means a tenancy for a term of at least one year but not
exceeding five years.

218.9

References to the terms of a contract or tenancy include covenants, conditions
and grants.

218.10

“Mortgagee” is to be read as if any charge or lien for securing money or
money’s worth was a “mortgage”.

218.11

References to regulations are to regulations made by the Secretary of State.

### Information about interests and dealings in land

#### Power to require provision of certain classes of information

219

219.1

Regulations may require the provision of information that is within the scope
of a permitted purpose.

219.2

So far as the regulations are to extend to England and Wales, the permitted
purposes are—

219.2.a

the beneficial ownership purpose (see section  220 ),

219.2.b

the contractual control purpose (see section  221 ), and

219.2.c

the national security purpose (see section  222 ).

219.3

So far as the regulations are to extend to Scotland or Northern Ireland, the
only permitted purpose is the national security purpose.

219.4

Regulations under this section must, for each requirement they impose,
specify—

219.4.a

the person on whom the requirement falls,

219.4.b

the occurrence or circumstances that gives or give rise to the requirement,

219.4.c

the time limit for complying with the requirement, and

219.4.d

the person to whom the required information is to be provided.

219.5

The occurrence or circumstances specified under subsection  (4) (b) —

219.5.a

must, in the case of a requirement to provide information within the scope of
the national security purpose, and

219.5.b

in any other case may,

be (or include) the giving of a notice in accordance with the regulations to
the person on whom the requirement falls.

219.6

In relation to such cases, the regulations may also make provision deeming
notice to have been given at a certain time in certain circumstances.

219.7

The person specified under subsection  (4) (d)  must be—

219.7.a

the Chief Land Registrar, or

219.7.b

another person exercising public functions on behalf of the Crown.

219.8

Regulations under this section may—

219.8.a

make provision about how information is to be provided (including provision
requiring it to be provided by electronic means specified in the regulations);

219.8.b

provide for, or make provision about, the application of the regulations to
persons outside, or information held outside, the United Kingdom;

219.8.c

relate to things done or arising before the coming into force of this section.

#### The beneficial ownership purpose

220

220.1

Information is within the scope of the beneficial ownership purpose if it
appears to the Secretary of State that the information would be useful for the
purpose of—

220.1.a

identifying persons who are beneficial owners of land in England or Wales, or

220.1.b

understanding the relationship of those persons with the land that they
beneficially own.

220.2

For the purposes of this section, a person beneficially owns land if either of
the following subsections applies.

220.3

This subsection applies where—

220.3.a

the land is owned by a body corporate or partnership, and

220.3.b

the person is, in relation to that body corporate or partnership, a beneficial
owner within the meaning given by regulation 5 of the Money Laundering
Regulations.

220.4

This subsection applies where—

220.4.a

the land is owned as part of—

220.4.a.i

a trust, foundation or similar legal arrangement, or

220.4.a.ii

the estate of a deceased person in the course of administration, and

220.4.b

the person is, in relation to that trust, foundation, arrangement or estate, a
beneficial owner within the meaning given by regulation 6 of the Money
Laundering Regulations.

220.5

In this section—

220.5.a

expressions that are also used in regulation 5 or 6 of the Money Laundering
Regulations have the same meaning as in that regulation;

220.5.b

references to ownership of land (except references to beneficial ownership)
are to the legal ownership of a freehold or leasehold estate in the land;

220.5.c

“ the Money Laundering Regulations ” means the Money Laundering, Terrorist
Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017 (
S.I. 2017/692 ).

#### The contractual control purpose

221

221.1

Information is within the scope of the contractual control purpose if it
appears to the Secretary of State that the information would be useful for the
purpose of understanding relevant contractual rights.

221.2

For the purposes of subsection  (1) , understanding relevant contractual
rights includes identifying the persons holding them and understanding the
circumstances in which they were created or acquired.

221.3

“Relevant contractual rights” are rights that—

221.3.a

arise under a contract,

221.3.b

relate to the development, use or disposal of land in England or Wales, and

221.3.c

are held for the purposes of an undertaking.

221.4

In this section—

      “ contract ” includes a deed (whether or not made for consideration);
“ undertaking ” includes—         a business,           a charity or similar
endeavour, and           the exercise of functions of a public nature.

#### The national security purpose

222

222.1

Information is within the scope of the national security purpose if—

222.1.a

the information relates to land that is within subsection  (2) ,

222.1.b

the information is within subsection  (3) , and

222.1.c

it appears to the Secretary of State that requiring the provision of the
information under section  219  would be justified in the interests of
national security.

222.2

Land is within this subsection if it appears to the Secretary of State that a
threat to national security arises in connection with the location of the land
or anything situated or done on it.

222.3

Information is within this subsection if it appears to the Secretary of State
that the information would be useful for the purpose of—

222.3.a

identifying persons who—

222.3.a.i

own relevant interests in the land,

222.3.a.ii

have relevant rights concerning the land, or

222.3.a.iii

have the ability, or are in a position that may involve the ability, to
control or influence (directly or indirectly) the owner of a relevant interest
in the land, or a person with a relevant right concerning the land, in the
exercise of that ownership or right, or

222.3.b

understanding the relationship of those persons with the land.

222.4

In subsection  (3) —

222.4.a

references to ownership include legal and beneficial ownership;

222.4.b

“ control or influence ” includes control or influence by reason of interests
or rights in or under a company, partnership, trust, foundation, or legal
structure or arrangement similar to any of those.

#### Requirements may include transactional information

223

223.1

The information that may (if it falls within the scope of a permitted purpose)
be required to be provided under  section 219  includes transactional
information about instruments, contracts or other arrangements—

223.1.a

creating, altering, extinguishing, evidencing, or transferring relevant
interests in land, or

223.1.b

conferring, amending, assigning, terminating or otherwise modifying relevant
rights concerning land.

223.2

“ Transactional information ” means—

223.2.a

details of the parties to a transaction;

223.2.b

details of persons on whose behalf or for whose benefit the parties to a
transaction are or were acting;

223.2.c

details of the terms of a transaction;

223.2.d

details of persons providing professional services in relation to a
transaction;

223.2.e

details of the source of any money paid or other consideration given in
connection with a transaction;

223.2.f

copies of documents giving effect to or evidencing a transaction.

223.3

“Transaction”, in subsection  (2) , means an instrument, contract or other
arrangement within subsection  (1) .

#### Use of information

224

224.1

Regulations may provide for—

224.1.a

the retention of information provided further to a requirement imposed under
section 219 ;

224.1.b

the sharing of such information with persons exercising functions of a public
nature, for use for the purposes of such functions;

224.1.c

the publication of such information.

224.2

In the case of a requirement to provide information within the scope of the
national security purpose, regulations under subsection  (1)  may be made so
as to apply to information provided further to the requirement only so far as
appears to the Secretary of State to be justified in the interests of national
security.

224.3

Regulations may provide for the payment of fees—

224.3.a

by persons providing information further to a requirement imposed under
section 219 , and

224.3.b

to the person to whom the information is provided, in respect of any functions
conferred on that person under subsection  (1) .

224.4

No civil liability is to arise from the sharing or publication of information
under regulations under this section by reason of any inaccuracy or omission
in the information as provided further to a requirement imposed under  section
219 .

#### Offences

225

225.1

A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement
imposed under section  219  commits an offence.

225.2

A person commits an offence if—

225.2.a

the person provides information in response to a requirement imposed under
section  219 ,

225.2.b

the information is false or misleading in a material particular, and

225.2.c

the person knows that the information is false or misleading or is reckless as
to whether it is.

225.3

But an offence under this section is committed under the law of a given
jurisdiction only if the requirement in question is imposed by regulations
extending to that jurisdiction.

225.4

A person who commits an offence under subsection  (1)  is liable—

225.4.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding the maximum term for summary offences or a fine (or both);

225.4.b

on summary conviction in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale (or both);

225.4.c

on summary conviction in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale (or
both).

225.5

In subsection  (4) (a) , “ the maximum term for summary offences ” means—

225.5.a

if the offence is committed before the time when section 281(5) of the
Criminal Justice Act 2003 comes into force, 6 months;

225.5.b

if the offence is committed after that time, 51 weeks.

225.6

A person guilty of an offence under subsection  (2)  is liable—

225.6.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding the general limit in a magistrates’ court or a fine (or both);

225.6.b

on summary conviction in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

225.6.c

on summary conviction in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

225.6.d

on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two
years or a fine (or both).

225.7

If—

225.7.a

an entity within subsection  (8)  commits an offence under this section, and

225.7.b

a person who is, or is purporting to act as, a relevant officer of the entity
authorises or permits, participates in, or fails to take all reasonable steps
to prevent the commission of the offence,

that person also commits the offence.

225.8

The entities within this subsection are those specified in the first column of
the following table; and “ relevant officer ”, in relation to such an entity,
means a person acting in a capacity specified in the corresponding entry in
the second column.

    Entity “Relevant officer”   A company. A director, manager, secretary or
similar officer. A partnership. A partner. A body corporate (other than a
company) or unincorporated body whose affairs are managed by a governing body.
A member of the governing body. A body corporate (other than a company) or
unincorporated body whose affairs are managed by its members. A member.

225.9

An offence under this section committed under the law of Scotland by a person
outside Scotland may be prosecuted in—

225.9.a

a sheriff court district in which the person is apprehended or in custody, or

225.9.b

a sheriff court district determined by the Lord Advocate,

as if the offence had been committed in that district (and in that event the
offence is for all incidental or consequential purposes deemed to have been
committed in that district).

225.10

In subsection  (9) , “ sheriff court district ” is to be read in accordance
with section 307(1) of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995.

#### Enforcement of requirements

226

226.1

Regulations may make provision to prevent a relevant registration act from
being carried out in relation to a relevant interest in land or relevant right
concerning land in relation to which a requirement imposed under section  219
has not been complied with.

226.2

For the purposes of subsection  (1) , a relevant registration act is any act
that would or could be carried out in relation to the register of title kept
under the Land Registration Act 2002.

226.3

Regulations under subsection  (1)  may—

226.3.a

amend the Land Registration Act 2002;

226.3.b

make consequential amendments of any other enactment.

#### Interpretation of 

227

In this Part—

      “ person ” includes any entity that has legal personality under the law
by which it is governed;           “ regulations ” means regulations made by
the Secretary of State;           “ relevant interest in land ” means an
estate, interest, right or power in or over land in the United Kingdom, except
an advowson, franchise or manor;           “ relevant right concerning land ”
means a right or power, arising under a contract or otherwise, that is not a
relevant interest in land but concerns the ownership, control or use of land
in the United Kingdom.

### Miscellaneous

#### Registration of short-term rental properties

228

228.1

The Secretary of State must by regulations make provision requiring or
permitting the registration of specified short-term rental properties in
England.

228.2

“ Short-term rental property ” means—

228.2.a

a dwelling, or part of a dwelling, which is provided by a person (“the host”)
to another person (“the guest”)—

228.2.a.i

for use by the guest as accommodation other than the guest’s only or principal
residence,

228.2.a.ii

in return for payment (whether or not by the guest), and

228.2.a.iii

in the course of a trade or business carried on by the host, and

228.2.b

any dwelling or premises, or part of a dwelling or premises, not falling
within paragraph  (a)  which is specified for the purposes of this paragraph.

228.3

The Secretary of State must consult the public before making the first
regulations under this section.

228.4

The requirement in  subsection (3)  may be satisfied by consultation
undertaken before the coming into force of this section.

228.5

Regulations under this section may, in particular, include provision about or
in connection with—

228.5.a

who may, or must, maintain the register or registers provided for under this
section;

228.5.b

who may, or must, register a specified short-term rental property on any
register provided for under this section;

228.5.c

conditions that must be satisfied for a specified short-term rental property
to be registered or conditions that may be placed upon a specified short-term
rental property’s registration (including provision about the circumstances in
which such conditions may be varied);

228.5.d

the circumstances in which the registration of a specified short-term rental
property may be revoked;

228.5.e

procedural requirements relating to the registration of a specified short-term
rental property, the variation of any conditions placed on the registration or
the revocation of the registration;

228.5.f

appeals against decisions made in relation to the registration of a specified
short-term rental property;

228.5.g

the form or content of—

228.5.g.i

a register provided for under this section,

228.5.g.ii

an application for registration on such a register, or

228.5.g.iii

any other document provided for under this section;

228.5.h

how the registration of a specified short-term rental property may or must be
publicised;

228.5.i

the collection, provision or publication of information in connection with
regulations under this section;

228.5.j

exemptions from some or all of the requirements imposed by regulations under
this section;

228.5.k

prohibiting the provision of a short-term rental property or anything done
wholly or partly for the purposes of promoting such a property to the public
or a section of the public, in the course of a trade or business, where the
property is not registered or another requirement imposed by regulations under
this section has not been met;

228.5.l

the enforcement of requirements or prohibitions imposed by regulations made
under this section.

228.6

Provision under  subsection (5) (l)  may, in particular, include provision—

228.6.a

conferring a power on a court or tribunal;

228.6.b

for the imposition of civil sanctions and appeals against such sanctions.

228.7

Regulations under this section may make provision for the imposition of civil
sanctions whether or not the conduct in respect of which the sanction is
imposed constitutes an offence.

228.8

Regulations under this section may—

228.8.a

provide for the charging of fees or other charges;

228.8.b

confer a function, including a function involving the exercise of a
discretion, on any person;

228.8.c

relate to all or only part of England (and still discharge the duty in
subsection (1) ).

228.9

In this section—

      “ civil sanction ” means a sanction of a kind for which provision may be
made under Part 3 of the Regulatory Enforcement and Sanctions Act 2008 (fixed
monetary penalties, discretionary requirements, stop notices, enforcement
undertakings);           “ premises ” includes any place and, in particular,
includes—         any vehicle or vessel;           any tent or moveable
structure;                 “ specified ” means specified or described in
regulations made under this section.

#### Pavement licences

229

Schedule 22  makes—

229.a

provision to make the regime for pavement licences under sections 1 to 9 of
the Business and Planning Act 2020 permanent, and

229.b

other provision relating to pavement licences.

#### Historic environment records

230

230.1

A relevant authority must maintain an historic environment record for its
area.

230.2

An “historic environment record” is a system for storing and making available
to the public information about—

230.2.a

any of the following in the area—

230.2.a.i

a listed building within the meaning given by section 1(5) of the Listed
Buildings Act;

230.2.a.ii

a conservation area within the meaning given by section 91(1) of that Act;

230.2.a.iii

a scheduled monument within the meaning given by section 1(11) of the Ancient
Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979;

230.2.a.iv

a garden or other area of land included in a register maintained by the
Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission for England under section 8C of
the Historic Buildings and Ancient Monuments Act 1953;

230.2.a.v

a site designated as a restricted area under section 1 of the Protection of
Wrecks Act 1973;

230.2.a.vi

a World Heritage Site (that is to say, a property appearing on the World
Heritage List kept under Article 11(2) of the UNESCO Convention Concerning the
Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage adopted at Paris on 16
November 1972);

230.2.a.vii

anything of a description specified in regulations under subsection  (3) ,

230.2.b

other sites in the area which the authority considers to be of historic,
architectural, archaeological or artistic interest,

230.2.c

objects found in the area in the course of archaeological investigations which
the authority considers to be of such interest, and

230.2.d

historical, architectural, archaeological or scientific investigations or
studies relating to—

230.2.d.i

anything within paragraphs  (a)  to  (c) , or

230.2.d.ii

the development, preservation or present character of any part of the area.

230.3

The Secretary of State may, by regulations, specify for the purposes of
subsection  (2) (a) (vii)  a description of object, structure or site that—

230.3.a

is designated, registered or similarly recognised under an enactment, and

230.3.b

appears to the Secretary of State to be so wholly or partly because of
historic, architectural, archaeological or artistic importance.

230.4

Subsection  (1)  requires information to be included in an historic
environment record only so far as the relevant authority—

230.4.a

has the information, and

230.4.b

considers it suitable for inclusion in the record.

230.5

A relevant authority must take such steps as it considers reasonable to—

230.5.a

obtain information for inclusion in its historic environment record, and

230.5.b

keep information included in its historic environment record up to date.

230.6

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

230.6.a

about how information is to be stored or made available as described in
subsection  (2) ;

230.6.b

for and in connection with the charging of fees by relevant authorities in
respect of—

230.6.b.i

the provision of advice or assistance to persons making use, or proposing to
make use, of an historic environment record;

230.6.b.ii

the provision of documents copied or derived from an historic environment
record.

230.7

Regulations under subsection  (6) (a)  may, in particular, make provision
requiring or enabling information to be stored or made available in accordance
with such standards or specifications as are published by the Secretary of
State from time to time.

230.8

The relevant authorities for the purposes of this section are—

230.8.a

each county council in England,

230.8.b

each district council for an area in England for which there is no county
council,

230.8.c

each London borough council,

230.8.d

the Common Council of the City of London,

230.8.e

the Council of the Isles of Scilly,

230.8.f

each National Park authority for a National Park in England, and

230.8.g

the Broads Authority.

230.9

For the purposes of this section—

230.9.a

the area of the Common Council includes the Inner Temple and the Middle
Temple,

230.9.b

an area comprising a National Park for which there is a National Park
authority is the area of that authority and no other relevant authority, and

230.9.c

the area comprising the Broads, as defined by section 2(3) of the Norfolk and
Suffolk Broads Act 1988, is the area of the Broads Authority and no other
relevant authority.

#### Review of governance etc of RICS

231

231.1

The Secretary of State may, from time to time, appoint an independent person
to carry out a review of—

231.1.a

the governance of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors,

231.1.b

the effectiveness of the Institution in meeting its objectives, and

231.1.c

any other matter specified in the appointment.

231.2

A matter may be specified under  subsection (1) (c)  only if the Secretary of
State considers that the matter is connected with—

231.2.a

the governance of the Institution, or

231.2.b

the effectiveness of the Institution in meeting its objectives.

231.3

On completion of a review, the appointed person must make a written report to
the Secretary of State—

231.3.a

setting out the result of the review, and

231.3.b

making such recommendations (if any) as the person considers.

231.4

The Secretary of State must publish a copy of the report.

231.5

In  this section  “ independent ” means appearing to the Secretary of State to
be independent of—

231.5.a

the Secretary of State, and

231.5.b

the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.
