11

After regulation 85 insert—

######### Assumptions to be made about nutrient pollution standards: general

11.85A

11.85A.1

Paragraph  (2)  applies where—

11.85A.1.a

a competent authority makes a relevant decision,

11.85A.1.b

the potential development includes development in England,

11.85A.1.c

the competent authority is required to make a relevant assessment before the
decision is made,

11.85A.1.d

waste water from any potential development would be dealt with by a plant in
England that, at the time of the decision, is—

11.85A.1.d.i

a nitrogen significant plant, or

11.85A.1.d.ii

a phosphorus significant plant, and

11.85A.1.e

the decision is made—

11.85A.1.e.i

where the plant is a non-catchment permitting area plant, before the upgrade
date, or

11.85A.1.e.ii

where the plant is a catchment permitting area plant, before the applicable
date.

11.85A.2

In making the relevant assessment, the competent authority must assume—

11.85A.2.a

in a case within paragraph  (1) (d) (i)  and  (e) (i) , that the plant will
meet the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard on and after the upgrade date;

11.85A.2.b

in a case within paragraph  (1) (d) (ii)  and  (e) (i) , that the plant will
meet the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard on and after the upgrade date;

11.85A.2.c

in a case within paragraph  (1) (d) (i)  and  (e) (ii) , that the plant will
meet the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard on and after the applicable
date;

11.85A.2.d

in a case within paragraph  (1) (d) (ii)  and  (e) (ii) , that the plant will
meet the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard on and after the applicable
date.

11.85A.3

Paragraph  (2) —

11.85A.3.a

is subject to regulation  85C  (direction that assumptions are not to apply),
and

11.85A.3.b

does not prevent the competent authority, in making a relevant assessment,
from having regard to outperformance, or expected outperformance, by a plant
that is a non-catchment permitting area plant.

11.85A.4

In paragraph  (1)  “ relevant decision ” means—

11.85A.4.a

where any of the following provides that the assessment provisions apply in
relation to doing a thing, the decision whether or not to do it—

11.85A.4.a.i

regulation 70 (grant of planning permission),

11.85A.4.a.ii

regulation 79 (special development orders),

11.85A.4.a.iii

regulation 80 (local development orders),

11.85A.4.a.iv

regulation 81 (neighbourhood development orders),

11.85A.4.a.v

regulation 82 (simplified planning zones), or

11.85A.4.a.vi

regulation 83 (enterprise zones), or

11.85A.4.b

where any of the following provides that the review provisions apply in
relation to a matter, a decision under regulation 65(1)(b) on a review of the
matter—

11.85A.4.b.i

regulation 71 (planning permission: duty to review),

11.85A.4.b.ii

regulation 79 (special development orders),

11.85A.4.b.iii

regulation 80 (local development orders),

11.85A.4.b.iv

regulation 81 (neighbourhood development orders),

11.85A.4.b.v

regulation 82 (simplified planning zones), or

11.85A.4.b.vi

regulation 83 (enterprise zones);

but this does not apply to a matter mentioned in regulation 71(4) (any review
of which would be conducted in accordance with another Chapter).

11.85A.5

In paragraph  (1)  “ potential development ”, in relation to a relevant
decision, means development—

11.85A.5.a

that could be carried out by virtue of the planning permission, development
order or scheme to which the decision relates, or

11.85A.5.b

to which the decision otherwise relates.

11.85A.6

In this regulation “ relevant assessment ” means—

11.85A.6.a

where the assessment provisions apply and an appropriate assessment of the
implications of the plan or project for a site is required by regulation
63(1), that assessment;

11.85A.6.b

where the review provisions apply and an appropriate assessment is required by
regulation 65(2), that assessment.

######### Assumptions to be made about nutrient pollution standards: general development orders

11.85B

11.85B.1

This regulation applies where—

11.85B.1.a

a local planning authority (within the meaning given by regulation 78(1))
makes a decision on an application under regulation 77 (general development
orders: approval of local planning authority) for approval as mentioned in
regulation 75 relating to proposed development in England,

11.85B.1.b

the authority is required by regulation 77(6) to make an appropriate
assessment of the implications of the proposed development,

11.85B.1.c

any waste water from the proposed development would be dealt with by a plant
in England that, at the time of the decision, is—

11.85B.1.c.i

a nitrogen significant plant, or

11.85B.1.c.ii

a phosphorus significant plant, and

11.85B.1.d

the decision is made—

11.85B.1.d.i

where the plant is a non-catchment permitting area plant, before the upgrade
date, or

11.85B.1.d.ii

where the plant is a catchment permitting area plant, before the applicable
date.

11.85B.2

In making the relevant assessment the local planning authority must assume—

11.85B.2.a

in a case within paragraph  (1) (c) (i)  and  (d) (i) , that the plant will
meet the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard on and after the upgrade date;

11.85B.2.b

in a case within paragraph  (1) (c) (ii)  and  (d) (i) , that the plant will
meet the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard on and after the upgrade date;

11.85B.2.c

in a case within paragraph  (1) (c) (i)  and  (d) (ii) , that the plant will
meet the nitrogen nutrient pollution standard on and after the applicable
date;

11.85B.2.d

in a case within paragraph  (1) (c) (ii)  and  (d) (ii) , that the plant will
meet the phosphorus nutrient pollution standard on and after the applicable
date.

11.85B.3

Paragraph  (2) —

11.85B.3.a

is subject to regulation  85C  (direction that assumptions are not to apply),
and

11.85B.3.b

does not prevent the local planning authority, in making a relevant
assessment, from having regard to any outperformance, or expected
outperformance, by a plant that is a non-catchment permitting area plant.

######### Direction that assumptions are not to apply

11.85C

11.85C.1

The assumptions in regulations  85A (2)  and  85B (2)  do not apply in
relation to a particular plant and a particular nutrient pollution standard if
the Secretary of State so directs.

11.85C.2

A direction under this regulation may be made in relation to a plant and a
standard only if the Secretary of State is satisfied—

11.85C.2.a

where the plant is a non-catchment permitting area plant, that the plant will
not be able to meet the standard by the upgrade date;

11.85C.2.b

where the plant is a catchment permitting area plant—

11.85C.2.b.i

that the plant will not be able to meet the standard by the applicable date,
or

11.85C.2.b.ii

that the first effect described in paragraph  (4)  will, on the applicable
date, be more significant than the second effect described in that paragraph.

11.85C.3

The Secretary of State may revoke a direction under this regulation if
satisfied—

11.85C.3.a

where the plant is a non-catchment permitting area plant, that the plant will
meet the standard by the upgrade date;

11.85C.3.b

where the plant is a catchment permitting area plant—

11.85C.3.b.i

that the plant will meet the standard by the applicable date, or

11.85C.3.b.ii

that the first effect described in paragraph  (4)  will, on the applicable
date, be the same or less significant than the second effect described in that
paragraph.

11.85C.4

For the purposes of paragraphs  (2) (b)  and  (3) (b) —

11.85C.4.a

the “first effect” is the overall effect on the habitats site associated with
the catchment permitting area of nutrients in treated effluent discharged by
all plants that discharge into the area;

11.85C.4.b

the “second effect” is the overall effect on the site of nutrients in treated
effluent that would be discharged by all plants that discharge into the area
if—

11.85C.4.b.i

the upgrade date that applied to nutrient significant plants that discharge
into the area was the same as the applicable date,

11.85C.4.b.ii

the standard concentration (of nutrients) applied to those nutrient
significant plants, and

11.85C.4.b.iii

those nutrient significant plants were (on that basis) meeting the nutrient
pollution standard on the applicable date.

11.85C.5

In deciding whether to make a direction under this regulation in relation to a
plant and a standard, the Secretary of State may, in particular, have regard—

11.85C.5.a

where the plant is a non-catchment permitting area plant, to when the plant
can be expected to meet the standard;

11.85C.5.b

where the plant is a catchment permitting area plant, to when—

11.85C.5.b.i

the plant can be expected to meet the standard, and

11.85C.5.b.ii

the sewerage undertaker for the plant can be expected to be in compliance with
conditions in the environmental permit for the plant imposed in pursuance of
section  96G (3) (b)  of the Water Industry Act 1991.

11.85C.6

Before making or revoking a direction under this regulation, the Secretary of
State must consult—

11.85C.6.a

the Environment Agency,

11.85C.6.b

Natural England,

11.85C.6.c

the Water Services Regulation Authority,

11.85C.6.d

any local planning authority who it appears to the Secretary of State would be
affected by the direction or revocation,

11.85C.6.e

the sewerage undertaker whose sewerage system includes the plant, and

11.85C.6.f

any other persons that the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

11.85C.7

A direction or revocation under this regulation—

11.85C.7.a

is to be made in writing, and

11.85C.7.b

takes effect—

11.85C.7.b.i

on the day specified in the direction or revocation, or

11.85C.7.b.ii

if none is specified, on the day on which it is made.

11.85C.8

As soon as practicable after making or revoking a direction under this
regulation, the Secretary of State must—

11.85C.8.a

notify—

11.85C.8.a.i

the Environment Agency,

11.85C.8.a.ii

Natural England,

11.85C.8.a.iii

every local planning authority who appears to the Secretary of State to be
affected by the direction or revocation, and

11.85C.8.a.iv

any other persons that the Secretary of State considers appropriate, and

11.85C.8.b

publish the direction or revocation.

######### Regulations 

11.85D

11.85D.1

In regulations  85A  to  85C  and this regulation, the following terms have
the meanings given by section  96L  of the Water Industry Act 1991—

      “catchment permitting area”;           “environmental permit”;
“habitats site”;           “nitrogen significant plant”;           “nitrogen
nutrient pollution standard”;           “nutrient pollution standard”;
“nutrient significant plant”;           “phosphorus significant plant”;
“phosphorus nutrient pollution standard”;           “plant”;
“sensitive catchment area”;           “ sewerage system ”, in relation to a
sewerage undertaker;           “standard concentration”;           “treated
effluent”;           “upgrade date”.

11.85D.2

In regulations  85A  to  85C  and this regulation—

      “ catchment permitting area plant ” means a nutrient significant plant
that discharges (or will discharge) treated effluent into a catchment
permitting area;           “ non-catchment permitting area plant ” means a
nutrient significant plant that discharges (or will discharge) treated
effluent into a sensitive catchment area other than a catchment permitting
area.

11.85D.3

For the purposes of regulations  85A  and  85B , “outperformance” by a plant,
which is a non-catchment permitting area plant and in relation to a nutrient
pollution standard, occurs where—

11.85D.3.a

the plant meets the standard before the upgrade date, or

11.85D.3.b

the total nitrogen concentration (in the case of a nitrogen significant
plant), or total phosphorus concentration (in the case of a phosphorus
significant plant), in treated effluent that it discharges is less than the
concentration specified in  section 96F (1) (a) (i)  or  (2) (a) (i) , under
section 96C (4) (e)  or  96D (5)  or by virtue of regulations made under
section 96D (11)  (as the case may be) of the Water Industry Act 1991 that
applies to the plant.

11.85D.4

For the purposes of regulations  85A  and  85B , the “ applicable date ”, in
relation to a catchment permitting area, is to be determined in accordance
with  section 96G (6) (a)  of the Water Industry Act 1991.

11.85D.5

For the purposes of regulation  85C (4) —

11.85D.5.a

a habitats site is “associated” with a catchment permitting area if water
released into the area would drain into the site;

11.85D.5.b

“nutrients”—

11.85D.5.b.i

in relation to an area designated under  section 96C (1)  of the Water
Industry Act 1991, means nutrients comprising nitrogen or compounds of
nitrogen;

11.85D.5.b.ii

in relation to an area designated under  section 96C (2)  of that Act, means
nutrients comprising phosphorus or compounds of phosphorus.

##### Proceedings for consideration of draft order

2

2.1

Schedule 1 to the Acquisition of Land Act 1981 (compulsory purchase by
Minister) is amended as follows.

2.2

In paragraph 4A (proceedings for contested orders), for sub-paragraphs (2) to
(8) substitute—

2.2.1A

The appropriate authority must cause a public local inquiry to be held if—

2.2.1A.a

the order is subject to special parliamentary procedure, or

2.2.1A.b

in the case of an order to which section 16 applies, a certificate has been
given under subsection (2) of that section.

2.2.1B

If sub-paragraph  (1A)  does not apply, the appropriate authority must either—

2.2.1B.a

cause a public local inquiry to be held, or

2.2.1B.b

proceed under the representations procedure.

2.2.1C

In deciding between those options, the appropriate authority must have regard
to the scale and complexity of what is proposed by the draft order.

2.2.1D

The representations procedure is a procedure to be prescribed.

2.2.1E

The regulations prescribing the procedure must include provision—

2.2.1E.a

enabling each person who has made a remaining objection to make
representations—

2.2.1E.a.i

in writing to the appropriate authority, or

2.2.1E.a.ii

if the person so requests, at a hearing, and

2.2.1E.b

enabling the Minister, and any other person the appropriate authority thinks
appropriate, to make representations—

2.2.1E.b.i

in writing to the appropriate authority, or

2.2.1E.b.ii

if applicable, at a hearing held as mentioned in paragraph  (a) (ii) .

2.2.1F

The regulations may provide for hearings to be held by the appropriate
authority or by a person appointed by the appropriate authority.

2.2.1G

In sub-paragraph  (1E) , “ representations ” means representations as to
whether the order should be made.

2.2.1H

Before the Minister makes the order, the appropriate authority must consider—

2.2.1H.a

each remaining objection;

2.2.1H.b

if a public local inquiry was held, the report of the person who held it;

2.2.1H.c

if the representations procedure was followed and the appropriate authority
held a hearing, the representations made at the hearing;

2.2.1H.d

if the representations procedure was followed and a person appointed by the
appropriate authority held a hearing, the report of that person;

2.2.1H.e

if the representations procedure was followed and written representations were
made, those representations.

2.2.1I

The Minister may make the order with or without modifications.

2.2.1J

Regulations under sub-paragraph  (1D)  may include provision as to the giving
of reasons for decisions taken by the appropriate authority in cases where the
representations procedure is followed.

2.3

In paragraph 4B (confirmation of order in stages), in sub-paragraph (3), for
“4A(2) or (3)” substitute  “4A (1A)  or  (1B) ” .

##### Conditional orders

3

3.1

Schedule 1 to the Acquisition of Land Act 1981 (compulsory purchase by
Minister) is amended as follows.

3.2

After paragraph 4A insert—

3.2.4AA

3.2.4AA.1

The Minister may make a compulsory purchase order conditionally.

3.2.4AA.2

The effect of making an order conditionally is that the order—

3.2.4AA.2.a

does not become operative until the Minister has decided, following
consideration by the appropriate authority (see paragraph 4(8)), that certain
conditions have been met, and

3.2.4AA.2.b

expires if the Minister has not decided that by a certain time.

3.2.4AA.3

The conditions and the time are to be specified by the Minister when making
the order.

3.2.4AA.4

The procedure to be followed in connection with the consideration and decision
referred to in sub-paragraph  (2) (a)  is to be prescribed.

3.2.4AA.5

The prescribed procedure must include provision for each relevant objector—

3.2.4AA.5.a

to be given notice that the appropriate authority is to consider whether the
conditions have been met (or for steps to be taken with a view to notifying
them), and

3.2.4AA.5.b

to have the opportunity to make written representations relating to that
consideration;

and may include provision as to the giving of reasons for the decision by the
Minister.

3.2.4AA.6

In sub-paragraph  (5) , “ relevant objector ” means a person who made an
objection to the draft order that—

3.2.4AA.6.a

was a remaining objection for the purposes of paragraph 4A, and

3.2.4AA.6.b

had not been withdrawn by the time the order was made.

3.3

In paragraph 6 (notices after making of order)—

3.3.a

in sub-paragraph (2)(b), for “date when the order becomes operative”
substitute  “day on which the Minister takes the final step needed to comply
with sub-paragraph (1)(a)” ;

3.3.b

in sub-paragraph (3), at the beginning insert  “Unless the order was made
conditionally,” ;

3.3.c

in sub-paragraph (4), after paragraph (b) insert—

3.3.c.ba

if the order was made conditionally, stating the conditions and time specified
under paragraph  4AA (3) ;

;

3.3.d

after sub-paragraph  (4A)  (inserted by paragraph  1 (6) ) insert—

3.3.d.4B

If the order was made conditionally and the Minister decides under paragraph
4AA  that the conditions have been met, the Minister must serve—

3.3.d.4B.a

a copy of the order, and

3.3.d.4B.b

a fulfilment notice,

on each person on whom a notice was required to be served under paragraph 3.

3.3.d.4C

Where sub-paragraph  (4B)  applies, the Minister must also—

3.3.d.4C.a

affix a fulfilment notice to a conspicuous object or objects on or near the
land comprised in the order, and

3.3.d.4C.b

publish a fulfilment notice—

3.3.d.4C.b.i

in one or more local newspapers circulating in the locality in which the land
comprised in the order is situated, and

3.3.d.4C.b.ii

on an appropriate website, until the end of the period of 6 weeks beginning
with the day on which the Minister takes the final step needed to comply with
sub-paragraph  (4B) .

3.3.d.4D

A fulfilment notice is a notice—

3.3.d.4D.a

stating that the conditions subject to which the order was made have been met
and that the order will therefore become operative, and

3.3.d.4D.b

annexing the information that was contained in the making notice.

;

3.3.e

in sub-paragraph (5), after “notice” insert  “or fulfilment notice” ;

3.3.f

in sub-paragraph (6)—

3.3.f.i

after “notice” insert  “, and any fulfilment notice,” ;

3.3.f.ii

for “it” substitute  “each such notice” .

  Grounds of appeal against final letting notice

Section  201

##### Grounds

1

That the vacancy condition was not met in relation to the premises on the day
on which the initial letting notice was served.

2

That the premises cannot reasonably be considered suitable for the use
identified in the final letting notice as the suitable high-street use.

3

That the local authority’s view that the local benefit condition was met in
relation to the premises was one that no authority giving reasonable
consideration to the matter could have reached.

4

That the local authority failed, while the initial letting notice was in
force, to give consent under section  196  to a proposed tenancy, licence or
agreement where the authority—

4.a

was required by section  197 (1)  to give consent, or

4.b

would have been so required had it not failed to be satisfied as mentioned in
section  197 (2) (c) , when any authority giving reasonable consideration to
the matter would have been so satisfied.

5

That the landlord—

5.a

intends to carry out substantial works of construction, demolition or
reconstruction affecting the premises, and

5.b

could not reasonably carry out those works without retaining possession of the
premises.

6

That the landlord intends to occupy the premises for the purposes, or partly
for the purposes, of a business to be carried on by the landlord in the
premises.

7

That the landlord intends to occupy the premises as the landlord’s residence.

##### Interpretation and application

1

Ground 2 is to be applied in accordance with section  192 (5) .

2

Works carried out in contravention of section  200 (1)  cannot be relied on
for the purposes of ground 5.

3

3.1

Where the landlord has a controlling interest in a company, the references to
the landlord in ground 6 include reference to that company.

3.2

Where the landlord is a company and a person has a controlling interest in the
company, the references to the landlord in grounds 6 and 7 include reference
to that person.

3.3

For the purposes of sub-paragraphs  (1)  and  (2) , a person has a controlling
interest in a company, if, had the person been a company, the other company
would have been its subsidiary.

3.4

In this paragraph—

      “ company ” has the meaning given by section 1(1) of the Companies Act
2006;           “ subsidiary ” has the meaning given by section 1159 of that
Act.

  Provision to be included in terms of tenancy further to contract under
section  204

Section 206

1

Provision about what obligations (if any) the landlord is to have with respect
to the maintenance or repair of anything outside the premises that enables or
facilitates the use of the premises.

2

Provision about what obligations (if any) the landlord is to have with respect
to the supply of water, energy or telecommunications services to the premises.

3

Provision requiring the tenant to keep the premises in repair.

4

Provision about—

4.a

what works and alterations the tenant can or cannot carry out, with or without
the consent of the landlord, and

4.b

(if applicable) the giving or withholding of such consent by the landlord.

5

Provision requiring the tenant to insure the premises (if they are not
otherwise insured).

6

Provision enabling the landlord to recover from the tenant costs reasonably
incurred by or on behalf of the landlord in connection with the premises.

7

Provision about circumstances in which the tenant can or cannot—

7.a

assign the tenancy,

7.b

sub-let the premises, or

7.c

otherwise allow another person to possess or occupy the premises.

8

Provision for, and in connection with, the giving of a deposit by the tenant
to secure the performance of the tenant’s obligations.

9

Provision about the circumstances in which the landlord can re-enter the
premises following a breach of the tenant’s obligations.

10

Provision requiring the tenant to deliver up the premises with vacant
possession at the end of the tenancy.

##### Enforcement

13

After section 7 of the 2020 Act insert—

######### Enforcement

13.7A

13.7A.1

The following provisions of this section apply where—

13.7A.1.a

a person puts removable furniture on a relevant highway for a purpose
specified in subsection (2), and

13.7A.1.b

the person is not authorised to do so.

13.7A.2

The purposes referred to in subsection (1)(a) are—

13.7A.2.a

use of the furniture by the person to sell or serve food or drink supplied
from, or in connection with relevant use of, premises which are adjacent to
the highway and are used or proposed to be used by the person;

13.7A.2.b

use of the furniture by other persons for the purpose of consuming food or
drink supplied from, or in connection with relevant use of, such premises.

13.7A.3

The local authority may by notice require the person—

13.7A.3.a

to remove the furniture before a date specified in the notice, and

13.7A.3.b

to refrain from putting furniture on the highway unless authorised to do so.

13.7A.4

If the person leaves or puts removable furniture on the relevant highway in
contravention of the notice, the local authority may—

13.7A.4.a

remove the furniture and store it,

13.7A.4.b

require the person to pay the authority’s reasonable costs in removing and
storing the furniture, and

13.7A.4.c

refuse to return the furniture until those reasonable costs are paid.

13.7A.5

If within the period of three months beginning with the day on which the
notice is given the person does not pay the reasonable costs, or does not
recover the furniture, the local authority may—

13.7A.5.a

dispose of the furniture by sale or in any other way it thinks fit, and

13.7A.5.b

retain any proceeds of sale for any purpose it thinks fit.

13.7A.6

In this section “ authorised ” means authorised by—

13.7A.6.a

a pavement licence,

13.7A.6.b

permission under Part 7A of the Highways Act 1980, or

13.7A.6.c

permission granted under any other enactment.

19.4.2A.b

give the applicant a certificate of registration stating that the applicant is
so registered.

19.5

In subsection (3), for “or (2)” substitute  “, (2) or  (2A) ” .

20

In section 65 (special procedure for persons already registered in a childcare
register), in subsection (1)—

20.a

in the words before paragraph (a), for the words from “a childminder” to “Part
A of the general childcare register” substitute  “an early years childminder
with or without domestic premises in the early years register, or as a later
years childminder with or without domestic premises in Part A of the general
childcare register,” ;

20.b

in paragraph (a), after “childminder” insert  “(as the case may be, with or
without domestic premises)” .

21

21.1

Section 65A (special procedure for persons already registered with a
childminder agency) is amended as follows.

21.2

In subsection (1), in the words before paragraph (a)—

21.2.a

after the first “early years childminder” insert  “with or without domestic
premises” ;

21.2.b

after the first “later years childminder” insert  “with or without domestic
premises” .

21.3

In subsection (2)(a), after “Chapter” insert  “(as the case may be, with or
without domestic premises)” .

##### Common provisions

22

22.1

Section 68 (cancellation of registration in a childcare register: early years
and later years providers) is amended as follows.

22.2

In subsection (3), for the words from “as an early years childminder” to the
end substitute

—

22.2.a

as an early years childminder with domestic premises if it appears to the
Chief Inspector that the person has not provided early years childminding on
domestic premises in England for a period of more than three years during
which the person was registered;

22.2.b

as an early years childminder without domestic premises if it appears to the
Chief Inspector that the person has not provided early years childminding on
non-domestic premises in England for a period of more than three years during
which the person was registered.

22.3

In subsection (4), for the words from “as a later years childminder” to the
end substitute

—

22.3.a

as a later years childminder with domestic premises if it appears to the Chief
Inspector that the person has not provided later years childminding on
domestic premises in England for a period of more than three years during
which the person was registered;

22.3.b

as a later years childminder without domestic premises if it appears to the
Chief Inspector that the person has not provided later years childminding on
non-domestic premises in England for a period of more than three years during
which the person was registered.

22.4

In subsection (5), for the words from “as a childminder” to the end substitute

—

22.4.a

as a childminder with domestic premises if it appears to the Chief Inspector
that the person has provided neither early years childminding nor later years
childminding on domestic premises in England for a period of more than three
years during which the person was registered;

22.4.b

as a childminder without domestic premises if it appears to the Chief
Inspector that the person has provided neither early years childminding nor
later years childminding on non-domestic premises in England for a period of
more than three years during which the person was registered.

23

In section 69 (suspension of registration in a childcare register: early years
and later years providers), in each of subsections (3) and (4), after
“childminder” insert  “with or without domestic premises” .

24

24.1

Section 98 (interpretation of Part 3) is amended as follows.

24.2

In subsection (1), in the definition of “domestic premises”, at the end insert
“(and references to non-domestic premises are to be construed accordingly)” .

24.3

After subsection (1A) insert—

24.3.1B

In this Part, references to a person registered—

24.3.1B.a

as an early years childminder with domestic premises are to a person
registered as such under section 37(1)(a) or 37A(1)(a);

24.3.1B.b

as an early years childminder without domestic premises are to a person
registered as such under section 37 (2A)  or 37A (1A) ;

24.3.1B.c

as a later years childminder with domestic premises are to a person registered
as such under section 56(1)(a) or 56A(1)(a);

24.3.1B.d

as a later years childminder without domestic premises are to a person
registered as such under section 56 (2A)  or 56A (1A) .

Regulations under Chapter 1 of Part 3 or Part 6: form and scrutiny

Section 252 (10)

##### Statutory Instruments and statutory Rules

1

1.1

Any power to make regulations under  Chapter 1  of  Part 3  or  Part 6 —

1.1.a

so far as exercisable by the Secretary of State acting alone or by the
Secretary of State acting jointly with a devolved authority, is exercisable by
statutory instrument,

1.1.b

so far as exercisable by the Welsh Ministers acting alone, is exercisable by
statutory instrument, and

1.1.c

so far as exercisable by a Northern Ireland department acting alone, is
exercisable by statutory rule for the purposes of the Statutory Rules
(Northern Ireland) Order 1979 ( S.I. 1979/1573 (N.I. 12))  (and not by
statutory instrument).

1.2

For regulations made under  Chapter 1  of  Part 3  or  Part 6  by the Scottish
Ministers acting alone, see also section 27 of the Interpretation and
Legislative Reform (Scotland) Act  2010 (asp 10)  (Scottish statutory
instruments).

##### Scrutiny of regulations

###### Scrutiny of regulations made by Secretary of State or devolved authority acting alone

2

2.1

This paragraph applies to regulations made by the Secretary of State, or a
devolved authority, acting alone which contain provision (whether alone or
with other provision) under—

2.1.a

section  152  or  153 ;

2.1.b

section  154  other than provision, made on the second or subsequent exercise
of a power in that section, for—

2.1.b.i

a description of consent, which is neither category 1 consent nor category 2
consent, to be either category 1 consent or category 2 consent, or

2.1.b.ii

a description of consent which is category 2 consent to be category 1 consent;

2.1.c

section  159 (2)  or  160 .

2.2

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
of the Secretary of State acting alone may not be made unless a draft of the
instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House
of Parliament.

2.3

Regulations to which this paragraph applies of the Scottish Ministers acting
alone are subject to the affirmative procedure (see section 29 of the
Interpretation and Legislative Reform (Scotland) Act  2010 (asp 10) ).

2.4

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
of the Welsh Ministers acting alone may not be made unless a draft of the
instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, Senedd
Cymru.

2.5

Regulations to which this paragraph applies of a Northern Ireland department
acting alone may not be made unless a draft of the regulations has been laid
before, and approved by a resolution of, the Northern Ireland Assembly.

3

3.1

This paragraph applies to regulations made by the Secretary of State, or a
devolved authority, acting alone which contain provision (whether alone or
with other provision) under  Chapter 1  of  Part 3  or  Part 6  and which do
not fall within paragraph  2 .

3.2

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
of the Secretary of State acting alone is subject to annulment in pursuance of
a resolution of either House of Parliament.

3.3

Regulations to which this paragraph applies of the Scottish Ministers acting
alone are subject to the negative procedure (see section 28 of the
Interpretation and Legislative Reform (Scotland) Act 2010).

3.4

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
of the Welsh Ministers acting alone is subject to annulment in pursuance of a
resolution of Senedd Cymru.

3.5

Regulations to which this paragraph applies of a Northern Ireland department
acting alone are subject to negative resolution within the meaning of section
41(6) of the Interpretation Act (Northern Ireland) 1954 as if they were a
statutory instrument within the meaning of that Act.

4

Paragraph  3  does not apply if—

4.a

a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution
of, each House of Parliament;

4.b

a draft of the Scottish statutory instrument has been laid before, and
approved by resolution of, the Scottish Parliament;

4.c

a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution
of, Senedd Cymru; or

4.d

a draft of the regulations has been laid before, and approved by a resolution
of, the Northern Ireland Assembly.

###### Scrutiny of regulations made by the Secretary of State and devolved authority acting jointly

5

5.1

This paragraph applies to regulations of the Secretary of State acting jointly
with a devolved authority which contain provision (whether alone or with other
provision) under—

5.1.a

section  152  or  153 ;

5.1.b

section  154  other than provision, made on the second or subsequent exercise
of a power in that section, for—

5.1.b.i

a description of consent, which is neither category 1 consent nor category 2
consent, to be either category 1 consent or category 2 consent, or

5.1.b.ii

a description of consent which is category 2 consent to be category 1 consent;

5.1.c

section  159 (2)  or  160 .

5.2

The procedure provided for by sub-paragraph  (3)  applies in relation to
regulations to which this paragraph applies as well as any other procedure
provided for by this paragraph which is applicable in relation to the
regulations concerned.

5.3

A statutory instrument which contains regulations to which this paragraph
applies may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before,
and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

5.4

Regulations to which this paragraph applies which are made jointly with the
Scottish Ministers are subject to the affirmative procedure.

5.5

Section 29 of the Interpretation and Legislative Reform (Scotland) Act 2010
(affirmative procedure) applies in relation to regulations to which sub-
paragraph  (4)  applies as it applies in relation to devolved subordinate
legislation (within the meaning of Part 2 of that Act) which is subject to the
affirmative procedure (but as if references to a Scottish statutory instrument
were references to a statutory instrument).

5.6

Section 32 of the Interpretation and Legislative Reform (Scotland) Act 2010
(laying) applies in relation to the laying before the Scottish Parliament of a
statutory instrument containing regulations to which sub-paragraph  (4)
applies as it applies in relation to the laying before the Scottish Parliament
of a Scottish statutory instrument (within the meaning of Part 2 of that Act).

5.7

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
which are made jointly with the Welsh Ministers may not be made unless a draft
of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of,
Senedd Cymru.

5.8

Regulations to which this paragraph applies which are made jointly with a
Northern Ireland department may not be made unless a draft of the regulations
has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, the Northern Ireland
Assembly.

6

6.1

This paragraph applies to regulations of the Secretary of State acting jointly
with a devolved authority which contain provision (whether alone or with other
provision) under  Chapter 1  of  Part 3  or  Part 6  and which do not fall
within paragraph  5 .

6.2

The procedure provided for by sub-paragraph  (3)  applies in relation to
regulations to which this paragraph applies as well as any other procedure
provided for by this paragraph which is applicable in relation to the
regulations concerned.

6.3

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of
Parliament.

6.4

Regulations to which this paragraph applies which are made jointly with the
Scottish Ministers are subject to the negative procedure.

6.5

Sections 28(2), (3) and (8) and 31 of the Interpretation and Legislative
Reform (Scotland) Act  2010 (asp 10)  (negative procedure etc.) apply in
relation to regulations to which sub-paragraph  (4)  applies and which are
subject to the negative procedure as they apply in relation to devolved
subordinate legislation (within the meaning of Part 2 of that Act) which is
subject to the negative procedure (but as if references to a Scottish
statutory instrument were references to a statutory instrument).

6.6

Section 32 of the Interpretation and Legislative Reform (Scotland) Act 2010
(laying) applies in relation to the laying before the Scottish Parliament of a
statutory instrument containing regulations to which sub-paragraph  (4)
applies as it applies in relation to the laying before that Parliament of a
Scottish statutory instrument (within the meaning of Part 2 of that Act).

6.7

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which this paragraph applies
which are made jointly with the Welsh Ministers is subject to annulment in
pursuance of a resolution of Senedd Cymru.

6.8

Regulations to which this paragraph applies which are made jointly with a
Northern Ireland department are subject to negative resolution within the
meaning of section 41(6) of the Interpretation Act (Northern Ireland) 1954 as
if they were a statutory instrument within the meaning of that Act.

6.9

If in accordance with this paragraph—

6.9.a

either House of Parliament resolves that an address be presented to His
Majesty praying that an instrument be annulled, or

6.9.b

a relevant devolved legislature resolves that an instrument be annulled,

nothing further is to be done under the instrument after the date of the
resolution and His Majesty may by Order in Council revoke the instrument.

6.10

In sub-paragraph  (9)  “ relevant devolved legislature ” means—

6.10.a

in the case of regulations made jointly with the Scottish Ministers, the
Scottish Parliament,

6.10.b

in the case of regulations made jointly with the Welsh Ministers, Senedd
Cymru, and

6.10.c

in the case of regulations made jointly with a Northern Ireland department,
the Northern Ireland Assembly.

6.11

Sub-paragraph  (9)  does not affect the validity of anything previously done
under the instrument or prevent the making of a new instrument.

6.12

Sub-paragraphs  (9)  to  (11)  apply in place of provision made by any other
enactment about the effect of such a resolution.

6.13

In this paragraph, “ enactment ” includes an enactment contained in, or in an
instrument made under—

6.13.a

an Act of the Scottish Parliament,

6.13.b

a Measure or Act of Senedd Cymru, or

6.13.c

Northern Ireland legislation.

7

Paragraph  6  does not apply if a draft of the instrument has been laid
before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

###### Interpretation

8

In this Schedule “ devolved authority ” means—

8.a

the Scottish Ministers,

8.b

the Welsh Ministers, or

8.c

a Northern Ireland department.
